fields.headline: Hoey lambasts 'ill-conceived' World Cup bid
fields.trailText: The sports minister Kate Hoey has launched an astonishing attack on England's failed attempt to stage the 2006 World Cup and in particular the bid leader Alec McGivan.
fields.body:
The sports minister Kate Hoey has launched an astonishing attack on England's failed attempt to stage the 2006 World Cup and in particular the bid leader Alec McGivan.

"We never had a chance of winning," Hoey said in an interview yesterday. "But people kept writing and saying that we did, and swallowed the words of Alec McGivan as if he was some kind of god."

Hoey said the bid was ill-conceived from the start, adding: "As I travelled around Europe and spoke to sports ministers, it became clear that the gentleman's agreement with Germany, which we went back on, had upset people and given us no hope.

"We shouldn't have gone ahead with it in that climate. The vote in the end was all about politics and the sort of things our bid team did were never going to make any difference."

McGivan hit back at Hoey and said: "I find Kate Hoey's comments puzzling, bearing in mind how much enthusiastic government support we had for England's bid from the prime minister and senior ministers. A World Cup held in England could have been worth £1bn to the country and they did everything they could do to help."

Meanwhile, the Fifa president Sepp Blatter said yesterday that the New Zealand delegate Charles Dempsey had had every right to abstain from the World Cup vote. Dempsey, aged 78, whose abstention cost South Africa the chance of holding the event, has been criticised for not carrying out the mandate of the Oceania federation.

"Mr Dempsey had the right to abstain, even though I regret the fact that he did," said Blatter. "Instead of shouting it from the rooftops that he abstained, he could at least have gone into the voting booth and spoiled his ballot paper."

In a dismissive postscript to Dempsey's resignation as Oceania president, Blatter added: "His future does not concern me."

Blatter was known to favour South Africa's candidacy and it was a disappointment and a political setback for the Fifa president when Germany won the vote 12-11. Blatter conceded there was no irregularity in the voting procedure and effectively ruled out a re-run. "The vote conformed to Fifa rules and Swiss law," he said.

But while Blatter declared himself "satisfied with the result", he admitted to being "very disappointed" on a political level. Blatter added: "It's the biggest disappointment of my career as an administrator.

"We had the chance to make history and we didn't take it. Europe had a great opportunity to make a grand gesture towards Africa. They didn't do it. But that's also democracy."

Blatter said the time had come to rotate the World Cup, a provision that could be enshrined in the Fifa constitution. A spokesman for the African Football Confederation (CAF), Viken Djizmedjian, confirmed that Fifa's executive committee had agreed to debate a proposal to rotate the World Cup finals among the continents when it meets in Zurich next month.

Fifa yesterday banned Harare's national stadium from staging international games for an indefinite period after the deaths of 13 people in a stampede at the match between Zimbabwe and South Africa on Sunday.

fields.headline: Rich pickings
fields.standfirst:
Summer jobs are a great way to have a cheap foreign holiday and to get to know the people and the culture. But it won't all be sunshine unless you plan ahead, warns Adi Bloom

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Summer jobs are a great way to have a cheap foreign holiday and to get to know the people and the culture. But it won't all be sunshine unless you plan ahead, warns Adi Bloom
fields.body:
There is the fantasy: the lazy three-hour lunch-breaks, plentiful pasta and days spent reclining in a field of strawberries under the warm Mediterranean sun. The idyll of the summer job abroad has powerful currency, especially during a dismal British July when the sun rarely shines.

Then there is the reality."People don't realise that fruit picking is actually very painful," complains Bill Mayes, an accountant who spent five months orange-farming on a kibbutz. "I wouldn't recommend it. Orange trees have thorns about three inches long."

There it is, the glaring gap between the expectations of the uninitiated summer worker who imagines his three-month contract to be some kind of paid holiday in the sun and his employer who regards him as someone who is, well, there to work. It is inevitable that even the most interesting overseas job will be complicated by the realities of day-to-day living. Thorns, heatstroke and other practicalities tend to be overlooked in the early stages of grand conceptualisation.

"We worked half in English and half in Icelandic," says Abigail Webb-Sear, a medical student who spent part of last summer on work experience in Reykjavik. "The main problem in theatre was that the Icelandic word for scissors is 'klips', so I never knew whether to cut or clip. One nasty moment ended with me getting what seemed like litres of blood in my eye."

If life is the pursuit of good anecdotes, however, the joy of reliving them afterwards compensates for the difficulties of working abroad. "It gives people the chance to experience a different way of life," says David Woodworth, editor of Summer Jobs Abroad. "If all you want is to make money, you should get a job at McDonald's and have your parents feed you for nothing. But working abroad you can experience a different culture, taste different foods, meet new people and get a bit of sunshine along the way."

This is the advice Woodworth dispenses to students, although more than half of migrant workers are fully fledged adults. "There is one employer I know of who specifically asks for retired couples," he says. "There are people who make their careers out of doing shift work around the world, spending the winters in ski resorts and the summers on cruise liners."

Veterans of the circuit learn to read between the lines of the job advertisements. To the less experienced, it is more a matter of luck. Simon Shaw, a law student, realised that his employers hadn't been entirely truthful almost as soon as he began his job at a summer camp in Pennsylvania. "We were told that we would be working six to eight hours a day, but we ended up working 14-hour days. And they wouldn't let us out of the camp until 9.30pm. The manager was only interested in making money. He told us that we meant nothing to him, that we were pieces of shit and that he could replace us any time he wanted."

The treatment of deserters was similarly harsh: "If anyone decided to leave, they were locked in an isolation room and forbidden to talk to anyone. They were then driven out of the camp and summarily dumped somewhere along the road - they had to make their own way on from there."

Working in a first-world country otherwise renowned for generally high standards of employee care is no guarantee of job satisfaction. "There was no hygiene supervision in the kitchens," says Shaw. "We weren't trained how to use the kitchen equipment. One worker was using the meat slicer to chop cucumbers and got his fingers too close to the blade. He sliced about half a centimetre off the end of his finger, which then fell into the pile of cucumbers. It stayed there for a good 10 minutes before anyone thought to take it out. Then they picked it out and served up the cucumbers anyway."

Many of the most enticing summer jobs abroad entail charity work in far-flung corners of the globe. They offer the advantage of knowing that your six weeks working for pennies in a flea-ridden death trap is for the greater good of mankind. It's mere detail if the greater good of mankind actually involves teaching Vietnamese schoolchildren the names of the Manchester United squad. "We were only there for a few weeks," says Zara Jay, who spent a summer at a children's shelter in Zimbabwe, "so it was easier for us to do things creatively and imaginatively. The teachers were quite happy to sit back and let us run the show - we would come in the morning and they would say: 'Right, you're doing this class. Now, go!'"

"All the men kept coming up to me and expecting me to sleep with them," says Jay. "I think Hollywood cinema has given them this image of all westerners as sex-crazed. People were constantly asking me for sex. It was very unnerving."

At least she was able to get to know Zimbabweans. "I thought that the best way to experience a country would be to work with the locals," says Simon Shaw, of his three-month culinary nightmare at the Pennsylvania summer camp. "But most of the people I was working with were English. There were only two Americans. One had just come out of prison for armed robbery, and the other kept a gun in his bunk."

Meeting and working with local people is more difficult than might be imagined. Working behind a bar in Ibiza has great appeal for the die-hard hedonist, but is likely to offer decidedly few opportunities for cross-cultural understanding (of the intellectual variety). "Go off the beaten track," suggests Bill Mayes. "The further out you are, the fewer English people there are likely to be."

Mayes, a seasoned overseas worker, believes that the benefits of an overseas job are more easily gained through speculative job-hunting than pre-arranged employment. "I had a return ticket, a work visa, enough money to keep me going, and an idea that I wanted to work in the desert, and I ended up with a wonderful job cleaning boats in Utah. I was living in an unbelievably beautiful place and working alongside disaffected Mormons and Navajo Indians from a nearby reserve." But, he warns, prospective workers should have some idea of what sort of work they are looking for.

"The year before that, I ended up working on the worst mini-golf course in South Carolina. It looked so unappealing we would have only three people playing during the first three hours of the day. The only entertainment came when every so often someone would get knocked on the head by baseballs from the nearby batting cage, and had to be rushed to hospital."

As with any job at home, luck is a factor in how well things go. "The best practical advice if you're looking for overseas work," recommends David Woodworth, "is to obtain as many details from employers as you can. Speak to someone who has done the job before, to find out what it's really like."

If all else fails, you can console yourself with the fact that no one back home knows that waiting tables in Marseille is about as exciting as waiting tables in Margate.

fields.headline: Summer of smut
fields.standfirst: Faced with a smutty sexual harassment case? Get a female barrister in, says our employment tribunal lawyer
fields.trailText: I've been having rather a steady diet of smut lately - maybe it's a summer thing. Maybe tribunals list these cases for dozy hot days when evidence about reorganisations and redundancy policies would have them all slumbering.
fields.body:
I've been having rather a steady diet of smut lately - maybe it's a summer thing. Maybe tribunals list these cases for dozy hot days when evidence about reorganisations and redundancy policies would have them all slumbering.

There is also of course the F-factor - the perennially popular get-a-female barrister-to-represent-the-employer-in-the-sexual-harassment-case ploy. The idea (I think) is that the tribunal's sensibilities will be less offended if a woman suggests to the applicant that she's a nasty old slapper who liked to have a giggle with the lads etc than if a man put the same questions.

I sometimes wonder rather queasily how the conversations go when solicitors book these cases with barristers' clerks:

Solicitor: "This might be a suitable case, ahem, for a female barrister."

Clerk: "Well, Miss Counsel is available on that day."

Solicitor: "And, umm, is Miss Counsel a large or a petite young lady?"

Clerk: "Well, she's probably of an average size."

Solicitor: "But, you wouldn't say butch?...."

Maybe not. But maybe.

The smut in this week's case, to be fair to it, did seem to be pretty evenly distributed between the applicant and her boss. He admitted to telling a joke which had a punchline involving him rubbing her breasts vigorously. But he said she had previously told an equally risque joke which culminated in her stroking his buttocks through his trousers. He admitted to bringing in a video entitled They Came In Outer Space and suggesting she might like to watch it at home so they could then discuss it over lunch. But she reciprocated with Pussies In Boots (no I can't imagine either).

Cross-examination in cases like this is usually a pretty dull "Yes you did" / "No I didn't" sort of affair, so I was a bit surprised when it went like this:

Me: And then, Ms Applicant, you sent him a Valentine's card, which you will find photocopied at page 54 of the bundle of documents. And we can see that there is a, um, reference to his genitals there?

Applicant: Yes. Me: Oh. Well then you left a vibrator on his desk some weeks later with the note which we see reproduced at page 55?

Applicant: Yes.

Me: Oh. Well, what is it about Mr Boss's jokes and remarks exactly that you are saying bothered you?

Applicant: I never said they did bother me.

Me: So why exactly are you bringing this case?

Applicant: Because my mate told me it was sex discrimination.

At this stage Applicant's solicitor has the air of a man who wishes he'd chucked a sickie. He has clearly failed to ask Applicant some key questions prior to sending her claim in. Because the fact is you can indulge in any old smut you like at work as long as nobody minds.

In the way of these things, Mr Boss manages to maintain his expression of deep gloom even when the tribunal boots the Applicant's case out at lunchtime. Now, it's all come out OK, I think he's wishing he had a male barrister so he would feel less embarrassed about his tragic jokes and extensive collection of pornography. Like I care.

fields.headline: A battle for brilliance
fields.standfirst: Royal Opera House
fields.trailText:
War and Peace
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.body:
War and Peace
Royal Opera House, London
****

Seasoned opera fans still go misty-eyed at the memory of the British premiere of Prokofiev's epic, staged at Sadler's Wells in 1972. They have had to wait a long time to see another production. The Kirov's staging, the last show in its triumphant Covent Garden season, was unveiled in the Maryinsky Theatre in March, directed by Andrei Konchalovsky in eye-catching designs by George Tsypin.

Peace and War would be a better title for this treatment of Tolstoy's teeming masterpiece. Interwoven in the novel, the twin threads of Russian life and the battles against Napoleon's invading armies are teased out in 13 scenes of the libretto. The first part deals with the ill-starred romance between Natasha and Andrei, and the second plunges into the conflict. The bulk of the score was composed in the middle of the second world war, and the patriotic theme of the work is deliberately emphasised. The way in which individuals are subordinated to the over-arching theme of Russian resolve makes the work more like a pageant than an opera, a series of tableaux peopled by two-dimensional characters.

A more finely detailed production might have brought the protagonists into sharper focus, but with such huge forces to muster, so many named characters and such a massive chorus, it would have been a difficult task. War and Peace is a work for special occasions and even if Prokofiev's music is uneven - much of the love music is sentimental, while the great battle set pieces are film music of a superior kind - the impact is massive. Conducted by Valery Gergiev with blazing conviction, it is hard to resist.

In St Petersburg, Gergiev made several cuts. Some of these, including the crucial monologue for Field Marshal Kutuzov, the dramatic linchpin of the second part, have been restored for London. Gennady Bezzubenkov's uneven singing of the role was, however, one of the few vocal disappointments. There were good contributions from Anna Netrebko (Natasha), Vladimir Moroz (Andrei) and Alexei Steblianko (Pierre). The chorus, sturdy, spectacularly rich-toned, were untiring. A better demonstration of the strength and depth of this extraordinary company is hard to imagine.

Further performances on Friday and Saturday. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Letsbuyit considers cut-price flotation
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
Letsbuyit
fields.trailText: Online retailer Letsbuyit.com is considering dropping its issue price as it makes a second attempt at a listing on the Neuer Markt in Frankfurt.
fields.body:
Online retailer Letsbuyit.com is considering dropping its issue price as it makes a second attempt at a listing on the Neuer Markt in Frankfurt.

The offering is scheduled for today and a statement on price is expected early on. The company said it was still in discussion with institutional investors.

Letsbuyit.com's original subscription period was due to close on Monday but was extended by a day when it emerged that bids on the grey market were below expectations on Monday at €5.5-€5.8.

The company, which pulled out of its first attempt at a listing in May following market volatility, could drop its flotation price from its initial estimate of €7. Analysts believe the company had already reduced its original valuation from a mooted £750m-£1bn to less than £500m when it decided to move ahead with the second attempt.

Sal Oppenheim, one of the four banks handling the issue, confirmed yesterday that it has pulled out of the flotation but did not say why.

Around 19.2m shares will be issued and the new funds will be spent on European marketing and continuing a high-profile marketing campaign.

Letsbuyit.com's business model is based on consumers pooling their buying power to bring down the price of a range of products such as TVs and personal stereos.

Around 700,000 users are registered with Letsbuyit, which took orders worth £4.3m in May.

Analysts believe the company had already reduced its original valuation from a mooted £750m-£1bn to less than £500m when it decided to move ahead with the second attempt. Sal Oppenheim, one of the four banks handling the issue, confirmed yesterday that it has pulled out of the flotation but did not say why. Around 19.2m shares will be issued and the new funds will be spent on European marketing and continuing a high-profile marketing campaign. Letsbuyit.com's business model is based on consumers pooling their buying power to bring down the price of a range of products such as TVs and personal stereos. Around 700,000 users are registered with Letsbuyit, which took orders worth £4.3m in May.

webTitle: Costly petrol pumps up inflation rate

fields.headline: Costly petrol pumps up inflation rate
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Soaring petrol prices forced inflation to a two-year high last month, keeping City analysts guessing over the next move in interest rates.
fields.body:
Soaring petrol prices forced inflation to a two-year high last month, keeping City analysts guessing over the next move in interest rates.

The annual rate of price increases climbed from 3.1% in May to 3.3% in June, the highest since July 1998, according to the office for national statistics.

The government's preferred measure of inflation, which excludes mortgage interest payments, also increased, from 2% to 2.2%, although it remained below the chancellor's 2.5% target for the 15th month in a row.

ONS officials said the biggest single cause of the acceleration of inflation was dearer petrol, which rose to an average of 84p per litre in June from 80p in May and 70p a year ago, driven by the recent surge in the oil price.

Other significant upward effects came from seasonal food and housing, although there was offsetting downward pressure from the high street, where early summer sales helped to reduce the prices of clothing and footwear.

Overall, core goods prices remained subdued, falling by 2.8% over the year, while service sector inflation rose to 3.5% from 3.4%.

Sterling and interest rates futures were unfazed by the data but analysts split into two camps about the implications for interest rates, pegged at 6% since February.

In the bearish camp, Michael Saunders of Schroder Salomon Smith Barney Citibank warned that the rise in headline inflation, used as a benchmark by wage negotiators, would add to upward pressure on pay.

"Although demand is slowing, it does not seem to be slowing quickly enough to ease capacity strains, especially given the scale of the acceleration in public spending that is likely to be confirmed in next week's comprehensive spending review," Mr Saunders said.

He forecast further increases in interest rates to keep the lid on inflation, with August the hot favourite for the next increase.

However, Philip Shaw at Investec said the figures did not represent a serious threat to the government's 2.5% target for underlying inflation.

While petrol costs would continue to rise in the near term, the prospect of an increase in supply was already driving the price of crude oil down, meaning that by the end of the summer the petrol price and inflation would be falling again.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst:
25. How I silenced the office gossip

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Angela Porter, 39 chief executive
fields.body:
Angela Porter, 39 chief executive

When I was an area sales manager, one of my reps used to gossip about the branch managers. Naively, I thought he had my interests at heart but really he was fuelling internal warfare. I'd make offhand remarks about them and he'd tell them. As a result of his gossiping, I confronted someone who'd made a disparaging remark about me and they refused to work with me. The situation became unmanageable and I had to get my boss involved to sort things out. Now I completely ignore gossips at work. It's true that if someone gossips to you, they are going to gossip about you.

Cheryl King, 32 production assistant

I work in TV and a female colleague found out that my boyfriend, who worked with us, had once gone out in secret with someone famous. Not only did she tell everyone about his previous relationship, she also commented that he had lowered his standards. This affected my work because I couldn't bring myself to be civil to her. In the end, I confronted her when we were alone together. I think she was shocked she'd upset me so much and she apologised. You have to tackle gossips head-on because they are thoughtless and need to realise how much hurt they cause.

Patricia White, 24 IT consultant

A woman I didn't get on with turned everyone else in the office against me. She was openly snide with me and the one ally I had told me she was running me down to all my colleagues. Things turned around when I won new business for the company. At the next office meeting I said: "Maybe S**** will stop gossiping about me behind my back now" and looked her in the eye. She was totally shocked and after that treated me with kid gloves. It was fantastic. Sometimes you have to humiliate gossips in public. They can't do it so easily when you challenge them in front of everyone else.

Richard Gough, 55 financial consultant

I worked in an office in which one of my male colleagues was spreading rumours about one of the women. She was a little naive and I think he took advantage of that. He told everyone he'd slept with her, flirting with her openly in the office and laughing at her behind her back. Nobody wanted to get involved, but I'm older than my colleagues and felt I could handle the situation. I took her out for lunch and gave her the general gist. She confronted this man - loudly and emotionally - when she got back from lunch. He denied everything but has since gone very quiet.

Catherine King, 41 PA

I used to work with a woman who didn't like me and who made sure none of her cronies did either. I was PA to the director of a property company and whenever I came into the main office, she and her group of chums would immediately stop talking because they were gossiping about me. She went on holiday and I decided when she got back, I'd be super-nice to her. Surprisingly she was polite back and from then on, she stopped talking about me. Sometimes people spread rumours because they feel threatened. By being nice to her, I disarmed her.

fields.headline: Willful abrasiveness
fields.trailText:
Composers' Ensemble
***
Hoxton Hall, London
fields.body:
Composers' Ensemble
***
Hoxton Hall, London

There is a wilful abrasiveness about the music of Dutch composer Louis Andriessen that produces some of his most memorable work - but it is also responsible for some of its most perplexing aspects. In the ensemble piece Zilver, performed at the first of the Hoxton New Music Days' Andriessen showcase, a tune is played slowly and smoothly by a clarinet, flute, cello and violin. At the same time, tuned percussion and piano create a completely opposed texture of loud, short chords that steadily become faster. The piece is about the interaction of these two kinds of material, which fuse together shortly before the end before drifting into their own, individual worlds.

Zilver magnifies one of Andriessen's central concerns: the investigation of how time flows in music. The speeding-up process of the percussion group is simple, but it produces complex rhythmic relationships. Meanwhile, it is the texture of music of the wind and string instruments that is problematic. The particular sound of these four solo instruments is liable to seem uncomfortable, their combined timbre positively disconcerting.

Andriessen's choice of forces turns Zilver into a listening experience that eschews comfort at all costs. It is as if he wants to make his audience forcefully aware of his techniques of construction, rather than creating an artful or beautiful surface result.

At that level, Andriessen's music is fascinatingly anti-bourgeois, something emphasised through a wonderful moment of audience participation in the second concert of the showcase. Together, audience and performers sang an unforgettably catchy street-song, which Andriessen wrote as an effort to reclaim the right to busk in Amsterdam.

The rest of the concert featured piano pieces that Andriessen composed as gifts for friends. Paradoxically, in the intimacy and unforced artistry of these menuets, romances and berceuses, Andriessen seemed to speak with as much - if not more - directness than in the works of the earlier programme. There was a distilled magic in the beautiful chiming of Andriessen's Deuxième Chorale for music box: precisely the quality that seemed so consciously suppressed in Zilver.

fields.headline: No, not the opera
fields.trailText:
Carmen
***
Watermill, Newbury
fields.body:
Carmen
***
Watermill, Newbury

No, not the opera. Director John Doyle has gone back to the original novel, transposed the entire story to the Spanish civil war and tacked on Bizet's melodies with new orchestrations. The result is an original and enjoyable piece of music theatre played by a band of eight actor-musicians who swap instruments and roles with equal skill.

Doyle has been pioneering these small-scale shows for some years now, and with considerable success. If the stage here is sometimes over-busy, the intimacy of the Watermill's auditorium ensures that the piece has a devastating emotional impact.

The scale may be small, but Doyle's ideas are all big: war, religion and sex are entwined in an earthy, sweaty carnival of love and death. Carmen's sudden end comes in a screech of silence, the pop of a gun and a chalice of red wine dribbling onto the floor. The air is thick with incense and whispered Hail Marys. Yet nothing can ward off the fatal conclusion of the piece.

Love is like a war here. Doyle strips away Bizet's romanticism and replaces it with something dirty, almost rank, but very seductive. For the women, sex is a weapon; for the men it is a little death. Even the music and singing is, at times, harsh, like a banshee wail.

This is all good stuff, although the intensity of the evening is a little wearing and the piece would be great at 75 minutes, not two hours. But it is boldly done and the cast led by Karen Mann's powerful, earthy Carmen - no romantic waif but a mature, sturdy woman - are top-notch. A reminder that the music theatre being done here and at the Bridewell can be as invigorating and radical as drama at other, more glamorous addresses.

Till August 26. Box office: 01635 46044.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Seeing the wooed for the trees

fields.headline: Seeing the wooed for the trees
fields.standfirst: Royal Exchange Theatre
fields.trailText:
As You Like It
Royal Exchange Theatre, Manchester
***
fields.body:
As You Like It
Royal Exchange Theatre, Manchester
***

It must be something in the genes. Forty years ago Michael Elliott directed a legendary Stratford As You Like It with Vanessa Redgrave as a radiant Rosalind. Now his daughter, Marianne Elliott, tackles the same play at the theatre her father co-founded. The result, whatever one's caveats, is a seriously good production that captures the magic realism that pervades Shakespeare's Arden.

Visually, the production pulls off one tremendous Spielbergian coup: in Liz Ascroft's design the forest, complete with wintry trees and snow-covered floor, descends from the fly-tower in the manner of the spacecraft in Close Encounters. And even if, because of the arboreal density, you can't always see the wooed for the trees, you get a sense of a total world on stage. Here, Arden is a kind of Eden where the rhythms of nature dominate and the characters achieve maturity and self-knowledge through love.

But magic is the keynote. At one point the banished Rosalind and the fugitive Orlando are isolated centre stage as if their destinies are intertwined. And down in the forest something stirs in the mock-wooing scenes between Claire Price's enraptured Ganymede and Tristan Sturrock's rather vehement Orlando. The stress is on mysterious androgyny, with the doublet-and-hosed Price kissing the surprised Sturrock full on the lips. Orlando is barely able to keep his hands off this tantalising boy-girl.

Both Price and Sturrock have exactly the right headlong ecstasy and embody the notion that "love is merely a madness". But the madness theme is over-extended. It takes in both Jaques and Touchstone, who are meant to be ironic observers of pastoral passion. Peter Guinness plays the former as a nervous wreck who rasps out his lines with manic intensity. And Jonathan Slinger's Touchstone is a similarly frenetic figure with a tiring line in phallic jokes. Far from emerging as choric commentators, both characters seem candidates for the funny farm.

In compensation, there is a witty Celia from Fenella Woolgar, who reacts to everything with a mischievous alertness. There is also good work from Joseph Mydell, tripling as the wicked Duke, a wise Corin and a weirdly wonderful Hymen. But the success of Elliott's production lies in its realisation of the play's journey from tyrannical darkness to religious reconciliation and in its stress on the sexual strangeness of the ardently androgynous Arden wooing.

Until August 12. Box office: 0161-833 9833.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Contrasts and climaxes
fields.trailText:
Michael Brecker/ Pat Metheny
Barbican, London
***
fields.body:
Michael Brecker/ Pat Metheny
Barbican, London ***

If Michael Brecker - one of the most influential saxophonists in recent jazz history - has a flaw, it has been that his storytelling skills are sometimes slumped on the platform while the express train of his technique roars by. But through the 90s, Brecker's improvising gradually shed grandstanding pyrotechnics and predictable repetition. Now his technique has acquired subtler colours, greater contrast and a compelling narrative strength without losing any of its legendary drive. He was demonstrating all that at the Barbican on Monday with guitarist Pat Metheny, who was back in the UK for the second time in three months.

Brecker and Metheny had put together their Special Quartet to play tunes from both their repertoires, but particularly from Brecker's most recent disc, the sweeping Time is of the Essence. Larry Goldings, a key presence on that disc, was the Special Quartet's Hammond B3 organist this week, and the dramatic and unpredictable Bill Stewart was on drums.

In a flat-out two-hour set with no interval, the contrast between Brecker's zigzagging journeys toward ecstatically wailing climaxes and Metheny's relaxed lyricism and fondness for the song-form kept thoughts of a jazz circus act at bay. The thoughtful avoidance of Hammond hot-licks from Goldings, and Bill Stewart's bumpy, fractious drumming did the rest.

They opened, as Brecker sets often do, with the fast postbop stalwart Slings and Arrows, a typical mix of swooping and percussive phrasing in which the saxophonist worked up his customary lather after a hesitant start. The insinuating, bluesy piece that followed was a gift for Metheny's lissom runs. As its momentum accelerated Brecker started toying with a guttural, four-note dissonant phrase, playing it in varying intonations and then cocking his head at it like a bird examining a meal. Brecker took the solo out with progressively softer low notes, which Stewart unsentimentally undercut, Art Blakey-style, with cantankerous tappings on the side of his snare drum.

A breezy swinger featured Goldings' absorbing blend of prickly, inquisitive phrases and Hammond-chord explosions. The many-stringed guitar Metheny uses for tone- poems and ballads backed some deliciously delicate playing from Brecker. The Metheny ballad, As I Am, revealed how eloquent Brecker has latterly become with slow music, and only a faintly self-conscious diversion into a clattery, metallic free-jazz seemed out of place. Stewart, of course, played like the blast of fresh air he always is.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Barclays heightens home loans war
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Barclays yesterday fired the latest shot in the mortgage price war by changing the way it calculates interest on its home loans. The change will cut monthly bills for 130,000 existing customers.
fields.body:
Barclays yesterday fired the latest shot in the mortgage price war by changing the way it calculates interest on its home loans. The change will cut monthly bills for 130,000 existing customers.

The bank said it was the first top 10 lender to calculate interest daily for all its mortgage customers, saving them thousands over the life of the loan.

The move, which the bank admitted would cost it "fairly big money", comes amid anxiety in the City that both established lenders and new entrants are stepping up the war over home loans. While potentially good news for borrowers, City analysts believe that this could dent banks' profitability.

HSBC last week cut almost one percentage point off its variable mortgage rate. Halifax's new telephone and internet bank, Intelligent Finance, starts selling its competitively priced products this week.

Newcomers such as Egg -still 25% owned by Prudential - have also suffered. While Egg shares recovered some lost ground yesterday, at 139.5p they were still below the 160p at which they were sold to investors last month.

Barclays said the change in interest calculations from August 1 will mean lower monthly payments for more than 130,000 existing repayment mortgage holders, and will also apply to all new customers.

It is also an attempt by the bank to restore its reputation, battered by branch closures, and rows over chief executive Matt Barrett's pay and cash machine charges, which have since been dropped.

"Customers do not need to apply for this or switch to a new product to get the benefits, as is the case with other top 10 lenders," Barclays said.

The change means that every mortgage payment a customer makes will immediately reduce the amount on which interest is charged.

Many other major lenders use the "annual interest" system, which results in borrowers paying interest on debt they no longer owe. Some, such as the Halifax, will credit interest daily - but only if customers ask for it. A growing number of the new banks have brought in daily interest as standard.

A customer with an £80,000 repayment loan would see the monthly bill reduced from £610 to £603 - saving £2,091 over the 25-year term at today's interest rates.

The monthly payment on an £80,000 mortgage is cut from £610 to £603 when interest is calculated daily instead of annually.

Over a 25-year term the saving is £2,091 at today's interest rates.

Extra payments reduce the outstanding balance and interest payable from the date they are credited. Minimum payments are £500 for base-rate trackers and £1,000 for other repayment mortgages. Customers with interest-only loans can benefit by making lump sum repayments of capital.
fields.bodyText: Barclays yesterday fired the latest shot in the mortgage price war by changing the way it calculates interest on its home loans. The change will cut monthly bills for 130,000 existing customers. The bank said it was the first top 10 lender to calculate interest daily for all its mortgage customers, saving them thousands over the life of the loan. The move, which the bank admitted would cost it "fairly big money", comes amid anxiety in the City that both established lenders and new entrants are stepping up the war over home loans. While potentially good news for borrowers, City analysts believe that this could dent banks' profitability. HSBC last week cut almost one percentage point off its variable mortgage rate. Halifax's new telephone and internet bank, Intelligent Finance, starts selling its competitively priced products this week. Newcomers such as Egg -still 25% owned by Prudential - have also suffered. While Egg shares recovered some lost ground yesterday, at 139.5p they were still below the 160p at which they were sold to investors last month. Barclays said the change in interest calculations from August 1 will mean lower monthly payments for more than 130,000 existing repayment mortgage holders, and will also apply to all new customers. It is also an attempt by the bank to restore its reputation, battered by branch closures, and rows over chief executive Matt Barrett's pay and cash machine charges, which have since been dropped. "Customers do not need to apply for this or switch to a new product to get the benefits, as is the case with other top 10 lenders," Barclays said. The change means that every mortgage payment a customer makes will immediately reduce the amount on which interest is charged. Many other major lenders use the "annual interest" system, which results in borrowers paying interest on debt they no longer owe. Some, such as the Halifax, will credit interest daily - but only if customers ask for it. A growing number of the new banks have brought in daily interest as standard. A customer with an £80,000 repayment loan would see the monthly bill reduced from £610 to £603 - saving £2,091 over the 25-year term at today's interest rates. The monthly payment on an £80,000 mortgage is cut from £610 to £603 when interest is calculated daily instead of annually. Over a 25-year term the saving is £2,091 at today's interest rates. Extra payments reduce the outstanding balance and interest payable from the date they are credited. Minimum payments are £500 for base-rate trackers and £1,000 for other repayment mortgages. Customers with interest-only loans can benefit by making lump sum repayments of capital.

webTitle: BT's investors tire of being kept on hold

fields.headline: BT's investors tire of being kept on hold
fields.standfirst: Plans for divisional splits and demergers fail to arrest share price decline
fields.trailText: Plans for divisional splits and demergers fail to arrest share price decline
fields.body:
Sir Peter Bonfield, chief executive of BT, is expected to come under renewed pressure today at the company's annual meeting to step up reform at the former state telecoms monopoly or step aside. Angry shareholders are likely to demand reasons for the dismal share price performance of BT as it wallows near an 18-month low of 815p.

Only yesterday the company made much of its new venture with AT&T for a mobile service that will allow people to use the same phone number in more than 100 countries in Europe, the Americas and Asia.

But analysts regard this as too little, too late. The poor performance has continued despite the announcement in April of a restructuring that was hailed as the beginning of BT's turnaround.

That announcement confirmed a part disposal of Yell, the print and online directories business, including Yellow Pages.

Since then the management has tried to tantalise the market with hints of part flotations of Openworld and Cellnet, its internet and mobile businesses respectively, and of Concert, the joint venture with AT&T in international corporate telecoms. Together these could raise £30bn for BT's balance sheet.

That would be welcome, says Nigel Hawkins, analyst at Williams de Broë, who is concerned at BT's ballooning debt. "The concern is that BT has switched from net cash position only about two years ago to now about £19-£20bn in debt and what have they got to show for it?" he asked.

In fact, BT's debt has increased because of several developments:

 buying back Cellnet shares from Securicor;

 winning a third-generation mobile phone licence in Britain;

 upgrading its domestic network with asymmetric digital subscriber line technology (providing high-speed internet access using existing "copper wire" cabling);

 investing in its patchwork of European joint ventures such as Viag in Germany and Cegetel in France.

But Sir Peter's fragmented spending and his strategy of divisional splits and part demergers have not appeased impatient investors.

Many are tired of what they regard as BT's lumbering performance when compared with more nimble and focused opponents such as Vodafone AirTouch and former state monopolies such as Deutsche Telekom, France Telecom and Spain's Telefonica.

The French and Germans have been swift to exploit their internet activities: France Telecom is listing its internet division, Wanadoo, and Deutsche Telekom has floated T-Online.

BT's recent discovery that it owns the patent for hyperlinks, which enable web users to click from one site to another, is cited as another example that the company has become unwieldy and unfocused. Many wonder how many other potentially valuable patents it owns - pointing out that IBM generates $1bn a year from intellectual property licensing.

Investors are also put off by BT's inability to lend any fizz to the continental operators in which it has a stake. Two years ago it was a leader in mobile telephony - taking stakes in emerging firms such as the Dutch Telfort and Spain's Airtel - and ahead of its peers in assembling a strong portfolio of minority interests in Europe.

Now its market capitalisation is merely a third of Vodafone's - which did not exist when BT was privatised in 1984.

BT may have also missed the opportunity to capitalise on investor appetite with its partial demergers plan; the telecoms and internet sectors are already saturated with companies seeking to raise funds from share issues.

The group's problems do not end there. It is engaged in several disputes with regulators and governments. These include battles with Oftel and the European commission over opening up its domestic service to competitors and a spat with the British government over the payment for third-generation mobile phone licences. Analysts say these are a distraction from growing the core business.

Worryingly, the management appears to have lost credibility in the City. News that Bill Cockburn would retire as UK managing director after the restructuring was accepted by the market as a step in the right direction. But a whispering campaign has suggested that finance director Robert Brace might also be retiring. BT has dismissed this as a rumour - and reacts the same way to talk that Sir Peter could be on the way out.

Mr Hawkins expects more management changes within the next year and possibly a specific timetable for the divisional demergers. "I think BT have to batten down the hatches in the short term as the market is getting a little impatient," he said. Other analysts expect more senior management heads to roll. "Somebody has got to carry the can," one said.

BT's ailing share price has brought continuing rumours that it might be the subject of a hostile takeover or merger; Spain's Telefonica is seen as a likely partner. Yet with an election on the horizon next year it would be politically unpalatable for the government to let the company slip into foreign ownership.

Sir Peter has denied that the restructuring of the business is "rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic". In fact, the restructuring did answer the investment community's demands for a better and more transparent way to value BT and understand its operations, strategy and management.

Even so, Sir Peter is still going to have to be faster out of the blocks to convince investors of the group's potential.

fields.headline: QXL offers arbitrage bonanza
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: While the rest of the market was fixated on the debut of Granada Media, the seemingly unstoppable slide of QXL continued.
fields.body:
While the rest of the market was fixated on the debut of Granada Media, the seemingly unstoppable slide of QXL continued.

Shares in the internet auction group, which started the year at around the 450p level, closed down 4.5p at 69p yesterday as investors took fright at concerns surrounding its German bid target, Ricardo .

Last week Ricardo was identified by widely read German newsletter Platow Brief as one of a number of Neuer Markt stocks facing financial ruin if it failed to secure fresh funding. While analysts say the concerns are unfounded and Ricardo will not run out of cash, it shares continue to fall (declining 18% yesterday) and hurt QXL.

According to a note published by Deutsche Bank, the fall in Ricardo has presented an interesting arbitrage op portunity. The steep decline in Ricardo's share price, it claims, has not been matched by the decline in the QXL share price. As a result, the current value of QXL's all-stock offer for Ricardo is around 35% higher than the German group's share price.

With the deal likely to go ahead (Ricardo's management team is sitting on 50% of the company's equity) an opportunity to "buy" Ricardo and "sell" QXL until the anomaly is corrected exists, Deutsche reckons.

With more than 5m QXL shares changing hands yesterday, it appears some shrewd arbitrageurs have picked up on the idea.

But it was not all bad news for new-economy stocks. Durlacher , the internet investment boutique, advanced 2.5p to 62p as investors greeted with relief news that it has managed to raise more than £10m in cash.

Durlacher raised the funds through a placing of 15.85m new shares at 65p with a small number of institutional investors.

The FTSE 100, meanwhile, ended a lacklustre session marginally higher (up 9.6 points at 6,475.8) as a good performance from Wall Street offset the impact of Granada Media , which sucked most of the buying interest out of the market. Shares in Granada Media, trading on a "when issued" basis (that is, before investors have received share certificates), closed at modest 35p premium to the 515p offer price after 125m shares had changed hands.

HSBC had another good day, rising 38p to 805p as Com merzbank initiated coverage with a "buy" recommendation and a 913p target price. Commerzbank reckons HSBC offers an attractive mix of high growth via its presence in Asia, and earnings stability from an increasing presence in Europe and the US.

BP Amoco also performed well, advancing 10p to 625p after unveiling some of its masin strategic pointers to City analysts.

Diageo reversed early gains, losing 0.5p to 604, after a disappointing trading update, but home shopping group GUS , managed to rise 6p to 458p as broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barnet lifted its target price to 540p

The FTSE 250 saw a return to form for old-economy stocks. British Energy led the charge, gaining 24p to 220p on unusually heavy turnover after its Bruce Power unit signed a lease deal with Ontario Power Generation for two nuclear power stations.

Shipbuilder Vosper Thornycroft stood out, rising 123p to £13.90 following news that it will build one of the Royal Navy's three new warships. The deal represents five years' work for Vosper's shipbuilding workforce of around 1,500 people.

Regal Hotel Group surged 3p to 29.5p after agreeing a 30.5p per share from Regent Corp.

Software firm Staffware climbed 100p to £22.75 p after winning a contract with Abbey National. The deal, which will see Abbey use its Enterprise Workflow product, is valued at £1.64m.

Sportsworld Media continued its good run, 25p stronger at 600p.

Icollector takes beating

As concerns have mounted over the ability of business-to-consumer internet stocks to secure fresh capital, the share price of Ofex-listed Icollector, an online auction site for the arts and antiques industry, has taken a beating.

After reaching £16.80 at the height of internet gold rush in March, the shares closed yesterday at 185p. But supporters of the stock claim the foundations are in place for some interesting developments.

Yesterday the company raised £6.5m in a convertible bond issue from shareholders, including the internet investment vehicle of luxury goods magnet Bernard Arnault, Europ@web. According to James Corsellis, Icollector's chief executive, the fund raising gives it enough cash for the rest of the year.

With Europ@web promising to play an active role in the development of Icollector - yesterday it placed another director on the board - the shares are an interesting, if risky, punt.

fields.headline: Jellyworks: from £300m to surrender
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
Jellyworks
fields.trailText: Jellyworks, the internet investment company run by a 24-year-old entrepreneur, is disappearing from the London market just six months after an extraordinary flotation which saw its shares soar from 5p to 50p on the first day of trading.
fields.body:
Jellyworks, the internet investment company run by a 24-year-old entrepreneur, is disappearing from the London market just six months after an extraordinary flotation which saw its shares soar from 5p to 50p on the first day of trading.

The company, which has come symbolise the waxing and waning of internet investment in Britain, is to be taken over by the small investment bank and stockbroker Shore Capital in a recommended all-share deal.

Jellyworks, run by Jonathan Rowland, the son of colourful entrepreneur David "Spotty" Rowland, said it had decided that its portfolio of quoted and unquoted investments would better off as part of a larger investment banking operation.

The company indicated that it had found it difficult to raise any fresh finance in the current investment environment.

The group's investments include direct stakes and options over shares in telecom services group Orchestream, sports website Sportal.com, internet incubator Antfactory and web news service Talkcast. But there has always been confusion in the City over the exact size of Jellyworks' investments, making the company difficult to value.

Under the terms of the deal finalised yesterday, Shore Capital will offer new stock for Jellyworks on a one-for-two basis. Existing Shore shareholders will hold three-quarters of the enlarged group.

At the same time Shore itself is floating on the junior AIM market, full details on which have yet to emerge.

With shares in Jellyworks up 2p at 30p yesterday, the company carries a valuation of £67m.

That compares with a valuation of close to £300m at the height of dot.com mania earlier this year.

Howard Shore, chairman at the investment bank declared that Jellyworks' portfolio of investment would be treated as "tradable assets," indicating that he was ready to sell off its various holdings as the new company felt fit.

fields.headline: Granada Media hits £7.5bn
fields.standfirst:
War chest will fund next steps towards a carve-up of ITV

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Granada paraded its £1.5bn war chest yesterday after securing a stock market listing for its media division - just days before the government's announcement of how the ITV network will be carved up.
fields.body:
Granada paraded its £1.5bn war chest yesterday after securing a stock market listing for its media division - just days before the government's announcement of how the ITV network will be carved up.

Granada could use the cash raised to make a bid for either Carlton or United News & Media - while both are waiting for regulatory clearance for a merger.

Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, has until Friday to decide on how the sector can consolidate. If the deal between Carlton and United is approved, Granada is likely to launch a counterbid for one of the two companies.

However Granada believes that the government will allow the three media companies to slice up the ITV network between them - avoiding a takeover battle which could fatally wound one of the trio.

The deadline falls exactly 20 days from when the competition commission handed over its recommendation, but it could be extended - a possibility given the complexity surrounding the issue.

Charles Allen, chairman of the newly-floated Granada Media, yesterday indicated that he thought it unlikely that the secretary of state would block any corporate action, given that the television regulator had itself suggested that some changes to the broadcasting act governing the industry were possible.

Under current rules Granada, with an 11% share of television viewing, would find it difficult to buy either Carlton or United in their entirety.

They control around 8% and 9% of viewing audiences respectively, and acquiring either would breach the limit of 15% of the audience for any one company. But media experts expect these rules to be scrapped in the near future.

Granada's non-media interests have been grouped with the Compass catering business. Demerging Granada Media, which makes programmes such as Coronation Street, gives the newly floated company "more flexibility" to take part in any consolidation, Mr Allen said yesterday.

He reiterated his view that he would like to engineer a carve-up of the ITV regions by Granada, United and Carlton - but made it clear that Granada would consider bidding for either of the others if agreement could not be reached.

"We've held no discussions with Carlton or United, and won't until we know how the roles are going to be structured," Mr Allen said yesterday.

He argued that the ITV network should be run by two companies and later "allow a single ITV that is appropriately regulated".

With £1.3bn of additional capital raised yesterday, and its higher-rated shares on the stock market, Granada was "well placed" for any negotiations.

Granada Media's shares made their debut yesterday at 515p but rose rapidly in heavy trading to 550p, giving the business a market capitalisation of £7.5bn.

Mr Allen, formerly chief executive of Granada, can expect to receive £1.8m when the deal with Compass is completed later this month; because under the terms of the deal all the directors' shares are turned into cash.

Granada Media produces 6,000 hours of programmes each year - including Coronation Street and Blind Date - and holds four ITV franchises: Granada, Yorkshire, London Weekend and Tyne Tees.

fields.headline: Tinkler tells of tear-gas pandemonium
fields.trailText: Eric Tinkler, the Barnsley midfielder playing for South Africa in Harare on Sunday, described as "pandemonium" the situation after Zimbabwean police fired tear gas into the 60,000 crowd and fans stampeded. Thirteen people were killed in the crush and the World Cup qualifier was abandoned.
fields.body:
Eric Tinkler, the Barnsley midfielder playing for South Africa in Harare on Sunday, described as "pandemonium" the situation after Zimbabwean police fired tear gas into the 60,000 crowd and fans stampeded. Thirteen people were killed in the crush and the World Cup qualifier was abandoned.

"We started seeing the smoke coming back towards us," said Tinkler. "It is the first time I have experienced tear gas. My eyes were burning like crazy, I was coughing up blood and all the players started to hit the deck. We saw fans coming on to the pitch to avoid the gas and trying to get out of the stadium. It was just one massive tragedy."

The trouble started after South Africa went 2-0 up in the 82nd minute at the National Sports Stadium. Missiles were thrown as Delron Buckley, the scorer of both goals, was receiving attention to a leg injury. He suffered a cut ear.

"The trouble was confined to a small section of the ground," said Tinkler. "Cans and plastic bottles were thrown. What shocked us so much was that it seemed so unnecessary for the police to react in the way they did. They appeared to go absolutely mental. Instead of spraying the tear gas into the one troublesome section they fired it all over the place."

Robert Mugabe, Zimbabwe's president, blamed the main opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, who were narrowly beaten at the polls a fortnight ago.

Although he did not mention the MDC by name, he said: "It is disturbing to hear that the people who sparked off the disturbances were members of a planted group taking advantage of the huge crowd to sloganeer and exhibit their symbols.

fields.headline: Spurs land Thatcher in £5m deal
fields.trailText: Who went where yesterday.
fields.body:
Wimbledon's Ben Thatcher has completed a £5m move to Tottenham and becomes their third major signing of the close-season after Sergei Rebrov and Neil Sullivan.

Everton are awaiting the arrival of the Ghana and Lens midfielder Alex Nyarko, 26, to open talks about a £4.75m move, though they face competition from Aston Villa and Sunderland. The Merseysiders are also close to tying up a £2m deal for Sheffield Wednesday's Niclas Alexandersson and hope to sign an as yet unnamed foreign midfielder for £1.5m.

Charlton's £2.5m bid for Don Hutchison has been accepted by Everton but they rejected Fulham's increased bid of £1.65m for John Collins.

Birmingham have signed the Fulham striker Geoff Horsfield, 26, for £2.25m while Blackburn have paid Barnsley £2.25m for their midfielder Craig Hignett. Benito Carbone has told Aston Villa that he will not be returning. Instead he is expected to join Napoli.

Leeds' work-permit application for their new £6m striker Mark Viduka has been turned down, though he is expected to be awarded one on appeal. Cardiff City have accepted a £3m offer for 81.2% of their shares from the former Wimbledon owner Sam Hammam.

InterToto Cup draw : Marila Pribram (Cz Rep) v Aston Villa; Bradford City v RKC Waalwijk (Neth). First leg July 15 or 16; second leg July 22

webTitle: Anelka set to return home in £20m deal

fields.headline: Anelka set to return home in £20m deal
fields.trailText: Real Madrid have signed an agreement to sell Nicolas Anelka to Paris St-Germain for £20m. But the deal is dependent on Lorenzo Sanz being returned to the post of president in next Sunday's club election at Real.
fields.body:
Real Madrid have signed an agreement to sell Nicolas Anelka to Paris St-Germain for £20m. But the deal is dependent on Lorenzo Sanz being returned to the post of president in next Sunday's club election at Real.

Sanz and Florentino Perez are candidates for the four-year post, with the former hoping to recover a substantial part of the £23.5m the club paid Arsenal for the troubled France striker while generating publicity to remind the voters that he oversaw Real's record eighth Champions Cup triumph.

If Perez wins, however, the agreement is invalid, although as the new president he too would look to move Anelka on, probably to Italy and for more money. Real are some 20bn pesetas (£75m) in debt.

Anelka was sold to Arsenal by PSG for £500,000 in 1997. The Paris club, runners-up in the league last season and qualified for the Champions League, have spent about £20m on strengthening their squad this close season. Canal Plus, the cable television company that owns the club, would finance the transfer and PSG's sponsor Nike would cover much of his pay packet of £30-35,000 a week gross, which is the 21-year-old striker's current wage after tax.

Anelka's brothers Claude and Didier, who act as his agents, have noted the pickings that have been made from Christian Vieri's and Ronaldo's series of quickfire transfers and would be delighted to bank another cheque so soon after pocketing about £2m for brokering the move to Madrid last August.

Anelka, who would relish a return to his home city, had a patchy season with Real, often substituted, in need of a knee operation and picking up a club suspension for missing training for three days. He went to France during his suspension and was on the point of joining PSG for £13m before being recalled and forced to make a public apology.

webTitle: Pizza and lager, Andy, is a recipe for redundancy

fields.headline: Pizza and lager, Andy, is a recipe for redundancy
fields.trailText: To say that excess weight has no bearing on Andy Flintoff's injuries is as fatuous as it is fanciful, writes Mike Selvey. He knows what he has to do.
fields.body:
Yesterday the Guardian printed a story saying that the increasing bulk of Andy Flintoff was a concern to his England employers, with a general belief that his excess weight had a bearing on his injury problems and that his laddish lifestyle was inappropriate for an international athlete. Consequently, as a player contracted by the England and Wales Cricket Board, he would this week be told his fortune in no uncertain terms.

The response has been predictable: hush from the board and flat denial from his county. "It is pure press speculation," the Lancashire secretary Dave Edmundson said yesterday. "Andy works tremendously hard to maintain his level of fitness. His injury is not weight-related at all. To say it is caused by weight is unfounded."

You think it is speculation, hey Dave? Well, I know it is not and, if Dave asks around, he will find that board officials, Flintoff's Lancashire team-mates, international colleagues and everyone connected with the England team know it as well.

"It's a bit embarrassing, to be honest," Flintoff said yesterday. "It's hard to look your friends in the face. I weigh 17st and I've kept it at that for the past year or so ... My back injury is something I've had since I was 14 when I was skinny as a rake."

But David Lloyd, who signed him for Lancashire and knows him better than most, felt compelled to write: "The time is fast approaching when he sits down with the people who matter and goes through a self-assessment of what he wants to achieve and how to go about it. I have to say he looks out of condition."

Kind understatement, Bumble: he's a porker, for goodness sake.

Lancashire's reaction is no surprise for it was they who failed to rein in Flintoff in the first place, prompting their then coach Dav Whatmore to contact the board to wash his hands of Flintoff's fitness development.

In any case it might be hard to be objective given that the club chairman Jack Simmons' legendary tussles with jumbo haddock led to a fish supper (the Simmo) being named after him, and that Flintoff's agent Andrew Chandler - whose clients include the golfers Lee Westwood and Darren Clarke - is known as Chubby.

There is a history to this. Two winters ago, before the England A tour to Kenya and Sri Lanka, Flintoff failed an undemanding fitness test and was forced into the humiliation of retesting. He just scraped through, but the board's displeasure was communicated in writing.

Then last winter he broke his left foot while bowling in the fourth test in Cape Town. No warning, it just went. Now, for the second time in a couple of weeks, his back has gone.

Saying that excess weight has no bearing on these injuries is as fatuous as it is fanciful. No one has suggested that the back injury was directly caused by being fat (although the jury is out on the fractured foot) but ask any orthopaedic surgeon whether carrying too much weight affects the chances of such an injury recurring and see what the response is.

There has been effort. In the aftermath of the foot injury Flintoff underwent a training programme under Steve Hampson, the former Great Britain rugby league full-back. His fitness levels rose and his weight fell.

This season, however, his weight has reportedly increased again by up to a stone, and that is unacceptable both in terms of fitness and conveying his desire and commitment to becoming a successful international sportsman.

Lancashire's protective stance is doing him no favours. Everyone recognises a massive talent but to fulfil it he needs to be helped, not defended.

The England management are trying to be proactive and might resort to making his fitness records public, in the hope that it will shame him into laying off the beer and fast food. They are not demanding more shuttle runs but a change in lifestyle. And in the end that is down to one person.

So how much do you want it, Andy?

But David Lloyd, who signed him for Lancashire and knows him better than most, felt compelled to write: "The time is fast approaching when he sits down with the people who matter and goes through a self-assessment of what he wants to achieve and how to go about it. I have to say he looks out of condition." Kind understatement, Bumble: he's a porker, for goodness sake. Lancashire's reaction is no surprise for it was they who failed to rein in Flintoff in the first place, prompting their then coach Dav Whatmore to contact the board to wash his hands of Flintoff's fitness development. In any case it might be hard to be objective given that the club chairman Jack Simmons' legendary tussles with jumbo haddock led to a fish supper (the Simmo) being named after him, and that Flintoff's agent Andrew Chandler - whose clients include the golfers Lee Westwood and Darren Clarke - is known as Chubby. There is a history to this. Two winters ago, before the England A tour to Kenya and Sri Lanka, Flintoff failed an undemanding fitness test and was forced into the humiliation of retesting. He just scraped through, but the board's displeasure was communicated in writing. Then last winter he broke his left foot while bowling in the fourth test in Cape Town. No warning, it just went. Now, for the second time in a couple of weeks, his back has gone. Saying that excess weight has no bearing on these injuries is as fatuous as it is fanciful. No one has suggested that the back injury was directly caused by being fat (although the jury is out on the fractured foot) but ask any orthopaedic surgeon whether carrying too much weight affects the chances of such an injury recurring and see what the response is. There has been effort. In the aftermath of the foot injury Flintoff underwent a training programme under Steve Hampson, the former Great Britain rugby league full-back. His fitness levels rose and his weight fell. This season, however, his weight has reportedly increased again by up to a stone, and that is unacceptable both in terms of fitness and conveying his desire and commitment to becoming a successful international sportsman. Lancashire's protective stance is doing him no favours. Everyone recognises a massive talent but to fulfil it he needs to be helped, not defended. The England management are trying to be proactive and might resort to making his fitness records public, in the hope that it will shame him into laying off the beer and fast food. They are not demanding more shuttle runs but a change in lifestyle. And in the end that is down to one person. So how much do you want it, Andy?

fields.headline: Lehmann not so bitter
fields.standfirst:
Durham 314
Yorkshire 129 & 386-4dec
Match drawn
fields.trailText:
Durham 314
Yorkshire 129 & 386-4dec
Match drawn.
fields.body:
At about tea-time there was an announcement that this was the only cricket going on in the country. All the other matches had been abandoned.

The handful of spectators, wearing heavy coats and stamping feet to keep warm and, when it wasn't drizzling, tilting umbrellas to form wind-breaks, wore "Why us?" expressions. There were more people watching Countdown on TV in the tea bar. Those actually watching the cricket resembled sullen relatives gathered bedside and waiting for a will.

It is high time there was a debate about euthanasia for certain cricket matches. They probably have it in Holland. To give the thing gravitas they could wheel in Ludovic Kennedy to look worriedly over his glasses.

This match could have been mercy-killed at the start of the day. By then the awful weather had already pushed the contest into a siding and there was absolutely no way it was going to go anywhere.

The players, hands stuffed in pockets and flannels fluttering vigorously like loose sails in the chill wind, looked longingly from clock to sky.

A cortege of clouds, dressed in solemn black, passed by. Light rain fell like a sprinkled blessing. But the match, like some wounded cockroach in a third-rate hotel, refused to die. It went on and doggedly on and the spectators stayed on too.

Yorkshire's Darren Lehmann wore a defiant smile that might have been irony. Or it might have been because he had just scored his first Headingley hundred in championship cricket.

Yorkshire resumed yesterday, half an hour late, on 149 for one, still 36 runs behind Durham after following on. Michael Vaughan soon lost Richard Blakey but found such a productive partner in Lehmann that the pair put on 102 in 25 overs.

Vaughan was bowled, shuffling forward, by Neil Killeen for 118. Lehmann, who was restrained when he was fit, then injured his back and suddenly started to play strokes all round the wicket, pulling and square-driving in particular.

He faced only 146 balls for his 136, hitting 18 fours. This was his 46th first-class century and his ninth for Yorkshire. But he had only once reached three figures while playing in a home game, and that was in Scarborough.

The match ended at 5.20 when Yorkshire declared at 386 for four, 201 runs ahead. Arguably a blessing.

Afterwards the umpire Roy Palmer also might have been accused of irony when he said that he had enjoyed the match more than most he had stood at recently. This was because of the excellent spirit between the two sides. Perhaps they were pulled together through adversity.

Meanwhile it was revealed that Durham's unwell opening batsman Michael Gough would remain in hospital, and in isolation, until Thursday, although the club would not disclose the nature of the illness. It is thought he may have picked up a chest infection during England A's winter tour of Bangladesh.

fields.headline: England Bristol fashion
fields.trailText: England's five-match Test series against Australia next summer will not be interrupted by a triangular one-day tournament. The international fixtures for the 2001 season were announced by the England and Wales Cricket Board yesterday, with no repeat of this summer's itinerary which has interrupted the Test series against West Indies for a month after England's thrilling victory at Lord's.
fields.body:
England's five-match Test series against Australia next summer will not be interrupted by a triangular one-day tournament. The international fixtures for the 2001 season were announced by the England and Wales Cricket Board yesterday, with no repeat of this summer's itinerary which has interrupted the Test series against West Indies for a month after England's thrilling victory at Lord's.

Next summer's triangular tournament will follow a two-match Test series against Pakistan and precede the Ashes series, which starts at Edgbaston on July 5. The ECB said this season's triangular series had been scheduled to avoid a clash with Euro 2000 after a request from Sky, which had the exclusive rights to screen the tournament live.

Three non-Test match grounds will stage one-day games, with Bristol the main beneficiary. England play Australia there on June 10, which should attract the largest crowd to Nevil Road - where the capacity has been increased to 15,000 - since Don Bradman's Australians toured in 1948.

"This will be the biggest sporting occasion ever held in the west country," said Colin Sexstone, Gloucestershire's chief executive. "It will be the first time ever that the full England side - be it in rugby, football or cricket - has played in Bristol."

Warwickshire, meanwhile, may have to look for a new overseas player next season, with the fast bowler Allan Donald admitting that he might not return despite having a two-year contract with the county.

"If I have a long South African summer then I would have to think about taking a rest to get my breath back," he said. "There is a lot of stress playing so much cricket, particularly on the county scene, and it is becoming really hard. I've discussed the situation with Warwickshire's coach Bob Woolmer and he has told me to keep an open mind."

Donald had the chance to put his feet up yesterday as rain washed out the final day against Sussex at Edgbaston, frustrating Warwickshire's hopes of building a big lead at the top of the Second Division.

The draw left them seven points clear of Worcestershire, who were rescued by the elements from probable defeat against Middlesex. In the wake of the drenching sustained at Southgate, Middlesex are now concerned that tomorrow's match against Glamorgan may not start on time. Rain also washed out play at Derby, Taunton and Trent Bridge.

2001 NatWest one-day series: June 7: England v Pakistan, Edgbaston (day/night). 9: Pakistan v Australia, Cardiff. 10: England v Australia, Bristol. 12: England v Pakistan, Lord's. 14: England v Australia, Old Trafford (day/night). June 16: Pakistan v Australia, Durham. 17: England v Pakistan, Headingley. June 19: Pakistan v Australia, Trent Bridge (day/night). 21: England v Australia, the Oval. 23: Final, Lord's.

Tests in 2001

Pakistan

Two tests

May 17-21 Lord's

31-June 4: Old Trafford

Australia

Five tests

July 5-9: Edgbaston

July 19-23: Lord's

August 2-6: Trent Bridge

August 16-20: Headingley

August 23-27: The Oval

webTitle: Police issue e-fit of Sarah Payne suspect

fields.headline: Police issue e-fit of Sarah Payne suspect
fields.standfirst:
See the e-fit
Graphic: where Sarah disappeared
fields.trailText: Detectives hunting for missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne tonight released an e-fit picture of man they want to question in connection with her disappearance.
fields.body:
Detectives hunting for missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne tonight released an e-fit picture of man they want to question in connection with her disappearance.

The computer-generated image is the likeness of a man seen with a young girl fitting Sarah's description at a service station, and police believe it could be the most significant lead yet in the ten-day inquiry.

Chief inspector Mike Alderson, the inquiry team spokesman, said he believed it would narrow down the search for the man, who was spotted with the girl at the Granada Services, Knutsford, on the M6 motorway.

Earlier today a police helicopter was called out after an unconfirmed sighting of the youngster with a man in south Wales.

The police search in South Wales centred around the village of Cilfynydd, just north of Pontypridd following a call from a member of the public this morning.

A spokeswoman for South Wales police said: "We're carrying out local inquiries in the area. Officers are going house to house, speaking to local shopkeepers and schools. The police helicopter was launched but a sweep of the area proved negative. We would like to stress at this point it is still just a possible sighting of Sarah."

Detectives revealed earlier that they had received 800 calls from the public since another possible sighting at a service station in Cheshire.

At a press conference at Littlehampton police station, officers also said there had been some possible sightings as far afield as Greece and Israel.

Assistant chief constable Nigel Yeo said of the Cheshire sighting that they had so far not been contacted by the man who was seen with the "upset" young girl or any of his friends or relatives.

Meanwhile, a 14-year-old boy charged with wasting the time of police officers involved in the search for missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne has been remanded in care.

The boy, who cannot be named, has appeared at Chichester magistrates court charged with causing the wasteful employment of the police by pretending to have information relevant to a police inquiry.

It is alleged the boy made a malicious phone call to the police inquiry team leading the hunt for Sarah in which he claimed to have seen the youngster.

He was remanded in the care of the local authority until Thursday, when he is due back at Chichester magistrates court.
