fields.headline: Whose advantage?
fields.standfirst: David Blanchflower and  Andrew Oswald, advisers on the new Russell Group report, explain why they believe in a rise in fees
fields.trailText: David Blanchflower and Andrew Oswald, advisers on the new Russell Group report, explain why they believe in a rise in fees
fields.body:
Universities in the UK are in trouble. The quality of the product - both teaching and research - is deteriorating fast. Something needs to be done, and done now. The new Greenaway report (written for the Russell Group), in which we had a hand, offers the way forward.

What is the problem and how can it be fixed?

First, the British higher education system has expanded too quickly and with inadequate funding. When we went to university in Britain in the 1970s, only one in 15 people did so. Now more than a quarter of the youth population does. Yet public funding per student has collapsed. It is down nearly 50% in real terms since 1980. This is unsustainable.

Second, British universities are no longer world-leaders. They do not pay remotely competitive salaries, and morale is low. Being an academic in Britain is now, in many universities, a pretty rotten job. The best and the brightest in our land can no longer afford to become a university lecturer. One option is to quit academia; another is to join the brain drain and move abroad (as one of us decided to do), usually to the United States, where universities are well funded and where both salaries and job satisfaction are high. This is bad news for Britain.

Third, and perhaps the worst of all, the taxpayer does not care. The reason is that the beneficiaries of higher education are the students themselves. Having good primary schooling and a better health service helps everyone in society. That is not true - repeat not true - of higher education.

The people who get degrees are the ones who benefit. Yet, currently, they are massively cross-subsidised by the rest of society. It is simply not reasonable to ask the carpenters and secretaries to stump up. Students should pay for themselves.

So the question is: what do we do next? The Greenaway report considers the options. It is particularly keen to foster wide access to higher education - in other words, to think of a way to get clever children from poor backgrounds into higher education. The report points out that at the moment Britain is very bad at that.

Our current system produces a huge transfer of money from poor people (though many of them are unaware of it) to rich people. It is grossly regressive. As in America, Britain should do the reverse and make rich students cross-subsidise the poor - the most obvious way is to have generous scholarship funds and even subsidised loan schemes. We strongly support that. Far too much talent is wasted at the moment in this country. How do you fund these scholarships and provide the universities with additional funding to recruit and retain high-quality staff?

The only viable option, in our view, is to make the beneficiaries pay the true cost of their education. Universities should be allowed to set whatever fees the market will bear - some will be able to set fees high - perhaps even as high as £10,000 per annum - because of the high quality of their product. If the price is too high for the product on offer, the students will not show up. Most fees will be much lower.

The Greenaway report recommends that we move to such a system, and we must. Big chunks of the money raised this way from those who can afford to pay could then be used to encourage children from the lowest social class groups, who attend ordinary state schools, to go to university. This is what happens in US Ivy League schools such as Dartmouth.

An indication of the level of the fees likely to emerge is to be found in the US, where a large and diverse private market exists alongside a (subsidised) public system. Undergraduate tuition fees (excluding board and lodging) in US private Ivy League universities such as Harvard, Princeton, Dartmouth and Yale are around £16,000 per annum for a four-year degree.

What is probably less well known in the UK is that, in the US, high fees are not confined to the elite Ivy League universities. Literally hundreds of other colleges and universities in the United States charge high fees.

For example, in the state of Massachusetts, which is home to both Harvard and MIT, 41 universities charge tuition of more than £10,000 per annum. Such students could have attended the University of Massachusetts, which is public, at any of its five main campuses for a fee of around £3,000 per annum. Yet they are investing wisely in themselves.

There is no reason why the bus drivers and lathe operators of Britain should have to pay for university funding. Fairness and common sense dictate that students should pay their own bills - supplemented by scholarships for children who come from low-income homes.

 David Blanchflower, professor of Economics and associate dean of the social sciences, Dartmouth College, US, and Andrew Oswald, professor of economics, Warwick University, UK. The authors were advisers on the Greenaway-Haynes paper prepared for the Russell Group.

webTitle: Wrong turn: the trouble with special measures

fields.headline: Wrong turn: the trouble with special measures
fields.standfirst:
Far from improving matters, the reform of failing schools is making things worse
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: In the bizarre world of Britain's target-driven schools, it is not only teachers who have joined children in cheating to get good results. The Department for Education and Employment is in there, too.
fields.body:
In the bizarre world of Britain's target-driven schools, it is not only teachers who have joined children in cheating to get good results. The Department for Education and Employment is in there, too.

We decided to test the DfEE's claims to be "turning around" failing schools, by analysing the academic results of every secondary school which has ever been put into "special measures", the programme of intensive reform and inspection which, according to the repeated claims of David Blunkett, sets schools "back on the path to success". "We are turning them around more quickly than ever," he said last year.

In the latest list, there are 166 secondary schools which have gone into special measures. Some 70% of them are either still in (87, including one that has been there for six years) or they have closed (29, including nine that have been re-opened as Fresh Start schools, which we examine later). Setting aside one school which has been merged, we looked at the remaining 50 for the signs of success which are celebrated by the education secretary.

We found that in the year before they went into special measures, on average only 13.24% of pupils were scoring at least five A to C grades at GCSE, the government's chosen measure of academic success. This was seriously low. Mr Blunkett announced in March that he would consider closing any school which failed to deliver at least 15% A to C grades. Then we looked at the average achievement of pupils in each of the schools for every year since it went into special measures and found that on average there have been only 13.66% of pupils scoring five A to C grades.

This tiny overall improvement has been secured at an estimated cost of £500,000 per school, a total bill of £25m.

Of course, our averages refer to schools of different sizes and they conceal wide variations. Among the 50, there are some who have moved upwards sharply: St Mary and St Joseph's in Bexley was scoring 35% A to Cs and now scores 45%; Hayes Manor in Hillingdon was scoring 18% and now scores 27%; Fairham in Nottingham has moved from 17% to 25%. Almost all of the 50 schools now have fewer students who fail to pass a single GCSE at any level (only six have deteriorated in this respect). Clearly, there is some genuine improvement.

However, the signs of continuing failure are striking. On Mr Blunkett's own 15% benchmark, 21 of these success stories are liable to be closed down: 14 of them are not even scoring 10% (one school scores only 2%, two others score 4%). Nearly a third of them have actually declined: 16 are turning in results for A to C grades which are worse than they were before they went in.

The signs of failure touch even the most renowned success story. Northicote school in Wolverhampton was the first secondary school ever put into special measures, in November 1993, and when it emerged two years later, it was greeted with a chorus of official acclaim. Its headteacher, Geoff Hampton, was knighted.

Last year, a team of Ofsted inspectors returned to the school and, although they found strengths, they also found just as many weaknesses. They reported: "Not enough teaching that is good or very good... monitoring of teaching is unsatisfactory... students' personal development is unsatisfactory... level of students' attendance is below the national average."

The underlying point is that schools can be improved by shaking up teaching and management, but this improvement is limited by the school's resources and by its intake of children. Phoenix school in Hammersmith has done everything which Mr Blunkett could ask to improve its teaching and management. Last year, Ofsted reported that five years after the school went into special measures, the leadership of its headteacher was "excellent" and 60% of the lessons were either good, very good or excellent. And yet despite this, the number of children at the school who scored five A to C grades at GCSE last year was only 5%. In the year before the school went into special measures, it was more than three times higher at 17%.

Anyone at Phoenix school can tell Mr Blunkett that this happened because the school was damaged directly by being put into special measures in 1994. This triggered a rash of publicity which created an immediate flight of teachers and of parents of motivated children. This left classes to be taught by supply teachers and drained many of the most able children from the new intake in September. The school's results immediately started to slide, from 17% to 11% in 1994 and then 5% in 1995.

For those schools which fare particularly badly in special measures, Mr Blunkett has created the Fresh Start programme, in which the school is closed and its entire staff is sacked before it is re-opened with a new name, a new head and a new staff. In March, he declared that "our Fresh Start policy is already being used by LEAs to tackle failing schools and is beginning to have an impact". A month later, he referred to the scheme again as an example of "rapid progress" in tackling failure and added: "A successful example of this is Firfield school in Newcastle".

However, Firfield has since been caught out by Channel 4 News and its "superhead" has resigned. Our understanding is that the LEA is now planning to take this "successful example" and close it down.

Most of the nine other Fresh Starts have also run into trouble. In Hull, Kingswood has seen 23 of its 50 teachers, including four heads of department, hand in their notice since the school went into Fresh Start last September. Riverdeen in Nottingham is expecting only half of their Year Seven places to be filled in September. Bishopsford in Merton, south London, has recruited only 60% of the new pupils it hoped for.

In Brighton, the new College of Media Arts similarly lost 18 of its 58 staff within two terms of its Fresh Start, before also losing its headteacher and its chair of governors.

Even Gary Orfield, who chaired the committee of experts which launched the San Francisco experiment, now recognises the limits of reconstitution. He told us: "My basic conclusion is that this is like open heart surgery. fields.headline: Learning the hard way
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: "No one forgets a good teacher," says the government ad - a clear reference to what colleagues, pupils and parents think about Indro Sen. Mr Sen has taught at Kingsland school, Dalston, in east London, since it opened more than 20 years ago.
fields.body:
As our modern trade unions become less and less inclined to defy the employers and the anti-union laws, they seem more and more determined to have a bash at their own members. "No one forgets a good teacher," says the government ad - a clear reference to what colleagues, pupils and parents think about Indro Sen. Mr Sen has taught at Kingsland school, Dalston, in east London, since it opened more than 20 years ago.

His dedication is legendary. He has often been spotted on Hackney Downs with a blackboard and a crowd of enthusiastic pupils discussing the finer points of mathematics. He is renowned for the care he takes with disruptive "special needs" children. But Mr Sen is not the sort of teacher who commends himself to Ofsted and its sanctimonious chief inspector Chris Woodhead. For a start, Mr Sen is a keen member of the National Union of Teachers and joint union rep at Kingsland, and is bitterly opposed to the craze for school privatisation. He has also campaigned tirelessly against the victimisation of black teachers.

On June 14, after a hostile Ofsted report about Kingsland, Mr Sen was put on "capability procedures", a form of final warning about his performance. The action was taken, apparently, because of a complaint about a single lesson plan that no one can find. His colleagues were incensed. They concluded that he was being victimised. At an emergency meeting they voted by 26 to one to strike for one day. This week the teachers are attending disciplinary hearings to account for their action.

Before they could answer their employers' charges, however, they were suspended by their union. An NUT spokeswoman tells me that the teachers had been warned in a letter from their general secretary that unofficial strike action was against the law, and that if they took such action the union would not be able to act on their behalf. No doubt that covered the union legally, but why on earth did the union take such drastic action against these teachers, who had done nothing more than stand up for an elementary trade union principle? The spokeswoman had no credible reply.

The defiance of the general secretary's letter, she suggested, justified the suspension. The teachers had broken rule 8, which bans all industrial action without the permission of national officers. I asked about rule 3, which names the decision-making body of the union as the national conference. What about the union leadership's refusal to accept the recent conference decision to ballot for a national strike in protest against performance-related pay? She replied that the leadership was entitled to take decisions in defiance of national conference when "circumstances changed between conferences". It seems to me, though, that the union leaders stick firmly to the rules when disciplining their own members, but are much more flexible when they want to overturn their members' decision to ballot for action in support of union policy.

 On the same sort of subject, I found myself speaking at the weekend under a union banner of the Manufacturing and Service Federation (MSF). I was delighted to see the banner adorned by a quotation from Shelley: "Rise like lions". I pointed out at once that the "lions" in this passage are animals, and have no connection whatever with Roger Lyons, general secretary of the MSF, whose problems with his expense account and his staff have so illuminated recent issues of the Guardian.

 Rivers of tears have flowed through the health services in the south-west over the terrible plight of Arthur Wilson, former chief executive of Plymouth hospitals trust, which I wrote about here recently. Poor Mr Wilson, who was brought in under the Tories to "improve standards" in the health service, vehemently supported the 1994 sacking of Sister Pat Cooksley, who spent most of her life trying to improve standards on her ward. She was eventually reinstated, but last year Mr Wilson was caught up in a rather messy inquiry into the massaging of waiting list figures at Derriford hospital. Ninety-two patients who had been waiting for operations for more than 18 months mysteriously disappeared from the lists. Mr Wilson and his deputy were suspended for several months and resigned before the report could be published. They left with a wad of public money in their pockets (no one will say how much). The tears can now stop. Mr Wilson has found another job. He is now a consultant to Avon health authority. In a job description typical of New Labour, he will "oversee a strategic review of the long-term future needs of health service provision in the county". The amount of public money he gets is obviously a public secret.

fields.headline: A question of cash
fields.standfirst: Will poorer students suffer if fees go up? Lee Elliot Major  grasps a red hot issue
fields.trailText: Will poorer students suffer if fees go up? Lee Elliot Major grasps a red hot issue
fields.body:
The febrile debate over top-up fees takes a new twist today when academics present research concluding that differential fees would deter poor students from degrees. The study shows that going to university is a riskier option for students from less privileged backgrounds, particularly as they are less likely to enjoy the higher career earnings secured by graduates from richer backgrounds with the same degree results.

The conclusions represent a spanner in the works for proposals published last week by university economists who propose differential fees as the solution to the academic sector's financial woes. The Greenaway-Haynes report, commissioned by the 19 Russell group universities, says that students themselves, rather than the taxpayer, should pay university fees because of the financial returns they experience later in life.

The economists argue that poorer students would not be put off university by fees if scholarships and loans were expanded. But at a conference organised today by the Royal Economic Society, Warwick University economists Robin Naylor, Jeremy Smith and Abigail McKnight counsel caution against any move to increase or deregulate fees.

They argue that returns for students are very unpredictable. Even with the same degrees, graduates from state schools and lower social classes, for example, are likely to earn less than their privately educated counterparts. Ironically, Naylor's office at Warwick is two doors down the corridor from that of Professor Andrew Oswald, one of the key advisors for the Greenaway report.

The difference in financial returns from degrees is seen by some economists as further reason for allowing universities to charge different fees for degree courses. But the Naylor group argues that the high risks associated with degrees will deter poorer students most.

"Top-up fees are likely to deter students from less privileged backgrounds," said Naylor. "And differential fees are likely to deter them further from courses which lead to better paid careers." A major concern is that professions such as law and medicine would remain the enclave of the middle classes.

The Greenaway-Haynes report has also split academic heads. The vice-chancellor of Nottingham University Sir Colin Campbell is among a small group of university heads thought to favour the introduction of differential tuition fees. Others rumoured to be sympathetic to the free marketapproach to university funding include the vice-chancellors at Bristol, Birmingham and Warwick.

Those openly against fees include the vice-chancellors of York, Glasgow, Edinburgh and Hull. Sir David Watson, director of Brighton University, also recently listed ten reasons for not supporting top-up fees as part of the debate.

Many of the 19 Russell heads want to dissociate themselves from Campbell's views. Alan Wilson, the vice-chancellor of the University of Leeds, is understood to be one of those particularly resistant to extra fees. The 1994 group, representing 16 small research-intensive universities, remains tight-lipped.

"The 1994 group agrees that all the funding options should be investigated - not only differential fees, but other ways of raising additional sources for universities," said Prof Ivor Crewe, vice-chancellor at the University of Essex, and the current convenor of the group. "We will not have a position until the funding review concludes."

Even among the economists who helped produce the Greenaway report there are differences of opinion over its implications. Professor David Blanchflower, based in Dartmouth College in the US, argues that fees could eventually rise to US levels, and that, if anything, public funding for UK universities should be cut. The other authors predict that fees in the UK would be less than those charged in the US and Australia, at least "in the medium term".

webTitle: Fiddling the figures to get the right results

fields.headline: Fiddling the figures to get the right results
fields.standfirst:
The UK's reporter of the year continues part three of his award-winning series on education in Britain. Today: the big cheat
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: There were 18 children in a classroom. All of them had three things in common: they were all studying Macbeth for GCSE English; they had all turned in essays to be assessed as part of their GCSE; and not one of them had written a single word of any of the essays, because their teacher (with a little help from her husband) had spent the weekend writing the whole lot for them.
fields.body:
There were 18 children in a classroom. All of them had three things in common: they were all studying Macbeth for GCSE English; they had all turned in essays to be assessed as part of their GCSE; and not one of them had written a single word of any of the essays, because their teacher (with a little help from her husband) had spent the weekend writing the whole lot for them.

This teacher says that routinely she writes her students' coursework and that a lot of her colleagues do the same. "I do it for two reasons. First, you give the kid a chance and second, you don't get beaten over the head. Otherwise, you get the blame for the fact that the kids don't do any work, or don't even turn up, and for the fact that the national curriculum is crap and doesn't do anything for a load of kids. You are bullied. The bullying of staff by senior management in schools is appalling."

Welcome to the other side of David Blunkett's drive for higher standards, to the world of tests and targets, where the career prospects of a teacher or the future of a school can be broken by one bad set of statistics, a world where teachers have been taught to fear failure with such an intensity that they have learned to cut corners to survive. Welcome to the Big Cheat.

We have spoken to teachers, headteachers, local education authority (LEA) advisers, Ofsted inspectors, officials and leaders of teacher unions, and we have not found a single one of them who has not heard of some kind of cheating to deliver the figures required.

The cheating goes far beyond GCSE coursework - to multiple fiddles on standard assessment tasks (Sats) and GCSEs, to the wholesale fabrication of figures on truancy and attendance, to the falsification of records on excluded children. It is certain that not all teachers have been driven to cheat; equally, our evidence suggests the fiddling is widespread.

The significance of the Big Cheat is not simply that the official figures are infected with fiction. Beneath the fiddling, there is little doubt that in the last 10 years there has been some real advance in the standards achieved in Britain's state schools. The more important point is that it is yet another sign of the enduring weakness of Labour's attack on poor standards, that its underlying analysis of failure is mistaken, with the result that its strategy repeatedly evades the real problems and imposes the entire burden of change on teachers and managers.

As this Guardian series has previously shown, the most important single factor in a school's failure to hit academic targets is its intake of children and, in particular, of the 30% of Britain's children who live with the damaging effects of poverty. The government swats this aside with its mantra that "poverty is no excuse" and continues with Kenneth Baker's [the former education secretary] market in school places, even though it penalises the schools with the most impoverished intake.

Beyond that, school failure reflects financial limits - large classes, scarce equipment, poor buildings, stressed teachers. As we revealed in March, this government has lied about the amount of extra money which it is investing in schools. Failing effectively to tackle these underlying problems, the government has inflicted overwhelming pressure on teachers and managers to deliver all the necessary change themselves.

There is no doubt that there was room for teachers and managers to improve - but they alone cannot deliver a change on the scale demanded. And so, some of those who have the most difficult intakes of children and/or the most stifling financial problems have learned to cheat to survive. As one West Country teacher put it: "We all know the system is ridiculous but we don't do anything about it. It's just a game we play." Or, to be precise, a collection of games.

Take, for example, the Truancy Game. The object is to make your attendance figures look good. This has been important since the mid 1990s when Ofsted (the Office for Standards in Education) started to log attendance as an indicator of a school's progress and the Department for Education and Employment (DFEE) started to publish annual figures. Now it has become an even higher priority: David Blunkett has announced that by the year 2002, schools must reduce the number of days lost to truancy by 30%. Schools who fail to hit their targets are liable to lose funds.

In the truancy game, points are scored by obliterating the evidence of unauthorised absences, and players can score these points in two simple ways: by pretending that an absent child was really in the school, or by admitting that the child was absent but pretending that there was a legitimate reason.

There are some who like to wait for the end of term and then spend a whole day on the figures, like this senior teacher at a secondary school in an inner city area: "At the end of term, if you've got less than, say, 92%, which is your attendance target, then you go right back through the register and you start putting in 'present'. You can do it with the new electronic registers just the same. Sometimes it's the head who says to the person who's doing the returns, to work on the figures, sort of 'we need our attendance at such and such, so make sure we get there'.

"It's a lot of work; you have to write in loads of 'presents'. You think about it: if the school has been doing two registers a day, it comes to about 150,000 attendances in one term, and if you find out you've only got 87% and you need 92 or 93%, you've got to put in about 7,000 extra 'presents'. It takes ages."

Other players prefer to keep the ball rolling all through the term, with a little fiddling each day, usually by pretending that somebody like a parent or a doctor has authorised a child to be absent, as numerous teachers explained: "You just write 'letter sent' or 'letter received', or it could have been a phone call ... You can use religious holidays ... No one checks, you just say the absence was authorised." Other fiddles are opportunistic. "We had to close the school for the day, because the heating broke down so we put it down as 100% attendance ... We have children in the behaviour unit who often only get taught for half the day but it gets put down as a whole day."

No control

The game is so widespread that it is scarcely secret at all. Here is a former headteacher, now a nationally respected expert on the improvement of schools: "I know that schools have fixed the attendance figures and I believe the government cannot be unaware of it." Or here is one of Ofsted's registered inspectors, formerly a senior LEA official: "Fiddling attendance figures is dead common. It's easy." Or this school clerk from the East Midlands: "We fiddle them because we have absolutely no control over how many children come to school." Or the deputy head from east London: "I don't feel any shame about it at all. There is no other way to do it. And that's the truth. Everybody does it."

For those who prefer something with a little more skill and imagination, the government has also organised the Great Exclusion Game. Just as with truancy, Mr Blunkett has set a target for the number of excluded children to be cut by 30% by 2002 with the threat of financial penalties for those who fail.

So, the trick here is to exclude children without admitting it. "It's 'jump before you're pushed'. You get hold of the parent and you say 'If you leave him here, we're going to have to kick him out, it'll be on his record for ever and he'll never get a job, so why don't you take him out yourself before it happens?' It usually works." Some headteachers call this 'cleansing': just about nobody admits that they are doing it, but just about everybody knows somebody else who has.

Jenny Price, of the Association for Education Welfare Managers, told us: "Children whose faces don't fit, children who will never get the required number of A to C grades or whose behaviour is disruptive: these children are removed off rolls. You cannot believe how easy it is. Nobody follows it up, nobody chases it."

It is, in fact, the oldest trick in the current Big Cheat book, and officials in the education department and the social exclusion unit admit that it has been happening. A few players show signs of real ingenuity, like Firfield School in Newcastle which was caught out by Channel 4 News last year arranging for the parents of regular truants to sign letters offering to educate their children at home. The parents had no such intention and said they signed the letters simply because they were told to.

A temporary exclusion is just as easy and, by all accounts, just as widespread: "You just phone the parents up and say 'We're sending him home and we don't want him back till Tuesday'. They just accept it. It's usually because there's been some pretty bad incident, so they're not going to argue about it. We don't log it as an exclusion, so it doesn't count as one. The only problem is that if we want to go for a 45-day exclusion, we can't do it, because we haven't recorded all the others." As a variation, children are told to come in for half days only.

There is no doubt that the most demanding play is seen in the Exam Games. Sats have become a central part of school life, the raw material for the league tables which, despite widespread acknowledgement of their failure to tell the truth about schools, have become firmly lodged as the key indicator of a school's success with critical implications for future enrolment and funding. The pressure from the DFEE has been intense since the secretary of state announced that he would resign if by 2002 he could not get 80% of 11-year-olds to reach level four in English and 75% of them in maths. There is almost no pattern to the play in Sats, more like an orgy of improvisation as different teachers slip through different loopholes in search of ways to meet the pressure.

Loopholes

Some of the loopholes are more or less legitimate, encouraged even: extra classes to prepare children for the tests; practice work on last year's papers, which are be ing sold in increasing quantities; the teaching of specific test-related skills, such as the layout and style for writing a letter, which is a regular question in English tests. The DFEE says much of this is simply part of improving literacy and numeracy, and they supply £42m for "booster classes" for children approaching Sats. However, in a narrow distinction, they also say that they do not recommend "cramming or teaching to the test" and there are many teachers who say that this whole focus on Sats is a perversion of education.

Some of the loopholes are more controversial, albeit they fall short of outright cheating: teachers who tell children that Sats are "the most important exams you'll ever take" and that their future sets will depend on them; the headteacher who wanders around the exam room, suggesting "You might want to have another look at that answer"; the English teacher who supplies a list of "wizard words" - sophisticated, unusual words - for the children to memorise so they can scatter them throughout their English answers; invigilators who ignore the clock and let children have as much time as they want to complete the test.

Then there are the loopholes which everyone knows amount to cheating. We spoke to some of those who mark Sats and who see the clues in the answers: the school where every single child used almost exactly the same form of words to describe how shadows are made; the incorrect answers which have been crossed out and replaced with correct ones; the school whose children reproduced the wording from an official answer sheet; the papers where tick boxes are filled out in a hand that is stronger and neater than that on the written parts of the paper.

The markers say they are supposed to report evidence of malpractice. They all said they didn't: too much hassle; their own marking would then have to be checked; they felt some solidarity with the classroom teachers. Some said they had made reports but that their anxieties had been dismissed.

Then we spoke to teachers and headteachers who explained how it is done. Mostly, they talked about the Main Trick, the numerous different ways in which teachers can get an early sight of the test papers. This turns out to be rather simple. Eighty per cent of the 11,000 Sats markers are teachers and, in order to standardise the marking, the examination boards have to give them access to the papers 10 days before the exam. In the same way, the exam boards also employ a further 1,100 teachers as team leaders who tour the country lecturing markers and who get to see the papers 24 days before they are officially revealed; others work as consultants who help the qualifications and curriculum agency (QCA) to set the papers and who know the rough contents of the papers 12 months in advance.

The QCA and the DFEE both told us emphatically that this causes no problem. There is no system for checking the behaviour of markers, team leaders or consultants. "We don't see this as a loophole," a QCA spokesman said. The teachers who see the advance papers beg to differ. Some said simply that it took a will of iron to say nothing to their colleagues or to their students; others admitted priming their pupils and some that they had applied for these positions precisely so that they would be able to get early sight of the papers and prepare their children accordingly.

At the conference of the National Union of Teachers in April, there was open talk in the bars about the (supposedly secret) contents of the papers to be sat in May. We were told, for example: "Everyone's been told the key stage two children have to know all about walls - Vietnam Wall, Great Wall of China and so on. Apparently, there's a whole section on that." Sure enough, the English Sats paper which was unveiled in mid-May included a section where children had to absorb and reproduce information about famous walls, Vietnam, China etc.

Armed with this information, teachers can simply prime their children or even persuade them to memorise set answers. A school governor in Yorkshire wrote to us that his headteacher had "heard stories about schools teaching pupils the answers to the actual questions; schools that put up the answers on classroom walls in the guise of educational aids; schools where teachers check papers as they are being written and make sure that answers are correct before they are handed in."

Beyond this, every headteacher in the country is sent the Sats papers a week or 10 days before their students are due to sit them. Headteachers told us there was little chance of being caught if they did open papers in advance.

Spot checks

Barry Dawson, chair of the National Primary Headteachers' Association, which supports the use of Sats but opposes league tables, said: "Heads and teachers are under such pressure that inevitably some will be tempted to bend the rules, and the current system is not rigorous enough to stop this. There is not anything like a rigorous system to check whether the tests have been opened or whether the tests are administered fairly."

LEAs carry out spot checks to make sure that the papers are not opened in advance, and the DFEE told us that "the incidence of the QCA finding anything untoward is so low as to be inexpressible". However, the LEAs are short of inspectors, and the QCA acknowledges that the reality is that 90% of schools receive no spot check when they sit Sats. Heads have to sign a declaration that they will keep the Sats papers secure, but there is no set punishment for a head who is caught out, and the QCA has dealt with cases where the LEA decided to take no action against heads who broke the declaration.

A headteacher in Sheffield has just been suspended after a colleague accused her of "irregularities in the administration of Sats exams". Another in Essex felt so guilty after talking to pupils about the contents of the papers which they were to sit, that he reported himself to the chair of governors and resigned. In Devon, a headteacher resigned last year after being accused by a colleague of similar behaviour (although the LEA there has done its best to conceal the incident). Just as with the truancy game, there is a strong suggestion that this is an open secret.

An HM inspector who retired last year after some 20 years in the job said he had seen "ridiculous and dishonest pursuits" to improve Sats results. "Some of them know why I'm asking them to write things out. With some of them, I just say 'Can you do me a favour? Write this out, I want to put it on the wall'."

Teachers put long hours into doing their students' work for them: "I taught GNVQ business and admin to 11 kids, the average attendance for the class was 63%. I'm between a rock and a hard place. If I don't do the coursework, I'm going to get zero passes. And no one is going to say 'Oh, that's understandable'. So I did everything I could; I bit the bullet. They had to do three different elements with three different modules: I was creating itineraries for them, I made up interviews they had done with people in business, wrote letters they were supposed to have sent to businesses, everything I could."

And there are some subtle manipulations. A recently retired secondary head told us: "If you are clever, you can improve your GCSE results by picking the right exam board for the right subjects. There are different pass rates and you can make quite a difference to your outcomes without making any difference at all to the children's education." Apparently on the same logic, more schools are taking drama GCSEs because they are said to be easy route to an A to C grade; and some are dropping German and Spanish as their second modern language and starting to teach Mandarin Chinese as an easier grade-scoring option.

Finally, there is conflicting evidence on whether the government is not merely enjoying the results of this cheating but actively stimulating it by making exams less demanding.

James Sabben-Clare, the head of Winchester college, told last year's conference of head teachers that he had no doubt that, despite government denials, A levels had become easier. First, you give the kid a chance and second, you don't get beaten over the head. Otherwise, you get the blame for the fact that the kids don't do any work, or don't even turn up, and for the fact that the national curriculum is crap and doesn't do anything for a load of kids. You are bullied. The bullying of staff by senior management in schools is appalling." Welcome to the Big Cheat. We have spoken to teachers, headteachers, local education authority (LEA) advisers, Ofsted inspectors, officials and leaders of teacher unions, and we have not found a single one of them who has not heard of some kind of cheating to deliver the figures required. It is certain that not all teachers have been driven to cheat; equally, our evidence suggests the fiddling is widespread. Beneath the fiddling, there is little doubt that in the last 10 years there has been some real advance in the standards achieved in Britain's state schools. The more important point is that it is yet another sign of the enduring weakness of Labour's attack on poor standards, that its underlying analysis of failure is mistaken, with the result that its strategy repeatedly evades the real problems and imposes the entire burden of change on teachers and managers. As this Guardian series has previously shown, the most important single factor in a school's failure to hit academic targets is its intake of children and, in particular, of the 30% of Britain's children who live with the damaging effects of poverty. The government swats this aside with its mantra that "poverty is no excuse" and continues with Kenneth Baker's [the former education secretary] market in school places, even though it penalises the schools with the most impoverished intake. Beyond that, school failure reflects financial limits - large classes, scarce equipment, poor buildings, stressed teachers. fields.trailText: This year's Becta/Guardian awards show the increasing sophistication of sites in schools
fields.body:
Flash graphics at primary level, a nursery website winner and an increasing gap between schools ahead of the information technology game and those that are not, will all be on the agenda at tomorrow's Becta/ Guardian UK School and College website awards presentation at the British Library in London.

Nine schools and colleges will each pick up an internet-ready desktop computer or i-book for winning the primary, secondary and post-16 sections of the whole website, learners and teaching resources categories. Lifelong learning minister Malcolm Wicks will present the post-16 awards.

Over 300 institutions entered their websites this year, trebling last year's entry and showing that websites have become more a part of the business of schools.

"Last year, sites tended to point to learning resources elsewhere," says Becta's director of schools, Niel McLean, who chaired the judging panel. "But now there is real content - teachers' ideas, lesson plans - and the sites have become more of a working tool for teachers rather than just a showcase for children."

But brochure-type sites have not gone away. Roger Blamire, now innovation manager at European SchoolNet and chair of last year's awards panel, found far too many when helping to draw up this year's shortlist.

"Most entries were prospectuses for prospective parents, with little for existing pupils and parents," Blamire says. And few site designers had considered access for those with special needs. Even so, he feels the pace of the internet has been so fast that what was deemed good enough last year is being seen as poor this year.

So fast, in fact, that some of the technically advanced schools have reached a crossroads. "It's make-your-mind-up-time," says McLean. "They've got as far as they can with a hand-knitted way of doing things. You can see sites now that have a lot of 'spaghetti' content. In two years' time it will be worse than useless. You start off with a bunch of enthusiasts, grow the site and all of a sudden people start forgetting links. Some material may not get used for two years. It can be left like a Stonehenge on the net. So for bigger schools it may mean investing more money, getting someone in to build a foundation for them."

But schools that are falling behind are not forgotten. The 2001 awards, due to be launched this autumn, will have a new category linked to the Comic Relief charity. This is to encourage beginners, particularly children, to submit entries. "You need a category to avoid people becoming dispirited," says McLean. "And also, as schools get slicker, kids will no longer be allowed to run the main site but just do bits."

Becta is hoping for a bumper crop of entries. "A big percentage of schools now have websites," says McLean. "It's an indication of confidence, so we're expecting nearer a thousand entries next year!"

Primary winners

Like last year's entries, the primary sites have proved the most entertaining, packed with colour, excitement and resources. The best ones have been generally more ambitious this year, several using "flash" graphics technology to liven up their pages.

Langstone Junior School from Portsmouth wins the whole site category for its wide mix of resources and clear navigation, which more than compensated for a slightly cluttered front page.

It draws the visitor into the school's activities, carrying a wide selection of photographs. Then a click on a hot spot in pictures taken during a British Museum trip brings up a second layer of photograph flashing up on screen to uncover more detail. And, refreshingly, pictures of the children with a visiting poet show pupils' actual hand-writing - not a font in sight. Add to that a minibeast quiz using graphics to inform about insects and a useful list of linked sites - particularly for parents - and Langstone leads the field in both showcasing school activities and keeping parents and grandparents bang up-to-date in true local newspaper fashion.

But it's hard to better the display of children's work on Edleston Primary School's site which carried off the Learners award. Don't miss the impressive array of artwork on a black background. The colours come to life; animations leap across the page, literally in the shape of a tiger turning the tables on its hunter in a beautifully done animation (older children animated younger children's work). Poetry is spoken in audio clips and the whole site is a walking, talking example of the children's learning.

For sheer rarity value, apart from anything else, the teaching resources award has to go to the small, rural Westfield Day Nursery at York - a real "incentive" site for small schools. The site offers a treasure trove for four-year-olds, parents, students of childcare and other professionals.

A simple but clear home page, built with Frontpage 2000, draws in visitors to the site, which aims to extend the school's open-door policy of allowing anyone to visit without an appointment. A digital camera constantly used by staff and children, a site search engine, and plans to allow pupils to search the net for pictures and add their own websites show what can be done at this age. Nurseries, take heart.

Secondary winners

Judges' responses to the secondary school sites varied widely, but in the end there was near unanimous agreement.

Although the sites had distinct and different characters, there were clear factors the winning sites held in common. Perhaps the most important was that, on the best sites, you could see that the site-builders had clearly worked out who the site was aimed at; in consequence they succeeded in pitching their content attractively to their audience. The second was that the best sites used straightforward design and were simple to find your way around.

In the whole school category, Thornton Grammar's site stood out for all those reasons. The front page is a simple picture, but supplemented with effective roll-over graphics, leading into a home page full of life, where each link nevertheless carries a crystal-clear summary of where it's going to take you. And it's easy to find your way back.

Most schools attempt to display students' work, and a few encourage students to build their own web pages. Denbigh School, Milton Keynes, won the learners' category because it enabled students to show off their own web efforts: the presentation of art work, with clickthrough thumbnails, was particularly well-executed.

The teachers' resources category was hardest to judge, principally because one of the shortlisted entries, kevinsplayroom.co.uk, proved to be a brilliant and eminently usable web guide. But Cornwallis School in Kent narrowly won the day by offering a rich selection of original content to which I, for one, would happily lead my teenage children.

Post-16 winners

Further education websites have come a long way, but many opportunities are still waiting to be taken. That was the judges' verdict for the post-16 category. The sector has much to gain from getting to grips with the web - not just because ICT skills are an increasingly popular option at this level, nor because potential students increasingly turn to the net to choose a course - but because FE students often research essays and projects online for the first time and need all the help they can get from their college.

The judges were a little disappointed that so few college sites had thought about displaying their students' work online. City & Islington College, the winner of the Learners' Award, was an outstanding exception. Professional and engaging, it also gives visitors a vivid sense of students' achievements and college life. The gallery section includes writing by students of English as a second language and - importantly for many students - the chance to place CVs online.

Spelthorne Farm's vivid, albeit rudimentary, site shows a little of what can be achieved when students with special needs contribute to a web project.

While it was good to see so many institutions with a web presence, the judges were looking for evidence of provision for students, too. The Buckinghamshire Adult Education site has made excellent efforts to attract rural would-be students with a course search engine, but it was just beaten into second place by the accomplished Southgate. This north London college offers staff and students webspace, a chat room and message boards as well as admissions information. It was also one of the few to provide a search engine.

Sheffield College's directory of almost 2,000 hand-picked links - recommended and reviewed by staff and students - carried off the Teachers' Award. Updated almost daily, it loads quickly, is easy to search and shows Sheffield's commitment to sharing knowledge across the curriculum.

Links directories are an excellent beginning for any online FE resource. Next year, it is to be hoped that teaching resources, shared advice and real cooperation with other institutions will all feature widely. Do it now - before a rival college steals your thunder.

 Ros Taylor

 Guardian journalists Ros Taylor, Colin Hughes and Richard Doughty were on the awards judging panel.

fields.headline: Why are these women smiling?
fields.standfirst: Simple: new research suggests lesbians like them earn more than straight women.  Anita Chaudhuri reports
fields.trailText: Simple: new research suggests lesbians like them earn more than straight women.  Anita Chaudhuri reports
fields.body:
Later this month, the BBC will screen Rhona, the first ever lesbian sitcom, starring the irrepressible Scottish comedian Rhona Cameron. It has taken her four years to get the project off the ground and only now has the Beeb had the nerve to agree the time may finally be right.

You can't blame them for feeling jittery. After all, look what happened to Ellen, the American sitcom that infamously pulverised its own ratings by allowing the star, Ellen DeGeneres, to come out as a lesbian mid-series. She has never repeated her earlier success, though her girlfriend, Anne Heche, has become a huge star in the wake of the furore.

But it looks as though the Beeb has little to worry about. For a start, Cameron claims Rhona is not a gay sitcom. "Sure, it informs who she is, but it is not the point of the show. Ellen was a show that gradually built up to her 'coming out', while Rhona is about a woman who just happens to be gay." Just to make sure we've got the message, she cites her main influences as Rhoda and Seinfeld, carefully avoiding any reference to Queer As Folk, the series that must surely have paved the way for her show getting the green light.

In any case, how gay the series turns out to be is hardly of much consequence; in fact, in many ways, the gayer it is, the higher the ratings may turn out to be. Lesbians are chic, everyone knows this, even this week's National Enquirer, with its Hollywood Lesbians Special. The big question is why? Is it to do with an enlightened sexual consciousness or a global breaking down of taboos? Maybe - but there's another, more significant reason. It's one we should have suspected all along, from the moment Vogue cheerfully endorsed the joys of "bi-try" and from recent snaps of newly-minted Sapphic superstars Drew Barrymore and Liv Tyler coyly puckering up together.

The real reason has been unearthed by the University of Maryland in America. It pays to be gay - particularly if you're a top-ranking star in the film or entertainment industry. A study of 100 top female stars reveals that gay women earn on average $7.9m while other stars take home a mere $6m. Perhaps this is the reason why actors such as Angelina Jolie are currently flirting with lesbianism - never mind that they're married: they know it will capture the stunted imaginations of male studio executives. Brooke Shields recently posed for US gay magazine Advocate, saying she expected to marry again but in the meantime "found women very attractive". Laura Dern was photographed kissing fellow actor Amy Yasbeck and her act was applauded by singer Melissa Etheridge.

So is going gay a good career move? Actor Sophie Ward, who came out as lesbian four years ago, laughs wryly at the suggestion. "After I came out, I certainly noticed that people were a bit wary of casting me, particularly for television parts. I think there was a feeling that I wasn't safe. Even now, I get the impression with some of the more commercial roles I'm up for that they still think I'm a bit risky. But it's very hard to tell if you don't get a job just because of your sexuality. Luckily most people in the business are strong-minded and don't get swayed by it, but I think it will take time for people to relax about me."

She points out that there may be one reason why lesbians earn more money, although there are no statistics to back this up in the UK: "You have to fight very hard to get where you are as a lesbian in this business. You have to be even more assertive and I think that might be reflected in how much you ask to be paid."

Jess Search, deputy commissioning editor for independent film and video at Channel 4, believes there's a mystique about being a lesbian that may reflect in success and earning power, particularly in creative arts and the media. "It's nothing new that a male audience will find a good-looking girl more interesting if they know she's a lesbian. In general, gay women used to be seen as subcultural, something that went on behind closed doors. Now we're no longer in the ghetto, we're more socially acceptable. Men find lesbians sexy, it creates a buzz around you."

Rhona Cameron, though, is not a typical example. "Most lesbians, especially those in the public eye, suffer from Navratilova syndrome," Search says, "where you can risk coming out only when you're at the top of your game. Then you can afford to do it. That may be the reason why the women surveyed in America were seen to be earning at high levels."

Madeleine Sheahan, a lesbian and business affairs executive with a TV company, believes gay women are not usually fantasy figures. "Most lesbians live smaller, more ordinary lives than anyone else. Men aren't really interested in us, unless there's a prospect that they might get sexually involved with two women. Otherwise it's boring to them. They tend to think women who end up with women do that because they are somehow disappointed in love or, worse, can't get anyone else. That's why they love Anne Heche - she defies all that. In reality, though, most lesbians aren't like that and they are not advantaged by their sexuality."

The University of Maryland study also examined the earning power of women employed in all sectors and found that lesbians in their mid-40s earned a third more than their straight counterparts. Seth Sanders, the economics professor who led the research, asserts that the reason for this imbalance is that lesbians will have known from an early age that they will have to be economically self-sufficient and also that they will not have children.

"This is absolute rubbish," counters Jo Monroe, a lesbian who runs a website for the television industry. "Many, many lesbians I know have children and many of them were married and had kids before they were confident enough to come out. Also, the childless lesbians I know tend to conform to the stereotype of being social workers or teachers, earning £20,000 per year. It's true that there are women like me who have set up our own businesses but that doesn't mean just because we're lesbians we're somehow going to be earning loads of money."

Jocelyn Watson is the lesbian caseworker for employment at the Lesbian and Gay Alliance, which provides help and advice for the gay and lesbian community. She claims she takes calls from women experiencing discrimination difficulties over parity of pay in many different sectors, including the film and TV industries. "I would strongly refute that the earning power of lesbians in this country is higher than that of their colleagues. Women are discriminated against across the pay scales and opportunities are limited. There's still a problem for women to be out and open with their sexuality. It may be fine for Hollywood stars and women in America for whom there are lots of opportunities, but here the big issue for lesbians is how they are going to get a job in the first place."

webTitle: Hague forced into u-turn on guarantee to cut taxes

fields.headline: Hague forced into u-turn on guarantee to cut taxes
fields.trailText:
William Hague last night embarked on the biggest u-turn of his career when he bowed to intense
 pressure and abandoned his flagship guarantee to cut taxes, regardless of the state of the economy.
fields.body:
William Hague last night embarked on the biggest u-turn of his career when he bowed to intense pressure and abandoned his flagship guarantee to cut taxes, regardless of the state of the economy.

In a humiliating climbdown forced on him by the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, Mr Hague pledged that a Tory government would place spending on health and education above his ' tax guarantee'.

The dramatic u-turn by the Tory leader was seized on by the government as a sign of weak leadership in the face of relentless criticism of Mr Hague's pledge to cut taxes even if the economy enters a recession. It will also be seen as a victory for Mr Portillo who has already forced Mr Hague to reverse Tory opposition to the minimum wage and Bank of England independence.

Mr Hague did not mince his words as he announced the abolition of the central plank of his common sense revolution - launched amid great fanfare at last year's party conference - in which he pledged that 'taxes will fall as a share of the nation's income'.

In an interview with the Daily Telegraph, Mr Hague said: 'We are being clear - in the event of severe recession, unexpected acts of God or war that our commitments to health, our commitment to prudent economic management will come first. People can be assured that our commitment to reduce taxation does not over-ride prudent economic management or our vital public services.'

Ministers reacted with glee last night to Mr Hague's u-turn, describing it as a significant victory for Tony Blair. At their weekly Commons clashes, the prime minister regularly taunts Mr Hague over his tax guarantee, saying that the Tory leader would never be able to match Labour spending on health and education because of his commitment to cut taxes.

But the u-turn was also being seen last night as a significant boost to Mr Portillo, who cast doubt over the tax policy as soon as he was appointed shadow chancellor his year. Mr Portillo told Mr Hague that the Tories had made themselves vulnerable to Labour attacks by guaranteeing key public spending while pledging to cut taxes.

Mr Hague's camp initially tried to hold the line on the tax guarantee, saying that they could match Labour's spending on health and education by cutting £4 billion from the welfare budget and from government bureaucracy and regulation. But the policy began to look vulnerable in recent weeks when Mr Hague attempted to regain some of the political centre ground with pledges that health and education would be safe in Tory hands.

The Tories' opponents last night rounded on Mr Hague. Andrew Smith, the chief secretary to the Treasury, said: 'You could not believe what the Tories said on tax in government. Now you cannot believe what they say in opposition. Their sums do not add up and people will never trust them again on tax.'

Matthew Taylor, the Liberal Democrat treasury spokesman, said: 'First we had soft Hague, followed by hard Hague. Now we have can't add up Hague. The tax guarantee was undeliverable and went to the heart of the contradictions in the Tory position. They want to talk about the tax cuts but they know that the electorate do not want public service cuts that go with that.'

A host of senior Tories, who dismissed the tax guarantee as a hostage to fortune, will feel vindicated by Mr Hague's u-turn. John Major described the idea as 'mad', adding: 'How do you deliver that in a recession? You don't. You simply don't unless you make swingeing cuts in the health service and education and the armed forces as are inconceivable.'

fields.headline: Moving with the times
fields.standfirst: Different skills are now needed and universities must recognise it
fields.trailText: Different skills are now needed and universities must recognise it
fields.body:
If top universities are serious about wanting to take a higher proportion of their students from state comprehensives, they could start by making clear that they will regard the new vocational A level just as highly as A levels.

A new survey from the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS) shows there is still a class barrier between A levels and the advanced general national vocational qualifications (GNVQs), even though they are supposed to be the same standard. As the education secretary, David Blunkett, said recently: "The key task is to raise the status, attractiveness and effectiveness of work-based learning and vocational education."

But the class barrier is set to continue even after GNVQs are renamed vocational A levels in September to get them accepted as the equal of A level. The survey reveals that next year, combined A level and vocational A-level programmes will be offered in eight out of 10 comprehensive schools and colleges of further education. But they will only be offered in one in five grammar schools and one in 10 fee-charging schools.

Fee-charging schools, which educate 7% of the population, provide about half the undergraduates at what the league tables say are Britain's top five universities. The most prestigious want A levels and look down on vocational qualifications.

The admissions service is trying to smooth the path to acceptance of the vocational A levels. Next year, it will scrap its system of A-level points scores and bring in a system which allocates points, not just for A levels, but for vocational A levels, GNVQs, Scottish qualifications, the new key skills certificate courses and the new advanced subsidiary (AS) levels. The system will come into effect for students applying to start courses in 2002. But universities can bring it in next year.

"Only about half the people applying to higher education through UCAS now have A levels," says chief executive Tony Higgins. "Until now there has been no way for admissions officers to compare different qualifications."

Dr Higgins does not expect universities to simply start counting points. But the two qualifications have been coming together for some years. The idea that A levels are more rigorous than GNVQs has been getting harder to sustain every year. GNVQs were considered inferior because they were modular, while A levels consisted of one course leading to an exam. But most A levels have become modular.

A mix of A levels and vocational qualifications will provide a broader course, enabling students to cross the supposed chasm between academic and vocational study. They will emerge better educated than those whose study was confined to traditional A levels.

The less prestigious institutions are leading the way in accepting vocational A levels, while the older universities have responded cautiously. Cambridge welcomes the broader curriculum, but has not guaranteed it will take vocational A levels as seriously. Oxford only promises flexibility. But University College, London expects offers to be based on three A levels and a pass in a fourth subject at AS or the equivalent GNVQ.

One joke is that GNVQ stands for generally not very qualified, but Ruth Silver, the principal of Lewisham College in south London, says universities will ignore the changes at their peril. "They must learn to value difference. Some schools are sticking to the old rules, hoping to win by doing the minimum but doing it well. They may win but it will be a short-term victory."

webTitle: Hoey whines, Harris pines and Sutton signs

fields.headline: Hoey whines, Harris pines and Sutton signs
fields.trailText: INVOLVED? US?
fields.body:
INVOLVED? US?

You can say what you like about New Labour, but you can't accuse them of desperately distancing themselves from things which go wrong just to save face. So imagine the Fiver's surprise when minister of sport Kate Hoey had a right pop at the way England's useless old 2006 World Cup bid was run. You know, that's the bid Tony Blair backed by having Sepp Blatter round for tea. (Blair's the bloke who rang Charles Dempsey before last week's vote to thank him for his support, by the way.)

"What I am calling for is that this is the last time that we have a World Cup bid handled in this way," said Hoey today as everyone admired her lovely clean hands. "As I travelled around Europe and spoke to sports ministers, it became clear that the gentleman's agreement with Germany, which we went back on, had upset a lot of people. We never had a chance of winning, but people kept writing and saying that we did and swallowed the words of Alec McGivan as if he was some kind of God."

Harsh words, and ones which stunned poor Allah McGivan. The creator supreme of the bid found the hoo-hah caused by Hoey "puzzling, bearing in mind how much enthusiastic government support we had for England's bid from the prime minister and senior ministers". All this is certainly something little William Hague and his chums could have a field day with - if they hadn't set the whole process off themselves in the first place, that is.

HARE AND HOUNDS

Scamper, scamper, scamper! Harry "the hare" Harris here. Yesterday I just managed to evade the slobbering jaws of the Sun's Brian Bouffant by exclusively revealing Internazionale's £31m bid for Paul Scholes. Phew, eh! But you left me facing the spiked trap of Manchester United chairman Martin Edwards, who claims there's been no contact with Inter. Oh, if only there was some way to leap over his bear pit of denial!

"Yes it is true. The story is correct. We are very much interested in signing Paul Scholes." Thank you, Internazionale president Massimo Moratti, for saving my hare bacon. But wait! I can still smell cheap hair lacquer in the vicinity... I desperately need another world exclusive to keep ahead of the pack.

Phew again! My Italian sources have just told me that AC Milan have announced they will soon spend £40m on one of the world's top five players. You want the names, right? OK then, how does David Beckham, Luis Figo, Rivaldo, Francesco Totti and, er, Filippo Inzaghi sound? Impressive, that's how! And at last I'm safe from those hounding hacks!

Hang on a second... where's that cyber-growl coming from? It's not the tenacious Planet Football is it? Oh no, it is! And they're claiming that Parma striker Hernan Crespo has completed his transfer to Lazio in a deal involving £13m, Mattias Almeyda and Sergio Conceicao. Crumbs! And they're also reporting that West Ham are in talks with Australian international defender Hayden Foxe over a possible free transfer. Oh, will I ever be free of these accursed predators? Pant, pant, pant...

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I have conceded a goal. Now it is up to me to equalise and score a winner" - Sepp Blatter, calling for Fifa to ratify an agreement which would ensure all six regional confederations take their turn to host the World Cup, lightens things up with a crazy analogy. We preferred him when he was boring.

MAKING THE RIGHT SOUNDS

Chris Sutton today finalised his £6m transfer from Chelsea to Celtic to become Scotland's record signing. This one's been on the cards for a while, so to some it may warrant no more than a shrug of the shoulders (unless you're Bryan Robson, in which case you'll be spitting feathers). But the Fiver, for one, is well excited, because it's the first major transfer since we picked up this patented K-Tel Obsequious-o-meter from the local car boot. We've been itching to give it a go - let's just get it out of the box...

"I am delighted to have signed for Celtic," said Sutton, who will join up with his new colleagues in Denmark ahead of Chelsea's friendly against FC Copenhagen tomorrow night, "and very much look forward to playing in front of such a massive, passionate and knowledgeable support." Hmm, the meter's just gone past 'fans onside' and into the 'predictably sycophantic' section.

"Celtic's history and tradition are well known to me and I consider myself very privileged to have the opportunity to play for such a fantastic club." That one's well up the scale... let's see... 'unpleasant toadying'.

"As soon I spoke to Martin O'Neill," he concluded, "I knew that I wanted to be involved with a club of Celtic's standing and I am excited about the prospect of playing alongside quality players." Hold on, the needle has sailed clean through 'stunningly unctuous' and gone right off the meter! Wow, this thing's accurate.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Everton are interested in Hamburg's Danish international Thomas Gravesen and have offered goalkeeper Thomas Myhre in part-exchange.

Fulham boss Jean Tigana has launched a £3m bid for Julian Joachim.

Teamtalk suggests Leeds may consider making a bid for Arsenal's Ray Parlour.

Emile Mpenza has put an end to speculation about his future by saying he will stay at FC Schalke.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Fifa have banned Harare's national stadium from staging international games for an indefinite period following the deaths of 13 people in a stampede at the venue on Sunday.

Manchester United have agreed to sell Massimo Taibi to Reggina for £2.5m.

Czech international goalkeeper Pavel Srnicek has signed for Brescia on a free transfer from Sheffield Wednesday.

Charlton keeper Simon Royce has completed a free transfer to Leicester.

Everton have confirmed that Ghana international Alex Nyarko will fly to Merseyside before the end of the week to discuss terms over a possible £4.5m move from French club Lens.

North and South Korean officials will meet Fifa chief Sepp Blatter during September's Sydney Olympics to discuss the possibility of co-hosting matches during the 2002 World Cup.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: World Football Show (6.30pm)

Sepp Blatter and Charles Dempsey don bowler hats and brown overcoats for their remake of the comedy classic The Plank.

Schoolboy Football Live (7pm, 12midnight)

England v Thailand. For the love of Allah McGivan, just accept the football season is over and find something else to watch or do.

webTitle: Loyalists form road blocks as violence continues

fields.headline: Loyalists form road blocks as violence continues
fields.trailText: Loyalists attempted to block roads across Northern Ireland today as Drumcree Orangemen continued protesting against being barred from marching down the mainly nationalist Garvaghy Road in Portadown.
fields.body:
Loyalists attempted to block roads across Northern Ireland today as Drumcree Orangemen continued protesting against being barred from marching down the mainly nationalist Garvaghy Road in Portadown.

Police said today's protests on roads in Belfast, Ballymoney, Kilrea, Coleraine, Portadown, Downpatrick and Lisburn had been peaceful. But many believed that a repeat of last night's violence, which saw security forces fired at, cars hijacked and set alight and property attacked, was inevitable.

Chief superintendent Brian McCargo, who was on central command duty last night, said: "Anyone in the present circumstances, particularly during Drumcree week, who brings these people out on to the road by way of peaceful protest are bound to realise that it is going to degenerate into disorder in some areas because they're just bringing thugs out on to the road."

He also rejected accusations from the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, among others, that security forces were not doing enough to stem the trouble.

Mr McCargo said that officers were engaged in a "fine balancing act" of allowing peaceful protest and enforcing the law without further aggravating circumstances.

"The people of this province can rest assured that we will be looking for these people who have been disrupting traffic and burning vehicles and burning shops," he said.

The Royal Ulster Constabulary today revealed that there have been 280 attacks on security forces since July 1. They include 288 petrol bombing incidents and 13 shooting incidents. A total of 57 RUC officers and five soldiers have been injured, with 77 homes, 55 commercial premises and 358 vehicles damaged. There have been 146 arrests with 72 people charged.

Two councillors told today how they were halted and threatened at the loyalist roadblocks. Oran Keenan said he had been stopped, surrounded and threatened in Antrim town while independent unionist Andrew Davidson said youths had leaped on to his car after he tried to move through a blockade on the outskirts of Londonderry.

" It's what you might call a hooligan element being stirred up, Mr Davidson said. "I don't give it credence as a political movement of any sort."

Dawson Baillie, the Orange county grand master for Belfast, said that the blame for the trouble lay with Tony Blair and the parades commission - the body which rules on disputed parades.

He claimed that commission rulings which restricted parades because of the danger of public disorder sent out the message that the threat of trouble could win.

Tomorrow Mr Baillie plans to lead thousands of Orangemen gathering in Belfast for the main July 12 demonstrations. They are to march to Ormeau Park, in the south of the city, beside the bridge at which members of the Ballynafeigh lodge will be blocked from entering the mainly nationalist Lower Ormeau Road.

webTitle: Nick  Park and Peter Lord live on our talkboards

fields.headline: Nick  Park and Peter Lord live on our talkboards
fields.standfirst: Click here to join the discussion.
fields.trailText: The Aardman Animations duo behind the hugely successful Chicken Run will be live on Thursday 13 July at 5.15pm to answer your questions. Nick Park and Peter Lord honed their classic line in claymation on the cherished Creature Comforts, the Oscar-winning Wallace and Gromit and (for those of you with longer memories) Morph.
fields.body:
The Aardman Animations duo behind the hugely successful Chicken Run will be live on Thursday 13 July at 5.15pm to answer your questions. Nick Park and Peter Lord honed their classic line in claymation on the cherished Creature Comforts, the Oscar-winning Wallace and Gromit and (for those of you with longer memories) Morph.

A poultry-themed Great Escape, Chicken Run is the first fruit of a £155m five-movie deal with Spielberg's DreamWorks studio and has opened to glowing reviews and hefty business on both sides of the Atlantic. Can Park and Lord maintain such an extraordinary rate of success (to date, they've collected three Oscars and three Baftas)?

So whether you want to know 'why chickens?', ask how they persuaded Mel Gibson to play a rooster, or see if you twigged all the film references in Chicken Run, post your questions now, and log on this Thursday afternoon to join in the chat.

You need to be a registered user to view or join our discussions. Registering will take a couple of minutes, and your details are strictly confidential and accessible only by Guardian Unlimited.

Follow this link to register. Once you have registered we will email you a link which enables you to participate in our talkboard discussions.

If you are already a registered user, click here to join the discussion.

Can Park and Lord maintain such an extraordinary rate of success (to date, they've collected three Oscars and three Baftas)? So whether you want to know 'why chickens?', ask how they persuaded Mel Gibson to play a rooster, or see if you twigged all the film references in Chicken Run, post your questions now, and log on this Thursday afternoon to join in the chat.
