fields.headline: The Tour de France
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the world's most gruelling sporting spectacle
fields.trailText: 1. The Tour de France is a bicycle race, in the same sense that a Rolls Royce is a saloon car. It's the Big One: an astounding test of endurance, strength and nerve, as more than 180 men in a score of teams hurl themselves at the gruelling course.
fields.body:
1. The Tour de France is a bicycle race, in the same sense that a Rolls Royce is a saloon car. It's the Big One: an astounding test of endurance, strength and nerve, as more than 180 men in a score of teams hurl themselves at the gruelling course.

2. This year's race will cover 3630km in three weeks. The current leader is last year's winner, America's Lance Armstrong. He captured the coveted yellow jersey, in lousy weather, with an astounding performance described in the Guardian as "almost supernatural". Armstrong would not recognise the description, being supremely confident in his own ability.

3. Today's eleventh stage covers nearly 200 kilometres and no fewer than six mountains. But that is merely a taster for Thursday's action, when the riders will set out from Carpentras to tackle the ferocious Mont Ventoux. This rarely-raced stage is, literally, a killer: in 1967 Britain's Tommy Simpson made it to the summit in scorching heat, fell from his machine, and died on the spot.

4. The Tour de France has taken place every year since 1903, with breaks for the first and second world wars. Past winners include the greatest names in the sport.

5. Four men hold the joint record for winning the race five times each: Jacques Anqetil and Bernard Hinault of France, Eddy Merckx of Belgium, and most recently Miguel Indurain- Big Mig to his fans - who won an unprecedented five times on the trot, from 1991.

6. Merckx is the only rider ever to have won all three jerseys in the same year: the yellow for overall winner, the green for points winner, and the red polka dot for King of the Mountains.

7. Britain's perennial hopeful is Chris Boardman, former Olympic track champion. But he is ill this year and not taking part. Leading Brit this year is David Millar, who actually won the first stage and wore the yellow jersey for two days. Ten days on, he is lying 32nd, and is not expected to be among the contenders when the Tour ends in Paris.

8. At least a million people will line the route of the race, and around a billion will watch it on television. British fans frustrated by Channel 4's minimal early-hours coverage can follow the Tour live on the internet, read the daily diaries of riders, and hear the stage winners interviewed. As with all popular sports, the net also spews forth statistics in numbing quantity, and a wealth of entertaining anecdotes.

9. The technology of race coverage is almost as amazing as the technology of the lightweight racing bicycles.

10. Though the doping scandals of recent years are receding, three riders have already been sent home for failing mandatory drugs tests.

webTitle: Can Clinton do a Carter at Camp David?

fields.headline: Can Clinton do a Carter at Camp David?
fields.standfirst: As the Israeli-Palestinian summit gets under way in the US, Middle East editor Brian Whitaker wonders if the same venue that brokered an historic deal 22 years ago can work its magic a second time around
fields.trailText: As the Israeli-Palestinian summit gets under way in the US, Middle East editor Brian Whitaker wonders if the same venue that brokered an historic deal 22 years ago can work its magic a second time around
fields.body:
President Clinton's choice of venue for the Israeli-Palestinian summit deliberately evokes memories of the Camp David meeting 22 years ago when President Jimmy Carter met Israel's prime minister, Menachem Begin, and the Egyptian president, Anwar al-Sadat.

Although the result then was an historic deal, there were times during the 13 days of talks when disaster seemed imminent. Despite the gloom at the start of the current talks, there are hopes that the atmosphere of the presidential country retreat in Maryland may yet work its magic.

The isolation of Camp David (mobile phones are banned) and the laid-back atmosphere (chess games, bicycle rides and, in 1978, a visit to the Gettysburg battlefield) are intended to help shift negotiators from entrenched positions. And it can work.

At one point during the 1978 talks, Begin declared: "My right eye will fall out, my right hand will fall off before I ever agree to the dismantling of a single Jewish settlement." But he agreed to it in the end, nevertheless.

The Israeli general, Moshe Dayan, later recalled that the differences at the start were "abundant, wide and basic". All three parties, he said, "had to resolve agonising psychological and ideological crises."

"It meant abandoning long-held traditional viewpoints and outlooks and taking up new positionsThere were times when only by clenching teeth and fists could I stop myself from exploding."

Mr Barak, still reeling from his narrow no-confidence vote victory in the Knesset Israeli parliament, may recall how his predecessor returned to Israel 22 years ago with a deal in his pocket, to be greeted by demonstrators waving rolled-up umbrellas and shouting "Chamberlain!".

In 1978 Begin adopted a robust position after Camp David, refusing to meet his own party and ignoring the Knesset foreign affairs and defense committee. After brow-beating his cabinet for seven hours, he swung them round by 11 votes to two, with one abstention. It was a similar story in the Knesset, where a 17-hour debate brought him a massive victory.

Mr Barak's domestic problems have overshadowed those of Mr Arafat, which are no less severe. The Palestinian riots last May were a foretaste of what might happen if he makes too many concessions.

One effect of the Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon has been to raise expectations among the Palestinians - and Arabs generally - of what might be achieved with more effective resistance. People ask: If the Israelis can withdraw completely from Lebanon, why not from occupied Palestine?

Whatever the justice of the argument, Mr Afarat's negotiating position is relatively weak, though the continuing Arab boycott of Israel is an important factor on his side. If there is a fair deal at Camp David, normalisation between Israel and the Arab world - which Israel badly wants - will quickly follow. If not, the Israelis may have a long wait.

Clinton's negotiating skills - over Israeli settlements, the status of Jerusalem, the refugees and more mundane matters such as water - will inevitably be compared with those of Jimmy Carter, the last Democrat in the White House before him.

Zbigniew Brzezinski, who was Carter's national security adviser, said last week: "Clinton is a very intelligent and able guy, extremely persuasive. But whether he is capable of seriously threatening, I don't know. And that's very important."

Carter certainly threatened both Sadat and Begin. During the 1978 talks he warned Sadat of dire consequences for relations with the US if the Egyptians pulled out, and accused Begin of throwing away a promising peace just to keep "a few illegal settlers on Egyptian land".

Despite his harsh words, Carter was perceived as even-handed. But today Palestinians complain that the Clinton administration is far more sympathetic towards the Israelis. Some even suggest it would be better wait for a change of president. Clinton's ability to threaten either side is limited by the fact that he will be out of office in six months and so has little time to carry out any threats.

The 1978 summit dragged on for almost two weeks, but this time it will be shorter. Clinton has said he intends to leave Washington on July 18 or 19 for the G8 meeting in Japan. Brzezinski recalled that little preparatory work had been done for Camp David I. "The differences not only had to be narrowed, but the end game had to be played at the same time," he said. This time, after months of preliminary discussions, the negotiators will move quickly to the end game. "In that sense, it makes it easier,'' Brzezinski said.

This pre-supposes that Clinton's aides, in their months of preliminary meetings, have judged the Israeli and Palestinian bottom lines correctly and have some solutions to offer. With so much at stake for Clinton, the Americans almost certainly have a workable plan - though there was no sign of that at Clinton's disastrous summit with the late President Hafez al-Assad of Syria earlier this year.

Almost certainly the Americans will try to lubricate the talks with money - billions of it. There will be offers of aid for the Palestinian state, and probably even larger amounts to keep the Israelis happy with their security. If the refugee problem is to be solved, compensation will play an important part.

One Israeli argument for retaining occupied land - especially in the Jordan valley - is security. American military expertise, and perhaps technology, could be called upon to allay these fears and remove the justification for keeping the land. But old-fashioned dictionaries - in Hebrew and Arabic as well as English - may also play a part. The original Camp David Accords were deliberately ambiguous in parts, in order to secure agreement. Although only the English version was binding, Begin was given a Hebrew version which obscured some of his concessions.

This time, "sovereignty" and "control" are likely to be key words, especially in connection with Jerusalem and the West Bank. It is likely there will be attempts to resolve some of the intractable territorial issues through leasing arrangements in which one side has sovereignty but the other gains rights of use under clearly-defined conditions.

The 1978 summit was hailed as a success even though it produced a framework for peace, rather than a full agreement. This time, with all sides reluctant to accept a deal which avoids confronting the thorniest and most frequently postponed issues, it looks like all or nothing.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst:
All today's rumours chopped and diced, and finished off with a drizzle of olive oil
Spurs land Thatcher in £5m deal
fields.trailText: Leeds have been linked with a move for Ray Parlour, reports Teamtalk. Yeah, yeah, we think, but they have evidence. Well, sort of. "The story is based on the new arrivals at Arsenal and that Parlour may find it harder to get into the first team for the coming season. Coupled with that is the connection with David O'Leary," they claim.
fields.body:
Leeds have been linked with a move for Ray Parlour, reports Teamtalk. Yeah, yeah, we think, but they have evidence. Well, sort of. "The story is based on the new arrivals at Arsenal and that Parlour may find it harder to get into the first team for the coming season. Coupled with that is the connection with David O'Leary," they claim.

However, yesterday's Harry Harris's exclusive - "Paul Scholes to Internazionale in £31m world record-equalling deal" - is rooted in fact. In today's Mirror, Inter president Massimo Morratti confirms: "Yes, it is true. The story is correct. We are very much interested in signing Paul Scholes." There is a catch, though. "Unfortunately for us it appears Manchester United are not prepared to release Scholes at the moment," he says. "It is going to be very hard for us to get him."

Aston Villa on the verge of an amazing double summer swoop by signing David Ginola and persuading Benito Carbone to return, according to the Mirror. Villa manager John Gregory said: "I'm confident about bringing Ginola to Villa Park. He's still coming to terms about not being wanted by Spurs. That's affected him more than anything and held things up." But news of Carbone is less clear. "I'm optimistic about bringing him back to Villa, and will be phoning him later this week," says Gregory.

Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson will make a £6.5m offer for Neil Lennon, reports the Mirror. Lennon is due to have talks at the Riverside this week, and Boro will offer him £30,000 a week.

Lorenzo Amoruso will join Sunderland for £3m if they agree to his £20,000 a-week pay demands. The Rangers defender said: "If Sunderland step towards what I want it should be much easier for me to make up my mind."

Fulham boss Jean Tigana has launched a £3m bid for Julian Joachim. But he may have to double his offer because John Gregory has reportedly slapped a £6m price tag on the want-away striker. Well, if it's what Chris Sutton's worth

Everton are favourites to sign Ghanian midfielder Alex Nyarko from Lens for £4.5m - despite interest from Sunderland and Aston Villa. The 26 year-old Nyarko is highly recommended by his former Lens teammate Olivier Dacourt, who says: "If you get the chance to sign him then do. He is a better player than me."

Another player high on Walter Smith's wanted list is Sheffield Wednesday's Niclas Alexandersson, and a deal could be completed this week.

webTitle: It was our hot air that inflated Blair's balloon

fields.headline: It was our hot air that inflated Blair's balloon
fields.standfirst:
The great expectations we had for New Labour were always illusory
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: New Labour always was a huge balloon of inflated expectations. We forget that essential part of the history that started on May 1 1997. The hot air pumped into it was our own. That's the oxygen of democracy. We want to believe that politics will produce wonderful results.
fields.body:
New Labour always was a huge balloon of inflated expectations. We forget that essential part of the history that started on May 1 1997. The hot air pumped into it was our own. That's the oxygen of democracy. We want to believe that politics will produce wonderful results. Looking at the Blair government now, you don't see the dirigible crashing to the ground. It is still quite airworthy. But much of the promise - our own passion to believe - has been exhaled. The government turns out to be an imperfect, struggling enterprise. It straddles the public instinct for cynicism as against optimism, for realism against aspiration. It has become a normal government.

At the start, ridiculous expectations were understandable. The feeling of optimism was backed by certain facts. One party had been in power for 18 years. It was thrown out with exaltation. The country showed two fingers to Thatcher-Major, as was said in this space the day after the election. New Labour and Tony Blair would carry all before them. Whatever they did would improve on the recent past, but the optimism was greater than that. The election spoke to a common belief that all problems had solutions, and the right people would now find them.

Mr Blair experienced this feeling, was aware that he personified it. Why act, and why vote, unless for something big? Actually he was cautious, promising no change for two years in the money spent on the things that mattered. But this was explained, and tolerated, as serious politics. While Blair has never had the media allegiance Mrs Thatcher enjoyed for her unpopular crusades, he was understood to be starting something that was new. It was to be revival- therapy for the nation. When he talked about fresh starts and new eras, and the erasing of important aspects of history, his hyperbole exceeded the cliches that normally attend such moments, but was forgiven because, to an extent not seen for two decades, people wanted it to be true.

The other big fact was the size of the majority: 179. The contrast with Major could not have been larger. Whatever else Blair turned out to be, he would certainly be strong. He wouldn't be battered by his backbenchers. New Labour could do what it had told us it wanted. A new mandate, uniquely huge, would see off all enemies.

And this is what started to happen. The government did do important things. It changed the constitution. It began to reform public services. It had no political trouble of the kind the country had grown used to over the last five Tory years. Its leader was a maestro of popular opinion, conducting it from the centre according to the score he had written. The other side became a voice unheard. The marginalisation of the Tories, which the nation had apparently decided on that May Day, duly occurred. The demand for two years of patience was agreed.

In fact, though, the uniqueness had its limitations. Though the parliamentary effect was sweeping, the vote was not a national statement that exempted Blair from normal politics. Half a million fewer people voted for him than gave Major his hair's-breadth victory in 1992. The accidents of the voting system produced the illusion of a landslide. Time, it became clear, would not produce a landslide of gratitude for New Labour solutions after all. For the most part, time has only made clearer the scale of the difficulties. Having ridden in on such extraordinary expectations - part cultivated by them, part by us - ministers find they cannot meet them. The majority remains, but the politics of optimism are now resoundingly finished.

We see, instead, the intransigence of problems. No matter where you look, this tends to be true. The latest episode of Nick Davies's ground-breaking reportage on education at the bottom end reveals crises which are amenable only to imperfect social responses, whichever party is in power. Under Labour as under the Tories, crime figures continue to rise. Whoever is running the country, the NHS will remain a marvellous idea that never gets enough resources. And so on. It is not that New Labour has failed, but that problems are even half-soluble only by tenacity, drudgery and an appetite for extremely slow results. Not just Britain but every advanced country in the world harbours social malfunctions that are at odds with the triumphalist rhythm of politicians' rhetoric.

Facing another election, the two main British parties address this in their own ways, both of them out of sync with the public. The Labour way is to insist the balloon is not in any way deflated. Every problem must still have its answer. The impression of success must be sustained, whatever the evidence to the contrary. Where the problems are inextricably stubborn, such as over law and order, the solutions get more reckless. The prime minister goes abroad and suddenly promises to haul every drunken hooligan to a cash machine. Or he appoints Lord Birt, the ultimate miscast crony, as his personal brainstormer. Panic grips him. It is the panic of someone who fears being fatally punished for not making good on the mirage of May Day 1997.

The Conservatives take the opposite tack, towards the politics of total cynicism. It is understandable, indeed traditional. They smack the government for every failure. They want to prick the balloon and empty it. But their opportunism under Mr Hague is more than usually obvious. Their education policy, announced last week, is the latest example. It seizes on public discontent, but its own answers are insultingly defective: no credible costings, no consideration of the issues around selection, not a word addressed to the agenda which Nick Davies can hardly be said to have invented. That is the other side of the politics that began on that famous day when we gulled ourselves into thinking we had voted to change the world.

We now know different. It is the lesson of the deflated balloon. The public has the sense to see that many problems are intractably hard. There are no easy answers, perhaps no answers whatever, except palliatives. The flashier the response, the less trusted it rightly is. The further we get from 1997, the better we understand that the expectations which that election unleashed must be replaced by different virtues.

What the public wants is not excitement and instant promise, but competence and simple honesty. The government can't at present be relied on for either. Its frantic law-and-order thrashing about shows abject incompetence. Its playing around with figures, trying to make the right impression come what may, means that next week's public spending review risks being greeted with an incredulous yawn. The high on which it started has shown us how little we should expect. But we can live with that. We are grown-ups. We can still be sure it will play an impossible hand better than the other lot.

fields.headline: Doomed to endure the dome
fields.standfirst:
They want to buy the Greenwich turkey. Now I've heard everything
The Millennium Dome: special report
fields.trailText: This is a historic moment because I do believe I have now finally heard  everything. A meeting was held yesterday at which the deputy prime minister and various cohorts were due to hear rival presentations for the future of the dome.
fields.body:
This is a historic moment because I do believe I have now finally heard everything. A meeting was held yesterday at which the deputy prime minister and various cohorts were due to hear rival presentations for the future of the dome. All expectations were that they would eventually agree to sell the whole thing to bidders whose magnificent concept is to leave the dome approximately as it is, with a few extra attractions: the New New Millennium Experience, perhaps.

Since this bid comes from the Japanese financiers Nomura, who are not known to be either charitable or idiotic, there must be a subtext that has not been mentioned. Possibly it helps them to say nice things about the dome to those ministers who authorised it all in the first place, before getting on with the real agenda. It is barely credible that anyone intends to pay to keep the current show running.

But there has of late been something of a fightback among the dome's supporters. Bob Ayling, the deposed chairman, last week called critics "pathetic", and complained that whenever anything went wrong with millennium projects, the coverage was always of the failures instead of celebrating "how great these things are for London". (Absolutely: the bridge is great too - how foolish we were to try to walk on it.) P-Y Gerbeau, the current dome chief executive, has now been quoted as saying that "Greenwich was not on the map before", which suggest his future is unlikely to include a chair in geography. His take, naturally, is that the dome was terrible until he arrived, but has now been turned around.

Even Time Out's critique now reads like a PR handout: "profound, provocative, engagingly human and funny marvellously entertaining only terminal cynics will find reason to sneer." The general implication is that, now that one or two teething troubles have been sorted, real people (not newspaper columnists) love it all.

Well, if Nomura really does keep it all going, maybe future generations will find out whether this is true or not. My suspicion is that no sensible operator would keep anything at all except some fragments just in case. After all, the most stylish car to own in America is the Ford Edsel, as famous in its day as a marketing calamity as the dome is now.

Let's get this straight: the dome, or at any rate what's in it, is an irredeemable turkey, which has no business whatever lasting even up to Christmas. I certainly don't urge people to boycott it - please go and make your own judgment: it is one of the most pleasingly uncluttered places for a stroll in London, though at £73.50 for a family of four it is a bit pricier than Hyde Park. What I believe you will find is an operation that is neither intellectually coherent nor even very good fun. In an age when you can simulate the take-off of a Boeing 747 on your own PC on software given away free, it is necessary to work a damn sight harder to entertain the public than was the case during the Great Exhibition or the Festival of Britain. But the average travelling funfair does far better than the dome; so do the excellent new hands-on science museums that have sprung up.

The Ford-sponsored travel zone tells us, in essence, that lots of people want to travel, and that makes things very difficult. It also says: "In 2025 Shanghai will have a popu" but then it's the end of the panel. The body zone, the biggest swizz of all, says nothing useful whatever.

The exhibits reek of committees and compromise, of sponsorship rather than invention. The house tone of voice is didactic, slightly hectoring, but not informative. Every opportunity is taken for a touchy-feely British Airways-ad style of video in which everyone hugs everyone else.

The pretentious centrepiece show is amazingly reminiscent of those silly opening ceremonies for major sporting events which Britain fails to win because the government gets those hopelessly wrong too. The whole enterprise at the dome is vapid, promising much, delivering little. You can use it as a giant metaphor for the entire Blair government, if you wish. But if Nomura wants it, this really is one amazing day.

 Matters arising: Alistair Richardson writes to agree that parliament should indeed move from Westminster, but suggests it no longer needs a site at all, but could exist purely as a cyberspace concept. Mike Rowland, meanwhile, proposes the Yorkshire town of Tadcaster as the new capital. In Mancunian days, there was a Guardian leader-writer's conceit that Tadcaster (famous for Sam Smith's bitter but difficult to locate) did not actually exist. Therefore these two ideas may be identical.

We will give the apostrophe a break now, I promise, but Mike Douse of Norwich saw the following sign outside a Helsinki restaurant: "Our cloudberry tarts taste just like your grannies".

Possibly it helps them to say nice things about the dome to those ministers who authorised it all in the first place, before getting on with the real agenda. It is barely credible that anyone intends to pay to keep the current show running. But there has of late been something of a fightback among the dome's supporters. Bob Ayling, the deposed chairman, last week called critics "pathetic", and complained that whenever anything went wrong with millennium projects, the coverage was always of the failures instead of celebrating "how great these things are for London". webTitle: S Africa doing nothing to halt Aids, HIV judge says

fields.headline: S Africa doing nothing to halt Aids, HIV judge says
fields.standfirst: UN Aids Programme
fields.trailText: A leading South African judge, who has revealed that he is HIV positive, berated President Thabo Mbeki yesterday for creating "disbelief", "confusion" and "consternation" by his controversial views on the causes of Aids.
fields.body:
A leading South African judge, who has revealed that he is HIV positive, berated President Thabo Mbeki yesterday for creating "disbelief", "confusion" and "consternation" by his controversial views on the causes of Aids.

Delivering a keynote lecture to the 13th international Aids conference in Durban, Edwin Cameron, a member of the high court in Johannesburg, condemned the president for his flirtation with those who claim that Aids is not caused by HIV, but by poverty.

"This has shaken almost everyone responsible for engaging the epidemic," he said. "It has created an air of unbelief amongst scientists, confusion amongst those at risk of HIV and consternation amongst Aids workers."

Judge Cameron has been widely lauded for his courage in publicly declaring his HIV status after the stoning to death of a young woman who admitted she had the virus.

He recalled the words of the African intellectual Mamphela Rampele, who described the government's official sanction for scepticism towards the cause of Aids as "irresponsibility that borders on criminality".

The judge continued: "If this aberrant and distressing interlude has delayed the implementation of life-saving measures to halt the spread of HIV and to curtail its effects, then history will not judge this comment excessive."

He referred to a speech last year in which the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, said that the response so far had failed Africa. That, said the judge, was seven months ago - more than 200 days, on each of which approximately 1,700 people in South Africa had become newly infected with HIV.

He castigated President Mbeki's government for failing to supply basic, affordable drugs to women in labour, to prevent them infecting their babies with HIV.

"Such a programme, if implemented, would have signalled our government's appreciation of the larger problem, and its resolve to address it. To the millions of South Africans living with HIV, it would have created a ray of light.

"To our shame, our country has not yet come so far as even to commit itself to implementing such a programme. The result, every month, is that 5,000 babies are born, unnecessarily and unavoidably, with HIV.

"Their lives involve preventable infections, preventable suffering, preventable deaths. And if none of that is persuasive, then from the point of view of the nation's self-interest, their HIV infections entail preventable expense. Yet we have done nothing."

Scientists and campaigners at the conference shared Judge Cameron's profound dismay at President Mbeki's failure to use his opening speech on Sunday to acknowledge that HIV causes Aids and must be tackled head-on with prevention campaigns and drug treatments.

They had hoped he would spearhead the battle to extract drugs from the pharmaceutical companies at prices low enough for the developing world to afford.

In seven countries in southern Africa, at least 20% of adults have HIV. In Botswana, which has the highest prevalence in the world, 35.8% of adults are now infected.

Hoosen Coovadia, the South African paediatrician chairing the conference, said: "There were great expectations that some of the disputes and the disquiet around the government's position on HIV/Aids and the dissidents and so on would be resolved and President Mbeki would employ the opportunity that was given to him to give a reappraisal of the position.

"People are now saying that they are really disappointed that it did not happen and instead we had another discussion about poverty which we already know is a fundamental problem in our society."

Roy Anderson, from the UNAids collaborating centre for epidemiological research at Oxford University, said: "I was disappointed, to put it bluntly. It was an opportunity to concentrate on the main task."

He said the growth of the global pandemic was particularly disturbing, given that we knew how HIV was spread.

There were different reasons for the failure to stem the tide, but some were common.

These included: "denial, a lack of political leadership, the failure to allocate sufficient resources to education and public health measures, poor educational attainment levels in the general population, low status of women in society and the failure of the richer countries of the world to allocate sufficient resources to education and public health measures."

There are 34.3m people with HIV infection - 24.5m in sub-Saharan Africa - but Prof Anderson predicted that the pandemic would get much worse.

· The Microsoft billionaire Bill Gates, his wife, and the pharmaceutical giant Merck announced yesterday that they would spend $100m in an attempt to contain the Aids epidemic in Botswana.

The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation pledged $50m over the next five years to Botswana's health system. Merck and Co, based in New Jersey, said it would match that donation by providing management for the project and anti-retroviral drugs.

Julian Borger, Washington

Is there really room for debate?

Who are these dissidents who say the HIV virus is not the cause of Aids?

There are quite a number of them now. The chief dissident, whose ideas are said to influence Thabo Mbeki, is Peter Duesberg, the professor of biochemistry and molecular biology at Berkeley, California.

What are the implications if HIV is not the cause of Aids?

Prof Duesberg says that Aids is not infectious. If that is so, there is no need for safe sex. There is also no need for drugs to prevent mothers transmitting HIV to their babies.

How is it possible for the dissidents to dispute the scientific evidence?

Prof Duesberg argues that there are people carrying the HIV virus who develop no symptoms of disease and that HIV has not been shown to induce Aids.

Is he right on either count?

Not according to the conventional scientists.They say that the simian immuno-deficiency virus (SIV), a close relative of HIV, has been proven to cause Aids in monkeys, even if the direct proof of HIV causing Aids is not yet available.

Does Prof Duesberg have other arguments?

Yes. He says HIV cannot be infectious, because viruses and bacteria work fast. HIV may not cause Aids for five to 10 years. International scientists say he is plain wrong.

The laboratory evidence for HIV causing Aids is clearly incomplete. What else do the scientists rely on?

The epidemiological evidence. In every country where Aids has appeared, says viral oncologist Robin Weiss, HIV has preceded it. "HIV is the singular common factor that is shared between Aids cases in gay men in San Francisco, well-nourished young women in Uganda, haemophiliacs in Japan and children in Romanian orphanages," he wrote in a demolition of the Duesberg hypothesis in Nature magazine, 10 years ago.

But the African epidemic is different from the western version. Is this the same disease?

The dissidents say no, but the conventional scientists say the only difference is in sub-type. The strain that afflicts the west is not the same as that in Africa, which is why vaccines developed for the US will not work in Botswana or Zambia where they are needed much more.

Sarah Boseley

webTitle: 11 July: In brief, and the latest casting news

fields.headline: 11 July: In brief, and the latest casting news
fields.standfirst: The Paltrows agree to family entertainment, Chelsea Clinton has stars in her eyes, Christopher Lee will play 'charismatic separatist' in Star Wars II, news on the next Talented Mr Ripley, and on the casting couch, Matt LeBlanc, Harvey Keitel and Steve Buscemi
fields.trailText: The Paltrows agree to family entertainment, Chelsea Clinton has stars in her eyes, Christopher Lee will play 'charismatic separatist' in Star Wars II, news on the next Talented Mr Ripley, and on the casting couch, Matt LeBlanc, Harvey Keitel and Steve Buscemi
fields.body:
 Gwyneth Paltrow's father, Bruce, has finally agreed to the cuts demanded by Disney for his comedy drama, Duets which also stars his daughter (pictured). The film, which will be premiered at the Toronto Film Festival in September is the tale of three off-the-wall-characters making their way to a karaoke competition. An 'insider' said: "The Disney people were worried that what was a family movie could be construed as being aimed at an adult audience."

 President Clinton's daughter, Chelsea, could be appearing in a film alongside Drew Barrymore, according to American newspaper The Daily Record. Apparently the 20-year-old Stanford student has set her sights on becoming an actress. Her actor boyfriend Jake Gyllenhaal who is currently filming Donnie Darko alongside Barrymore, apparently asked if Chelsea could have a part too.

 As we reported several weeks ago, Christopher Lee has officially joined the cast of the latest Stars War film, currently filming in Australia. The official site reports that his part will be that of a "charismatic separatist." Said Lee, "It will not just be another part. It will be another 'arrow in my quiver.' I'm looking forward to it enormously."

 Friends star Matt LeBlanc is set to star in an indie film All the Queen's Men, a comedy drama centring around a mismatched team of British Special Forces agents led by an American during the second world war. The team must infiltrate a female-run factory in Berlin that makes decoding devices and bring back the device that will end the war. The $15m picture will begin shooting next month in Eastern Europe. LeBlanc, who has just finished shooting his role in the forthcoming as an Angel boyfriend in Charlie's Angels, last appeared on the big screen in the big flop Lost in Space.

 Pierce Bronson could play Mr Ripley in a sequel to The Talented Mr Ripley according to Entertainment Weekly. New Line, which owns the rights to Patricia Highsmith's Ripley's Game is due to begin production in Italy and Germany this Autumn.

 Harvey Keitel, Steve Buscemi, David Arquette and Mira Sorvino, are in final negotiations to star in Holocaust drama The Grey Zone. The ensemble piece concerns the Sonderkommando - Jews who were forced to work in the crematoria of Auschwitz against their fellow Jews, and is based on writer-director Tim Blake's award-winning play.

fields.headline: Tmoin
fields.standfirst: Gwenalle Bayse describes performing at France's annual Fte de la Musique
fields.trailText: Gwenalle Bayse describes performing at France's annual Fte de la Musique
fields.body:
On est un groupe vocal de six chanteurs et trois musiciens. On fait de la musique de jazz, du gospel et des musiques du monde. Pendant notre concert, le public était génial - ils étaient assez nombreux et il y avait une super ambiance.

On a chanté des morceaux qui plaisent généralement au public parce qu'ils sont gais et rythmés... le gospel en particulier, ils aiment ça, c'est une musique qui est faite pour animer une salle. En plus on a une petite chorégraphie donc visuellement c'est plus attirant. Faire un concert pour cette fête, c'est un plaisir: comme on offre gratuitement, on n'a pas le même stress, la même pression que pour un concert traditionnel. On peut se permettre de se défouler, de s'amuser ensemble, pour le fun.

Après, on est allés voir d'autres concerts - on était plutôt dans des petites rues. On a évité des coins comme République ou Bastille où il y a des grandes scènes et les grandes vedettes. Cette année à République, il y avait le group Oasis et le chanteur David Halliday - un drôle de mélange.

Justement c'est ça la Fête de la Musique - tu mélanges les amateurs et les professionnels, les styles de musique... ça va du classique en passant par l'accordéon et les bals musettes en allant vers la techno, les musiques du monde et le jazz. Il y a des concerts partout. On s'imagine que tout le monde va se mettre à chanter dans les rues, mais même si le but de la fête, c'est d'encourager tout le monde à devenir musicien ou à découvrir un talent caché, les gens restent quand même timides.

Glossaire/Glossary

une ambiance atmosphere
se défouler to go wild, let go
être attirant to be attractive
être drôle to be funny
être génial to be wicked
être timide to be shy
éviter avoid
mélanger to mix
la musique du monde world music

webTitle: Should we believe Hague's reform act?

fields.headline: Should we believe Hague's reform act?
fields.standfirst: The Tories' plans for parliamentary reform should not be dismissed simply as Labour-bashing. For they contain proposals that would improve the workings of British democracy, argues Julian Glover
fields.trailText: Why we should listen to the Tories' plans for parliamentary reform, argues Julian Glover
fields.body:
Opposition parties always seem to turn to political reform just as governments are growing to hate it. William Hague is the latest to prove this political rule, with the publication this week of a party report on strengthening parliament.

Thirty years ago it was Ted Heath promising Scotland devolution as an escape from Labour government in London; 10 years later it was Margaret Thatcher and Lord Hailsham attacking the 'elective dictatorship' of the late 1970s, and most recently it has been Labour, promising, in opposition, all manner of change from regional autonomy to freedom of information as an antidote to Conservative dominance.

In office, of course, these commitments are tucked away as the pressing business of running the country comes to the fore. Only this week Labour has come close to abandoning its promise to hold a referendum on proportional representation. PR thus joins devolution to the English regions, full-blown reform of the House of Lords and proper freedom of information on the Downing Street backburner.

So it's easy to be sceptical about the Conservative party's new-found enthusiasm for parliamentary reform. If Hague ever makes it to Number 10, one suspects that sorting out the powers of the House of Commons will be low on his list of priorities. Right now, the issue gives the Tory leader a chance to indulge in his favoured sport of New Labour-bashing as well as allowing him to climb onto the policy high ground. But for all this the report of his party's Commission on Strengthening Parliament is worthy of attention.

Produced over the past year by a committee of Tory heavyweights and has-beens, including former ministers Lord Waldegrave, Lord Forsyth and Peter Brooke, under the chairmanship of the Tory peer and political academic Lord Norton, the report concentrates on the House of Commons, a part of our democratic process neglected by reformers from other parts of the political spectrum.

Everyone seems to agree that the Commons doesn't do its job properly. Legislation is passed which turns out to be unworkable, while empty debates and the Victorian theatre of question time hardly suggest a body which deals sensibly with the issues of the day. The cutting edge of politics has drifted away from Westminster: these days Downing Street, Europe, the law courts and the devolved assemblies are what count.

Lord Norton's proposals are far from the radical overhaul that some would like. But among the report's 90 or so recommendations are some significant changes that would improve the workings of British democracy. Forget the headline-grabbing proposal to reinstate a second weekly prime minister's question time This has been played up by William Hague in order to publicise his success last week against Tony Blair, but would have little effect in practice beyond clogging up the prime ministerial diary.

What matters are the reforms proposed to free select committees from the control of the party whips. At the moment committees are packed with MPs likely to toe the party line. Persistent radicals, of whatever party, are liable to find themselves shunted off in favour of more reliable members. Norton's proposals in this field might improve things.

So would his suggestion that there should be no more than 20 cabinet ministers and 50 junior ministers. This would slash the bloated payroll vote in parliament, raising the prospect of more government defeats in tight votes and perhaps leading some MPs to refocus their ambitions away from the prospect of ministerial office.

All this would make governments think harder about their often dismissive attitude to parliament. For this reason no government is likely to do it. But it might be worth a try.
fields.bodyText: Opposition parties always seem to turn to political reform just as governments are growing to hate it. William Hague is the latest to prove this political rule, with the publication this week of a party report on strengthening parliament. Thirty years ago it was Ted Heath promising Scotland devolution as an escape from Labour government in London; 10 years later it was Margaret Thatcher and Lord Hailsham attacking the 'elective dictatorship' of the late 1970s, and most recently it has been Labour, promising, in opposition, all manner of change from regional autonomy to freedom of information as an antidote to Conservative dominance. In office, of course, these commitments are tucked away as the pressing business of running the country comes to the fore. Only this week Labour has come close to abandoning its promise to hold a referendum on proportional representation. PR thus joins devolution to the English regions, full-blown reform of the House of Lords and proper freedom of information on the Downing Street backburner. So it's easy to be sceptical about the Conservative party's new-found enthusiasm for parliamentary reform. If Hague ever makes it to Number 10, one suspects that sorting out the powers of the House of Commons will be low on his list of priorities. Right now, the issue gives the Tory leader a chance to indulge in his favoured sport of New Labour-bashing as well as allowing him to climb onto the policy high ground. But for all this the report of his party's Commission on Strengthening Parliament is worthy of attention. Produced over the past year by a committee of Tory heavyweights and has-beens, including former ministers Lord Waldegrave, Lord Forsyth and Peter Brooke, under the chairmanship of the Tory peer and political academic Lord Norton, the report concentrates on the House of Commons, a part of our democratic process neglected by reformers from other parts of the political spectrum. Everyone seems to agree that the Commons doesn't do its job properly. Legislation is passed which turns out to be unworkable, while empty debates and the Victorian theatre of question time hardly suggest a body which deals sensibly with the issues of the day. The cutting edge of politics has drifted away from Westminster: these days Downing Street, Europe, the law courts and the devolved assemblies are what count. Lord Norton's proposals are far from the radical overhaul that some would like. But among the report's 90 or so recommendations are some significant changes that would improve the workings of British democracy. Forget the headline-grabbing proposal to reinstate a second weekly prime minister's question time This has been played up by William Hague in order to publicise his success last week against Tony Blair, but would have little effect in practice beyond clogging up the prime ministerial diary. What matters are the reforms proposed to free select committees from the control of the party whips. At the moment committees are packed with MPs likely to toe the party line. Persistent radicals, of whatever party, are liable to find themselves shunted off in favour of more reliable members. Norton's proposals in this field might improve things. fields.headline: Heavyweight froth Ungaro's ooh-la-la comeback
fields.trailText: Haute couture is all about gorgeous frocks - after all, if you have spent in the region of £20,000 on your outfit, you want to hear jaws hit the floor when you enter the room. No one understands this better than Emanuel Ungaro, who pulled out all the stops for his latest couture collection.
fields.body:
Haute couture is all about gorgeous frocks - after all, if you have spent in the region of £20,000 on your outfit, you want to hear jaws hit the floor when you enter the room. No one understands this better than Emanuel Ungaro, who pulled out all the stops for his latest couture collection.

These were truly spectacular gowns, from the fans of pleated net half shading the models' faces, through the overblown silk roses at the shoulder and hip, to the lace fishtail hems sweeping the floor. There was a decadent 30s feel to slithery bias cut dresses, flimsy as lingerie, slit thigh high and lace trimmed, and to evening coats edged with rabbit fur.

Dresses in floral-painted satin and coats in devoré velvet, in a palette of parma violet, dove grey, ivory and pistachio, added to the nostalgic mood of Merchant Ivory glamour beneath the arches of the Alexandre III bridge in Paris - despite rain dripping through the roof on to the catwalk.

The house of Ungaro is undergoing something of a renaissance. Emanuel was born in Provence to Italian parents, and worked at Balenciaga and Courreges before launching his own label in 1965 at the age of 32.

During the 80s, the house became known for brash, fussy clothes in bright floral prints, and the house was slow to distance itself from this look when fashion moved on.

But in the past few years it has found a more modern look and re-established itself. The daywear which opened the show, however, was still heavily influenced by the 80s: tapered satin trousers teamed with diamante seamed ankle boots and voluminous blouses. Over past seasons many designers have attempted to spark an 80s revival, but the trend has been almost completely ignored off the catwalk.

Let us hope they give up the ghost soon.

fields.headline: Der Einstieg in den Ausstieg
fields.standfirst: Has Germany done the right thing by trying to get rid of atomic energy?  Nicole Prestle asks some youngsters their opinion
fields.trailText: Has Germany done the right thing by trying to get rid of atomic energy? Nicole Prestle asks some youngsters their opinion
fields.body:
Schluß mit der Atomenergie. Deutschland steigt aus. In 32 Jahren. Endgültig. Endgültig? Diese Frage wird wohl offen bleiben. Vor wenigen Tagen haben sich Bundesregierung und Stromwirtschaft auf einen Kompromiß im Ausstieg aus der Atomkraft geeinigt. Noch rund 30 Jahre sollen die Kernkraftwerke laufen - moderne Anlagen etwas länger, ältere etwas kürzer.

Doch was Rot-Grün in harten Debatten durchgesetzt hat, will Schwarz nicht gelten lassen: Eine unionsgeführte Bundesregierung werde den Ausstieg auf keinen Fall fortsetzen, hat CDU-Chefin Angela Merkel bereits angekündigt. Atomkraft ja, Atomkraft nein, Atomkraft ja . . . Erinnert ein wenig an das Spiel, das Verliebte spielen, wenn sie Blatt um Blatt von einer Blume reißen, um herauszufinden, ob der oder die Liebste sie mag.

Kritik an den Kernpunkten des Ausstiegs gibt es genug. Noch ein Vierteljahrhundert lang soll Atommüll produziert werden, ohne daß es bereits eine vernünftige Lösung für die Lagerung des Atommülls gebe. "Wenn uns das als Ausstieg verkauft wird, ist das ein Hohn", betonten die Sprecher von Umweltinitiativen. Halbherzig nennen es andere, selbst die Atommeiler abzuschalten, um dann aus Nachbarländern Atomstrom zu importieren. Und sogar besagte Nachbarn sind verängstigt. Wo sollen die Mitarbeiter der Wiederaufbereitungsanlage La Hague in Frankreich arbeiten, wenn es aus Deutschland bald gar nichts mehr zur Aufbereitung geben wird? Wir haben uns bei Jugendlichen erkundigt, wie sie den Einstieg in den Ausstieg beurteilen.

Deutschland will seine Atommeiler herunterfahren. Was haltet Ihr vom Ausstieg aus der Kernkraft?

Iris (16): Ich finde es gut, daß wir diesen Schritt machen wollen. Gleichzeitig ist es aber eine Farce, wenn wir danach Atomstrom aus dem Ausland importieren, nur weil wir feststellen, daß wir unseren Bedarf nicht mehr selbst decken können. Und ich befürchte, dazu könnte es kommen.

Fritz (15): Ich habe zwar keine Angst vor Atomenergie, bin einem Ausstieg aber nicht abgeneigt. Es gibt genügend Alternativen. Wind-, Solar-, Wasserenergie. Jetzt muß man eben einen Ausweg suchen.

Sabrina (17): Deutschland ist ein kleines Land, das diesen Schritt wagt. Der Ausstieg sollte aber noch viel weiter gehen. Alle anderen Länder müßten sich auch nach anderen Möglichkeiten umsehen. Man sieht doch, was mit Kernkraftwerken passieren kann. Wenn ich nur an Tschernobyl zurückdenke... Da haben wir mehr abgekriegt, als wir immer gedacht haben. Leider muß wahrscheinlich wie so oft erst etwas passieren, bevor auch die anderen Schluß machen.

Welche Alternativen zur Atomenergie seht ihr?

Claudia (18): Ich denke da vor allem an Sonnen- und Windenergie. Auf jeden Fall sollte man nicht wieder auf Kohle zurückgreifen. Ich gehe sogar soweit: Die Länder, die im Moment noch Strom aus Kohlekraftwerken gewinnen, sollten gar nicht mehr den Schritt zur Atomenergie wagen, sondern ihn einfach überspringen. Regenerative Rohstoffe müßten auf der ganzen Welt viel mehr zur Energiegewinnung genutzt werden.

Markus (14): Ich setze vor allem auf eine Energiegewinnung, die nicht so viele Abfallstoffe hinterläßt. All die Transporte von gebrauchten Brennelementen, all die Endlager . . . Das ist etwas, das mich an der Atomenergie schrecklich nervt.

Die rot-grüne Regierung hat den Vertretern der Stromwirtschaft Zugeständnisse gemacht, um den Kompromiß zu erzielen. Waren es annehmbare Zugeständnisse?

Fritz: Also, wenn die Regierung sagt, sie wird in Zukunft keine erhöhten Sicherheitsansprüche an die Atomkraftwerke stellen, finde ich das schon schwach. Auf Kosten der Sicherheit darf der Atomausstieg doch nicht gehen, oder?

Claudia: Ich denke, daß vor allem die Grünen ihr Gesicht verloren haben. Ein Ausstieg nach über 30 Jahren kann für sie kein befriedigender Kompromiß sein. Ich glaube, sie haben einfach zugestimmt, um die Koalition nicht zu gefährden. Aber man sieht ja, daß es nichts gebracht hat. Jetzt gibt es Zoff innerhalb der eigenen Partei.

Markus: Ich denke schon, daß dieser Kompromiß in Ordnung ist. Ein frühzeitiger Ausstieg hätte nichts gebracht, weil wir jetzt, glaube ich, noch nicht genügend Alternativen zur Energiegewinnung haben. Und wenn beide Seiten mit dem Ergebnis leben können, kann es nicht schlecht sein. Die Stromwirtschaft hat sich ja auch bereit erklärt, marode Atommeiler schon früher abzustellen.

Kommt der Einstieg zum Ausstieg zur rechten Zeit?

Sabrina: Ja. Wir müssen jetzt Zeichen setzen. Auch als Vorbild für andere Länder.

Claudia: Ich habe ein paar Bedenken, was den Ersatz des Atomstroms betrifft. Ich glaube nicht, daß die Energiegewinnung aus regenerativen Ressourcen schon so weit erforscht ist, daß sie die Atomenergie ganz ersetzen kann. Ob allerdings 30 Jahre reichen, um so weit zu kommen, mag ich bezweifeln.

Fritz: Ich glaube, man hätte nicht diese 30 Jahre zugrunde legen sollen. Dadurch, daß die produzierten Strommengen auf verschiedene Atomkraftwerke verteilt werden dürfen, kann man ja nicht einmal sagen, daß 2030 Schluß sein wird. Die Grenzen sind zu verschwommen. Es wäre besser gewesen, die Kernkraftwerke nach und nach abzuschalten. So nach dem Motto: Bist du zu alt, um sicher Strom zu erzeugen, schalten wir dich ab.

Glossar/Glossary

der Bedarf the need, requirement

die Farce bad joke, farce

halbherzig half hearted

hinterlassen to leave behind, bequeath

das ist ein Hohn it's a joke

der Kompromiß compromise

marode dilapidated

nerven to annoy someone, get on someone's nerves

der Zoff (coll.) quarrel

das Zugeständnis concession

webTitle: Petrol prices push up inflation rate

fields.headline: Petrol prices push up inflation rate
fields.trailText: Rising petrol prices helped drive up the rate of inflation to its highest level for two years, according to official figures published today.
fields.body:
Rising petrol prices helped drive up the rate of inflation to its highest level for two years, according to official figures published today.

The Office for National Statistics (ONS) reported that inflation in June rose from 3.1% to 3.3% - its highest since July 1998.

The key underlying inflation rate, which excludes mortgage interest payments and is used by the Bank of England when setting interest rates, was also up from 2.0% to 2.2% - which is still below the government's 2.5% target.

The ONS said the main reason for the rise in inflation was a steep increase in prices at the petrol pumps because of the higher cost of crude oil. The average price of a litre of unleaded petrol rose from 80p to 84p in June compared to an average of 70p a year ago.

The cost of crude oil has risen sharply in past months. But Saudi Arabia, the world's leading oil producer, has said it intends to increase output to drive down prices.

The annual rate of increase for petrol and oil prices was 18.4%. The inflation figures were also affected by the wet spring, which pushed up the price of potatoes and other fresh fruit and vegetables.

The eurozone measure of inflation - the harmonised index of consumer prices - was also up, from 0.5% to 0.8%.

Economists believe that the Bank of England, which has kept interest rates unchanged at 6% for the past five months, will not raise rates this summer because the economy is showing signs of slowing down.

fields.headline: 'Studio goons stalked me' claims Myers
fields.trailText: The latest news on the aborted but still headline-grabbing monkey movie sees Austin Powers star Mike Myers counter-suing Universal Studios. Myers is claiming that the studio hired men to stalk him in an attempt to bully the actor into making the comedy
fields.body:
They just won't let the Dieter row lie. The latest news on the aborted but still headline-grabbing monkey movie sees Austin Powers star Mike Myers counter-suing Universal Studios. Myers is claiming that the studio hired men to stalk him in an attempt to bully the actor into making the comedy. Last month Universal served a writ to Myers for breach of contract (see our report after he bailed out of the project, blaming the script. Myers's law-suit is the latest exchange in what looks set to become an ugly round of legal tit-for-tat.

Myers's suit charges Universal with intimidation and bullying. It claims that the studio and its "co-conspirators" at Imagine Entertainment committed fraud and defamation.

Myers claims the project became a question of profits over quality. The suit claims that the actor worked for two years on 14 different versions of the script and came under increasing pressure to go ahead with the film even though he believed the script was still "fundamentally flawed".

'This case presents a classic example of a movie studio placing studio short-sightedness and greed above artistic integrity," the suit reads. "When Myers informed Universal that the script had problems and was not ready, Universal responded by suggesting that the script was good enough and with Myers's 'star power', the motion picture would make money in any event." Myers also claims that Imagine boss Ron Howard (of Happy Days fame) belied his good-guy image by warning the star "it's going to get ugly" unless he agreed to make the film.

But the suit's most bizarre claim is that Universal invaded Myers's privacy by hiring someone who was given "instructions to stalk Myers in the street, near his home and chase Myers in a threatening manner down dark, winding and unlit streets".

Imagine and Universal declined to comment.

webTitle: The Williams sisters a lesson for the ECB

fields.headline: The Williams sisters a lesson for the ECB
fields.trailText: In the least surprising move since Patsy Kensit left Liam Gallagher, the Lawn Tennis Association has announced that it wants to employ Venus and Serena Williams to promote tennis in Britain's inner-city areas.
fields.body:
In the least surprising move since Patsy Kensit left Liam Gallagher, the Lawn Tennis Association has announced that it wants to employ Venus and Serena Williams to promote tennis in Britain's inner-city areas.

The last black woman to win Wimbledon was Evonne Goolagong Cawley, in 1971 and 1980. Then a 20-year drought  though Zina Garrison made the final (and inspired Richard Williams) in 1990. Now the LTA, a body so conservative that it makes the MCC look like the SWP, has been handed two evangelists on a plate.

The Williams may rub people up the wrong way in the locker room but on court they win points, plaudits and passion. The sight of Venus bounding around Centre Court like Tigger was enough to bring a wobbly lower-lip to even the most sceptical watcher in the Royal Box. And that semi-final, though it didn't live up to its billing, was the most eagerly anticipated match of Wimbledon 2000 - even more than Henman v Philippoussis or Rafter v Sampras. Not bad for a tournament in which the male champion's prize money still outweighs the women's by £47,500 (though the gap is closing), ostensibly because people would rather watch men play.

That cricket could do with a similar Billy Graham figure has been said, and dreamt about, endlessly. Many all-time greats have been black, but no black English player has ever completely captured the public's imagination. Devon Malcolm perhaps came closest. Otherwise: Chris Lewis? Gladstone Small? Norman Cowans? Nice men, yes; Wisden Cricketers of the Century, no. However this roll call is sparkling when compared to the women's game.

Since England's women began playing international cricket in 1934-35, no black woman has ever played for them. Never in a Test, never in a one-day international.

The reasons are fairly obvious. Until the 1990s cricket was dying in most state schools. Even now, in times of Kwik cricket and praiseworthy ECB initiatives, a quick glance at the list of girls' secondary schools that play cricket reveals them to be almost exclusively private.

A recent survey of 465 adults with children at school by Brand and Issues for sportscore.co.uk has shown that parents spend 25% less on sports gear for their daughters than for their sons. When decent cricket bats aren't exactly cheap, you can see why girls from poorer families will not be encouraged to play.

The same survey shows that parents spend 15% more on books for their daughters than their sons, but as it is likely that this extra allowance is being spent on Judy Blume and Sweet Valley High rather than the Art of Cricket or Beyond A Boundary, this doesn't offer much relief to the ECB.

There are young black players coming through. And not everybody needs a role model in exactly the same mould as them. Women idolise men, white men idolise black men, and the other way round. But to have a figure of the Williams' exuberance and star quality emerging in the England Women's team would do more for England's prospects than all the ECB special initiatives in the world.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read her previous column, on why cricket needs Annamania of its own, click here

The last black woman to win Wimbledon was Evonne Goolagong Cawley, in 1971 and 1980. Then a 20-year drought  though Zina Garrison made the final (and inspired Richard Williams) in 1990. Now the LTA, a body so conservative that it makes the MCC look like the SWP, has been handed two evangelists on a plate. The Williams may rub people up the wrong way in the locker room but on court they win points, plaudits and passion. The sight of Venus bounding around Centre Court like Tigger was enough to bring a wobbly lower-lip to even the most sceptical watcher in the Royal Box. And that semi-final, though it didn't live up to its billing, was the most eagerly anticipated match of Wimbledon 2000 - even more than Henman v Philippoussis or Rafter v Sampras. Not bad for a tournament in which the male champion's prize money still outweighs the women's by £47,500 (though the gap is closing), ostensibly because people would rather watch men play. That cricket could do with a similar Billy Graham figure has been said, and dreamt about, endlessly. Many all-time greats have been black, but no black English player has ever completely captured the public's imagination. Devon Malcolm perhaps came closest. Otherwise: Chris Lewis? Gladstone Small? Norman Cowans? Nice men, yes; Wisden Cricketers of the Century, no. However this roll call is sparkling when compared to the women's game. Since England's women began playing international cricket in 1934-35, no black woman has ever played for them. Never in a Test, never in a one-day international. The reasons are fairly obvious. Until the 1990s cricket was dying in most state schools. Even now, in times of Kwik cricket and praiseworthy ECB initiatives, a quick glance at the list of girls' secondary schools that play cricket reveals them to be almost exclusively private. A recent survey of 465 adults with children at school by Brand and Issues for sportscore.co.uk has shown that parents spend 25% less on sports gear for their daughters than for their sons. When decent cricket bats aren't exactly cheap, you can see why girls from poorer families will not be encouraged to play. The same survey shows that parents spend 15% more on books for their daughters than their sons, but as it is likely that this extra allowance is being spent on Judy Blume and Sweet Valley High rather than the Art of Cricket or Beyond A Boundary, this doesn't offer much relief to the ECB. There are young black players coming through. And not everybody needs a role model in exactly the same mould as them. Women idolise men, white men idolise black men, and the other way round. But to have a figure of the Williams' exuberance and star quality emerging in the England Women's team would do more for England's prospects than all the ECB special initiatives in the world. webTitle: Curb on early retirements that cost taxpayer £1bn a year

fields.headline: Curb on early retirements that cost taxpayer £1bn a year
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of public sector workers are to be banned from taking early retirement on health grounds under government plans to stamp out abuses which cost the taxpayer £1bn a year.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of public sector workers are to be banned from taking early retirement on health grounds under government plans to stamp out abuses which cost the taxpayer £1bn a year.

In a damning report published today, the Treasury will claim that drastic action is needed after research showed there were a third more early retirements in the public sector than in private business.

The report, which is being published by the Treasury chief secretary, Andrew Smith, and which was selectively leaked yesterday, will highlight significant variations in early retirement dates throughout the public sector. More than half of retirements from the fire service (60%) are on grounds of ill health, with the figure rising to 93% in some areas.

The crackdown on early retirement is a key part of the government's public spending review, which is to be announced by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, next Tuesday.

Ministers will hammer home the message that without reform - such as ending the practice of retirement on bogus health grounds - Britain's public services cannot expect an injection of extra money. In his statement to the Commons, the chancellor will unveil new "service delivery agreements" which contain rigorous new targets to cut back retirement on the ground of ill health.

Mr Smith's report will propose a series of strict new measures, including new medical assessments to be carried out with more "consistency and rigour" and moving workers who are considered unfit for operational duties into less stressful work.

Government sources said that they would not remove the right to early retirement from genuine cases.

Ministers were particularly alarmed by a report into the fire service which said that many firefighters believed they had a right to retire early. The report, Fit for Duty - seeking a healthier fire service, said: "It is morally incumbent upon all employees, managers, fire authorities and representative bodies to act with integrity and prudence to ensure benefits of the scheme are not abused and remain available for all those working for genuine medical reasons. However, the lack of management control and the prevailing culture that exists in some brigades appears to have caused a threat to this."

webTitle: How Curtly is spending his three-week break

fields.headline: How Curtly is spending his three-week break
fields.standfirst: In the latest instalment of wisden.com's gossip column, Charles de Lisle reveals Curtly Ambrose's unlikely hobby, and rubs shoulders with his West Indian colleagues in the West End
fields.trailText: Curtly: the one that got away from it all
fields.body:
Curtly: the one that got away from it all

How is Curtly Ambrose occupying himself during his three-week break from the tour of England? The official line from the West Indies camp is that Ambrose, who flew home to his native Antigua last Tuesday, is "recharging his batteries" for his return to action in the last three Tests.

As well as taking a well-earned rest, Ambrose is catching up with his family at his home in Swetes Village, enjoying the beaches and sunshine, keeping an eye on the one-day tournament on TV, and doing something as different from fast bowling as almost anything you can imagine: fishing. Ricky Skerritt, the team manager, says: "I guarantee you that, six evenings out of seven, Curtly will be out fishing with his friends. He loves it."

However Ambrose, 36, must also be pondering his future. Should he stick to his decision to retire from international cricket after the fifth Test at The Oval, or should he give in to the pleas of Brian Lara and Sir Viv Richards, among others, and have one final blast at the Australians, Down Under next winter?

Skerritt concedes that the Windies pace attack is "hurting" without Ambrose's experience, deadly accuracy and "focus", but says that the promise to rest either Ambrose or Courtney Walsh from alternate one-day series had to be honoured. "Curtly deserves a rest after a very tough six months," he says.

And how is Ambrose, who rejoins the tour in time for the game against Leicestershire (July 28-30), keeping himself fit? "Curtly isn't going to the gym, or doing anything like that," says Skerritt. "He doesn't need to. He's naturally very fit, and looks after himself very carefully. He's never touched alcohol and he's never smoked."

Do of the Week (the fourth in an occasional series)

Occasion A "Meet the Players" party on Friday, July 7, hosted by Sandals Resorts and Carib lager, sponsors of the West Indies' touring side. The team didn't have far to come: the do took place in the gloomy Adelphi Suite at their London hotel, Le Meridien Waldorf, in the West End.

Format Cocktail reception from 7pm to 9pm. Substantial Caribbean eats washed down with the sponsor's product, which is brewed in Trinidad. The obligatory steel band set the tone of a lively, informal evening.

Attendance 200, including all 17 members of the Windies one-day party - for obvious reasons, it was a three-line whip - smartly turned out in a variety of sponsors' shirts, and dark-blue trousers. Also there: Caribbean diplomats, Michael Holding, Colin Croft, Phil Simmons, the all-rounder who retired after the last World Cup, and Geoff Howarth, the former New Zealand captain.

Notable absentee Curtly Ambrose (see story above).

Main surprise Why were the Windies staying at this somewhat dated hotel? "It's a traditional place," explained a friend of the team. "And the guys like being close to Covent Garden. They can go out, unrecognised, to the pubs and cafes, lose themselves - and see some good-looking women."

Main talking points The excellent PR and team spirit of the Windies team, who betrayed little sign of a shattering week: the Test defeat at Lord's, and their first ever loss to Zimbabwe, in the Bristol one-dayer the night before. All the players were approachable and friendly, though Franklyn Rose (who has a crunching handshake) was clearly wary of the media. Impressively, the entire squad was still there at 9.30pm, half an hour after the scheduled close, and the senior players - Jimmy Adams, Sherwin Campbell, Walsh and Lara - were still dishing out the charm and the autographs as things began to wind up at around 10.15pm.

Principal entertainment Jeffrey Dujon, the assistant coach, introducing the players individually, who performed with a certain style reminiscent of his days as a master wicketkeeper-batsman. Lara gave Dujon a warm hug after being hailed as "our premier batsman", and there was a special round of applause for Sherwin Campbell, back that morning from a flying visit to Barbados, where he was present at the birth of his second child, a daughter ("even he isn't quite sure of the name", joked Dujon). Dujon rounded off by saluting "the guys who just sit down and watch" - his backroom colleagues, including Ronald Rogers, the sports therapist, and Garfield Smith, the scorer. Smith is so small, he could fit in Courtney Walsh's pocket.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). You can e-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com

webTitle: Flawed nuclear fuel sent back to Britain

fields.headline: Flawed nuclear fuel sent back to Britain
fields.trailText:
Environmental campaigners condemned a decision today to return a shipment of flawed nuclear fuel to Britain from Japan. 
British Nuclear Fuels Ltd said it had agreed to take back the fuel after months of negotiations with Japanese ministers and energy companies.
fields.body:
Environmental campaigners condemned a decision today to return a shipment of flawed nuclear fuel to Britain from Japan. British Nuclear Fuels Ltd said it had agreed to take back the fuel after months of negotiations with Japanese ministers and energy companies.

BNFL has also agreed to pay £40 million in compensation after shipping the fuel to the Far East. If BNFL meets certain conditions then just under half this amount could be paid in replacement MOX nuclear fuel. A statement from BNFL said: "The companies have agreed that the eight MOX fuel assemblies currently in Japan should be returned to the UK and BNFL has agreed to bear the costs. "BNFL has also agreed a settlement with Kansai regarding their compensation claims."

The decision comes seven months after British Nuclear Fuels admitted it had misled the Japanese about safety checks on its reprocessed plutonium pellets.

The admission sparked protests from environmentalists in Japan over the consignment from the BNFL Sellafield plant in Cumbria. It is not expected the consignment will be moved in the near future. There will have to be further negotiations involving the US and other countries to agree a route back to the UK before the shipment is returned.

Greenpeace nuclear campaigner Bridget Goodman said: "This way of dealing with the problem is the worst of all possible solutions. "The process of shipping it back will threaten the environment and security and will cause a diplomatic storm. "This fuel contains plutonium which is one of the most toxic elements in existence. "The most responsible way of dealing with it would be for it to be stored in Japan and for BNFL to pay for it to be stored."

The Japanese Kansai Electric Power company has announced it is lifting the suspension on new MOX and reprocessing business and a BNFL spokesman said this opened the door for new and existing business worth around £4 billion.

BNFL chief executive Norman Askew, who met with Kansai in late June, said: "We have been working very hard with our customer to find a solution. "I am very pleased that these matters have been resolved, and with the lifting of the moratorium it opens the way for the re-establishing of a normal business relationship.

"We still have much work to do to continue the process of rebuilding customer confidence. This agreement is the start of that process."

webTitle: Reluctant Britain 'would be unwelcome in euroland'

fields.headline: Reluctant Britain 'would be unwelcome in euroland'
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Britain would not be welcomed into the euro unless there was a cross-party consensus in favour of both the European Union and the single currency, according to a founding father of the euro.
fields.body:
Britain would not be welcomed into the euro unless there was a cross-party consensus in favour of both the European Union and the single currency, according to a founding father of the euro.

In an interview with the Guardian, Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa, a member of the executive board of the European central bank and the man widely credited as the intellectual impetus behind the euro, said Britain's inclusion in "euroland" would destabilise the euro unless there was a fundamental shift in British attitudes towards Europe.

"In most European countries a shift in politics does not fundamentally change the country's European policy," he said.

"But there are some countries, like the UK, where the fundamental attitude of the population is not united behind the EU. So long as they are not members of euroland this fragility of support does not worry me. I would be concerned if this fragility remained and they were part of euroland."

His comments came as the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, last night accused Tony Blair of running away from a decision on whether Britain should join the euro and called on him to openly state his policy.

But, according to Mr Padoa-Schioppa, even if a Labour government were to win a referendum on joining the single currency, it would still need to win over the hearts and minds of the vast majority of the electorate before it could comfortably take its place at the heart of Europe's economy.

In countries on the continent a change in government would not signal a meaningful change in policy where European integration was concerned, he said. In Britain, however, there were significant differences not only between parties but within them.

He said the euro's long term credibility had not necessarily been damaged by its low value: "The real sign of success, or lack of success, is that the euro is accepted as a reality ... that it is here to stay."
