webTitle: Take a break from the KitKat crisis

fields.headline: Take a break from the KitKat crisis
fields.standfirst:
The unions want action on the high pound, but have they been hoodwinked by politicians?

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The TUC yesterday urged the government to adopt a 30-point plan to tackle what the unions call "the crisis in manufacturing". Emergency action to help run-down regions, lower interest rates, and coordinated action to bring down the level of the pound are what Congress House wants from the government.
fields.body:
The TUC yesterday urged the government to adopt a 30-point plan to tackle what the unions call "the crisis in manufacturing". Emergency action to help run-down regions, lower interest rates, and coordinated action to bring down the level of the pound are what Congress House wants from the government.

Coming after last week's warnings from a leaked Department of Trade and Industry document about a meltdown in industry, a casual observer could be forgiven for thinking that the government is sitting idly by while manufacturing in Britain is allowed to wither and die.

Nestlé is the latest company to go public about the damage to its bottom line caused by sterling's strength, issuing a veiled threat that the future of its plant in York might be in doubt should the value of the pound not come down.

Nestlé has already switched production of up to 5,000 tonnes of KitKats from York to Hamburg. John Sunley, human resources director for UK operations, said: "If the strength of the pound is maintained then there is a risk that our export business would suffer further and this would lead to job losses."

In large part, this sense of impending doom has been whipped up by those with a political agenda which goes as follows: manufacturing is in crisis, and the reason it is in crisis is because the pound is too high. The pound is too high because Britain is not a member of the eurozone, so the answer is to speed up entry into the single currency. (Nestlé, incidentally, is based in Switzerland, which is not even a member of the European Union, and the exchange rate between the pound and the Swiss franc is the same as three years ago.)

Actually, the evidence that manufacturing is in crisis is hard to find. Unlike 1980-81, when manufacturing output fell by 15%, and 1990-92, when it declined by a further 6%, the amount produced by Britain's factories has been rising - albeit slowly - in recent years. The latest figures show that output rose by 0.3% in the latest quarter and is up 1.8% on the corresponding quarter in 1999.

So why the vociferous complaints? A closer look at the data finds that manufacturing is having mixed fortunes, with some parts doing well and others pretty badly. Hardest hit are the low-value-added sectors - basic metal bashing and textiles - while the top performers are high-value-added sectors such as pharmaceuticals and information technology.

The outlook for firms competing on price in global markets is indeed bleak with the pound at the equivalent of around 3.10 German marks. To hold on to their markets, they need sterling to be DM2.80, and to make serious money they would like it be be in the region of DM2.50-2.60.

But whether Britain has a future in these sectors even if the pound does fall substantially is unclear. Low-value-added manufacturing is gradually drifting to low-wage countries in eastern Europe and Asia - a change which predates the recent overvaluation of the exchange rate.

In other sectors, such as cars, globalisation has resulted in huge overcapacity, hence the motivation for the big players to forge strategic links and concentrate production at the most competitive plants.

There have been far fewer complaints from firms in the so-called sunrise industries - the dynamic sectors that government ministers consider vital for Britain's future prosperity. A survey in last weekend's Observer revealed that software and computer companies put membership or non-membership of the euro at the bottom of their list of priorities when con sidering investing in Britain. Despite all the furore caused by the leaked memo from the British embassy in Tokyo last week, one senior Japanese diplomat said that cutting-edge firms from his country were far less concerned about the state of the pound than were firms making single products such as hi-fi systems, where global competition from developing countries was already ferocious.

"The question is not whether jobs in these low-value-added sectors will go, but when," he said. "This will apply whether or not Britain is in the euro."

None of this is to say that manufacturing does not matter. As Eamonn Fingleton, the author of the book In Praise of Hard Industries, said in the Guardian recently: "Whereas post-industrial businesses provide jobs mainly for people among the most intelligent 10% of the population, even the most advanced areas of manufacturing provide jobs for people of almost every level of capability."

The government is undoubtedly uncomfortable with the exchange rate at current levels, but believes that attempts to massage the pound down artificially would represent just the latest in a series of quick-fix remedies tried over the past half century.

There are three big problems with the argument that Britain needs a strategy for getting the pound down and then joining the euro. The first is that there is no clear idea how this could be done. Second, a much lower pound would mean either higher interest rates or Irish-style inflation, something ignored by the single-currency bandwagon. Finally, and most importantly, it disguises the real problem - that the exchange rate has been falling for the entire post-war period to cover up Britain's poor productivity record.

Ministers believe that the productivity record is the real reason for Britain's share of world trade declining relentlessly since 1950, and that until that situation is improved manipulating the exchange rate to create the "right" conditions for manufacturing is no real solution.

In other sectors, such as cars, globalisation has resulted in huge overcapacity, hence the motivation for the big players to forge strategic links and concentrate production at the most competitive plants. There have been far fewer complaints from firms in the so-called sunrise industries - the dynamic sectors that government ministers consider vital for Britain's future prosperity. A survey in last weekend's Observer revealed that software and computer companies put membership or non-membership of the euro at the bottom of their list of priorities when con sidering investing in Britain. Despite all the furore caused by the leaked memo from the British embassy in Tokyo last week, one senior Japanese diplomat said that cutting-edge firms from his country were far less concerned about the state of the pound than were firms making single products such as hi-fi systems, where global competition from developing countries was already ferocious. "The question is not whether jobs in these low-value-added sectors will go, but when," he said. "This will apply whether or not Britain is in the euro." None of this is to say that manufacturing does not matter. As Eamonn Fingleton, the author of the book In Praise of Hard Industries, said in the Guardian recently: "Whereas post-industrial businesses provide jobs mainly for people among the most intelligent 10% of the population, even the most advanced areas of manufacturing provide jobs for people of almost every level of capability." The government is undoubtedly uncomfortable with the exchange rate at current levels, but believes that attempts to massage the pound down artificially would represent just the latest in a series of quick-fix remedies tried over the past half century. There are three big problems with the argument that Britain needs a strategy for getting the pound down and then joining the euro. The first is that there is no clear idea how this could be done. Second, a much lower pound would mean either higher interest rates or Irish-style inflation, something ignored by the single-currency bandwagon. Finally, and most importantly, it disguises the real problem - that the exchange rate has been falling for the entire post-war period to cover up Britain's poor productivity record. Ministers believe that the productivity record is the real reason for Britain's share of world trade declining relentlessly since 1950, and that until that situation is improved manipulating the exchange rate to create the "right" conditions for manufacturing is no real solution.

fields.headline: Single minded
fields.standfirst:
You won't have heard of him, but in 1982, Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa gave a speech which set Europe on the road to monetary union. Gary Younge traces the genesis of the ambitious idea that became Britain's hottest political issue
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: You won't have heard of him, but in 1982, Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa gave a speech which set Europe on the road to monetary union. Gary Younge traces the genesis of the ambitious idea that became Britain's hottest political issue
fields.body:
In June 1982 a little-known Eurocrat, Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa, delivered a little-noticed speech to the second symposium of European banks. It was the month when the Argentinians surrendered the Falkland Islands, the Israelis invaded Lebanon and the late Princess Diana gave birth to Prince William. But Padoa-Schioppa, the then director of economic and financial affairs at the European commission, had other things on his mind. Expounding and expanding his views on the liberalisation of capital, he started by quoting article 67 of the Treaty of Rome; he ended by calling for a single currency. "Fully fledged European monetary union is the high road to policy coordination and economic convergence," he said. "It would be sufficient to realise one major achievement: monetary union."

The speech was never going to make the headlines. Talks entitled Capital Mobility: Why is the Treaty not Implemented? rarely do. Moreover, 18 years ago, advocating a single currency was much like calling for the world to speak Esperanto - idealism masquerading as common sense. An intellectual house of cards which would collapse at the first whiff of reality. Now it is a reality, albeit a faltering and controversial one. And Padoa-Schioppa, who is now a member of the executive board of the European Central Bank (ECB), has been key to making it one. The Financial Times has described him as: "One of a small group of people who can claim that they invented the single currency." Sir David Walker, the chairman and chief executive of Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter Europe, who worked alongside Padoa-Schioppa over several decades, goes further, describing him as: "The central figure in the thinking that lead to a new Europe."

At a time when the issue in Britain is wrapped up in evasions, distortions and semantic arguments, might a visit to the man who started it all cast a little light on a debate which often feels as though it is being held in semi-darkness? Perhaps this quintessential European, this Italian who lives in Germany, spent his childhood in France and thinks in English, can offer us a glimpse of the European ideal in its purest form?

You will find him amid the alphabet soup of acronyms which make up the European lexicon, in between Pace (Programme of Advanced Continuing Education) and Palabre (a project con cerned with the integration of artificial intelligence). In Britain he is as little known as ever. But among the relatively small circles who follow the twist sand turns of EU development, he is the brains behind the project which has united much of Europe, is dividing the present UK government and brought down the last one.

He was the secretary of the Delors committee whose report in 1989 returned the issue of monetary union to centre stage and provided a blueprint for the Maastricht Treaty. The man who drew up the initial draft of the Rome Extraordinary Summit of October 1990; one of the "Gang of Four" who prepared all the technical and diplomatic stages which led to the "Rome conclusions". These, in turn, declared January 1994 as the beginning of the second stage of a more intensive economic and monetary coordination before the creation of a central bank. He was there when the vital documents were passed from the civil servants to elected premiers to sign; he is there in Frankfurt supporting the euro on the world stage.

But back in 1982, when he delivered his speech, such progress seemed a long way off. "There is a difference between what you think is necessary and what you think is possible," he says. "In the early 80s I was convinced that European monetary union was necessary. This was not a Damascene conversion but something that occurred to me over a period of time." His role in its construction was not upfront at the despatch boxes of individual European parliaments, where the political battles were being waged, but in the thinking, crafting and drafting behind the scenes.

"We all have a range of activities at our disposal which go from participating in intellectual debate into more concrete policy statements and positions," he says referring to his speech in 1982. "I regarded this idea as a part of an intellectual debate." His versatility and discipline in this regard, says Walker, is awesome. "He has an extraordinary capacity to see both the wood and the trees at the same time. He can see the big vision from the top down and the details from the bottom up. He sits with a blank piece of paper and maps out an entire strategy. He'll say 'There are 24 steps here', and then he'll go through them all systematically."

This is also how he talks: in precise measured sentences often punctuated by numbers. There are "three" reasons why the euro has been a success; "two" conflicting problems with speaking a foreign language; and "two" strands to Britain's negotiating techniques.

It is a degree of precision which does not just stop at his speech but which is clear from his clothes and general appearance. He keeps himself fit - he is a very young 59 - with a daily exercise regime which lasts exactly 11 minutes. His suit, like his hair, is a well-cut grey. A small man with a large brain rattling around in a huge office on the 34th of the European central bank. It is a vast plot in the middle of the Frankfurt skyline with space enough for a badminton court and a few table-tennis tables. The enormous windows offer an impressive view of a rather unimpressive, anodyne city.

He is very much the product of both his age and his upbringing, brought up in the north-east of Italy by a father who worked in insurance and a mother who raised four children. "Both my parents were intellectuals. My father had been a teacher. We were a cultivated family."

Born in 1940, he is part of the generation of continental Europeans whose views on the future of Europe were shaped by the aftermath of the second world war. With despair just behind them, they were intoxicated with optimism that in an age of reason they could construct a better world than their parents.

"I first met my father when I was five when he came back from the war. It was a time not so much of poverty but real indigence. People of this generation grew up with a strong conviction that the unity of Europe was the only way out."

He became a model European. He learned German at school and during a gap year in Bremen, English as a graduate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and French during holidays in the Alps. He dreams in Italian and thinks in either Italian, French or English. "I tend to think in the language in which I'm working at the time. But for most things I very much like to use English even though it is not my mother tongue because it is more concise, more precise, more concrete. It's like being an artisan. I have to weigh up how refined the tool is in my hands and how much I like to use it."

Economics was not the obvious conduit for all these talents. As a young man he was far more taken with history and philosophy, but felt the need to apply those disciplines in the real world: "I needed to do something closer to reality.

"Economics was the compromise, but in a way it was quite painful for me to be an economist." When his contemporaries were taking to the streets to bring down capitalism throughout the western world, Padoa-Schioppa was helping to shore it up with a job at the Italian Central Bank. After that came various high-level jobs related to banking, economics and finance, both in Italy and the European Commission.

He was not the first person to have proposed a single currency. There are several people who could make that claim to fame, although the chief responsibility sits on the fragile shoulders of Pierre Werner, the former prime minister of Luxembourg, who is now 87 and recently suffered a stroke. In 1970 he put his name to the report which called for the establishment of EMU and a European Central Bank by 1980. But the economic slump of the 70s jettisoned Werner's plans and they were not to be fully considered again until the Delors committee got together in the late 80s.

If anything, Padoa-Schioppa likes to play down his role. It was not until the late 80s that he started to think that a single currency had gone from a necessity to a possibility. "There was no single moment when it went from a dream to a reality," he says. "But there were several decisive moments. The Delors committee, the inter-governmental conference, the agreement of the heads of state were among them." And throughout there was always the possibility of failure. "There were moments when the whole thing could have fallen apart. The positive additions were always partial developments; but any negative developments would have been total. The biggest risk came with the currency crisis of 1992 - most people at that stage thought the likelihood of us achieving EMU was very low."

Even though he doesn't say it, chief among the headaches throughout this time were the recalcitrant British. He seems quite bemused and not a little impressed by Britain's negotiating strategy. "They did it in a masterful way. First they influenced the substance of the project so that it would be more suitable to them if they did want to sign up to it. And then they carve out a special status for themselves which means they do not have to sign up to it."

He is not worried by Britain's decision to stay out of the euro. In fact he thinks that unless Britain emerges with a pro-European consensus its inclusion could damage Britain and destabilise the entire project. "In most European countries a shift in politics does not fundamentally change the country's European policy," he says. "There is not much difference between Kohl and Schroeder or Juppe and Jospin when it comes to supporting the EU process. But there are some countries where this is not the case, such as the United Kingdom, where the fundamental attitude of the population is not united behind the European Union. So long as they are not members of Euroland this fragility of support does not worry me. I would be concerned if this fragility remained and they were part of Euroland."

That said, from the outset Euroland has seemed to have done a pretty good job of exuding fragility all on its own. No sooner had the euro been released than the market took it by the scruff of the neck and threw it down so hard it sank below the dollar and has yet to surface. "I did take it as a sign of a bad start but not as a crisis," Padoa-Schioppa says. "To some extent in the financial world perceptions are a reality and even misperceptions can be a reality and so its decline was significant in that sense. But the day it actually fell below the dollar was not important to me. I remember what I was doing the day Kennedy was assassinated [studying English on a course in Britain] or when man first walked on the moon [on a trip to Maine from Boston]. But I don't remember the day the Euro fell below the pound.

"British people are worried by the strong pound and we were concerned about a weak Euro. The real sign of success, or lack of success, is that the euro is accepted as a reality . . . that it is here to stay in Euroland. Nobody, not the financial system, the market, the unions, business sectors, questions the fact that the euro is a fait accompli ." Unless, that is, you happen to live in Britain, where almost everybody questions that very fact. Most people still do not want it, and a referendum (when and if it comes) is as likely to split families and friends as parties and governments. To some it represents a threat to our sovereignty; to others the most potent symbol of our xenophobic insularity. But to Padoa-Schioppa it is money that can be used from "Lisbon to Leipzig". Something that started as necessary, became possible and now, he believes, is unavoidable.

fields.body: Charity workers Ruth Wyner and John Brock were arrested in connection with heroin dealing at the homeless drop-in centre they ran in Cambridge. Wyner, director of the Wintercomfort charity, was jailed for five years; Brock, a manager at the charity's day centre, the Bus, was jailed for four. webTitle: 'It is terrible, this plebeian culture that celebrates itself'

fields.headline: 'It is terrible, this plebeian culture that celebrates itself'
fields.standfirst:
Famous author accuses Blair of leading socialist revolution that is destroying the idea of civilisation and the arts.
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sir Vidia Naipul, better known as the novelist VS Naipaul, has launched an extraordinary attack on the prime minister, comparing him to a pirate at the head of a socialist revolution that is "destroying the idea of civilisation in this country".
fields.body:
Sir Vidia Naipul, better known as the novelist VS Naipaul, has launched an extraordinary attack on the prime minister, comparing him to a pirate at the head of a socialist revolution that is "destroying the idea of civilisation in this country".

The Trinidad-born author of An Area Of Darkness and A House For Mr Biswas, accused Mr Blair of trying to destroy the very idea of high culture by championing an "aggressively plebeian culture that celebrates itself for being plebeian" and of turning elitism into a dirty word.

"Every day you hear on the radio some minister from this appalling government saying something about things no longer being for the privileged few. This has destroyed the idea of civilisation in this country," he said.

The rot, he claimed, began with the post-war Labour government of 1945. "We now have a full socialist revolution and the bizarre thing is that it does not mean high culture becomes available to everybody. It is terrible, this aggressively plebeian culture that celebrates itself for being plebeian."

He concedes that it is not only the prime minister who has done the damage. "He comes at the end of a period of destruction going back 50 years. But yes, yes, he is in command now, holder of the black flag, the skull and crossbones."

Sir Vidia, 68, who was knighted in 1990 claimed New Labour's relentless dumbing down and downgrading of the arts had further lowered the battered image of Britain abroad. In the end, the economy will suffer, he warned.

"This is no small thing. Creating a cultural void will have a long-term effect on the economy. Despite being so anti-elitist, the prime minister talks about the great geniuses of this country, as if somehow there is something going on. There is nothing going on. It is all over."

The writer, who has long seen himself as a lone upholder of absolute standards in a decaying world, unleashed his withering attack in an interview with Tatler, the most blue-blooded of glossy magazines, and a publication not until now associated with Olympian intellectual endeavour.

Despite his knighthood, Sir Vidia's own background is far from grand. The son of an Indian civil servant, he overcame poverty and prejudice - and a suicide attempt - to shine at Oxford and become the undisputed star of post-colonial literature in the 60s and 70s.

Whether writing about corruption in Indian politics, or the west's cynical treatment of its former colonies, his writing has been characterised by a moralist's outrage. He won the Booker Prize in 1971 for In A Free State, and dissected the evil at the heart of the cult of personality in his later book, The Return Of Eva Peron.

There are echoes of that hatred of manipulation of the public in his attack on Mr Blair and the language New Labour uses. "I think they don't believe half the things they say and they are trying to find words to cover up their lack of belief."

Despite his curmudgeonly reputation and an outlandishly bitter feud with his former disciple, the equally combative travel writer Paul Theroux, Sir Vidia's words will further wound a prime minister who likes to think of himself as "arts friendly".

During his early career, Sir Vidia was dogged by money worries and loneliness. His first wife, Pat who he met at Oxford and married in 1955 died in 1996. He admits that during the marriage, he slept with prostitutes and had a long term Anglo-Argentinian mistress.

He met his second wife, Lady Nadira Naipaul, at the home of the American consul general in Lahore, where she was a newspaper columnist.

The managing director of FT.com, the Financial Times' flagship website, has quit abruptly, sparking rumours that the operation faces a round of cost-cutting.

Michael Foster, the man credited with transforming FT.com into a global business portal, is leaving the company after turning down an alternative post within the Financial Times Group.

Two senior executives are being brought in to step up the process of integrating the FT Group's on and off-line publications and search for greater efficiencies, a spokesman for Pearson, the FT's owners, said last night.

Staff at FT.com fear the development could result in staff cuts. However, Pearson insists that Mr Foster's departure was entirely amicable and that no job losses were planned.

Zach Leonard, head of the recently launched FTMarketWatch initiative, and Michael Murphy, head of FT business and of the online publication of group magazines, will as sume overall control of FT.com.

"FT.com is maturing fast from a start-up to a substantial business with very strong user and revenue growth," said Financial Times group chief executive Stephen Hill.

"We have already successfully integrated our editorial and advertising teams across our newspapers and our network of business and personal financial websites. We expect major benefits from stepping up the process."

Pearson has invested heavily in FT.com over the last year in an attempt to develop a leading global business portal and compete with the online offering of arch-rival the US based Wall Street Journal.

Under Mr Foster's stewardship, FT.com monthly page impressions have risen from 7m one year ago to 27m. Revenues are forecast to climb from £5m to £16m over the same period.

Mr Hill is determined to build the FT's circulation in the US where it currently lags behind the long-established Wall Street Journal.

webTitle: Gun chase gangster who shot five gets life

fields.headline: Gun chase gangster who shot five gets life
fields.standfirst:
Passers-by fired on and injured as would-be robbers attempted to shake off police in 50-mile pursuit
Gun violence in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: An armed gangster who took a woman hostage and shot five people during a 50-mile car chase was given eight life sentences yesterday.
fields.body:
An armed gangster who took a woman hostage and shot five people during a 50-mile car chase was given eight life sentences yesterday.

Olatunde Adetoro repeatedly fired a Kalashnikov AK47 assault rifle and a Smith and Wesson pistol as he attempted to shake off his police pursuers.

Mr Justice Douglas Brown said the gangster's disregard for human life placed him in a special category of dangerousness. He said he should be released only when he was no longer considered a danger.

The judge told Adetoro, 30, of no fixed address, and his two co-defendants that they had brought real terror to people.

Adetoro was convicted at Manchester crown court of 21 charges including the attempted murder of a police officer, a motorist and cyclist, kidnap, using firearms to resist arrest and threatening to kill a motorist. Francis Dixon, 24, from Newton Heath, Manchester, was given life for carrying firearms with intent to commit robbery. Andrew Dennis, 24, of Failsworth, Manchester, was given 15 years for the same offence.

During a seven-week trial, the jury heard that the episode was one of the most remarkable in recent criminal history. Adetoro decided to shoot passers-by in a desperate attempt to stop police following the gang through Lancashire and Greater Manchester.

The car chase had begun after a chance discovery by a plainclothes policeman of three men kitted out for armed robbery on a slip road of the M6 near Lancaster.

Adetoro and Dennis were chased in one car and Dixon escaped separately. Adetoro put on a balaclava and fired a handgun at police officers who stopped them on the motorway. At traffic lights near Bolton, they ordered Melanie Williams out of her car at gunpoint and drove off in her car.

When they reached Bolton they hijacked a silver BMW and took pedestrian Amanda Ryan hostage - forcing her into the back of the vehicle at gunpoint. She heard Adetoro suggest to Dennis that they should shoot someone.

Their first victim was Peter Hayles, a cable installer, who was shot in the leg by Adetoro as he worked on the main Bury to Rochdale road. A mile later community doctor Saranth Senerath-Yapa was shot as he drove to work - fracturing his arm. Martin McKay Smith, a solicitor, was shot in the leg on his motorcycle as he passed the car. Pensioner James Gallagher was shot in the leg at a bus stop and cyclist David Hassall was hit by a bullet in the back. Other shots narrowly missed police officers.

When Adetoro and Dennis were arrested in Rochdale they were carrying guns, balaclavas and boilersuits. Dixon was caught in Bolton.

Adetoro, who is well connected in the Manchester underworld and is believed to have connections with the West Indian Yardie gangs, said he did not realise it was the police chasing him and he was unable to remember shooting any civilians. He claimed to be in fear of his life.

After the case ended, Detective Superintendent Dave Brown praised the courage of police who were fired on. "They dealt with it with great courage. It is a matter of deep regret that so many innocent people were injured, but we are thankful that no one was killed," he said.

PC Dave Bentley was shot at when he stopped the gunman's car on the motorway. "It was an extremely frightening experience," he said. "I was lucky in that I just ducked and felt the bullet part my hair. If I hadn't ducked, it would have hit me straight in the chest." He has since been unable to work on outside duties.

The doctor who was shot in the arm has been unable to carry out operations since.

webTitle: Hague forced into u-turn on guarantee to cut taxes

fields.headline: Hague forced into u-turn on guarantee to cut taxes
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague last night embarked on the biggest u-turn of his career when he bowed to intense pressure and abandoned his flagship guarantee to cut taxes, regardless of the state of the economy.
fields.body:
William Hague last night embarked on the biggest u-turn of his career when he bowed to intense pressure and abandoned his flagship guarantee to cut taxes, regardless of the state of the economy.

In a humiliating climbdown forced on him by the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, Mr Hague pledged that a Tory government would place spending on health and education above his "tax guarantee".

The dramatic u-turn by the Tory leader was seized on by the government as a sign of weak leadership in the face of relentless criticism of Mr Hague's pledge to cut taxes even if the economy enters a recession. It will also be seen as a victory for Mr Portillo who has already forced Mr Hague to reverse Tory opposition to the minimum wage and Bank of England independence.

Mr Hague did not mince his words as he announced the abolition of the central plank of his common sense revolution - launched amid great fanfare at last year's party conference - in which he pledged that "taxes will fall as a share of the nation's income".

In an interview with the Daily Telegraph, Mr Hague said: "We are being clear - in the event of severe recession, unexpected acts of God or war that our commitments to health, our commitment to prudent economic management will come first. People can be assured that our commitment to reduce taxation does not over-ride prudent economic management or our vital public services."

Ministers reacted with glee last night to Mr Hague's u-turn, describing it as a significant victory for Tony Blair. At their weekly Commons clashes, the prime minister regularly taunts Mr Hague over his tax guarantee, saying that the Tory leader would never be able to match Labour spending on health and education because of his commitment to cut taxes.

But the u-turn was also being seen last night as a significant boost to Mr Portillo, who cast doubt over the tax policy as soon as he was appointed shadow chancellor his year. Mr Portillo told Mr Hague that the Tories had made themselves vulnerable to Labour attacks by guaranteeing key public spending while pledging to cut taxes.

Mr Hague's camp initially tried to hold the line on the tax guarantee, saying that they could match Labour's spending on health and education by cutting £4bn from the welfare budget and from government bureaucracy and regulation. But the policy began to look vulnerable in recent weeks when Mr Hague attempted to regain some of the political centre ground with pledges that health and education would be safe in Tory hands.

The Tories' opponents last night rounded on Mr Hague. Andrew Smith, the chief secretary to the Treasury, said: "You could not believe what the Tories said on tax in government. Now you cannot believe what they say in opposition. Their sums do not add up and people will never trust them again on tax."

Matthew Taylor, the Liberal Democrat treasury spokesman, said: "First we had soft Hague, followed by hard Hague. Now we have can't add up Hague. The tax guarantee was undeliverable and went to the heart of the contradictions in the Tory position. They want to talk about the tax cuts but they know that the electorate do not want public service cuts that go with that."

A host of senior Tories, who dismissed the tax guarantee as a hostage to fortune, will feel vindicated by Mr Hague's u-turn. John Major described the idea as "mad", adding: "How do you deliver that in a recession? You don't. You simply don't unless you make swingeing cuts in the health service and education and the armed forces as are inconceivable."

Mr Hague will see his u-turn as an important piece of housekeeping as he sweeps aside awkward policies in the run-up to the election. But his opponents in the party will say that the move raises new questions about his judgment, overshadowing the blows he has struck against the prime minister. They will say that for all his knockabout success in the Commons, Mr Hague has again been found wanting over a key policy.

fields.headline: Now we're all larging it
fields.standfirst:
Why doing a Euan Blair is now normal in Britain
India Knight's darkest hour

More about Euan Blair

What is Britain: special report
fields.trailText: This summer, a good proportion of British teenagers will successfully convince their parents that Ibiza isn't "like that" for the sensible majority.
fields.body:
This summer, a good proportion of British teenagers will successfully convince their parents that Ibiza isn't "like that" for the sensible majority. The place may have a terrible reputation, fuelled by TV exposés and "what every parent should know" scare stories in the Daily Mail, but, they'll say, they have no desire to join the knickerless hordes in San Antonio or the topless ravers at Space. Far from it, they will say. They and their seven mates intend to spend the two weeks "chilling" and, if they have the time, exploring the "real" Ibiza. "There are some really sweet villages." "Why don't you go to Corfu, then?" their parents, who weren't born yesterday, will suggest. But nothing will put them off.

I wonder if Euan Blair has made any plans for the summer. Presumably he is grounded but I'd be very surprised if Ibiza wasn't on his radar. Where else, after all, would an evening spent lying prone in a pool of vomit be referred to as "having it large"? According to a recent study, of the 700,000 or so young people expected to visit Ibiza this year, roughly a third will be taking ecstasy. But if I were a parent, I would find this statistic less scary than the certainty that everyone who goes there will be pissed from the minute they arrive.

Kids who give themselves credit for not being "stupid" enough to take drugs will think nothing of excessive drinking, believing it a matter of form to down a Sex on the Beach before they hit the town, then a jug of Red Bull and vodka, then a few beers and maybe a chaser, then a glass of the champagne some mate of the DJs gave them in the club. And so it goes on. By 4am they are unconscious and one of the girls they came with is exchanging her thong for a lightstick while her mate is getting her tits out for this bloke who says he's got a jeep. The next day they will sleep for three hours, get up, have a cup of coffee, rinse out their mouths with the Listerene they bought at the airport and repeat the whole routine.

This is not unusual behaviour. As Euan Blair's headmaster noted, "Children are growing up much earlier than they used to", and while this is not, in itself, an explanation for the phenomenon of teenage binge drinking, it does suggest that the problem is much broader than anyone seems to suppose. In spite of the warning signs that the Brits' attitude to drink has gone from being comical to dysfunctional in a generation, we still can't help feeling that getting paralytic is "normal". Through this prism, Euan's antics were just "high spirits" - a "perfectly natural" coda to the end of his O levels and even a rite of passage. For this to be popular opinion, society must have shed its anxieties about alcohol - a fact which may be causal or symptomatic of the weirdly Bacchic atmosphere of the pre- and post-millennial periods. Walk around Soho at night and you'll see revelling to compare with anything San Antonio has to offer, which may be why many adults have a tendency to view their children's exploits as the laughs they insist they are.

These are fairly recent developments. When I was a teenager we got drunk but not hysterically so and always remembered where we'd left our handbags. The people who went for it madly were, at that time, a social sub-group - the "lager louts" you saw on telly who intimidated locals and disrespected holidaying families in Benidorm or Torremolinos. The girls who chose these destinations behaved nothing like the men. If and when they got tipsy it wasn't so much the cue for a mass debauch as the precursor to (yet) another chorus of the Birdie Song. Remember those holiday records? Like Agadoo. They belong to a more innocent age when having fun was a simple matter of snogging waiters and formation dancing.

Fifteen or so years later, Sangria is off the menu and a young girl's idea of paradise is a couple of wraps of charlie and a placing in the mud-wrestling competition. As devotees of the TV docusoap Ibiza Uncovered will know, there's very little difference between the genders in terms of how they choose to enjoy themselves. Men run about shouting obscenities - so do women. Men go about in packs and leer at passers by - so do women. Men moon at tourist coach windows - so do their female companions. Some would doubtless call this equality. It certainly shows that the old-fashioned British lout has been replaced by a strange, many-headed beast. No longer exclusively male or working class, the drunks of Tony Blair's nightmares are as likely to be young female professionals as tattooed, underclass no-marks.

To take Ibiza as a microcosm of the way things are going back home, the drive to excess is no longer linked with any class or gender. Unlike Benidorm, the island's hotspots are as likely to be peopled by Alexandras on their gap years as Terrys on the promise that they won't spend theirs and Sheryl's savings. Hedonism is a great leveller and the House revolution has meant that the middle classes now regard debauchery as their right. Excess is no longer merely escapism for the underprivileged, rather it is the means by which well-balanced high-achievers shore up their worldly gains. Without drugs and drink, it's fair to say, their lifestyles would be unsustainable. The faster the world gets, the longer hours everyone works, the more we put into everything the greater our need for an off switch as decisive as two weeks in Ibiza.

It's hard to see what the government can do about this situation. When drink was linked to disaffection, the answer lay in social policy. Now that it's the motor for our booming economy, it no longer carries a stigma. Getting drunk is as much a part of the fabric of our national life as playing football or watching EastEnders. It's come back into fashion as a way of keeping everything great - its function no longer to alleviate misery but to fuel all kinds of achievement, from good exams to corporate promotions. In this sense, alcohol is the oil which prevents us from being ground down by the demands of our daily lives. The more we are required to "keep pace" and make the most of our potential, the harder it is to resist the lure of low-level hooliganism. However keen we may seem superficially on all the "great advances" and successes we have made, there's something about the British that isn't at ease with modernity. Our medieval drinking habits are just one of the manifestations of our desire to stick two fingers up at progress while being far too cowardly to halt its forward march.

A passage too far from India

Am I alone in wishing a bit of ill fortune on India Knight? Her rise to fame - due largely to her unfailing ability to talk about make-up in the face of adversity - always seemed to me a puzzle. One minute she was writing emails about the latest lip gloss for her dying friend Ruth Picardie, the next she was being offered untold funds to write about it for the Sunday Times. Her uniquely defiant stance on why, as a Clever Woman, she should not be prevented from drivelling on about mules, won her a lot of admirers among men who like to hear women going on like that. I've never heard a good thing about India Knight from a woman.

For the people it is actually aimed at, My Life On a Plate is set to be a big disappointment. Unlike Bridget Jones, it isn't funny, charming or familiar. There's nothing to identify with. Its heroine, Clara, is too much India to make it as Everywoman. No one's going to think, "My god, that's me", just a no one else would live in a house like India's or holiday with the Self family. In its every detail, India's life and outlook is unique. Which might have been OK if it had gained something in the translation. As it is, reading My Life is a little like looking at the holiday slides of someone you don't give a fig for. Uninteresting themselves and less appealing than a postcard of the locations they cover, you wonder why they thought that anyone would want to follow their progress through this market and that tourist attraction. You get the same feeling for India's ouevre. You're never going to go there, so why bother?

Unlike Bridget Jones, it isn't funny, charming or familiar. There's nothing to identify with. Its heroine, Clara, is too much India to make it as Everywoman. No one's going to think, "My god, that's me", just a no one else would live in a house like India's or holiday with the Self family. In its every detail, India's life and outlook is unique. Which might have been OK if it had gained something in the translation. As it is, reading My Life is a little like looking at the holiday slides of someone you don't give a fig for. Uninteresting themselves and less appealing than a postcard of the locations they cover, you wonder why they thought that anyone would want to follow their progress through this market and that tourist attraction. You get the same feeling for India's ouevre. You're never going to go there, so why bother?

fields.headline: Labour abandons roads plans
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The introduction of motorway tolls is to be abandoned by the government to prevent a backlash from motorists, ministerial sources confirmed last night.
fields.body:
The introduction of motorway tolls is to be abandoned by the government to prevent a backlash from motorists, ministerial sources confirmed last night.

The issue is so politically sensitive that Downing Street has decided to rule it out for 10 years when it makes a statement on transport spending next week. The levies had the support of the Treasury and John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, who runs the transport department, and were endorsed by business on the basis that they would raise money and ease congestion.

The news is likely to be coupled with an announcement that the government has decided not to embark on a huge road building programme. It was stressed in Whitehall that while more money is to be spent, it will only be at agreed "hot spots " - places of extreme congestion.

Motorway tolls, together with the introduction, in the near future, of congestion charging in city centres, have been pressed on the prime minister by the Treasury and Mr Prescott. But Tony Blair has overruled them and opted for a cautious approach. In effect, this means a return to the status quo.

The introduction of tolls on some motorways, including the M1, M4 and M6, had formed part of the government's transport white paper published two years ago. But fear of upsetting middle-class voters in the lead up to the election has convinced ministers that it is better to scrap the plan for the foreseeable future.

Whitehall sources also said there will be no new road or motorway building over the decade, apart from the 40 schemes currently in the road building plan. Many are bypasses round towns.

The government will spend more on roads, but will identify what it calls "hot spots". It wants to combine road widening with improving public transport in congested areas.

Ministerial sources said the M25 will not be widened further in spite of increasing congestion in the stretch between Heathrow and Gatwick airports. The M6 could be widened, but only where there is bad congestion in the Midlands and around Manchester.

Ministers say they want to study the impact of the first privatised tolled motorway, the proposed Birmingham ring road, which will bypass the busy Midlands section of the M6, before deciding whether to extend the idea.

This rules out a decision for many years. Work has not even started on the Birmingham project, which Labour inherited from the Tories.

The revised plan will infuriate the roads lobby. Signs from the government had encouraged it to think that Labour was ready to sink more money into roads.

Ministers are to argue that they do not need the money which would have been collected from tolls to be spent on improving public transport. They believe they will eventually collect revenue from the introduction of congestion charging in large cities and towns. But the schemes will take some years to put into place and the first one may not be operating until 2005.

Mr Prescott has worked hard on winning over the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to congestion charging. This has produced Treasury forecasts that £1bn a year could be raised by local authorities from charging motorists to drive into city centres at peak hours. The money would be spent on transport improvements.

But ministerial sources were arguing yesterday that the timescale for the schemes is lengthening, and they may not be introduced by a new Labour government. Ken Livingstone, the mayor of London, is in favour of introducing charges, and Birmingham, Manchester and Leeds are among provincial cities studying them with various degrees of enthusiasm.

First call Internet portal Yahoo!'s content is to be made available to British mobile phone users for the first time, following an agreement with Virgin Mobile . Customers accessing Sir Richard Branson's virtual mobile phone network will be able to access Yahoo! news, finance, sport and other content.

webTitle: Pace claims digital TV to oust PCs

fields.headline: Pace claims digital TV to oust PCs
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Pace Micro Technology, the world's biggest maker of set-top boxes, yesterday predicted the number of British homes connected to digital television would exceed those that own a personal computer by the end of the year.
fields.body:
Pace Micro Technology, the world's biggest maker of set-top boxes, yesterday predicted the number of British homes connected to digital television would exceed those that own a personal computer by the end of the year.

Digital television is now in one in four homes and is expected to rise to one in three homes by year end as viewers opt to have services such as email and online banking through their television rather than purchase a PC as well. PC ownership is hovering at around 25%, said Pace Micro.

Shares in Pace Micro fell 8.2% to 894.5p yesterday, despite the company reporting a 59% leap in pre-tax profits to £24m. The profitability was buoyed by a 146% increase in set-top box sales to 2m. Turnover was up 106% to £377.6m as digital broadcasters like BSkyB and OnDigital continued to buy set-top boxes in bulk and give them away to attract customers.

Pace Micro's declining share price, however, was partly caused by the announcement that two directors would sell 6% of the company raising £118m. Pace Micro co-founder and non-executive director David Hood is expected to pocket £100m, while operations director Robert Fleming should gain £18m.

Malcolm Miller, chief executive of Pace Micro, also said that the company's gross margin had dropped substantially from 26.5% to 19.7% after the prices of components used inside the set-top boxes failed to fall as expected.

"In the short term, we do not see that this situation will improve and we anticipate continued tightness in component supply," Mr Miller said.

Williams de Broe has put a "sell" on the stock and has raised concerns about the component shortage, which means the company is unlikely to generate generous profits from its rapid growth.

Pace Micro said 92% of its sales were sourced in Britain in the past year. However, it has recently signed contracts in the US with cable firms Time Warner and Comcast, which have 12m and 8m subscribers respectively. A large boost in sales to the US is expected to reduce the company's reliance on Britain. It is seeking to have 30% of its sales from exports within two years and 50% shortly after that.

Its strong growth is also expected to see the company hire more software and hardware engineers, with suggestions in the industry that Pace Micro is seeking at least a further 200 staff in this area to add to its team of 394.

Mr Miller said the company was confident of continued growth in the next 12 months.

Pace Micro recently signed a contract with Invensys to develop technology for handheld devices to operate household electrical appliances. The aim is also to make the appliances "smart" so they can be programmed to operate at a certain time or so that the appliance can alert the homeowner via the handheld device of any faults.

The company is also considering putting technology into its set-top boxes that allow the pay-TV operators to offer more content to its subscribers.

fields.headline: Antfactory in $100m Latin America drive
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Antfactory, the internet investment company that specialises in supporting the online strategies of old economy companies, yesterday announced it is to invest $100m (£67m) in the Latin American market in partnership with one of the region's leading private equity firms.
fields.body:
Antfactory, the internet investment company that specialises in supporting the online strategies of old economy companies, yesterday announced it is to invest $100m (£67m) in the Latin American market in partnership with one of the region's leading private equity firms.

The London-based company is jointly funding the venture with CVC Latin America, a private equity unit of Citigroup. They hope to bring in other strategic partners from the region.

Latin America is seen as one of the internet's great untapped growth areas.

Antfactory hopes to help old economy firms in the region take their brands and businesses online by leveraging existing customer bases and distribution networks. Typically it will take on operational control of the online business in return for financial assistance and a significant equity stake.

Offices have been opened in Sao Paulo, Mexico City and Buenos Aires.

Chief executive Harpal Randhawa said Antfactory Latin America had agreed to invest $6m in an unnamed business-to-business portal and online aggregator of healthcare products and services. It hopes to link the region's patients, medical practitioners and insurers.

Analysts say the health industry is one of the most likely to benefit from being taken online. However, shares in leading US online health companies such as Dr Koop and Healtheon Web MD have failed to set the market alight.

Last month Antfactory raised $150m, taking the total it has raised since set-up nine months ago to $545m.

fields.headline: Violence at Ulster shutdown
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Orange Order supporters brought much of Northern Ireland to a halt last night, mounting hundreds of roadblocks in the biggest coordinated campaign of civil disobedience in the province for at least four years.
fields.byline: John Mullin  in Belfast and Jamie Wilson  in Portadown
fields.body:
Orange Order supporters brought much of Northern Ireland to a halt last night, mounting hundreds of roadblocks in the biggest coordinated campaign of civil disobedience in the province for at least four years.

The protests, scheduled to end at 8pm, were continuing late last night. They had initially been peaceful, but violence soon broke out for the ninth successive night, with several cars set alight.

Johnny Adair, the notorious Ulster Freedom Fighter, was present at one of the biggest protests, in north Belfast.

Loyalist protesters clashed with nationalists in Lurgan, Co Armagh, one of several towns cut off to outside traffic. Riot police came under attack after moving in to quell fighting, and the RUC seized several pipe bombs and scores of petrol bombs.

They also evacuated nearby Portadown after a bomb hoax, and were engaged in fighting with loyalists on the Corcrain estate, where RUC officers baton-charged a group of 300 loyalist protesters. Witnesses described seeing elderly women being kicked by police.

Security forces fear more problems tomorrow as thousands of Orangemen converge close to the nationalist Lower Ormeau Road in Belfast.

But protests surrounding the Drumcree crisis in 1996 were worse. Then, ports and Belfast International Airport were blockaded for days.

Orangemen in Portadown said the response to their call for last night's protests demonstrated overwhelming support for their quest to march down the nationalist Garvaghy road. They were banned on Sunday from completing their parade down their preferred route for the third year running, and are blocked at Drumcree.

David Jones, spokesman for the Portadown district, refused to accept responsibility for the violence. He instead blamed the parades commission, the independent body ruling on contentious demonstrations, and the government.

He warned of more protests, saying: "We want these demonstrations to send a signal to the secretary of state. We aim to force the abolition of the parades commission."

Business leaders said they were left with no option but to send home thousands of workers before the protests got under way at 4pm. Tourists left early and workers began heading home at 3pm, leading to gridlock in parts of Belfast. By the time protesters were beginning to build barricades, roads were deserted.

Frank Caddy, chief executive of the Belfast chamber of commerce, said: "This is threatening businesses and jobs. It makes us look terrible, and hardly helps the fight to attract investment."

There were signs again yesterday of splits within Orangeism.The Grand Lodge of Ireland, the governing body, issued a demand for last night's protests to be peaceful, and significantly omitted to give explicit backing to the Portadown district's call.

Several lodges refused to back the protests, believing the involvement of loyalist paramilitaries is undermining the Orange Order's reputation. Unlike previous years, there has been scant political support, even among hardline unionists.

webTitle: Back-bedroom inventor with a yen for private jets

fields.headline: Back-bedroom inventor with a yen for private jets
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: David Hood is expected to receive a £100m windfall from Pace Micro Technology, the business he co-founded in his Yorkshire bedroom in 1982.
fields.body:
David Hood is expected to receive a £100m windfall from Pace Micro Technology, the business he co-founded in his Yorkshire bedroom in 1982.

Mr Hood, 52, now a non-executive director of the set-top box maker, is to sell 11m shares while Robert Fleming , the operations director, plans to sell about £18m of his stock.

The low-profile Mr Hood became one of Britain's richest men when he took £100m in cash from Pace Micro's listing in 1996, a year in which he also received an OBE in the Queen's Birthday Honours.

Mr Hood designed the satellite television decoder that transformed Pace Micro into a leading electronics manufacturer and formed the basis of its flotation. More an inventor than businessman, his design for one of the first portable modems had given the company its first revenues.

His passion for flying has him listed as one of the new-rich British who like getting around by private jet.

He will invest proceeds from the sale in his other business interests, including Multiflight, an aviation company.

Mr Fleming plans to spend his share on historic aircraft.

fields.headline: Tory frontbenchers 'should give up directorships'
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Conservative frontbenchers in the Commons and Lords should lose their lucrative directorships and put all their shares in blind trusts, Lord Neill's committee on standards in public life was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Conservative frontbenchers in the Commons and Lords should lose their lucrative directorships and put all their shares in blind trusts, Lord Neill's committee on standards in public life was told yesterday.

The proposal from the Labour backbench MP Fraser Kemp came as the Tories argued before the committee for "no change" in a rule that allows them not to declare their business interests in the Lords' register.

Lord Mackay, the former Tory lord chancellor, told the committee that he did not see the need for "a millimetre, centimetre or metre" change to the system. At present 200 peers do not declare anything in the register. He added that the "intrusiveness" of the mandatory register in the Commons "is damaging MPs and it saddens me that the public just fall apart laughing when they read that so and so has a ticket to the FA Cup Final and has declared it."

Mr Kemp has submitted a "dirty dozen" list of Tory frontbenchers who could face potential conflicts of interest. These include Treasury spokesmen David Heathcoat-Amory and Howard Flight who have City interests, health spokesman Liam Fox who has shares in a medical education company and culture spokesman John Greenway who advises ITV.

Archie Norman, environment spokesman, is a director of Knutsford which specialises in retail and property. Opposition peers' leader Lord Strathclyde said later that he had been told some people would not want to continue serving in the House of Lords if the regime on disclosure of interests was changed. He argued there was no need to change a system which worked perfectly well.

webTitle: Throwing out time at the Unfunny Politician

fields.headline: Throwing out time at the Unfunny Politician
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The Commons is always at its best when it's discussing a topic it can actually do something about. Interest rates, globalisation, French foreign policy - all these are beyond the control of MPs and ministers. Their debates on these subjects are as futile as endless discussion of the weather; it's nice to get it off your chest but it doesn't prevent one drop of rain falling.
fields.body:
The Commons is always at its best when it's discussing a topic it can actually do something about. Interest rates, globalisation, French foreign policy - all these are beyond the control of MPs and ministers. Their debates on these subjects are as futile as endless discussion of the weather; it's nice to get it off your chest but it doesn't prevent one drop of rain falling.

The naming of pubs is different. Yesterday the culture secretary, Chris Smith, answered a planted question with a jeremiad against trendy brewers.

"There is a growing fashion for rebranding pubs with names like" - and here his voice took on an air of fastidious distaste - "the Dog and Doughnut and the Goose and Granite."

A nice spin doctor (they're not all arrogant nitwits) told us later that these two places really exist, in Cheltenham and Dulwich. He added that this was a subject on which Mr Smith felt strongly.

(Ministers now remind me of the old joke about the man who says : "In my family I take all the key decisions, such as whether Red China should join the UN, and my wife takes the minor ones, like where we go for our holidays." Mr Smith was marking the brochures.)

"We are surely in danger of losing local history and our local folk memory; I hope the brewers will think twice before destroying this link with the past," he went on. "Certainly, consulting regulars and the community is not too much to ask."

(I think he is a little unfair. I used to live near a pub with the silly name of The Frog and Nightgown, which was named after a fictitious pub in the radio series, Ray's A Laugh. It was near The World Turned Upside Down, whose sign showed footballs playing cricket on one side, and cricket balls playing football on the other. Both had dotty names, but genuine roots.)

There then followed an example of parliamentary humour, which causes MPs to laugh riotously but which makes most people's toes curl involuntarily and a red flush to crawl down from their scalps. Mr Geoffrey Clifton-Brown rose and asked "how many pubs in the country called 'The Spinner' might there be?"

Tories rolled around merrily at a gag so feeble that it might have been eschewed by Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned. Mr Smith replied: "I suspect that the number is similar to that of pubs called 'The Silly Question'." This time it was Labour's turn to whoop at a joke which in any comedy club would have evinced whistles and cries of "Taxi for Mr Smith!"

But this was vintage Oscar Wilde compared to the discussion of the Millennium Dome. Denis MacShane had taken four children there. We held our breath. Surely the ultimate New Labour loyalist would not breathe a word against the dome, and, phew, he did not.

"We had eight hours of information, education and fun, all for 57 quid!" he said. What got him were "the whingeing, whining wallies and the anti-dome dumpers of the party opposite!" I enjoyed the dome but I think I'll be careful of returning if there's a chance of finding MacShane there telling me what a marvellous time I'm having.

Peter Ainsworth, the Tory spokesman, had a suggestion to boost visitor numbers: a quiz, with only one question. "What have in common: the debt-ridden dome, the closed millennium bridge, the U-turn on free admission to museums, the fiasco over Wembley, the failure of our World Cup bid?" he yelled.

The answer was, as you've guessed, that Chris Smith was responsible for the lot, but so lumpish and poorly timed was this gag that almost nobody laughed, and again Mr Smith got away with it.

webTitle: Cable knit takes edge off chill

fields.headline: Cable knit takes edge off chill
fields.trailText: A chill wind has blown through the technology sector since the collapse of the Nasdaq index in the spring but certain sectors remain hot. One is optical networking, and news of a mega-merger in the US was enough to bring further gains for Oxford's Bookham Technology yesterday.
fields.body:
A chill wind has blown through the technology sector since the collapse of the Nasdaq index in the spring but certain sectors remain hot. One is optical networking, and news of a mega-merger in the US was enough to bring further gains for Oxford's Bookham Technology yesterday.

Shares in the optical technology specialist, £10.00 on flotation in April, surged 440p to £46.60 in the wake of the $41bn all-stock merger of fibre optics makers JDS Uniphase and SDL.

Dealers said it was good news for Bookham on two fronts. Bookham supplies JDS with arrayed wave guides, crucial in the transmission of data along fibre optic cables. Merger with SDL means a bigger potential market for AWD. The deal also gives a pointer to Bookham's worth.

"There aren't too many companies is this area and evidence of consolidation can only be good news," one sector specialist said.

Bookham is due to report second-quarter results on August 9 and strong figures are expected.

Despite the fine performance of Bookham, the FTSE 100 closed the session down 31.3 points lower at 6,466.2. Volume was a meagre 950m by the official close of trade as institutional investors sat on their hands.

London's equity market faces a number of tests this week starting with figures from internet group Yahoo! today and ending with US producer price figures on Friday.

Dealers fear that weak figures from Yahoo! or Motorola on Wednesday could see valuations of new economy stocks questioned again. This was reflected in the Techmark closing down 41.88 at 3,404.75.

A weak performance from the Nasdaq hit accountancy software specialist Sage, down 27.5p at 522p, Anglo-Dutch software group CMG, 56p lower at 932p, and Misys, off 20p at 540p.

HSBC and Standard Chartered offered some support for the market. Both prospered after a trip to Hong Kong by a leading broker triggered a reappraisal of their prospects. Citing improving operating conditions, loan volumes and margins in the former colony, Deutsche Bank lifted its rating on HSBC to "market perform" and on Standard to "buy".

Deutsche said its preference for Standard reflected its higher exposure to the region (70% of Standard's pre-provision profit comes from Asia Pacific as opposed to 46% at HSBC) and its attractive valuation (Standard is on a forward p/e ratio of 12.6). Shares in Standard finished up 33p at 888p and HSBC closed 18.5p better at 767p.

But Lloyds TSB continued to suffer, falling 25.5p to 584p. Expectations that interim figures on July 28 will prove disappointing were to blame.

Telewest improved 8p to 242p as Nomura and Dresdner Kleinwort Benson reportedly reiterated their "buy" stances on the stock after Microsoft's decision to limit its investment in the cable group to a minority stake.

Nycomed Amersham was the FTSE 100's worst performer, down 32p to 668p after HSBC Securities lowered its rating to "hold" from "buy".

Among second-tier stocks, communications and marketing group Aegis, down 0.5p at 189p, attracted attention following a block trade of 27.9m shares. However, brokers quickly dismissed talk of stake-building, pointing out that the trade related to a big shareholder switching stake between funds. Aegis' two biggest shareholders are Deutsche Bank and Putnam, with stakes of 11.2% and 8.21% respectively.

Strong full-year figures from set-top box maker Pace Micro Technology were overshadowed by concerns over margins and news that two directors are to sell 13m shares. It fell 78.5p to 896p.

But Independent Energy topped the FTSE 250 performance table. Shares in the power distribution company, which last month announced a strategic review after problems with its billing system, closed 167.5p up at 685p. Dealers played down merger speculation, pointing out that real reason behind the strong performance was a surge in the group's US-listed shares on Friday.

Navan on the move

Long-standing Irish metals exploration punt Navan Resources is changing its name to Navan Mining and shifting its domicile from Dublin to London. While the stock has burnt the fingers of careless investors in the past, there are genuine hopes that the price will make headway when trading starts this morning on the official lists of the London and Irish stock exchanges.

House broker SG Securi ties has set a target price of 84p against yesterday's quote of 52.5p and rates the shares a "strong buy". It is excited by the prospects for its new Spanish zinc mine and reckons a Bulgarian copper/gold prospect offers dramatic (if unproven) turnaround potential.

There are also strong hopes for a second mine in Bulgaria.

The shares are a speculative, short-term buy.

webTitle: MPs attack 'precarious' New Deal jobs that last only weeks

fields.headline: MPs attack 'precarious' New Deal jobs that last only weeks
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's initiative to tackle youth unemployment is placing tens of thousands of people in precarious jobs which last no more than a few weeks, a cross-party Commons committee reports today.
fields.body:
Labour's initiative to tackle youth unemployment is placing tens of thousands of people in precarious jobs which last no more than a few weeks, a cross-party Commons committee reports today.

In a strong attack on the £670m New Deal programme, Labour and Tory MPs express concern that ministers appear to have shown little interest in what they call "false start" jobs.

The jobs programme, which is held up by Tony Blair as one of the government's finest achievements, uses money raised from the windfall tax on privatised industries to provide special training for young people. Since it was established in 1998, 215,000 young people have been found jobs.

But the report by the Commons education and employment committee found that 25% of those who obtained jobs through the New Deal have found themselves out of work within 13 weeks. Expressing concern at such "precarious employment", the MPs say: "We are concerned by the relatively high level of moves into unsustained jobs."

Ministers come in for criticism for their failure to employ people from the New Deal in government departments. A mere 675 New Deal workers are employed in the entire civil service. "We are very disappointed that, almost two years on, the public sector has not proved more willing to offer job opportunities to New Deal participants," the MPs say.

They also criticise the programme for failing to provide adequate support for ex-offenders and drug users. "Future developments must be aimed at improving [the New Deal's] performance in helping the most disadvantaged participants and participants from non-white ethnic minority groups to obtain sustained jobs."

A row over funding of the programme broke out yesterday after details of the select committee report were leaked. Tessa Jowell, the employment minister, told the committee earlier this year that each New Deal job costs £4,000, a figure she reached by dividing the £650m costs of the scheme by the 215,000 jobs which have been created.

Graham Brady, a Tory member of the committee, said that the true cost was nearer £11,000 because most of the jobs would have been created anyway by the booming economy. Ms Jowell accused him using wild figures to attack the initiative.

fields.headline: Universities to teach detection
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Dixon of Dock Green will be spinning in his grave. Britain's next generation of detectives are to learn the art of investigation in universities rather than on the beat.
fields.body:
Dixon of Dock Green will be spinning in his grave. Britain's next generation of detectives are to learn the art of investigation in universities rather than on the beat.

Lady Blackstone, education minister, announced yesterday that Anglia Polytechnic University and Portsmouth University were drawing up plans with the police to provide courses in the "detection and investigation of crime".

The announcement, appalling to police officers who believe that the university of life provides the best training ground for detectives, received a warm welcome in the Lords.

The Conservative peer Lord Campbell of Croy thought a BA in detection would at last provide recognition of the intellectual prowess of detectives.

"Detectives in fiction have not been short of intellectual erudition - for example, Sherlock Holmes, Hercule Poirot and Inspector Maigret," he said. "But the detective's role in police forces is not highly regarded, and it doesn't seem to lead to the higher ranks."

Lord Mackenzie of Framwellgate, a Labour peer and a former detective, looked forward to the promotion of career detectives. The policy of many forces of moving CID officers back to uniformed duty after three to five years had "destroyed the concept of a career detective".

webTitle: Oil price surge drives up manufacturing costs

fields.headline: Oil price surge drives up manufacturing costs
fields.trailText: The first signs that the recent surge in world oil prices is feeding inflationary pressures in the British economy emerged yesterday when government figures showed that the price of goods leaving the factory gate is increasing at its fastest rate in four years.
fields.body:
The first signs that the recent surge in world oil prices is feeding inflationary pressures in the British economy emerged yesterday when government figures showed that the price of goods leaving the factory gate is increasing at its fastest rate in four years.

Producers increased output prices by 0.4% last month, according to the office for national statistics. This brought the annual rate of factory gate inflation to 2.9% - its highest level since April 1996.

Though now easing, oil prices more than doubled in the past year and increased manufacturing costs. The ONS said the price of fuels and materials rose 1.4% in May, pushing the annual rate up to 14.1%.

Rising producer output prices are usually taken as a warning sign of future in creases in retail prices. However, some analysts said it was too early to panic about a general pick-up of price pressures in industry.

The underlying measure of factory gate prices, which strips out volatile components such as petrol and food, was much more subdued, showing a rise of just 0.2% over the month and an annual increase of 1.1%.

"The rise in output prices is still very much an oil price phenomenon," said Jonathan Loynes at HSBC markets. "Core output prices remain weak at 1.1% and could therefore reverse quickly if oil prices drop back."

Mr Loynes said the link between factory gate price rises and inflation on the high street appeared to have weakened in recent years in any case. "Because of the growing importance of consumer price sensitivity, it's harder for retailers to automatically pass on manufacturers' price increases."

Business confidence among financial services firms has fallen for the first time in 1 years, separate figures released by the Confederation of British Industry showed yesterday. Securities traders reported the sharpest falls, followed by building societies and insurance brokers.

The CBI survey will add to a growing body of evidence suggesting that the economy is coming off the boil. "Business growth is easing after the hectic pace seen in the second half of last year," said Sudhir Junankar, the CBI's associate director of economic analysis. "Firms are becoming increasingly concerned about the level of domestic competition and its likely impact on business over the coming year."
