webTitle: Black gold takes its toll on margins

fields.headline: Black gold takes its toll on margins
fields.standfirst: Shops cushioned from oil shock
fields.trailText: The oil price matters. A good rule of thumb is that when the cost of black gold goes shooting up, the world economy comes crashing down. That was true in the wake of the Yom Kippur war in 1973, it was true when the conflict between Iraq and Iran flared up in the late 70s and it was true when Saddam Hussein's troops invaded Kuwait in the summer of 1990.
fields.body:
The oil price matters. A good rule of thumb is that when the cost of black gold goes shooting up, the world economy comes crashing down. That was true in the wake of the Yom Kippur war in 1973, it was true when the conflict between Iraq and Iran flared up in the late 70s and it was true when Saddam Hussein's troops invaded Kuwait in the summer of 1990.

Bill Clinton has been sufficiently concerned about the possible consequences of a fourth oil shock to put diplomatic pressure on Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest producer, to break ranks with the rest of the Opec cartel and start pumping more crude. But, as yesterday's British producer price data showed, the effects of demand outstripping supply are already being felt by industry. Fuel and raw material costs for manufacturers are up by 14% over the past year.

Traditionally, producer prices are a harbinger of prices in the shops. Manufacturers pass increased costs on to their customers - retailers - who in turn make consumers pay through the nose. Higher inflation leads to higher interest rates, and before you know it firms are going bust.

So is history about to repeat itself? The answer, tentatively but for a number of different reasons, is no. First, the oil price is not that high in real terms.

Despite the 14% increase over the past year, industry's fuel and raw material costs are still more than 6% down on 1995 levels, and there would need to be a further 14% increase over the coming 12 months - and then some - for the price to reach the same level as it hit after the Iran-Iraq war.

Second, a combination of a slowing US economy and restraint by Opec producers (who know that their long-term interests are not served by a recession in the West) should mean that oil prices will hold steady or even fall back slightly over the coming months.

Finally, the transmission mechanism between factory gate and retail prices is less powerful than it once was. While fuel and raw material costs are up by 14% over the past year, industry's output prices have risen 2.9% and the cost of goods to retail consumers was 2.3% lower in April than a year earlier. Consumer mentality has changed, and manufacturers know it.

The impact of dearer fuel will be felt on profit margins rather than in the high street.

Accountability

Big shareholders in Vodafone AirTouch appear unanimous in their irritation over the £10m cash and shares bonus meted out to chief executive Chris Gent, as reward for pulling off the takeover of Mannesmann of Germany.

What appears to be causing the controversy now, however, is quite what can be done about it. One senior fund manager was horrified last night at the recommendation by the National Association of Pension Funds that shareholders should abstain in the vote at this month's annual general meeting on Mr Gent's re-election to the board.

The advice is seen as trivial, if only because the institutions are very happy with Mr Gent's work turning the mobile company into a communications powerhouse.

What is clear is that the real cause of shareholder angst is the way fund managers heard about the bonus: according to one fund manger, letters detailing plans to alter the share-based performance schemes went out in May and the details of Mr Gent's special deal emerged during subsequent discussions with the company on stopping performance-based awards to non-executive directors.

So Vodafone might have not have got into this mess in the first place if it had told shareholders about the bonus earlier - and putting the detail in the reams of documents associated with the Mannesmann takeover would have been sensible, despite the hostile timing. However awkward, Mr Gent and his team should remember that the people who own the business he is running do actually matter.

Bubble burst

Oxygen, the internet investment shell company which sucked in more amateur punters than many of its kind during the market's six months of dottiness, has come up with a new wheeze which threatens to reduce the wealth of its shareholders further. They will be able to act as parallel investors in the start-up ventures which Oxygen's "young expert team" identifies, essentially buying shares directly in Oxygen's investments in relation to the number of Oxygen shares they already hold. But the effect of this is to magnify shareholders' risk, since they will simply be buying a bigger stake in each new-fangled venture. Any Oxygen shareholders who bought during the bubble phase of this company's development probably know how destructive risk can be: the shares have fallen from a high of 65p to 5.5p.

Bubble burst Oxygen, the internet investment shell company which sucked in more amateur punters than many of its kind during the market's six months of dottiness, has come up with a new wheeze which threatens to reduce the wealth of its shareholders further. They will be able to act as parallel investors in the start-up ventures which Oxygen's "young expert team" identifies, essentially buying shares directly in Oxygen's investments in relation to the number of Oxygen shares they already hold. But the effect of this is to magnify shareholders' risk, since they will simply be buying a bigger stake in each new-fangled venture. Any Oxygen shareholders who bought during the bubble phase of this company's development probably know how destructive risk can be: the shares have fallen from a high of 65p to 5.5p.

fields.headline: Bulmer looks for £150m beer deal
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest cider brewer, HP Bulmer, could announce an acquisition worth £150m in the next 18 months, according to chief executive, Mike Hughes.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest cider brewer, HP Bulmer, could announce an acquisition worth £150m in the next 18 months, according to chief executive, Mike Hughes.

Mr Hughes said yesterday the company was looking at a number of beer branding and partnership deals which could broaden the group's market.

He said the company, which is valued at £200m, would fund any major purchase through issuing shares. Such a move could again call into question the Bulmer family's 50% stake in the company. Alan Flockhart, financial director said the family would be behind any board strategy, but that no specific plans were in place.

Esmond Bulmer, yesterday announced his intention to step down after 40 years as chairman, further fuelling speculation that pressure could be brought on the family to reduce their shareholding. That would allow the board to pursue its aim of transforming HP Bulmer into "a £1bn company" by 2004.

The group, which makes Strongbow, Woodpecker and Scrumpy Jack ciders, has made a number of acquisitions over the past year.

They include a £32m purchase of British independent drinks wholesaler Beer Seller in April and a £19m deal to buy the American Hard Cider Company last November - giving Bulmers 40% of the US cider market.

Annual results, released yesterday, showed underlying profit for the year to April 28 up 14% to £28.4m - £1m above analysts' predictions. Turnover was up 6% to £335m and the annual dividend was increased by 10% to 17.6p per share.

Analysts have set expectations for the new financial year at £30-£32m. Shares closed up 17.5p at 510p.

webTitle: Hague forces PM into power debate

fields.headline: Hague forces PM into power debate
fields.standfirst:
Tory leader portrays himself as champion of parliament

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague last night stepped up the pressure on Tony Blair's wobbling administration when he challenged the prime minister to a Commons debate on his record of undermining the authority of parliament since 1997.
fields.body:
William Hague last night stepped up the pressure on Tony Blair's wobbling administration when he challenged the prime minister to a Commons debate on his record of undermining the authority of parliament since 1997.

The Tory leader's decision to open Thursday's debate on "the transfer of power from parliament to the executive" effectively forced Mr Blair to respond in person - making it his seventh scheduled Commons encounter planned for the next fortnight.

The prime minister's aides deny he is overtired, though some ministers think otherwise. To show he is in charge Mr Blair had arranged four Commons statements, plus two sessions of prime minister's questions with a long flight to and from the economic summit (G8) in Japan in the middle of them.

The Tories believe Mr Blair is vulnerable over his barely disguised disdain for parliament and last night issued figures to show that he has voted less than any recent premier - in just 10% of divisions - and also debates far less.

Mr Hague rubbed the point in yesterday when he pledged himself to restore twice weekly sessions of PMQs if he wins the coming election as a contribution towards the growing cross-party campaign for "proper democratic accountability".

In endorsing calls to give backbench select committees greater independence from government - by taking appointments away from the party whips - the Conservative leader set himself up as a parliamentary champion in direct opposition to Mr Blair.

One of Labour's first acts in 1997 was to combine the 15-minute PMQs on Tuesdays and Thursdays - a tradition since the 1960s - into a single 30-minute session on Wednesday. Downing Street says he takes more questions that way, but MPs feel that accountability is reduced.

Yesterday the Tory leader called it proof of Mr Blair's "total disdain for the House of Commons and proper democratic accountability". He said: "I want to see the prime minister of the day held properly accountable to the representatives of the British people," and promised two 20-minute sessions a week.

Today Mr Blair will move the traditional motion of congratulations to the Queen Mother for her 100th birthday. On Thursday he will unveil the government's annual report, risking certain complaints that he is sidelining Mo Mowlam, the cabinet office minister whose predecessor, Jack Cunningham, did it last year. He will also report on G8 and introduce the NHS national plan on July 26 after Gordon Brown, the only senior minister who refuses to be upstaged, has unveiled the comprehensive spending review on July 18.

Mr Hague was speaking yesterday to mark publication of his party's Norton commission, a series of proposals for "strengthening parliament." It coincided with Margaret Beckett, leader of the Commons, being forced to justify the government's rejection of a reform package put up by the all-party liaison committee, the 33 chairmen of all Commons committees.

As in Margaret Thatcher's heyday older MPs on both sides are concerned about the inbalance of power between the legislature and the executive in a Commons where Labour's 177-seat majority is impregnable. But the liaison committee's crucial proposal that they rather than the party whips pick who goes on select committees - and who gets taken off for making trouble for ministers - was rejected last week by the government.

Appearing before the committee yesterday Mrs Beckett called the change fundamentally flawed and a recipe for conflict. The report produced by the Hull political scientist, Lord Norton of Louth, contains nearly 90 recommendations, some simple like debates ending at 8 or 9pm, others highly ambitious - like cutting the number of MPs - or technical. "If parliament is to call government effectively to account we believe that ministers - and indeed members - must be brought back into the chamber," Lord Norton, himself a Tory peer, said. His proposals include:

 Cutting the size of the cabinet (23) to a maximum of 20.

 Not allowing more than five questions to the prime minister to allow more in-depth exchanges on subjects.

 Forcing ministers to announce important proposals to parliament rather than the media by changing the ministerial code of conduct.

webTitle: IPC snaps up Prima with Gruner & Jahr stablemates

fields.headline: IPC snaps up Prima with Gruner & Jahr stablemates
fields.trailText: IPC is to buy rival publisher Gruner & Jahr UK, adding the titles Prima, Best, Your Home, Focus and Prima Baby to its stable of consumer magazines.
fields.body:
IPC is to buy rival publisher Gruner & Jahr UK, adding the titles Prima, Best, Your Home, Focus and Prima Baby to its stable of consumer magazines.

Final touches are being put to a deal in which the German group Bertelsmann will sell its UK consumer publishing arm for an undisclosed sum, closing a 14-year chapter in the British magazine sector. An announcement about the deal might come within days.

Gruner & Jahr burst into the British market in 1986 with Prima, the monthly magazine that now sells 413,000 copies per issue. Best, a women's weekly that sells 462,000, followed in 1987.

The publisher, 75% owned by Bertelsmann and 25% by the Jahr family in Hamburg, was expected to emerge as a leading player in the British women's magazine market, challenging the long-standing dominance of IPC.

However, growth slowed and subsequent launches have been limited to the 62,000-selling men's science and technology magazine Focus in 1992, Your Home (180,000 copies) in 1997, and Prima Baby (51,000) in 1998. Here! merged into IPC's Now in April 1997, only a year after launch.

Britain has remained a niche market for G&J, top sellers among its 13 international markets being France, where it owns the country's second largest publisher, Prisma Presse, and the US, where it has a 100% stake in Gruner & Jahr USA.

While the decision to sell G&J UK has been expected for some time, some in the magazine industry are surprised that IPC has decided to snap it up. G&J's titles appear to clash with many in IPC's stable of 19 women's magazines, which include Marie Claire, Essentials, Woman's Weekly, Family Circle and Woman's Own, and nine home and garden titles. IPC is carrying £540m in debt.

"Why are they buying new brands when they're hundreds of millions of pounds in debt and have recently publicly stated that they are interested in multimedia platforms rather than magazine brands?" asked one industry insider. "It is also treading on the toes of a new 30-plus women's launch in the pipeline at IPC."

Despite IPC's debt, which stems mostly from its leveraged buy-out from Reed two years ago, it is believed the publisher feels Prima and Best are such strong brands that it could not pass up the opportunity to acquire them. Adding the two titles to its portfolio will substantially increase advertising revenue across the group, IPC believes.

The publisher is also determined to strengthen its hold on the women's magazine market in anticipation of the launch of Eve, the BBC's first foray into the sector, due later this year.

In a revamp announced last month, IPC changed its name from IPC Magazines to IPC Media and said it would follow a new direction "based on media brands rather than magazines".

fields.headline: Bonus row at National Grid
fields.standfirst: Pension funds to oppose handouts for 98 directors that ignore performance rules
fields.trailText: National Grid is on a possible collision course with the National Association of Pension Funds over a plan to ditch performance criteria in potentially lucrative options plans for its 98 top directors.
fields.body:
National Grid is on a possible collision course with the National Association of Pension Funds over a plan to ditch performance criteria in potentially lucrative options plans for its 98 top directors.

The scheme, similar to those adopted in the US, is also raising concern at the Association of British Insurers, another large representative body for shareholders, as it contravenes its guidelines which stipulate that options awards should be related to performance.

The concerns by the NAPF come as the pension advisory body is raising its profile in the City by issuing its first recommendations to shareholders on how to vote at annual general meetings of companies.

In what may prompt a wave of fresh shareholder activism in the City, the NAPF has also recommended to shareholders that they take action against a £10m bonus awarded to Chris Gent, the chief executive of Vodafone AirTouch as a reward for clinching the takeover of Mannesmann.

While the £10m bonus was paid to Mr Gent earlier this year, the NAPF, which has the potential to influence share holders representing up to 25% of the stock market, is telling investors to abstain in protest on the vote for his re-election to the board at the AGM on July 27.

One big institutional investor last night scorned the idea of abstaining from his vote but said a clear message did need to be sent to other companies that such bonuses were not acceptable.

Yesterday the NAPF said National Grid was also causing its corporate governance experts anxiety. Chris Baldry, manager, voting issues service at the NAPF, said the body was looking at new pay awards at National Grid. "We're struggling with National Grid," he said.

The main issue, which the NAPF is expected to publish guidance to shareholders on in the coming days' is over the decision to remove performance criteria attached to an options scheme.

The same move prompted comment from the ABI. "Waiving performance criteria does represent a break of the ABI guidelines and it is therefore a matter for the shareholders to judge whether the circumstances for the departure are justifiable," said Michael McKersie, manager, investment affairs at the ABI.

The executive share option scheme makes awards to 98 top executives including National Grid chief executive David Jones who earned £489,000 last year including bonuses.

But National Grid, which said it had discussed the plan with the ABI and individual shareholders, said the change was necessary to reflect the changing nature of its business, no longer just focused on the business of electricity generation but also in telephones operations such as Energis.

In a notice to shareholders of the AGM, also on July 27, the company explains the move by saying that it is "pursuing a policy of maximising shareholder value by investing in start-up opportunities, such as Energis and Intelig [in Brazil], which are expected to contribute to National Grid's long-term profitability".

"This policy has had a positive effect on shareholder value; however it does mean that start-up losses are being incurred which impact adversely on National Grid's earnings per share".

The present scheme's awards are based on EPS, which the firm says would be higher if the start-up costs of the telecoms business were ripped out.

fields.headline: Eads market debut flops
fields.trailText: European investors yesterday spurned the market debut of European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company (Eads), the group formed by French, German and Spanish businesses to compete with bigger US and British rivals.
fields.body:
European investors yesterday spurned the market debut of European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company (Eads), the group formed by French, German and Spanish businesses to compete with bigger US and British rivals.

Shares in the world's third largest aerospace company ended a dismal day's trading in the doldrums at €17.50 in Paris compared to the €19 offered to institutions and the €18 available to retail investors. In Madrid they closed at €17.

Eads co-chief executives Rainer Hertrich and Philippe Camus put a brave face on the slump in the €3bn (£1.9bn) initial public offering, blaming market conditions and insisting the stock had long-term growth potential.

But its fortunes contrasted sharply with those of BAE Systems, the British group which turned its back on European consolidation and is seeking strategic alliances with US groups such as Boeing and Lockheed Martin.

BAE was among the day's biggest gainers in London, its shares rising 2.16%, closing 9p up at 425p. Many analysts say the stock is seriously undervalued and could be nearer 600p by the end of next year.

Hailing "an historic day" for the group formed from Aérospatiale Matra, DaimlerChrysler Aerospace and Spain's Casa, an Eads spokesman blamed the dull performance on "a day of lethargy, at least in Frankfurt, where people are thinking more of holidays".

He added: "We have a high market volatility, definitely not the ideal circumstances to complete a merger and an IPO." But he said an early placement was crucial and compared the seven months it had taken with the 11 months for BAE to absorb GEC's Marconi defence arm last year.

"We thought the priority was to get a high quality shareholder base and we've done that, with 50% retail and 50% institutional investors from around the world."

Traders and analysts said aerospace stocks were unfashionable but the real problems with Eads were its trinational nature, the 15% stake held by the French government and its dual management team.

"The dual structure simply doesn't hold up," one said. "This is not a steady industry and people are worried that the French state will block the play of market forces," said another.

webTitle: Earthquake, typhoon and volcano all hit island idyll

fields.headline: Earthquake, typhoon and volcano all hit island idyll
fields.trailText: If you think Britain is enduring a miserable summer, pity the residents of Miyake-jima. The tiny Pacific island has been hit by three natural disasters - an earthquake, a typhoon and an erupting volcano - in the past three days.
fields.body:
If you think Britain is enduring a miserable summer, pity the residents of Miyake-jima. The tiny Pacific island has been hit by three natural disasters - an earthquake, a typhoon and an erupting volcano - in the past three days.

At this time of year Miyake-jima is normally packed with holidaymakers from the Japanese mainland who fly south to swim, spot dolphins or go fishing.

Yesterday the island's 46 hotels and inns and its camp sites were virtually deserted; the twice-daily flights between Miyake-jima and Tokyo less than half full.

The conjunction of cataclysms began two weeks ago when the 815-metre (2,670-ft) Mount Oyama began to rumble. Half of the 4,000-strong population were evacuated from their homes and an undersea explosion shook the island's western coast.

In the last two weeks, Miyake-jima and neighbouring islands have been jolted by thousands of quakes, including one on July 1 which registered 6.4 on the Richter scale and crushed a motorist to death under falling rocks.

Then, on Saturday, Mount Oyama erupted at its peak for the first time in 60 years, according to the meteorological agency in Tokyo. A cloud of yellow ash shot up 800 metres, showering cars, houses and streets with stones. There were no casualties.

On Sunday morning, an earthquake measuring 6.1 sent rocks and mud tumbling, cracked roads and burst a water main. Later in the day, a typhoon that had killed more than 80 people in the Philippines raced up Japan's eastern coast, lashing Miyake-jima with strong winds and heavy rains. Five people were killed on the Japanese mainland.

And there is no end in sight just yet. Yesterday the meteorological agency warned the earthquakes indicate that the volcano will continue to erupt.

webTitle: Department heads at risk as Dyke cuts 1,100 BBC jobs

fields.headline: Department heads at risk as Dyke cuts 1,100 BBC jobs
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC was plunged into months of uncertainty yesterday when the director general, Greg Dyke, revealed plans to cut 1,100 jobs and force some senior staff to reapply for their posts.
fields.body:
The BBC was plunged into months of uncertainty yesterday when the director general, Greg Dyke, revealed plans to cut 1,100 jobs and force some senior staff to reapply for their posts.

Heads of 10 departments will have to compete for three new senior positions, as the management structure across the BBC is slimmed down in order to free up more cash for programmes.

The changes are the most radical at the corporation since Mr Dyke's predecessor, John Birt, introduced the much-hated internal market.

Staff were left fearing for their future, and unions urged managers to treat employees fairly. But change was essential, Mr Dyke told them yesterday, "otherwise we will simply end up managing our own decline".

Mr Dyke said he expected some "high-profile casualties" over the next few months as the details are worked out. The head of entertainment, Paul Jackson, was thought to be considering his position, while the BBC's economics and business editor, Peter Jay, will lose some responsibility as part of plans to improve coverage of the business world. A new post of business editor will be created.

The job losses, many of which will be compulsory and which include the 200 announced last week in the BBC's resources division, should net £750m over the next six years. Most of the axed posts will be support staff, the rest will be managers.

Coverage of business issues was "not as good as it should be", Mr Dyke said. A new business editor will be appointed, leaving Mr Jay in charge of economics coverage on the BBC's news programmes, and coverage of business affairs across the BBC will be improved.

There will be a new head of religious affairs and ethics, with a view to reinvigorating the BBC's religious programmes.

Mr Dyke said: "A lot of the research we've done suggests that there are many people who are interested in spirituality today, who are not particularly interested in formal religion. In the factual and learning division, new "super-heads" will be created to lead three beefed-up departments: documentaries and investigation; leisure and factual entertainment, which includes docusoaps; and specialist factual, incorporating science and natural history programmes.

webTitle: Yugoslavia is dead, says Montenegrin leader

fields.headline: Yugoslavia is dead, says Montenegrin leader
fields.standfirst: Serbia: special report
fields.trailText: Montenegro's pro-western president, Milo Djukanovic, took another step towards independence for his fledgling nation yesterday by claiming that Yugoslavia no longer exists because the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, has opted for its destruction to preserve   power and avoid war crimes charges filed against him.
fields.body:
Montenegro's pro-western president, Milo Djukanovic, took another step towards independence for his fledgling nation yesterday by claiming that Yugoslavia no longer exists because the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, has opted for its destruction to preserve power and avoid war crimes charges filed against him.

Montenegro's lawmakers on Saturday backed their government's decision to reject Belgrade's changes last week to the federal constitution - amendments aimed at concentrating power into the hands of the Yugoslav president.

Mr Djukanovic said his republic, which forms Yugoslavia with Serbia, will not take part in federal elections scheduled by Mr Milosevic for the autumn.

"It is evident that Yugoslavia no longer exists," said Mr Djukanovic. "Instead of the two equal states - Montenegro and Serbia - we have a one-state model."

He said that with the latest federal constitutional changes - and Montenegro's decision to ignore them - his country "has practically left the constitutional and legal system of Yugoslavia".

"Milosevic's dilemma was Yugoslavia or the Hague... he chose to destroy Yugoslavia," Mr Djukanovic said.

Mr Milosevic was indicted by an international war crimes tribunal in the Hague for atrocities committed during his crack down in Serbia's Kosovo province, which triggered Nato's 78-day bombing campaign last year. Mr Milosevic appears to believe that staying in power is his best guarantee against prosecution by the UN war crimes court.

There are fears that Mr Milosevic, who started four Balkan wars, might intervene militarily against Montenegro if it proclaims outright independence. His Yugoslav Army remains the only federal institution still functioning in Montenegro.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Shoppers play a home game
fields.body:
Shoppers play a home game

Retail sales growth slowed last month as shops began summer sales earlier than usual and the Euro 2000 soccer tournament kept consumers glued to their television sets.

The British Retail Consortium and KPMG's sales monitor found the growth in monthly sales slipped to 5.2% in June, compared with 5.7% in May. The increase in value of retail sales also slowed, to 2.8% in June from May's 3.2%.

The BRC said the trend was led by deep discounting, and summer sales starting earlier than usual. Male shoppers preferred to stay at home watching the football rather than buying clothes, though beer sales rose.

Arbuckle rescue plan

Fatty Arbuckles, the chain of American-style diners which collapsed yesterday, is likely to be rescued by a management buyout, but not before job cuts and the closure of several restaurants.

Alan Bloom and Andrew Wollaston of accountants Ernst & Young, who have taken control of the chain's 50 restaurants after their appointment as joint administrative receivers, said about a quarter of the sites were lossmaking and would close immediately.

Sites operated under franchise, which account for about half the chain, will continue as normal.

Television Corp buys Venner

Television Corp said it acquired award-winning independent Venner TV, producer of Channel 4's coverage of the Tour de France and other sporting programmes.

VTV is producing daily coverage of the Tour de France for Channel 4 as well as international programming as a joint venture with the race organisers, Amaury Sport Organisations for worldwide distribution.

Television Corp said VTV's production and rights contracts complemented its portfolio and would help it to expand the business into new areas around the world.

Manhattan transfer

DaimlerChrysler, the car group formed by the acquisition of the American company by Daimler-Benz of Germany, is considering a move to the landmark Manhattan building that bears its name.

The company is discussing leasing the top few floors of the Chrysler building, New York's art deco masterpiece, for executive meetings to be held twice a month.

That would cause consternation at the group's US headquarters near Detroit, which is already expecting a round of job cuts. Executives are understood to hope the new venue would help to attract more American investors.

$100m online ad spend

Merrill Lynch and HSBC are to spend more than $100m on advertising and marketing their new on-line investment services over the next 18 months.

The account has been awarded to Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide.

webTitle: As one in four homes go online, the country's digital divide widens

fields.headline: As one in four homes go online, the country's digital divide widens
fields.standfirst: Initiatives struggle to bring net skills to poorer areas
fields.trailText: Britain's poorest households are being left behind in the digital revolution because they cannot afford access to the internet.
fields.body:
Britain's poorest households are being left behind in the digital revolution because they cannot afford access to the internet. Figures released yesterday reveal that a "digital divide" has opened up between the poorest households and the better off. While the number of households with access to the internet has doubled in 12 months to 6.5m - around one in four homes - levels of access vary greatly depending on income.

As few as 3% of poorer households are online, compared with 48% of more affluent households. Of households in the poorest third (those with a weekly income of £270 or less) access varies between 3% and 6%. Further up the income scale, access increases, with just under half of all homes in which the weekly income exceeds £900 enjoying web access.

The report, from the Office of National Statistics, also revealed huge regional variations - with households in London and the south-east enjoying the highest levels of access at an annual average of 25%. Access is most restricted in Northern Ireland, Scotland and the north-east, at less than 15% across the regions.

The figures, in the government's first survey of internet access, will be sobering to an administration that has stressed the importance of the digital economy. In his 1999 budget speech, Gordon Brown warned that "anyone left out of the new knowledge revolution will be left behind in the new knowledge economy." Writing in the Guardian last year, Tony Blair warned against "a society divided into computer haves and have-nots."

But according to Claire Shearman, co-chairwoman of Communities Online, which works to increase internet access among the poor and eth nic minorities, the gap is growing despite government initiatives.

"There is a growing belief that dot.coms are the future of the economy. But if you don't have access to the skills and the knowledge to thrive in that economy because of where you live, or how much money you earn, you won't be included," she said.

"The internet is a very important form of expression and can provide the poor and those from ethnic minorities, who are traditionally excluded, with an empowering sense of identity.

"Many of the government's programmes - putting computers into all schools and libraries - are fine in principal, but you have to provide people with the skills to do more than just consume information.

"There's no point, for example, in giving Moss Side a community web page unless you also give the people of the community the confidence to develop their own ideas, and present them to the world via the internet."

Malcolm Forbes runs Lambeth Online, a community project based in Brixton, south London. He believes that exclusion from the internet "will leave people at the bottom of the heap".

"If the low paid are excluded from the internet and the new competencies associated with it, then they will be excluded from the tools that will allow them to compete in the global knowledge economy. They will be in the same position as the person who couldn't read in the "old" economy," he said.

Patricia Hewitt, minister for small business and e-commerce, maintained that the government's UK Online project, which aims to achieve universal access to the internet by 2005, and online facilities in all schools and libraries by 2002, was on target.

"We want everyone to realise the opportunities of the internet. That is why we are connecting all our schools and libraries and taking the internet to poorer communities through UK Online centres," she said.

Alex Allan, the government's "e-envoy" in charge of widening internet access, said yesterday that the programme would see 700 special access centres open in deprived areas. He said UK Online was on target to meet a pledge to offer 80% discounts on basic IT courses and help 100,000 low income families to lease or buy cheap computers.

Defending the government's record on improving access to the internet, he said that the figures released yesterday were "encouraging".

"The figures show a doubling, in 12 months, of the number of homes with access. This is spread right across the board, with the middle groups in particular showing a big increase," he said.

"Although we have still got a lot to do, we must remember that these figures concentrate on access from home, whereas poorer people can often have other means of getting online."

The survey did not take account of the newer forms of internet access developed since the new year, including digital television and WAP telephones, he said.

A report in the consumer magazine Which? says one in four people refuse to use the internet because they think it is expensive and irrelevant to their needs; another quarter admit they do not know what the web is used for.


Who's on and who's not

 6.5m UK households (25%) are connected to the internet

 London has the highest proportion of online households at 25%. In the south-east as a whole 24% are online, with 22% online in the east

 The smallest proportion of online households is in Northern Ireland, where 11% have access, while 14% of homes in Scotland and the north-east have access

 In the lowest income groups internet access varies between 4% and 6%. Access levels increase rapidly with income, reaching 48% in the highest group

 Access is highest in two-parent households; 35% of households with two or more children and 31% with one child are online. Seven per cent of single parent homes with one child and 11% of those with two children have access

 Sixteen per cent of adults living alone have internet access. The figure drops to 1% after retirement

 Twenty-six per cent of couples without children can access the internet

webTitle: £500m for town halls to recycle waste

fields.headline: £500m for town halls to recycle waste
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is to announce an extra £500m for recycling waste to help local councils meet tough targets announced in the government's strategy last month.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is to announce an extra £500m for recycling waste to help local councils meet tough targets announced in the government's strategy last month.

Councils will be expected to recycle 25% of their waste by 2005, compared with a current average figure of under 8%. Some of the worst authorities include Sedgefield in the prime minister's constituency and Oldham in the environment minister Michael Meacher's constituency which recycle only 1.3% and 2.9%of waste respectively.

Mr Meacher is said to have argued that authorities had no chance of reaching the targets unless they received around £350m over the next three years. Ministers are said to have been alarmed that some recycled materials have been sent to landfill sites because there has not been a market for the goods.

Downing Street's policy unit is also said to be keen to introduce additional funding to promote new recycling schemes through voluntary bodies, community schemes and new businesses. The government also hopes to trounce the Conservatives' policy, which would offer everybody in Britain the chance of door to door recycling services.

The new cash will be in addition to the growing amount of money made available - currently around £100m a year - in landfill tax credits administered by the private regulator, Entrust.

Originally ministers thought of redirecting cash through this scheme, but following an investigation by the Guardian and Channel 4's Dispatches programme into landfill and the use of tax credits, the Treasury is said to have changed its mind. Waste companies can avoid landfill tax by donations to environmental bodies, but it is alleged that firms are manipulating some of the money for their own benefit. The serious fraud office is investigating one case.

fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Bill of the day
fields.body:
Bill of the day

Disgraced media tycoon Robert Maxwell has been in his grave at the Mount of Olives for eight years, but still the bills keep coming in. Junior trade minister Lord Sainsbury told peers that inspectors investigating the former Mirror magnate's affairs would complete their inquiries "shortly". And at a price - £7.6m so far.

Quote of the day

"Rotherham and hundreds of other towns and cities have got a day in the dome and kids are really looking forward to it. What they are fed up with is the whinging, whiney wallies, the anti-dome dumping drongos of the party opposite who are always out to destroy a good day out for the children of this country." - Denis MacShane (Lab, Rotherham).

Today

Commons: Police (Northern Ireland) bill, timetable motion and remaining stages. Lords: Limited liability partnerships bill, amendments. Utilities bill, third reading. Postal services bill, third reading. Insolvency bill, report.

webTitle: Convoy of mourners return to Srebrenica

fields.headline: Convoy of mourners return to Srebrenica
fields.standfirst:
Hundreds of Muslim women to relive the day their city fell

Serbia: special report
fields.trailText: There is nothing to break the silence inside the battery factory, where dust coats the abandoned machinery and weeds sprout from crumbled corners. Not even the lone Serb security guard who sits in the shade, guarding rubble.
fields.body:
There is nothing to break the silence inside the battery factory, where dust coats the abandoned machinery and weeds sprout from crumbled corners. Not even the lone Serb security guard who sits in the shade, guarding rubble.

Daylight seeps in from where a mortar shell has perforated the roof. Grenades have carved craters on the path to the door. Bullet holes sketch a zig-zag pattern on the walls of the factory, which is surrounded by barbed wire that refuses to rust.

Rising up on each side of its battered silhouette are hills baked yellow by the sun. And between the fields are farmhouses with black cavities for windows and doors.

About midday today a convoy of about 45 coaches is due to halt outside the factory. Five years after a convoy took them away and Serbs took over their houses, the women of Srebrenica will return, for one, maybe two, hours.

Crunching over gravel, they will pray together before the concrete husk which was supposed to be their sanctuary. They will remember husbands, fathers, sons and brothers - victims of Europe's worst atrocity since the second world war.

Day the world watched

The world will watch, just as it did on July 11 1995 - the day the Bosnian Serb army finally overran the Muslim enclave. Three years of resistance in Bosnia's civil war, three years of soaking up 30,000 refugees, bombardments and western assurances, ended in catastrophe when Srebrenica fell to the Serbs.

"We are not going to enter Srebrenica, we just want to pacify Srebrenica," the Serb General Ratko Mladic said at the time. He smiled for the cameras and patted a Muslim child's head, but he was lying. The women knew it even then. He was a butcher.

The United Nations had declared the town a "safe area". A unit of 100 Dutch soldiers set up its headquarters in the battery factory, in the suburb of Potocari, to make it so. The Serb noose tightened.

Uncoordinated Muslim attacks on outlying Serb villages yielded to superior firepower. Blocks of flats, shops and streets crumbled. As water and food ran out, British and UN dignitaries - Sir David Owen, Douglas Hurd and Kofi Annan, among others - bolstered their rhetoric. Srebrenica could not fall.

Serb soldiers entered the outskirts. Dutch pleas for air attacks were rebuffed. The capital Sarajevo heard an amateur radio operator in Srebrenica plead: "We beg you to do something - whatever you can. In the name of God, do something."

Surrender came swiftly. Some men tried to escape through the woods, others joined their families and fled to the factory and the protection of the Dutch troops.

Tens of thousands crammed into the site, starving, dehydrated and terrified. "We couldn't sleep. There were screams all through the night," said Suhra Dilovic, 41.

During the next four days males over the age of 13 were segregated and the women and children were bundled into buses. Many couples did not have time to say goodbye.

Fatima Husejnovic, 51, still wonders why she and her husband Munib did not embrace for a last time. "We couldn't look each other in the eye," she said. "Neither of us could say a word."

Gunfire echoed from the hills as the buses hissed and thundered down the driveway from the factory, turning right at the road and heading west to dump the women in Muslim-held areas.

"There were bodies piled up on the road. The driver tried to avoid them but he couldn't," Ms Dilovic said.

It took more than a year to confirm what happened next. The males were bussed and marched to execution sites: about 7,300 were killed, according to the International Committee for the Red Cross.

Srebrenica stands today as a charred memorial to inhumanity. Two-thirds Muslim before the war, it is now populated by 18,000 Serbs, has a Serb flag over its town hall and lies deep inside Republika Srpska, a para-state within Bosnia ceded to Serbs by the 1995 Dayton accord.

It is 100% Serb, almost. Four Muslims have returned to live there; defying warnings from some Muslim officials, they are rebuilding their homes.

Sacir and Mevlida Halilovic were the first. Climbing a winding road that leads to a goat track and ends in a precipice, they came back in April to discover their one-room cottage still standing. In their 80s, they cleaned away and mended five year's of neglect. Neighbours, tentative at first, came to help, doing the heavy lifting and painting.

Sipping coffee on his porch at sunset this week, Sacir expressed no surprise. "My father and his father were born here. We have always lived among Serbs. They have been good to us since we returned.

"I had to come back. This is my land. I am poor but at least here I can grow vegetables and raise animals," he said. His wife sat beside him, nodding.

A homecoming of sorts

Hajrudin Nalic returned two months ago to his fourth-floor flat on Svetosavska Street. His wife will follow when it is repaired. "So far I haven't had any problem. I've had lunch and dinner with my neighbours," he said.

But despite the apparently warm welcome, the decaying remains continue to dominate past and present. War-crimes investigators have exhumed 4,700 bodies, many with blindfolds and bound arms. Now they are crammed into two tunnels behind the city of Tuzla's mortuary,where in the next four years investigators will attempt one of the most ambitious programmes of DNA tests. Traditional methods have identified only 76 bodies.

The UN admits that Srebrenica will haunt it for ever. General Radislav Krstic, who commanded troops there, is on trial this week at the Hague war-crimes tribunal, charged with genocide. His superior, Ratko Mladic, is indicted but free, lying low in Banovo Brdo, a plush Belgrade suburb.

Five years on from the massacre, Srebrenica remains a town filled with despair and anger. Most of the town's Serbs are themselves refugees - ethnically cleansed by Croats and Muslims from other parts of Bosnia.

The Dodik family, farmers, were hard at work yesterday, weeding and clearing rubbish from the site of today's ceremony. "The Muslims promised us DM300 (£95) for this." Did they approve of the ceremony? A shrug of the shoulders. "There was no massacre."

Watching from the shade was the lone security guard, Drago Spajic, 44, who packed batteries into boxes before being called up to fight his Muslim neighbours in 1992. He will be on duty today when the women arrive.

Shielding his eyes from the sun, he spoke softly: "I hate them. They have no right. They should not be here." Muslim soldiers crushed his 63-year-old father's skull in a raid on the village of Obadi on July 8 1992, he says. He, himself, is disabled from a grenade. "And you ask me to pity them."

He echoes the denial of the local Serb veterans association, which issued a statement last month, saying: "It is known that, on July 11 1995, nobody was hurt in Potocari, let alone killed." Those Serbs who admit that the exhumed bodies are real say they were killed in battle, or blown up by landmines.

The inhabitants scoff at the notion of living in the crucible of Muslim suffering. Serbs are the victims, they say. Chased from their homes to this hell-hole, they have no drinking water, no jobs, no prospects.

"We're miserable but we have nowhere else to go. A lot of us are from Sarajevo but if we return the Muslims will make us second-class citizens," said Dragan Jeftic, the deputy mayor. He accuses the Party for Democratic Action, the nationalist Muslim party which governs Bosnia, of orchestrating the ceremony to provoke a confrontation.

Privately, western diplomats and aid agencies agree that the PDA hopes to create tension in advance of the elections in November.

For some in today's convoy, the trip will not be to pray for the dead but to pray for a miracle. Still traumatised, they believe their men are alive and labouring in a jail in Serbia. Mrs Husejnovic thinks the ceremony will help jolt them into reality.

"It's their last hope. We all had it five years ago. But it's another July. It's time to grieve, not hope."

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Helen McPhail writes: It would be impossible to tally up the number of people who are grateful to Joan Tate (Obituary, July 7) for her interest, help or support in their personal or professional lives. She was a perspicacious neighbour, and, though reticent about her own achievements, she delighted in her profession.
fields.body:
Helen McPhail writes: It would be impossible to tally up the number of people who are grateful to Joan Tate (Obituary, July 7) for her interest, help or support in their personal or professional lives. She was a perspicacious neighbour, and, though reticent about her own achievements, she delighted in her profession.

My experience, when I ventured into her world of literary translation in middle-age, could be matched by many others. Her attitude - that if you were serious about it, even the rawest beginner deserved her full professional attention - was exhilarating, and she became a remarkable source of help, guidance and encouragement. I was immediately treated as a serious colleague and ushered into this peculiar world, where work is isolated and personal, with contacts and friendships often distant and electronic, but frequently intimate and revealing in practice.

Always outspoken in championing the underdog, Joan was not to be argued with lightly. Indeed, it was not easy to dispute the views and commments that poured out in her conversation. But the friend in distress, the professional colleague, and especially the young, all found her untiring in her enthusiasm, interest and practical response.

fields.headline: 'No basis' to suspend nurse
fields.trailText: The nurses' regulatory body decided yesterday against suspending Elaine Chase, an Essex community nurse under police investigation for alleged involvement in the deaths of 18 children.
fields.body:
The nurses' regulatory body decided yesterday against suspending Elaine Chase, an Essex community nurse under police investigation for alleged involvement in the deaths of 18 children.

After a hearing in London, the UK Central Council for Nursing and Midwifery said there was no evidence to remove Ms Chase, 47, from the professional register pending the outcome of inquiries by Essex police.

The council can suspend people from the register before an investigation only if the public risk is absolutely clear.

The hearing came after Essex police began an inquiry into the deaths of terminally ill children who had been in Ms Chase's care. She was suspended from her post with the local NHS trust last September.

In a tearful statement on the steps of the council's offices in central London, Ms Chase said the decision added weight to her case that she had always acted professionally.

webTitle: Minister bitter over pub signs of the times

fields.headline: Minister bitter over pub signs of the times
fields.trailText: Breweries should call time on modern pub names such as The Rat and Parrot or risk destroying Britain's cultural heritage, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Breweries should call time on modern pub names such as The Rat and Parrot or risk destroying Britain's cultural heritage, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, said yesterday.

Fashionable new names for long established watering holes were destroying the links between public houses and local history, he said, and he called on pubs to consult their regular customers and the wider community before consigning old favourites like the Royal Oak and the King's Arms to history.

Pubs were an "integral part of the local heritage" in many parts of the country, he told MPs in the Commons, yet figures for London show that an average of 11 pubs have seen a name change each month in the past five years.

Mr Smith's comments were the highest profile support yet for a growing campaign to save traditional pub names, but he resisted calls for legislation.

Last year MPs on all sides backed a private member's bill brought by Ann Winterton, Tory MP for Congleton, aiming to bring in a law protecting pubs from being renamed as part of "themed" refurbishments by big chains.

Mr Smith said: "It does appear to me that there is a growing fashion for rebranding pubs with names like the Dog 'n' Donut or the Goose and Granite which, I have to say, would appear to have little relevance to the history of any area. We are surely in danger here of losing an important part of local history.

"While it is up to the owners of a business to choose the name they give it, I hope breweries will bear in mind the unique historic role many of our public houses have and think twice before destroying that link with the past. Consulting with the pub's regulars and the wider local community before renaming it would not seem too much to ask."

Among the most controversial name changes have been The Castle in Newbury, Berkshire, which became the Pig in Hiding, and the Roe Buck in Cannock, Staffordshire, which turned into the Laughing Lepardz, with yellow and black spots on the walls.

A spokesman for the culture secretary said that the Goose and Granite had previously been the Plough at Dulwich, while the Dog 'n' Donut pub in Cheltenham had undergone numerous changes since its first incarnation as the Lansdown.

fields.headline: Lord Leverhulme
fields.standfirst: Soap fortune heir devoted to horseracing and animal health
fields.trailText: Philip Lever, the third and last Viscount Leverhulme, who has died aged 85, was a successful racehorse owner and pillar of the Jockey Club. If millionaire Arabs' racehorses were said to "run on oil", Lever's ran on soap - the £30m fortune amassed by his Bolton grandfather, William Lever, from the production of Sunlight soap. This, with Lifebuoy and Lux, financed the Port Sunlight garden city, and eventually became the multinational Unilever.
fields.body:
Philip Lever, the third and last Viscount Leverhulme, who has died aged 85, was a successful racehorse owner and pillar of the Jockey Club. If millionaire Arabs' racehorses were said to "run on oil", Lever's ran on soap - the £30m fortune amassed by his Bolton grandfather, William Lever, from the production of Sunlight soap. This, with Lifebuoy and Lux, financed the Port Sunlight garden city, and eventually became the multinational Unilever.

William Lever became Baron Leverhulme in 1917, during Lloyd George's peerage-selling period, and Viscount Leverhulme in 1922. His son, the second viscount, showed a filial interest in the business, becoming governor of Lever Brothers and Uni-Lever. Philip, however, served only as advisory director in the firm, in which he had £5m in shares. With the rest of the family, he also owned a third of Unilever's share through the Leverhulme Trust.

Lever was brought up near the Wirral, on the 11,000- acre family estate, Thornton Manor, which he later inherited. After Eton, he attended Trinity College, Cambridge, where he rode some point- to-point winners. During the second world war he joined the Cheshire Yeomanry, where he made some firm friends, including the father of the future trainer of his flat racers.

He inherited the title, and a tax-diminished fortune of £500,000, when his father died in 1949. Undeterred by the loss of his dairy herd from foot-and-mouth, in 1954 he bought the 22,000 acre Badanloch estate in Sutherland, with its grouse moors and deer forests - he was always a keen shot.

Horses became his consuming interest. He began by buying jumpers trained at George Owen's stables at nearby Malpas, Cheshire. His success with Royal Stuart in 1949 was followed by Fascinating Forties. Further success came in flat racing, winning with Minipal, ridden by Lester Piggott, and Hot Grove in 1977.

Lever played his role in the racing establishment, rising from deputy senior steward in the Jockey Club to senior steward, 1973-76, during which time he helped settle the 1975 stableman's strike. For 25 years, he served on the executive of the Animal Health Trust, retiring as chairman in 1989, after having been made a knight of the garter by the Queen the previous year.

Although a staunch Conservative, it took him 27 years to make his maiden speech in the Lords, predictably about the problems of financing racing. After this, Tory whips were only able to drag him in about once a year.

His wife of 36 years, Margaret Moon, died in 1973. He leaves his three daughters. With no son, the viscountcy dies with him.

Andrew Roth

fields.headline: From tiny acorns
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Somerset
fields.body:
Somerset

My journey often coincides with the twice daily ritual at the pedestrian crossing by Charlton Horethorne School. Cars, mothers and pushchairs gather by the low church wall in a narrow, leafy section of the road near the village centre. The ritual proceeds at a leisurely pace.

A driver in a hurry might curse to himself as each new group of an apparently endless succession steps off the kerb. But in fact, the class of 2000 is smaller than he might guess; it numbers 68. We know this because the school has contributed some stone to the Millennium Green, and the children's individual school numbers have been carved onto pieces of stone set randomly into the wall beside the new pond. Soon there will be a bronze plaque giving their names and numbers.

The green has been created in a space of one and a quarter acres which a local farmer and parish councillor used to rent for grazing. When the council was debating how to mark the millennium, it occurred to him that he no longer had much use for the field. He talked to the landowner and the council. In time, the countryside agency became involved; Bass the brewer made a grant; the millennium commission contributed lottery funds; a trust was formed; and lawyers negotiated a 999 year lease.

It was agreed that a permanent, tranquil space, protected from building development, safe from traffic, should be dedicated to peaceful recreation. It was declared open at this year's annual village feast day.

The green is approached by a short, walled path overhung with trees, a few yards from the village centre. We went by the perimeter path laid by one contributor and admired the picturesque bridge constructed by another and the shelter built by a third.

The shelter is roofed with ancient stone tiles left unused when repairs were done at the church, and it incorporates pinnacles replaced on the perpendicular tower. Not far away, the Tree of Peace 2000 is the direct descendant of an acorn brought here from Berlin by a soldier returning home at the end of hostilities.

fields.headline: In defence of irony
fields.trailText: Robert McCrum might be "lucky to live in a stable, liberal democracy during one of the most extraordinary economic booms in memory" (Are these men bad for Britain?, G2, July 10), but he is literary editor of a big newspaper and, presumably, not short of a bob or two. I'm 48-years-old, I haven't worked for four years and my local council just decided to cut my housing benefit by five quid a week, perhaps to make it easier for me to get a job as a Big Issue salesman. And there are lots of people worse off than me.
fields.body:

And there are lots of people worse off than me.

While hypocrisy like Mr McCrum's is still loose in the land, there is a need for much more irony, not less, and for sarcasm, lampoon, litotes and satire as well.

Southampton

fields.headline: Jerome Richardson
fields.standfirst: Versatile US jazzman making music from coast to coast
fields.trailText: Jerome Richardson, who has died aged 79, was an exceptionally versatile jazz wood- wind player. A superb technician and rewarding soloist on alto and tenor saxophones, he could surprise audiences with the drive and verve of his performances. He played on more than 4,000 jazz and popular recordings, and the producer Quincy Jones was especially enamoured of his flute (and piccolo) playing, so much so that he hired Richardson for his touring orchestras, including a nine-month stint with Free and Easy, a musical show which performed in Europe in 1959.
fields.body:
Jerome Richardson, who has died aged 79, was an exceptionally versatile jazz wood- wind player. A superb technician and rewarding soloist on alto and tenor saxophones, he could surprise audiences with the drive and verve of his performances. He played on more than 4,000 jazz and popular recordings, and the producer Quincy Jones was especially enamoured of his flute (and piccolo) playing, so much so that he hired Richardson for his touring orchestras, including a nine-month stint with Free and Easy, a musical show which performed in Europe in 1959.

Later, there were several tours of Japan with Jones. In 1961, Richardson was a founder member of the Thad Jones-Mel Lewis big band in New York, something of a jazz haven for studio players. "It's a band of enthusiasts, and an opportunity to cleanse our souls," he explained.

After 20 years as a freelance musician, he moved to California, where his worklist included television and concert credits, and playing with the likes of Frank Sinatra, Sammy Davis, Lena Horne and Peggy Lee. He made many recordings and peformed myriad sessions with musicians of the quality of Louis Armstrong, Charles Mingus and Miles Davis.

He had, in fact, been something of a youthful prodigy and become a professional musician (and member of the Musicians' Union) at the age of 14. Word of his prowess spread quickly. The Los Angeles saxophonist Jack Kelso remembers a trumpeter named Winnow Allen "raving about this saxophone player up in Oakland, and insisting that we drive in his car to hear Jerome Richardson. So we knocked on his door and Jerome said later: 'You guys scared the shit out of me.'"

Richardson himself was for long unsure about his background. He was, in fact, adopted, a fact he only discovered in mid-life. Early on, he assumed he had been born in Oakland, on Christmas Day 1920; it turned out his birthplace was Sealey, Texas, and that he was six weeks older than he thought. He was, of course, the product of a mixed-raced relationship, then taboo.

His adoptive parents bought him an alto saxophone when he was eight, and he was soon proficient enough to give radio recitals and play in churches. He liked the big bands he heard, and local bandleader Ben Watkins liked what he heard of Richardson. He was soon in the thick of the Oakland jazz scene, and began to tour with bluesman Saunders King, the local equivalent to T-Bone Walker.

Club work, a cruelly brief engagement with the Jimmie Lunceford orchestra, and college followed before Richardson volunteered for the US navy in 1941, or, more accurately, its pre-flight school orchestra, based at Moraga, California. The all-black station big band was packed with jazz stars and masterminded by saxophonist Marshal Royal, later with the Count Basie orchestra. This congenial sinecure endured until December 1945, and allowed Richardson ample opportunity to moonlight at bay areas clubs.

After demobilisation, he tried day-jobs, but was happy to accept an offer to tour with the Lionel Hampton orchestra from 1949 onwards. Like others, Richardson enjoyed Hampton's music, but found the pay insufficient to support a family. After two years with the pianist Earl Hines, which left him stranded in Los Angeles, he made for New York in the mid-1950s. He led his own bands and played for Cootie Williams and in Broadway pit orchestras, while breaking into the commercial studio scene.

Richardson's visits to Britain were infrequent; there was a 1969 season at Ronnie Scott's with the Jones-Lewis band, a well-received solo gig at Peter Ind's Bass Clef, and, most recently, an appearance at Brecon Jazz in 1997 with the prestigious Carnegie Hall Jazz Band.

Companionable, if under-appreciated, Richardson is survived by his wife, Rowena, two daughters and two grandchildren.

 Jerome Richardson, jazz musician, born November 15 1920; died June 23 2000

fields.headline: Loathing? - no fear
fields.trailText:
The Diary (July 5) carried a piece of nonsensical gossip about a private party I attended. Now that this gossip has been taken up as fact by other newspapers, I feel I must write to put the record straight. At no stage did I suggest that the Blair-Brown relationship was deteriorating into one of loathing. I have never said any such thing to anyone, not even my nearest and dearest, for the very good reason that I do not believe it to be true.
Roger Liddle
Prime Minister's Policy Unit
fields.body:

Now that this gossip has been taken up as fact by other newspapers, I feel I must write to put the record straight. At no stage did I suggest that the Blair-Brown relationship was deteriorating into one of loathing. I have never said any such thing to anyone, not even my nearest and dearest, for the very good reason that I do not believe it to be true.
Roger Liddle
Prime Minister's Policy Unit

 You suggest (Life after Living Marxism, July 8) "LM has forged strong links with internet companies, including Cyberia". I would not call it a strong link - LM has in the past been a customer of ours. We have provided the venue for meetings, conferences, parties and launches for countless other customers, regardless of political view or status.
Richard Leader
Cyberia

 As a Unitarian minister, I take some comfort in our modest progress from being "virtually moribund" (Bishop of Oxford) to the marginally less terminal status of "a spent force" (Colin Sedgwick, Face to Faith, July 8). Perhaps this reiteration from the Christian mainstream reflects the fear that Unitarians just might still be a force to be reckoned with.
Keith Gilley
London

 Volkswagen is fined £57m by the European Court of Justice (Guardian Finance, July 7) for preventing car dealers in Italy from selling to customers elsewhere in Europe. On the previous day you carried a report on the collapse of the tunnel at Heathrow, in which workers' lives were placed at severe risk and for which the principal civil engineering contractor was strongly criticised and fined a "record" £1.2m.
Roger de la Court
London

fields.headline: Why Brideshead won't be revisited
fields.trailText: Your leader on university funding (July 8) seems to be a reaction to speculation on what Greenaway-Haynes contained rather than on the report's actual contents. More importantly, aside from the odd hint that further government funding might be in order, it fails to offer any credible alternative to the report's proposals.
fields.body:
Your leader on university funding (July 8) seems to be a reaction to speculation on what Greenaway-Haynes contained rather than on the report's actual contents. More importantly, aside from the odd hint that further government funding might be in order, it fails to offer any credible alternative to the report's proposals.

If you are making the case for additional public funding, you need to answer the following: Why should low income taxpayers pay yet more to subsidise those who will be high income taxpayers for the rest of their working life? Why should any additional taxpayers' money go to universities rather than to schools or hospitals? Why should government funding not be targeted to a greater extent to support students from less well off backgrounds? Why do we need a dirigiste "one size fits all" funding regime/pay policy/regulatory regime?

Our report offers a basis for enhancing funding for all universities to improve quality and access for all students which is efficient and socially just. Hankering after "Brideshead" levels of public funding is naive: those days are gone - forever.
Prof David Greenaway
University of Nottingham

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Our Tom Paine chronology, page 8, yesterday, was awry. We said Paine was forced out of England by the uproar caused by his book, Rights of Man, that he went to revolutionary France and then to America where "he had a hand in the Declaration of Independence". In fact, Paine went to America in 1774 (his influential pamphlet Common Sense appeared in January, 1776, but there is no evidence that he had a hand in the Declaration of Independence that appeared later that year). He returned to England in 1787 and wrote Rights of Man 1791-92, then had to flee to revolutionary France. He was unable to leave France to return to the United States until 1802.
fields.body:
Our Tom Paine chronology, page 8, yesterday, was awry. We said Paine was forced out of England by the uproar caused by his book, Rights of Man, that he went to revolutionary France and then to America where "he had a hand in the Declaration of Independence". In fact, Paine went to America in 1774 (his influential pamphlet Common Sense appeared in January, 1776, but there is no evidence that he had a hand in the Declaration of Independence that appeared later that year). He returned to England in 1787 and wrote Rights of Man 1791-92, then had to flee to revolutionary France. He was unable to leave France to return to the United States until 1802.

In our review of the book, Northern Protestants: An Unsettled People, page 11, Saturday Review, July 8, we referred to "the million and a half people who live in the north of Ireland who are collectively known as Protestants..." The total population of Northern Ireland is about 1.7m and of those about 54% are Protestant.

In our motorcycling report, page 5, Sport, yesterday, we described Joey Dunlop as a former 125cc world champion. In fact, he won the world Formula One title, not that for 125cc, five times.

In our feature You're nicked, monsieur, pages 8 and 9, The Guide, July 8, we somehow put Georgetown, Guyana, in Africa, some way from its real location in the north eastern corner of South America.

Contrary to what we said in her obituary, page 22, July 8, Genevieve Cooper did not work at the London Daily News. The error was inserted in the editing and was not the author's.

We gave an incomplete and (mercifully) unobtainable telephone number at the end of our feature, Harry, Jessie and Me, page 36, Weekend, July 8, for people wishing to order a reduced price copy of Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire. The CultureShop number in full is 0800 3166102.

Our feature, Life after Living Marxism, page 10, July 8, included among the "cultural glitterati" invited to speak at an event organised by the Institute of Ideas, Timberlake Wertenberger. That should have been Timberlake Wertenbaker. She was correctly named as the author of a letter, page 17, yesterday, in which she made it clear that her participation as a committee member of PEN implied no affiliation with the Institute of Ideas.

The television remote control handset illustrated on page 9, Media, yesterday, was accidentally flipped, as the reference to "no" rather than "on" digital may have suggested.

webTitle: The fur flies as Wolfe faces an intellectual backlash

fields.headline: The fur flies as Wolfe faces an intellectual backlash
fields.trailText: Tom Wolfe (The tyranny of theory, Saturday Review, July 8) is rarely gifted. He's an intellectual who can be erudite and funny at the same time. He can present his views in clear and entertaining prose. Pity that, when it's boiled down the argument turns out to be too simple, and the evidence turns out to be straw.
fields.body:
Tom Wolfe (The tyranny of theory, Saturday Review, July 8) is rarely gifted. He's an intellectual who can be erudite and funny at the same time. He can present his views in clear and entertaining prose. Pity that, when it's boiled down the argument turns out to be too simple, and the evidence turns out to be straw.

His beef against the Rococo Marxists only applies to those whose writing he thinks is too opaque, whose interests are too trendy, and whose demands (eg that the plural of woman is womyn) are just plain silly.

I attend conferences in sociology and cultural studies (I confess: our son was almost named Rococo!) where increasing numbers of young scholars from all over the world present a radical critique of society in plain language unmarred by the "political correctness" that so enrages people like Wolfe.
Max Farrar
Leeds

 Tom Wolfe's crude grapeshot blast against intellectuals needs fine sifting to reveal the odd nugget among the dross. He is right to keep a beady eye on poststructuralism, but without it we would not have so sharp a sense of the structuring power of discourse. The most eloquent refutation of Wolfe, also in Saturday Review, was the profile of Stuart Hall, whose admirable work rightly displays only the first of the categories Wolfe ascribes indiscriminately to intellectuals - scepticism, cynicism, irony and contempt.
Colin McArthur
London

 Tom Wolfe's ignorant and undignified rant against US intellectuals showed us that Marshall McLuhan's verdict - "moral indignation is a technique used to endow the idiot with dignity" - didn't get it quite right after all.
Prof Jane Caplan
Richmond, Surrey jcaplan@brynmawr.edu

 From beatnik to cold warrior, poor Tom Wolfe has become the kind of person he used to despise. Nowadays Wolfe presents us with a simplistic dualism that his muse Nietzsche never would have tolerated: we must either love America, and be virtuous, or hate it and be satirised.

Of course, there is an alternative - one can both admire American contributions to art and science in the 20th century, and abhor its foreign policy disasters and its treatment of its own underclass. Understanding this seeming paradox is what theory is for.
Richard A Wilson
Editor, Journal of Anthropological Theory
Anthrotheory@sussex.ac.uk

 Is Tom Wolfe saying that the problem with the US is insufficient self-satisfaction?
David Beeson
Strasbourg
dbeeson@imaginet.fr

 Why give so much space to a piece that, among many other quarter-truths, doubts the fascism of Franco? The generalissimo would be furious.
AD Atienza
Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk
tony@atienza.freeserve.co.uk
