fields.headline: Manchester's united
fields.standfirst:
It is no longer grim up north. But the regeneration of certain cities is due to independent visions rather than corporate strategies
North-south divide: special report
fields.trailText: Manchester is the most successful city in the United Kingdom outside London, but during the past decade Mancunians have noticed something deadly about their path to prosperity. It hides a stealth attack by centralised, London-based, corporate business culture.
fields.body:
Manchester is the most successful city in the United Kingdom outside London, but during the past decade Mancunians have noticed something deadly about their path to prosperity. It hides a stealth attack by centralised, London-based, corporate business culture.

The world's biggest Marks & Spencer (a mile to circumnavigate) and the world's best Waterstones (at least until they sacked its inspirational manager Robert Topping last month) are among the many flags waved by Manchester in justified PR for its current success. But a recent meeting of city activists asked bluntly: so what? Aren't whopping Waterstones and Marks & Sparks (and Starbucks, and Pr t à Manger and Café Uno) just as much the badges of Nottingham, Birmingham and Leeds?

Becoming Anywhereville UK has been a seductive danger to the big cities before. In the 60s, large new developments engulfed so many of their centres. Coincidental was the demise of great provincial names which told you unquestionably where you were: Schofields store in Leeds, Binns in Newcastle - some survive as names, but only a handful have their budgets and strategies decided outside the City.

That is the financial reality facing Manchester's city- centre independents, but they went ahead the other night to hammer out an agreement at The Cube, the cool local gallery. According to developer Nick Johnson, who owns the Atlas bar and brought back city centre living to Manchester in the 90s with Tom Bloxham of Urban Splash, "Independents generate wealth that stays here. Our money doesn't go off to the City. It's spent in the local economy."

This helps towards every regional city's dream of insulation from outside economic buffetings, especially that sense of powerlessness when accountants far away close down a plant, shop or bar for reasons which have nothing to do with the micro-economy. For that reason alone, Manchester city council is instinctively friendly towards the independents.

The council's attitude has also been shaped by the benign effects of the McEnroe Club. This was founded in the mid-90s in spontaneous, you-cannot-be-serious, horror at a banal marketing slogan - "Manchester's Up and Going", which was speedily dropped, along with most of the executives at the Marketing Manchester quango. The club has always been more of an idea than a formal association, but has become a conduit between bright sparks in the commercial sector and city hall. It helped, crucially, to boost the pride Manchester wears like a distinctive badge on the physical fabric of its post-IRA bomb development.

Tom Bloxham likes quoting the Athenian oath: "We will leave this city greater, better and more beautiful than it was left to us." That is evident in the quality of new building. The centre has its first new street in 50 years. A new view of the cathedral has been opened up and Tudor houses and pubs boldly dismantled and repositioned. The glass wall of M&S and the coming £60m Urbis art gallery and museum opposite the Printworks centre are world-class designs.

"There's been a shared understanding of each other's position, recognising the collective benefit of doing something that little bit better, that little bit different," says Nick Johnson. "The city took on the challenge to raise the quality of the built environment partly because we independents wouldn't stop banging on about it. If we can do it for the built environment, we can do it for the people who occupy the spaces that are created by the built environment. That's what this is about."

The banging-on illustrated another role unique to the independents. As pathfinders, they have taken risks - in the same way in which developer Peter Connolly has in Leeds. His daring in converting rotting mills - and a barge - triggered the regeneration of the Yorkshire city's disgusting riverfront in the early 90s. Similarly, the Atlas bar's £200,000 investment in Manchester's Castlefields was followed, when it was crystal clear that the venture was blue chip, by Wolverhampton & Dudley spending £2m on their Quay Bar just down the road.

The pattern is spreading, even to Manchester planners' supposed reservation for funky, one-off enterprises in the Northern Quarter. The warren of shoplets in Afflecks Palace, where Tom Bloxham started in business selling posters such as "On the sixth day, God created Man. . . chester", is having to get used to the idea of sharing the streets with £20m worth of mixed-use and private sector housing in Smithfield Buildings (mixed use which, crucially, developers AMEC have reserved in part for independent firms). On Canal Street, where Carol Ainscow got the village going with her independent bar a decade ago, Whitbread's now runs four gay pubs.

The independents' movement is not gunning for the corporates, only against their dominance. Mr Johnson and fellow-organisers acknowledge that design triumphed in the 90s' cityscape "not by belligerence but by clever negotiation": outside investment is an essential part of civic success. Rebellion is limited to demanding balance in order to "allow inde pendent operators to flourish and add a richness and dimension that we desperately need."

Last week the north-west's (non-statutory) regional assembly held a talk-in in Manchester, drawing energising groups such as Aurora, a boosters' club run by such people as Ruth Turner, co-founder of the Big Issue in the North. She has left the magazine (another Northern Quarter inhabitant) to go into lobbying and regional politicking full-time.

Ms Turner, Aurora and the others are devolutionists. They refer to the sense of distinct identity notable in Glasgow and Edinburgh, especially in the run-up to Scottish devolution. They reject the alternative, which would be to rename the north-west Anywhereville.

webTitle: Warmer weather due - 50 years from now

fields.headline: Warmer weather due - 50 years from now
fields.standfirst:
Met Office says blocked pattern means more rain to come

The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Geoff Jenkins of the Met Office has some good news for rain-hammered Britons. He and other weather experts have been running data through some of the world's most powerful supercomputers, and it's going to get warmer and drier.
fields.body:
Geoff Jenkins of the Met Office has some good news for rain-hammered Britons. He and other weather experts have been running data through some of the world's most powerful supercomputers, and it's going to get warmer and drier.

There is a downside. This is in 50 years' time, when the average temperature will have risen by 1.5 degrees celsius, and - in south-east England, anyway - there will be 20% less rainfall.

So much for the globally warmed future. In the cold, bleak here and now of a sodden July, Mr Jenkins's bad cop colleague Andy Yeatman has a simple explanation: the weather is temporarily blocked.

"It's a blocked weather pattern," he said. "At the moment those areas that are getting bad weather are keeping it and those that are getting good weather are keeping it."

It gets worse. "Our 30-day forecasts are just pointers," he said. "But the trends are that it might get a little bit better by the end of July or the beginning of August."

In the first 10 days of July Britain experienced an average temperature of 13.7C, 0.8 lower than usual. There were only three hours of sunshine a day - just over half the average for the month. Oddly, rainfall was half the average, but the month is still young.

Blocked weather cuts both ways. The famous soil-cracking summer of 1976 was caused by a similar stalling of weather, the difference being it was hot, not wintry. The same blockage is keeping southern Europe roasting as persistent high temperatures cause deaths and forest fires.

Our lost summer is jammed in mid-Atlantic, wedged between two areas of bad weather over Britain and the eastern seaboard of the US.

"Basically, you've got a huge great high in the mid-Atlantic and another one down towards the Balkans, with a low over the UK and the eastern US. They're that special distance apart and they ain't moving," said Mr Yeatman.

He gently suggested Britons should remember which country they lived in. "So many of us are used to going abroad now that we think our summers should be like they are abroad. But four or five weeks of dry, sunny weather is currently the exception rather than the norm in the UK. August is usually the second wettest month of the year."

In Sussex, where increasing numbers of English vineyard owners are putting their faith in a warm future, David Carr Taylor, producer of a sparkling English wine which has taken prizes against French champagne in competition, was sanguine about the weather.

There had been 10 days of below average temperatures, he said, but this was counterbalanced by good spring sunshine.

With 29 years in the business, Mr Carr Taylor confirmed a creeping warmth has set in over a decade. The grapes at the vineyard near Hastings now ripen two to three weeks earlier than they did 12 to 13 years ago.

The winegrower is more relaxed than the Royal Meteorological Society, which has gathered hundreds of weather experts from around the world for a millennium conference in soggy, overcast Cambridge to celebrate the organisation's 150th birthday, and has planned a garden party for tomorrow.

Richard Pettifer, the society's executive secretary, said: "Looking at the prognosis Wednesday does look as if it's going to be the best day of the week. That's entirely fortuitous. There are a lot of terribly learned people here and they're all poring over the charts."

fields.headline: The lost causes of crime
fields.trailText: The new crime statistics due on July 18, which are expected to show a rise in recorded crime of 3% and a 10% jump in violent crime, (Crime rise adds to Blair's woes, July 10), show that the Labour law and order theory has slipped its handcuffs.
fields.body:
The new crime statistics due on July 18, which are expected to show a rise in recorded crime of 3% and a 10% jump in violent crime, (Crime rise adds to Blair's woes, July 10), show that the Labour law and order theory has slipped its handcuffs.

Three years ago, like many others, I bought into the Labour promise that things would be better, yet it has become impossible to ignore the gap between the reality and the promise.

I believe that much of the rise in violent crime is linked to the increasing problem of drug misuse and the desperate measures that addicts resort to in order to obtain it. Three years after Labour came to power, there are still just four opiate detoxification beds in the city of Manchester, and an addicted heroin population of around 10,000.

Moreover we continue to release around 100,000 prisoners a year, and give each an amount of money less than one week of income support, in the full knowledge that they cannot receive benefits until they have been released for two weeks.

We have seen increasingly harsher criminal justice policies, but what happened to the promise that the government would be tough on the causes of crime too?
Mark Leech
Chief executive, Unlock

 Your extravagant claim that the annual recorded crime statistics will be "slipped out" on July 18 is fanciful nonsense, it betrays a woeful ignorance of the procedures I have put in place to prevent political interference with their publication.

The publication date for the crime statistics has been publicly known now for many months. This follows a change I made in October 1997 to ensure the objectivity of the Home Office's research and statistic work, and to improve the way in which crime statistics were recorded and published. As a result, decisions over publication dates for statistics are made by the director of research, development and statistics at the Home Office rather than ministers.

All this is in sharp contrast to the previous administration, whose ministers did pick and choose publication dates to suit their partisan ends.
Jack Straw MP
Home secretary

 Clearly, Lord Birt's appointment as the government's adviser on crime is based on New Labour's belief in the sanctity of transferable skills in their globalised world. I therefore look forward to the call from Tony Blair offering me, a criminologist, the chance to transfer my skills to the BBC for one day a week. I feel sure that I can bring an "outsider's view" to the corporation's work and stem the tide of criticism directed at it.
Prof Joe Sim
John Moores University
Liverpool

 Will the onerous duties now to be shouldered by Lord Birt cover crimes against public service broadcasting?
Dermot Carley
Chichester

 Marcel Berlins (Jack plays the blame game, July 10) summed up very accurately the concern of magistrates on hearing proposals by the Home Secretary to name and shame magistrates for wrong bail decisions.

It must be remembered that in general everyone has a right to be released on bail when they have not been convicted of the charge and it is up to the prosecution to object to that right. Bail decisions are not taken lightly and magistrates have to rely on information laid before the court and, indeed, have to state why bail is not granted in open court
Harry Mawdsley
Chairman, Magistrates' Association

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Nothing delights the Diary more than a reunion with an old friend, so this is as joyous a day as they come. This you may well not believe (it hasn't quite sunk in with us yet, either) but Helen Brinton has been the victim of a railway incident yet again
fields.body:
Nothing delights the Diary more than a reunion with an old friend, so this is as joyous a day as they come. This you may well not believe (it hasn't quite sunk in with us yet, either) but Helen Brinton has been the victim of a railway incident yet again. A so-called rival reveals that last Thursday the android MP for Peterborough excused some odd ranting to her constituency party by saying she was "terrified" after being robbed on the train ("left her purse on the table" as a transport policeman put it). This is the fifth serious incident. In June 1997, she was "mugged" (pickpocketed) at Euston, and that November another purse went missing in transit. In April 1998, she reported finding a woman passenger "semi-naked and crying" and claiming an attempted rape (later amended to "I lost my handbag"), and within a month she wrote of being marooned late at night inside a small Kent station that was locked and unmanned (she had to climb to freedom). And now this. Helen, we're begging you, do go and buy yourself a car.

 A day after Helen's trauma, Middlesbrough MP Stuart Bell was involved with the police himself. The erstwhile racy novelist was arrested over an alleged assault after his wife pranged her BMW into their neighbours' son's van. As an ecclesiastic commissioner and 17th most powerful spiritual leader in a Sunday Times list, surely Stuart knows the commandment that counsels "thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's wife nor his ass nor his ox, nor shalt thou let thy missus smash her Beamer into thy neighbours' son's van". But apparently not.

 Writing in Saturday's Telegraph, meanwhile, Daniel Johnson took as his subject the father-son relationship and its difficulties, but declined to share any insights about Paul. Even so, news of that very naughty boy arrives from a different quarter. On Thursday, even as Helen's purse was vanishing, Francis Wheen was being interviewed for Newsnight outside the Spectator party about another famous son, Euan Blair _ and filmed in the background, wandering about yelling "Gatecrashers! Gatecrashers!" was my sane and rational friend. Marvellous.

 Even as Paul was barging to the front of the queue to enter the party, still bellowing "Gatecrashers! Gatecrashers!" as he passed polite bearers of tickets, Spectator editor Boris the Jackal Johnson was rushing off to Henley for the selection meeting to choose Michael Heseltine's successor - and the splendid news is he's made it to the shortlist of three. "The guv' nor ain't 'ere," says the Arthur Mullard character when we call to congratulate him. "'E's gawn to talk to a couple of geezers about private 'elf care plans." A couple... but aren't there two others on that Henley shortlist? Surely he would not... "Don't you worry what my guv'nor would or wouldn't do," says the voice. "Just sod orf, sonny, and play with the traffic."

 Speaking of which, if the receiver hadn't been so swiftly replaced we would have asked for confirmation of rumour that the Jackal was seen in Islington driving a new Rolls-Royce with personalised number plates. Any information gratefully received.

 Finally to Roger Liddle, whose letter appears on the facing page today. For a key figure in the party of rapid rebuttal, waiting a week to deny an allegation seems a bit slack, while denying he said the Brown-Blair relationship was "deteriorating into loathing" may be viewed as Clintonesque semantic cuteness when we reported him saying that they loathe each other already. Perhaps Alastair should tell him to write again, this time denying the stuff about the lack of direction to European policy and Ali inventing the spot fines nonsense, but it was kind of Rog to revive the story when it appeared to have breathed its last. But what are friends for?

webTitle: Met chief calls for crime safety body

fields.headline: Met chief calls for crime safety body
fields.standfirst: Policing crime: special report
fields.trailText: The country's top police officer calls today for an independent watchdog to be set up with statutory powers to make builders and manufacturers responsible for fighting crime.
fields.body:
The country's top police officer calls today for an independent watchdog to be set up with statutory powers to make builders and manufacturers responsible for fighting crime.

Sir John Stevens, commissioner of the Metropolitan police, believes society must go "upstream of crime" if the service is to cope with the challenges of the 21st century.

Today he tells the Police Foundation, the policing research and development charity, that designers of products such as mobile phones and television sets, as well as builders and architects, must be called to account by a crime safety executive.

The publicly funded body could prosecute companies that flouted crime prevention standards and would be run on similar lines to the health and safety executive.

A Scotland Yard source said: "The commissioner believes that crime prevention has to start in the concept stage, when products are being designed. A crime safety executive would make manufacturers much more responsible for goods that are prone to crime. This is just an idea at the moment. There are no firm proposals."

Another speaker, Nick Ross, presenter of BBC TV's Crimewatch programme, is expected to tell the foundation that mobile phone crime has become an industry. He will call on manufacturers to make phones that are unusable if stolen.

fields.headline: International roundup
fields.trailText: Landslide kills dump dwellers
fields.body:
Landslide kills dump dwellers

At least 46 people, including many young children, were killed on the outskirts of the Philippine capital, Manila, when part of an enormous rubbish dump collapsed yesterday on to a group of shanty houses. Dozens are still missing.

The dump's foundations had been weakened by Typhoon Kai-Tak, which battered the Philippines for five days, leaving at least 39 people dead.

Twenty-seven survivors were pulled from the mountain of stinking refuse in the suburb of Quezon City, where 60,000 scavengers live by recycling refuse.

Rescuers were hampered by a large section of the dump catching fire shortly after the landslide. It is thought the blaze was started by a severed power cable.

Survivors said they heard a sound like rumbling thunder and then watched in horror as a wall of rubbish 15 metres high crashed down on flimsy homes made of wood and corrugated iron.

The dump takes a quarter of the 4,500 tonnes of refuse Manila's 10m people produce daily.

John Aglionby

Berlin lays red carpet for Khatami

Thousands of demonstrators dodged tight security yesterday to protest against a visit to Germany by President Mohammed Khatami of Iran.

The police rounded up 50 suspected troublemakers. A spokesman for the interior minister said intelligence reports suggested that the Iranian opposition had been planning a "massive disruption".

Leaders of the National Council of Resistance (NCR), the political wing of the Iraq-based Mojahedin Khalq armed opposition group, claimed that several thousand of their supporters had been turned back at Germany's normally open frontiers.

"Freedom of expression is being curtailed at the heart of Europe for the sake of Khatami," said Perviz Khazai, the NCR's representative in Scandinavia.

Mr Khatami, who was welcomed with full military honours at Tegel airport, is the first Iranian leader to visit Germany since a violent trip by the late shah in 1967, when a German student was shot dead by the police. His arrival in Berlin marked the latest stage in a concerted attempt by European states to strengthen his hand in the still-unresolved stand-off between moderates and conservatives in the Islamist regime.

John Hooper, Berlin

Sanctions consensus crumbles

EU foreign ministers conceded for the first time yesterday that sanctions against Yugoslavia are not working and raised the prospect that some of them may need to be dropped, a move which Britain strongly opposes.

In a frank public statement which is likely to anger the Foreign Office, the French minister, Hubert Védrine said most EU countries believed the sanctions were failing to achieve their stated aim of undermining President Slobodan Milosevic.

EU diplomats disclosed that only Britain, the Netherlands and Denmark favour maintaining a hard line on sanctions and predicted that the oil embargo would be dropped "within months".

Britain has profound reservations about reducing sanctions. "You can only make these changes by looking at the way that things are developing on the ground . . . now is not the time to send such a signal," a British official said.

Andrew Osborn, Brussels

Fire sweeps heatwave Europe

Forest fires, fanned by strong winds and aided by sweltering temperatures, engulfed vast swaths of southern Europe yesterday, costing lives in France, Italy, Bulgaria, Cyprus and Greece.

Six people, mostly firefighters, died battling the blazes. Hundreds of thousands of hectares of forest, farmland and olive groves have been reduced to cinders in a heatwave which claimed about 40 lives last week.

Firefighters said they could not recall so many blazes in Europe at the same time.

Helena Smith, Athens

Russian industrialist murdered

A powerful Russian industrialist was assassinated as he left his home in the Urals city of Yekaterinburg for work early yesterday.

Oleg Belonenko, general director of Uralmash, a machine-tool factory in the city, was shot twice in the head as he left his flat and walked towards a chauffeur-driven car. He died a few hours later on the operating table. The two assassins fatally shot Belonenko's chauffeur twice in the stomach before fleeing.

Colleagues suggested that Belonenko's murder was prompted by his fight against mafia groups. Yekaterinburg, 900 miles east of Moscow, became a notorious criminal centre at the beginning of the 1990s when several rival gangs tried to take control of the city's business interests by violent intimidation.

To the consternation of Uralmash factory executives, the most powerful of them became known as Uralmash, after the suburb where both the factory and the criminal leadership are based.

In an attempt to distance the factory from the criminals, Belonenko tried to acquire a patent on the Uralmash name and began suing mafia-owned businesses for using it. "I believe he was killed to show that it's not safe to stick your neck out," a colleague said.

Amelia Gentleman, Moscow

Would-be assassin vilifies Pope

The man who shot the Pope in 1981 accused the Vatican yesterday of being the "enemy of God and humanity", and said he had launched "a cultural war" against the Holy See.

Mehmet Ali Agca made the accusation at his trial in Istanbul for the armed robbery of a soft-drinks factory, stealing a car, and robbing a jewellers shop, all in 1979.

Italy pardoned Agca and extradited him to Turkey last month after he had served almost 20 years for shooting the Pope. The Vatican was instrumental in his pardon. At that time he said through a lawyer that he was grateful to the Pope and the Vatican.

But as he was being led out of court in Istanbul, Agca shouted: "The Vatican is the enemy of God, it is the enemy of humanity. I will make the Vatican empire . . . feel remorse. I have launched a cultural war against the Vatican."

Later his lawyer distributed a handwritten statement in which Agca accusing the Vatican of "changing" the secrets of Fatima and orchestrating his attempt to assassinate the Pope - the Pope believes the "third secret" was his attempted murder and that he was saved by the intervention of the Madonna of Fatima.

"My Catholic brothers, I love you, why do you not abandon a Vatican which arranges the assassination of its own Pope?" the statement said.

AP, Istanbul

Dozens are still missing. The dump's foundations had been weakened by Typhoon Kai-Tak, which battered the Philippines for five days, leaving at least 39 people dead. Twenty-seven survivors were pulled from the mountain of stinking refuse in the suburb of Quezon City, where 60,000 scavengers live by recycling refuse. Rescuers were hampered by a large section of the dump catching fire shortly after the landslide. It is thought the blaze was started by a severed power cable. fields.headline: Two steps back
fields.standfirst:
Caution rules on PR and Commons reform
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The lust for modernisation which ran through Labour's 1997 manifesto did not stop at the doors of parliament. Labour's appetite for parliamentary reform made the Tory alternative look timid. Even the system we use for electing MPs would not be sacrosanct. An independent commission would be asked to recommend a proportional alternative to first-past-the-post (FPTP). The nation would then decide in a referendum.
fields.body:
The lust for modernisation which ran through Labour's 1997 manifesto did not stop at the doors of parliament. Labour's appetite for parliamentary reform made the Tory alternative look timid. Even the system we use for electing MPs would not be sacrosanct. An independent commission would be asked to recommend a proportional alternative to first-past-the-post (FPTP). The nation would then decide in a referendum.

That was what you might have expected. The Conservatives, after 18 years in power, were painfully aware how difficult government was already. Labour, powerless to hold up the Thatcherite tide through 18 years in opposition, was warier of executive power. But perspectives shift when the parties change places. How far we have come since May 1997 has been neatly demonstrated this week. The issue of changing the voting system has been shelved until further notice. And yesterday the Conservatives published plans for parliamentary reform which far upstage anything yet offered by Labour.

Labour duly fulfilled its pledge by setting up a Modernisation of the House of Commons select committee which published its second report last week, calling for an end to late night sittings and for routine timetabling of bills. But where they are happy with modest, incremental changes, a committee set up by William Hague and chaired by the academic and Tory life peer Philip Norton wants radical modernisation. Its aim is "to shift the balance in the relationship between parliament and government, providing parliament with the capacity to call government effectively to account". Not so radical, perhaps, when one remembers that much of this agenda - like freeing select committees from control by the whips, and giving them proper backup - was the cry of reform pamphleteers in the 60s. But other proposals - for select committee chairs to be paid ministerial rates, for inquiries into how new legislation is faring, for a cut in the number of cabinet and other ministers as well as PPSs - give it new bite. Since Mr Hague aspires to be prime minister, and therefore has to be wary about "providing parliament with the capacity to call government effectively to account", he has not endorsed the lot. But he says that the next Tory government will use Norton as its route map. That is a useful start - if he means it.

And then there is PR. Labour duly fulfilled its pledge by setting up a committee under Roy Jenkins. The committee was canny. It did not recommend some best-possible system which no one would implement: its findings were tailored - excessively so - to winning approval from Tony Blair and Paddy Ashdown and appealing to New Labour tastes. Jenkins favoured the Alternative Vote but with a top-up to make the results more proportional than AV, which can exaggerate government majorities even more than FPTP. But even that was too much. Faced with revolt at the weekend's party policy forum, Peter Mandelson talked in terms of using straight AV, discarding Jenkins's decorous add-on. But now Labour has decided not to move on this front at all until new voting systems in Scotland and Wales have "bedded down". We have yet to hear on which five tests that will be judged to have happened.

The outcome in both cases is this. Party pressures and governmental convenience have tempered and amended the New Labour dream, the vision of a new kind of politics with which Mr Blair wooed the nation in those innocent days three years ago. Some will call that realism. For others, a better word is retreat.

fields.headline: An odd concept of loyalty
fields.standfirst:
The twisted logic of Drumcree Six
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: One advantage of the nonexistent summer is that it rained on what might have been a violent parade. Thanks to the persistent drizzle, the weekend standoff in Portadown - billed, like a Hollywood blockbuster, as Drumcree Six - turned into something of a damp squib. Hundreds of the marchers sought refuge from the rain rather than face down the Royal Ulster Constabulary, who had come to stop them marching their traditional route down the mainly Catholic Garvaghy Road.
fields.body:
One advantage of the nonexistent summer is that it rained on what might have been a violent parade. Thanks to the persistent drizzle, the weekend standoff in Portadown - billed, like a Hollywood blockbuster, as Drumcree Six - turned into something of a damp squib. Hundreds of the marchers sought refuge from the rain rather than face down the Royal Ulster Constabulary, who had come to stop them marching their traditional route down the mainly Catholic Garvaghy Road.

But if Sunday night was mercifully more peaceful than had been feared, Drumcree Six has not been a violence-free affair. On the contrary, the standoff has inspired trouble across Northern Ireland, from the petrol bombs and burning barricades in "loyalist" areas to Sunday's 300lb car bomb in Stewartstown - planted by the rejectionist Real IRA in a bid to ratchet up the Drumcree crisis.

Still, the chief tension gripping the province is not so much between Catholics and Protestants as between Protestants and Protestants. For this is a civil war within unionism, even within the Orange Order itself, centred on a direct, rejectionist challenge to David Trimble and his strategy of compromise: witness the branding by the Drumcree marchers of Mr Trimble as a Judas who deserves to be drummed out of the order - if he is not lynched first.

The Ulster Unionist leader has a strong case to throw back to his detractors. He can charge them on a multiple count of hypocrisy. First, they are guilty of what Progressive Unionist leader David Ervine calls "à la carte United Kingdom-ism" - meaning that these loyalists pick and choose what it is they are loyal to. They insist that the RUC must remain unchanged, even as they pelt it with stones and brand it "the military wing of Sinn Fein". They claim to be loyal to UK law, yet ignore the ruling of the parades commission, a fully lawful UK body. They say they hate the peace process because it puts former terrorists into government, yet their leaders refuse to condemn violence and they are cheered on by a convicted loyalist terrorist, Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair. Mr Trimble is on a collision course with the hardliners of Orangeism. He wants to reduce their influence within unionism. He is right. For what they have demonstrated this last week is that they are stuck in the bigotry of the past. And that is the force to be stood against at Drumcree.

webTitle: Abduction fear over Briton in Tokyo

fields.headline: Abduction fear over Briton in Tokyo
fields.trailText: Japanese detectives were yesterday investigating the possibility that a missing British woman may have been abducted by a customer of the Tokyo nightclub where she was working as a hostess.
fields.body:
Japanese detectives were yesterday investigating the possibility that a missing British woman may have been abducted by a customer of the Tokyo nightclub where she was working as a hostess.

Lucie Blackman, 21, who speaks no Japanese, has been missing since July 1, when she failed to show up after reportedly spending an afternoon at the seaside with an unknown man.

Detectives yesterday questioned the owner of the Casablanca nightclub about the man, but they have also not discounted claims that Ms Blackman might have been kidnapped by a religious cult.

"We cannot rule anything in or out at the moment," said Toshihiko Mii, deputy superintendent at the Azabu police station. "The truth is that we have so little to go on that we still don't know what to make of this case."

Ms Blackman, a former British Airways flight attendant from Sevenoaks, Kent, began working at the Casablanca, a small bar in the Roppongi entertainment district, soon after arriving in Japan on a tourist visa on May 4.

She and several other hostesses from Britain, Australia and Sweden poured drinks and chatted with customers, who pay more than £150 to spend time with them. Such clubs are either run by or pay protection money to Yakuza gangsters.

It is not prostitution, but the women are sometimes expected to join customers for afternoon dates at coffee shops, cinemas or the beach. Tetsuo Nishi, the manager of the bar, was reluctant to provide the names of customers.

"We have good and bad customers. The good ones, who leave their business cards, aren't likely to be involved. And the bad ones either don't tell us their names or they lie."

Mr Nishi said that he did not think Ms Blackman was with a customer because Saturday and Sunday were her days off.

Police are making little headway with two other lines of investigation: the possibilities that Ms Blackman might have entered a religious cult or that she might have disappeared suddenly because of depression.

Louise Phillips, who flew out with Ms Blackman to work at the Casablanca, said that she received a disturbing call two days after the disappearance from a man who claimed to be with the missing woman in Chiba, a district next to Tokyo with many beaches.

"You'll never see Lucie again," he said in broken English. "She is in our cult." Detectives have been checking the calls taken on Ms Phillips's mobile phone and they have also drawn up a list of religious organisations in Chiba.

Ms Blackman's friends dismissed the notion that she was depressed or in trouble.

"She has seemed very cheerful recently. She's also streetwise - a real tough cookie," said a regular drinking partner, who works as a barman at a club in the same building in Roppongi. "It's not like her to go missing."

Ms Blackman failed to collect her pay, which was due on the day she disappeared.

The lack of progress in the investigation is of growing concern to Ms Blackman's family. Later this week, her father, Tim Blackman, will fly to Tokyo to join his younger daughter, Sophie, in the hunt.

"Much of the information we have remains dubious," Sophie Blackman said. "I know Lucie well. It wouldn't be expected of her to go off with someone she doesn't know."

Lucie Blackman's disappearance has received extensive coverage in the Japanese media, and the businessman Richard Branson has offered to help with a leafleting campaign.

Officials at the British embassy are also assisting the local authorities in the search.

webTitle: Jail for doctor who preyed on male patients

fields.headline: Jail for doctor who preyed on male patients
fields.trailText: An investigation was launched yesterday into how a family doctor was able to sexually assault male patients undetected over a 17-year period.
fields.body:
An investigation was launched yesterday into how a family doctor was able to sexually assault male patients undetected over a 17-year period.

Peter Green, 49, was yesterday sentenced to eight years in jail for nine counts of indecent assault against young patients at his Loughborough surgery. He denied all the charges.

Green, of Oakham, Rutland, picked his victims like a "burglar picks a house" - because they were vulnerable and unlikely to tell, Nottingham crown court heard. Some of his victims had been referred after routine school check-ups.

The judge, Mr Justice Astill, told him: "You are an utter disgrace to a noble profession. You were using the privacy of your consulting room to satisfy your own sexual wishes.

"You started along this course not long after you had qualified and carried on for a number of years."

During the seven-and-a-half week trial, witnesses said they had felt compelled to bow to Green's greater medical knowledge.

Green was cleared of a further nine indecency charges against male patients and their female partners.

Peter Joyce QC, prosecuting, asked that a further 21 counts, alleging indecent assaults on men and administering a drug with intent to assault, should be left on file.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, yesterday requested an investigation by the commission for health improvements (CHI) into how Green's assaults went undetected for so long.

The health minister, John Denham, said: "I am saddened by the fact that the public's trust in the medical profession may be shaken once again by an individual who was very clearly out of control.

"This case shows very clearly how difficult it was in the old NHS to spot and take action in cases such as this, because of the lack of proper systems for monitoring and regulating medical practice."

Green's case brings to a total of four the number of ongoing official investigations into health professionals in England and Wales.

Peter Homa, CHI director, said: "When things go wrong in the health service, it is vital to find out why so that lessons can be learned for the whole NHS.

"The reports of our investigations will, at times, make uncomfortable reading for people inside and outside the health service."

He added: "We will not flinch at that."

"This case shows very clearly how difficult it was in the old NHS to spot and take action in cases such as this, because of the lack of proper systems for monitoring and regulating medical practice." Green's case brings to a total of four the number of ongoing official investigations into health professionals in England and Wales. Peter Homa, CHI director, said: "When things go wrong in the health service, it is vital to find out why so that lessons can be learned for the whole NHS. "The reports of our investigations will, at times, make uncomfortable reading for people inside and outside the health service." He added: "We will not flinch at that."

fields.headline: Racists threaten with a noose
fields.trailText: Rope fashioned into a noose, among the most potent symbols in the racist's armoury, is being increasingly used to intimidate black workers, according to US employment experts. The Equal Opportunity Commission has at least 20 such cases on its books, but the it says that this represents only part of the problem, because it handles only a fraction   of the allegations and many companies settle out of court.
fields.body:
Rope fashioned into a noose, among the most potent symbols in the racist's armoury, is being increasingly used to intimidate black workers, according to US employment experts. The Equal Opportunity Commission has at least 20 such cases on its books, but the it says that this represents only part of the problem, because it handles only a fraction of the allegations and many companies settle out of court.

A noose may be left on a worker's chair, on a door or in a locker, but the culprit is hard to find because he or she invariably acts anonymously.

"What I see as alarming is not just that employers are fighting us in courts but that they're also making statements implying that such incidents are just horseplay," said Ida Castro, the commission's chairwoman.

Lynch mobs killed thousands of black people between 1865, when the civil war ended, and 1968, and memories of those years have been stirred this year by Beyond Sanctuary, a photographic exhibition at the New York Historical Society.

"[Nooses are] a sign that something serious is going on in the workplace," said David Bennet Ross, a partner in a Chicago law firm which represents employers.

Some lawyers believe that the practice of using a noose to intimidate employees is a reflection of the bigotry of young white workers who were either not alive or have no knowledge of the civil rights campaigns of the 1960s.

The success of affirmative action in winning jobs for minorities in areas that were previously closed to them is also put forward.

Jeff Lanza, an FBI agent in Kansas City, where two cases are being investigated, said nooses appeared to be replacing burning crosses as icons of hatred.

"I've been here 12 years and I can't remember any other noose cases that preceded the two we now have," Mr Lanza said.

Asians, Hispanics and Native Americans have also been picked on. Their tormentors face up to 10 years in jail.

The commission's Miami office is bringing a case on behalf of a man who says that while he was working for a tree company he had a noose placed around his neck and then pulled.

The company declined to comment on the allegation.

In another case, a black groundsman at a Florida country club said that other workers held a noose in front of him and asked him if he wanted to go for a ride. The club says that the case is without merit.

Claims of racial harassment, which numbered about 10,000 in the 1980s, jumped to 50,000 in the 90s, the commission says.

fields.headline: A very rich Gent indeed
fields.standfirst: Deals like this one need to be stamped on
fields.trailText: Protests by UK institutional shareholders over the £10m bonus for Chris Gent, chief executive of Vodafone AirTouch, are bound to fail - if only because most of the shares are owned abroad - but it is very important that they are made. No one these days disputes the idea that successful managers should be properly remunerated. Chris Gent has converted Vodafone, a company that did not exist 20 years ago, into the world's biggest mobile phone service provider by a series of bold acquisitions. As a result there could be benefits not only for shareholders but also for the country, especially if mobile internet phones become the biggest selling consumer product on the planet.
fields.body:
Protests by UK institutional shareholders over the £10m bonus for Chris Gent, chief executive of Vodafone AirTouch, are bound to fail - if only because most of the shares are owned abroad - but it is very important that they are made. No one these days disputes the idea that successful managers should be properly remunerated. Chris Gent has converted Vodafone, a company that did not exist 20 years ago, into the world's biggest mobile phone service provider by a series of bold acquisitions. As a result there could be benefits not only for shareholders but also for the country, especially if mobile internet phones become the biggest selling consumer product on the planet.

If Mr Gent and his colleagues deliver new wealth to the company they deserve to be rewarded (though, of course, they are not the only employees involved in the success). But that is not the issue. Mr Gent's £10m bonus (on top of earnings last year of £1.4m, excluding existing share options) is a "thank you" for negotiating the takeover of Mannesmann of Germany. Some £5m is to be paid under a scheme (details of which have not been disclosed) linked to how the share price performs in future. That, at least, relates it to future success. But the other £5m is being paid in cash simply because Gent concluded the deal.

This is an alarming development. Vodafone is now one of Britain's biggest companies and this move could set a precedent that prompts other companies to reward directors for negotiating takeovers, good or bad. Since research shows that most mergers fail to deliver benefits (including to shareholders), this development should be stamped on from the start. Vodafone's own share price has fallen from its post-merger peak. The company should withdraw this element of the package before "deal bonuses" become a standard practice. If directors make deals simply because they give them risk-free bonuses, there is likely to be a negative impact on the whole of industry.

webTitle: New lead in Sarah Payne hunt

fields.headline: New lead in Sarah Payne hunt
fields.standfirst:
Upset girl seen in M6 toilets hours after eight-year-old disappeared
Sussex police appeal
fields.trailText: Detectives leading the search for Sarah Payne were last night investigating a possible sighting of the missing eight-year-old at a service station hundreds of miles from where she vanished.
fields.body:
Detectives leading the search for Sarah Payne were last night investigating a possible sighting of the missing eight-year-old at a service station hundreds of miles from where she vanished.

The youngster, who was accompanied by a man, was described as being "upset" and said her name was Sarah.

Sussex police said the girl, wearing a blue dress similar to the one worn by Sarah when she disappeared on July 1, was seen in the women's toilets at Knutsford services on the northbound carriageway of the M6 motorway in Cheshire.

A woman who saw that the girl was upset asked if she was all right and what her name was, to which the child replied: "Sarah."

Chief Inspector Mike Alderson said the sighting was at 5am on Sunday July 2, around 10 hours after Sarah disappeared from a country lane near her grandparents' house in Kingston, West Sussex.

He said: "This is the first significant sighting we have got. Her name was Sarah, she fitted the description and she was wearing a blue dress. If you were leaving Sussex and travelling northwards it would be around that sort of time that you would be up there."

Ch Insp Alderson said the woman had contacted police "several days ago" and that investigators had been working on the new lead since then. The call is among 5,000 made to police since the hunt began.

But police said it had not been appropriate to make the information public until yesterday.

Ch Insp Alderson said that the witness had not been able to say from a photograph whether the child she had spoken to was the missing girl.

Detectives were continuing to interview employees at the service station and appealed for any motorist who might have seen something to come forward.

Ch Insp Alderson said: "We want to hear from people everywhere, not just in Knutsford. Where did they go from Knutsford? Did they go to Wales, Liverpool, Scotland? Did anyone see them at another service station?"

He added it was not possible to scan Knutsford CCTV for further clues as the system had not been working at the time.

The assistant chief constable of Sussex police, Nigel Yeo, said the man seen with the child was "white, aged 30, around 6ft tall, with a solid build, crinkly sandy hair, clean-shaven and with a strong jaw and wide nose".

He was wearing a dark grey bomber jacket, washed out black jeans and a plum shirt.

Mr Yeo told a press conference at Littlehampton police station: "It is very important that if that person with the little girl is aware that they were there and is listening to this we really need to get hold of him."

Police are also appealing for information from anyone who rented out a lock-up garage around Littlehampton or Worthing to someone with a white van, or anyone who saw a white van entering or leaving a lock-up garage in that area, around the time Sarah went missing.

Mr Yeo was accompanied at the press conference by Sarah's mother, father and grandfather, who held tightly to each others' hands throughout, looking drawn and exhausted.

Sara Payne, 31, made an emotional plea to whoever had her daughter to "please send her back to her family".

She said: "We know you love her as much as we do. Of course you do, nobody wouldn't. It would be impossible not to love her. Please, I understand what you are going through but please send her back."

fields.headline: A kind of homecoming
fields.standfirst:
Real Lives : As a child she was spirited from Austria at the outbreak of war, and has watched its continuing fascination with far-right politics from afar. But returning to write a book, Hella Pick has at last reconciled herself to her homeland


The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: As a child she was spirited from Austria at the outbreak of war, and has watched its continuing fascination with far-right politics from afar. But returning to write a book,  Hella Pick has at last reconciled herself to her homeland
fields.body:
Would I ever be able to see Austria as my Heimat? For a long time the question did not pose itself - even though I frequently came to Austria, both professionally as a journalist and on holiday. Alienation was too profound. Now something has changed. Researching and writing this book [Guilty Victim] has brought me closer to Austria. It has been a kind of homecoming.

If others are surprised that I could reach such a conclusion, I am even more surprised myself. How to explain the paradox: that someone who was uprooted at a young age from Hitler's Ostmark - as it was called after its annexation by Nazi Germany - and who reached Britain in 1939 in a kindertransport (evacuation of children) as a bewildered refugee, could ever again come to feel comfortable and at ease in Austria?

I have always felt that the wounds of being uprooted all those years ago can never heal entirely. However well integrated into British life, some damage remains. I have virtually no memory of life before coming to Britain, and only the vaguest recollection of arriving in London and huddling in a big hall with the other children on my kindertransport , as we waited to be claimed by British families prepared to take care of us. I knew no English, and remember nothing of my first term at school.

I was fortunate that my mother managed to reach Britain just before war broke out, and I was able to live with her in the Lake District where she worked as a cook. Even as a schoolchild I had to carry documents describing me as an enemy alien. For several years I refused to speak German. Nor could I bring myself to acknowledge that I was Jewish until my first visit to New York, when it dawned on me that it was possible for large numbers of Jews to assimilate into a national culture and lead unmolested lives.

Unlike many other Austrian and German refugees, my mother did not develop a dislike or hatred of her former countrypeople, and she never encouraged me to reject Austria after the war. Eventually she even started taking holidays there, although she never went back to Vienna.

Still, it is no accident that the title of my book qualifies Austria as a "guilty victim". While I was writing it, I learned a great deal that shocked me profoundly. I had not fully understood the extent to which far too many Austrians still cultivate their big lie - the delusion that as a country and as individuals they were Hitler's victims, and only exceptionally Hitler's willing executioners. Or again, the extent to which anti-semitism manifested itself among the first generation of Austria's postwar leaders, even though several had themselves been in concentration camps. There were more uncomfortable questions. How endemic is Austria's anti-semitism? How could it elect Kurt Waldheim as head of state? How could almost a third of Austria's electorate vote for Jörg Haider, and how could the others countenance a coalition that gave Haider's Freedom party a major role in government this year?

Many would argue that Austria is beyond redemption and must remain alien territory for victims lucky enough to have survived the Nazi era. But Austria does not conform to the stereotypes in which it is so often perceived. It is not a neo-Nazi state. The sinister cloak-and-dagger impression of Vienna belongs to history. It has become a prosperous country with an enviable quality of life. As a society, even though it is conformist and its elites are cynical, it does not suffer from political apathy - on the contrary, there is political argument wherever two or more are gathered. It may not solve anything; but at least people at all levels feel involved.

Haider is abhorrent to me, but he does not personify Austria. One of the heartening byproducts of his electoral success has been a far-reaching debate that contains the seeds of a much needed rejuvenation of the two mainstream parties, and a strengthening of the admirable Green party.

When I first returned to Vienna, soon after the 1955 state treaty (under which the allies agreed their withdrawal from Austria), there was an overwhelming sense of being a stranger, an outsider; or at best a tourist. This feeling persisted in later visits, when I was working for the Guardian. But a sort of watershed came in 1980, when I was invited to the celebrations marking the 25th anniversary of the state treaty. Bruno Kreisky, who was then chancellor, was trying to persuade Auslandsoesterreicher (Austrians living abroad, as the Austrians prefer to portray Nazi victims who had escaped as refugees) to associate themselves more closely with their former country.

In the company of ex-Austrians who had made a distinguished life for themselves in Europe or the US, I experienced for the first time an odd sense of association with a national entity called Austria. Yet, not long afterwards, when Kreisky asked me if I wanted to have my Austrian nationality restored, I turned it down: I had no wish for dual nationality.

My relationship with Austria remained uncertain until the early 90s, when two things happened. Close friends, Auslandsoesterreicher who have moved back to Vienna and have a house in the mountains, invited me to stay with them. I have been back almost every summer and made to feel part of an extended family and circle of friends. At about the same time I was working on a biography of Simon Wiesenthal, the so-called Nazi-hunter, who has made his home in Vienna. I spent a lot of time there, again expanding my circle of friends. I began to appreciate the range of views that existed and the extent to which many people were grappling with their consciences and that of their country.

Later, as I researched the new book, a long string of interviews brought home to me that among the younger, postwar generations, the need to take cover behind the big lie - the victim syndrome - is not as pronounced as it is among their elders. Instead there is well-founded cynicism about a democratic process that keeps tired politicians in power and seems unable to break the coalition monopoly of Austria's two big mainstream parties.

Unfortunately, Haider was better able to exploit the sense of impotence among Austria's grassroots than anyone else around.

Of course, it is possible to argue that Haider can do this because he expresses far-right views that appeal to Austria's inbred Nazi instincts. I believe that this is only a very small part of the story. In sum, I need not cover my head in shame for confessing that Austria, and not only Britain, now increasingly counts for me as home.

Guilty Victim - Austria from the Holocaust to Haider, by Hella Pick is published by IB Tauris, priced £24.50

webTitle: Parishioners urged to put 5% of take-home pay on plate

fields.headline: Parishioners urged to put 5% of take-home pay on plate
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Churchgoers should double their donations to the plate at Sunday services and stop donating candles and flowers, a report to the Church of England Synod in York suggested yesterday.
fields.body:
Churchgoers should double their donations to the plate at Sunday services and stop donating candles and flowers, a report to the Church of England Synod in York suggested yesterday.

It challenged churchgoers to give at least 5% of their weekly take-home pay, "as an initial target", to reduce the church's financial problems. That would mean about £15 a week for families on average incomes. Current giving averages £6.37.

The proposal follows a report, First to the Lord, published at the synod which said that not all money raised in parishes was used sensibly; too much was spent on committees and not enough on priests.

Yesterday's report states: "There are those in most parishes who have traditionally given items to the church such as candles, wine, flowers. It would be wise to approach them sensitively and explain that it would be better for them to give the money to the church under Gift Aid and for the church to buy these items, in their name if they so wished."

Last year parishioners gave about £467m to the collection plate, towards the church's overall income of £730m. It spent £704m. About 800,000 people attend services a week.

Launching a debate on the report, the Right Rev John Packer, bishop of Ripon and Leeds, said: "If we loved God half as much as we love our grandchildren, money would be coming out of the church's ears. I do not apologise for that. It seems to me to be resonant of some of Jesus's phraseology in comparing our response to him with our response to our family ties. I am reliably informed that things are so hard in one fairly affluent Liverpool parish that they have cancelled their order for communion wine from the church suppliers... and resorted to the supermarket."

The bishop called for the church to make better use of European grants, national lottery contributions and English Heritage support.

The report said churches should consider investing in larger collection boxes to take account of the weight of extra money expected to come in.

 A Church of England report yesterday said the urban fund, set up in 1987 in response to its Faith in the City report drawing attention to urban poverty, might have to be run down because a fresh fundraising campaign would cost more to organise than it would raise.

The fund has pumped more than £37m into renewal projects, but the number of donors is declining by 2,000 a year, the report said.

 Clergy accused of immorality and other offences are likely to be brought before tribunals rather than ecclesiastical courts, following synod decisions. The standard of proof required will be lowered to the balance of probability. However, the new system will require parliamentary approval.

Last year parishioners gave about £467m to the collection plate, towards the church's overall income of £730m. It spent £704m. About 800,000 people attend services a week. Launching a debate on the report, the Right Rev John Packer, bishop of Ripon and Leeds, said: "If we loved God half as much as we love our grandchildren, money would be coming out of the church's ears. I do not apologise for that. It seems to me to be resonant of some of Jesus's phraseology in comparing our response to him with our response to our family ties. I am reliably informed that things are so hard in one fairly affluent Liverpool parish that they have cancelled their order for communion wine from the church suppliers... and resorted to the supermarket." The bishop called for the church to make better use of European grants, national lottery contributions and English Heritage support. The report said churches should consider investing in larger collection boxes to take account of the weight of extra money expected to come in.  A Church of England report yesterday said the urban fund, set up in 1987 in response to its Faith in the City report drawing attention to urban poverty, might have to be run down because a fresh fundraising campaign would cost more to organise than it would raise. The fund has pumped more than £37m into renewal projects, but the number of donors is declining by 2,000 a year, the report said.  Clergy accused of immorality and other offences are likely to be brought before tribunals rather than ecclesiastical courts, following synod decisions. The standard of proof required will be lowered to the balance of probability. However, the new system will require parliamentary approval.

webTitle: Drugs cocktail 'killed' patients at French clinic

fields.headline: Drugs cocktail 'killed' patients at French clinic
fields.trailText: The pristine wards behind the steel and glass facade of La Martinière private clinic in Saclay, in the Paris suburbs, give no clue to the five years of horror that are alleged to have occurred since it opened.
fields.body:
The pristine wards behind the steel and glass facade of La Martinière private clinic in Saclay, in the Paris suburbs, give no clue to the five years of horror that are alleged to have occurred since it opened.

But nurses wept yesterday as they talked about the "cocktail of death" which they said was served to the old and dying, killing between 20 and 40 patients.

The 120-bed clinic has been almost emptied by families who came at the weekend to take relatives home, driven by rumours of necrophilia, body snatching and other practices which a public prosecutor described as "surpassing all understanding".

As police and judicial investigators inspected the clinic, set up by former military doctors, officials warned against adding "ghoulish fantasy" to allegations of what might turn out to be killing for convenience by overworked staff.

One of the six nurses who have talked to the police anonymously said she believed that intensive care patients had been given the "cocktail of death" - a mixture of sleeping draughts - so that doctors could have their weekends free.

"I thought I was going mad," the nurse said. "It seemed that everyone avoided talking about what was going on. I remember seeing an old patient walking about and laughing and then the next day she was dead. Trying to break the silence seemed impossible, but then we nurses formed a little group and informed the public prosecutor."

The cocktail of death, according to one of her senior colleagues, was often administered at the weekend by a doctor she named.

"He gave us the impression that he was doing people good," the colleague added. "In the end, the practice became institutionalised. It's true that some of these were patients nearing the end of their lives, but no one has the right to decide the moment of death."

A public prosecutor, Laurent Davenas, opened an investigation on suspicion of "murder, attacks on vulnerable patients and grievous bodily harm" after hearing the evidence of another former nurse who described the practices as "disguised euthanasia".

"It is very difficult to draw the line between a strong dose of tranquillisers and deliberate euthanasia where old people are concerned," she said.

"The cocktail was sometimes administered as a general anaesthetic and in one case a patient took four days to die."

Another nurse told a radio programme that the cocktail was administered to some patients who were neither in a coma nor approaching a natural death. Some of them were relatively young.

The nurses also claimed that members of the staff sexually abused corpses in the mortuary, and tortured patients.

A judicial source said that the clinic, which is controlled by the French national health service, had been the subject of a number of staff complaints about harassment and unjustified sackings.

"There has been a lot of depression as a result, and this has to be taken into account when studying whether some of the allegations might be pure fantasy," the source said, adding that the inquiry was concentrating on between 20 and 40 deaths linked to the administration of tranquillisers.

"But certain factors agree on several points and are unlikely to be the subject of consensual imagination."

fields.headline: 100 years of attitude
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: The Queen Mother is related to Alice in Wonderland through Alice's Lyon grandmother. Not many people know that.
fields.body:
The Queen Mother is related to Alice in Wonderland through Alice's Lyon grandmother. Not many people know that. The Real Queen Mother (Channel 4) didn't for one. It may explain why, as a young woman, she belonged to a set called The Mad Hatters and account for this rather disconcerting description of her father - "Very thin, very agile and extremely interested in forestry. He could quote endlessly from Alice Through The Looking Glass."

There is something Lewis Carrollish about the whole set-up. The king, the queen, the duchess, and encounters along the way with eccentrics invisibly attached to reality like barrage balloons. The Rev Harbottle, a royal chaplain, said, "Her expression, as I have been priviledged to see in the Royal Chapel, defies description. It is beatific. Quite simply Queen Elizabeth has got a foot in heaven."

And in the middle of wonderland is the figure of a very determined little girl indeed.

Curiously enough, when Mrs Simpson was having her whirl with the Prince of Wales, Mr Simpson called her Wallis in Wonderland and worried about her awakening. A friend of the Queen Mother, Mrs Cazalet, spoke very acerbically of the duchess and would hardly have done so without her approval. "I don't know if she was common or not but she certainly looked common, didn't she? You can't think of anybody more different than Mrs Simpson and Queen Elizabeth."

Oh, I don't know. I would say there were marked similarities. They were both Elizabeth or, in the duchess's case, Bessie. They were both jockeyed into marrying adoring, psychologically shattered men, and devoted their lives to supporting and promoting them. They both maintained in the teeth of the evidence that this was happy-ever-after, though, as the duchess said, "You've no idea how hard it is to live out a great romance." They both found their style and stuck to it. The Queen Mother's flowerlike image was the joint creation of Hartnell and Beaton. Gay men seemed to find them both attractive. They both - I put it down to that core of steel - lived to extreme old age.

And they loathed each other. You do feel life is too short for such venom but, in fact, life is quite long.

This 90-minute film also went on a bit without adding much to the sum of common knowledge. There seemed to be an unusual shortage of material, which suggests tight control at the top. As a girl there was a romance with a dashing war hero, James Stuart, firmly nipped in the bud by parental pressure. Penelope Mortimer, who wrote the first unblinking biography of the Queen Mother, said harshly, "Rather like her daughter, when the time came she hadn't the guts to stand up against the pressure of Queen Mary and her own mother." Or, perhaps, as the Duchess of Gloucester put it on marrying the stolid Prince Henry, "I thought I had enjoyed myself enough." That generation rather buckled down to marriage.

There is something actressy about both the Queen Mother and Princess Margaret. A cluster of showbiz words recurred: trouper, absolute pro, star of the royal roadshow. No royal before her thought of putting on a show and, during the war, doing the show right here. One of her few recorded comments is "Bertie, you must wave!" Her publicity was excellent. "She was in many ways far better at this than Goebbels", as Andrew Roberts, a historian, put it. "Hitler never visited a bomb site."

After the death of the king, with no role left, she recreated herself as Thora Hird.

According to Claws on BBC2 Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean is infested with red crabs. Or, as the crabs see it, with pink people. Motorists who ignore RED CRABS CROSSING end up punctured. But it's on the golf course they make their presence felt most. They deflect fine putts. They hide in the holes. Cries of "Goo on! Gitarterit!" and "Ow! Another bloody crab!" lead me to believe that the golf playing population is largely Australian. Claws said special rules applied in the crab marching season, but it didn't say what. I think crabs give a bit of bounce to the whole pointless business.

webTitle: Answer me Getting personal with... Morgan Lander (Kittie)

fields.headline: Answer me Getting personal with... Morgan Lander (Kittie)
fields.trailText: Have you ever adopted a pseudonym, and if so why?
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym, and if so why?

I've never adopted a pseudonym before, I've never really had the need to, except for when I'm on the computer, to ensure anonymity!

Have you ever lied about your age, and if so why?

Sure, I lie about my age all the time, specifically for fun, or to drink.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?

Tall, dark and handsome, likes death metal.

What was the last illegal thing you did?

It's all legal in Amsterdam!

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

I can't remember.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

Talena, Fallon, Mercedes.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?

I haven't come into contact with any unpleasant people yet. Hopefully I won't any time soon.

Has a critic ever made you cry?

Ha! I may be a girl but I'm not a pussy.

What would you advertise without a fee?

Toilet paper.

What would you never advertise?

Used toilet paper.

What wakes you up screaming at 4am?

Dreams about men with pumpkins for heads.

What takes you to a happy place?

Drugs. Lots and lots of drugs.

Interview by Phelim O'Neill

Kittie's single Charlotte is out now on Ng/Artemis

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Operation Petticoat | The Mask Of Zorro | Poltergeist | Raining Stones
fields.body:
Operation Petticoat

(Blake Edwards, 1959)

6pm, Sky Cinema

Blake Edwards's first big box-office hit and the proverbial antidote to all those tense submarine thrillers. Tony Curtis plays Lieutenant-Fixit to Cary Grant's aloof admiral, together rescuing their leaky sub (along with a bevy of army nurses) from Davy Jones' locker after a wartime battering. Their bright and breezy double-act also keeps the film afloat when it's almost scuttled by a weak script: jokes about nurses' frilly underwear, a submarine painted pink, that sort of thing.

The Mask Of Zorro

(Martin Campbell, 1998)

11.05am, 8pm, Sky Premier

Old California's own Robin Hood legend is overlong, but done with real verve. Antonio Banderas , a dashing hero in the Tyrone Power mould, is the rugged, buffoonish Murrieta, protege of the now elderly Zorro (Anthony Hopkins) who trains him to fight, ride and smile wickedly, and to take on corrupt Governor Montero (Stuart Wilson). Catherine Zeta-Jones plays Zorro's long-lost daughter, pretty sharp with a blade herself.

Poltergeist

(Tobe Hooper, 1982)

9pm, TCM

Scriptwriter Spielberg visits mayhem on middle America again, with too much telly proving a bad thing for the Freeling family: their seemingly ordinary TV becomes a gateway into a netherworld because their suburban home stands on an Indian burial ground.

Raining Stones

(Ken Loach, 1993)

10pm, FilmFour

Not just the nitty-gritty of real life on a 90s Manchester housing estate, but the everyday flights of humour and heroism too. Bruce Jones's Bob is one of those on Peter Lilley's list, committing the outrageous crime of supplementing his dole pittance with any odd job that comes along, and they are odd. Now he sets off on a quest to buy daughter Coleen (Gemma Phoenix) a communion dress, in much the same spirit that the hero of Loach's Land And Freedom joins in the Spanish civil war.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Attacking a tree with a blowtorch doesn't seem the best way to preserve it. But, as Dr Wolfgang Bopp explains to Kerry Ten Kate in The Plant Hunters (11.0am, Radio 4), fire is the necessary agent to persuade some Australian species to procreate.
fields.body:
Attacking a tree with a blowtorch doesn't seem the best way to preserve it. But, as Dr Wolfgang Bopp explains to Kerry Ten Kate in The Plant Hunters (11.0am, Radio 4), fire is the necessary agent to persuade some Australian species to procreate. He is one of the team establishing the National Botanic Garden of Wales, the first such British facility for 200 years. Not all its wonders are natural: it also has a millennium dome, designed in glass by Sir Norman Foster.

It might have been called The Case Of The Cockeyed Corbus. Unfortunately, as Sue Armstrong reveals in It Couldn't Happen Here (9.0pm, Radio 4), the discovery of crows reeling drunkenly around New York's streets was the start of a major health crisis. But for the persistence of Tracy Macnamara, a veterinary pathologist at Bronx Zoo, the arrival in the city of the virulent West Nile virus could have caused many more than seven human deaths.

And don't think it ends there, because doddering gamely along behind is the equally senescent Tina Turner, in town later this week for her allegedly last ever British show at Wembley in aid of her album Twenty Four Seven. I could make another age-related joke now but, frankly, I feel a bit of a nap coming on...

fields.headline: Don't blame it on Rio
fields.standfirst: Classical music in Brazil has long been overshadowed by bossa nova and samba. But not any more, says  Jessica Duchen
fields.trailText: Classical music in Brazil has long been overshadowed by bossa nova and samba. But not any more, says Jessica Duchen
fields.body:
"The higher you fly, the further there is to fall," muses Brazilian-born pianist Arnaldo Cohen. "People often think of Brazilian music in terms of carnival, the bossa nova, dancing and happiness. But there is a great deal of sadness in it: a deep sadness which concerns love. Brazilians love everything intensely; we are passionate people. And when you are passionate, contrasts become strongly marked. And when you have passion, you have disillusionment."

Passionate, sorrowful and joyous it may be, yet most Brazilian classical music is almost unknown overseas - a fact that may now be about to change. This month, Brazil's rarely heard composers are the basis of the Wigmore Hall's series Rhythm, Romance and Remembrance, the classical component of this summer's Brazil 500 festival. The concerts feature some of Brazil's most celebrated musicians: Cohen, fellow pianists Cristina Ortiz and Nelson Freire, and the guitarist Fabio Zanon.

Carving out their national identity in their music, classical composers such as Heitor Villa-Lobos, Lorenzo Fernandez, Camargo Guarnieri, Fructoso Vianna filtered European forms through the same seething mix of cultures that makes Brazilian popular music so exciting: Amer-indian music, the African influence from Brazil's history of slavery and the sounds of the Spanish guitar.

Villa-Lobos (1887-1959) travelled around Brazil collecting traditional folk music, making extensive use of it in his own work and becoming Brazil's greatest composer. There's a pride in this musical nationalism, and nostalgia, too; as pianist Ortiz says: "Villa-Lobos used his heritage. He set down the sounds of his country, so his music is incredibly evocative. When I play it, I can almost smell my favourite Brazilian dishes and see the green of the jungle."

Villa-Lobos is world famous, but while Fernandez, Guarnieri and Vianna achieved successful careers in their day, they are not exactly household names here. Guarnieri was well known in the USA, as a conductor. Fernandez founded the music conservatory in Rio de Janeiro. Ortiz describes Vianna, whom she met when she was 12, as "a Brazilian Schumann". Meanwhile, Cohen recently discovered that Eduardo Dutra, composer of one of his favourite piano pieces, actually owned a chemical lab and only scribbled music in his spare time.

Why has it taken so long for them to gain any recognition abroad? Partly because Brazilian composers faced an uphill struggle in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Brazil, now officially 500 years old, is a relatively young nation and came late to classical music. Geographically, it was isolated, even within South America, being the continent's only Portuguese-speaking country. Without the long European traditions of established conservatories and fine teaching, opportunities to study music in Brazil were limited. For a real musical education, Villa-Lobos and his contemporaries gravitated to Paris, where they absorbed powerful influences from the luxuriant colours of Debussy and Ravel.

Cohen and Ortiz, who both settled overseas years ago, point regretfully at the vast musical talent in Brazil that has gone undeveloped. "You had to be wealthy to learn music in Brazil," says Ortiz. "And in my day there was no chance to do it at school." Cohen adds: "You wonder how many people could have become first-class composers but never had the chance."
