"People often think of Brazilian music in terms of carnival, the bossa nova, dancing and happiness. But there is a great deal of sadness in it: a deep sadness which concerns love. Brazilians love everything intensely; we are passionate people. And when you are passionate, contrasts become strongly marked. And when you have passion, you have disillusionment." Passionate, sorrowful and joyous it may be, yet most Brazilian classical music is almost unknown overseas - a fact that may now be about to change. This month, Brazil's rarely heard composers are the basis of the Wigmore Hall's series Rhythm, Romance and Remembrance, the classical component of this summer's Brazil 500 festival. The concerts feature some of Brazil's most celebrated musicians: Cohen, fellow pianists Cristina Ortiz and Nelson Freire, and the guitarist Fabio Zanon. Carving out their national identity in their music, classical composers such as Heitor Villa-Lobos, Lorenzo Fernandez, Camargo Guarnieri, Fructoso Vianna filtered European forms through the same seething mix of cultures that makes Brazilian popular music so exciting: Amer-indian music, the African influence from Brazil's history of slavery and the sounds of the Spanish guitar. Villa-Lobos (1887-1959) travelled around Brazil collecting traditional folk music, making extensive use of it in his own work and becoming Brazil's greatest composer. There's a pride in this musical nationalism, and nostalgia, too; as pianist Ortiz says: "Villa-Lobos used his heritage. He set down the sounds of his country, so his music is incredibly evocative. When I play it, I can almost smell my favourite Brazilian dishes and see the green of the jungle." fields.headline: Space oddities
fields.standfirst: Adrian Searle  thinks Carl Andre really should know his place by now
fields.trailText: Adrian Searle thinks Carl Andre really should know his place by now
fields.body:
Do we need this Carl Andre show in London right now? Since his 1978 exhibition at the Whitechapel Art Gallery, in the wake of the controversy surrounding the Tate's purchase of those bricks, Andre has had two museum-quality exhibitions in Britain: at the Museum of Modern Art in Oxford, in 1996; and at Edinburgh's Inverleith House in 1998.

The bricks, Andre's Equivalent VIII, are now on show at Tate Modern, alongside a Jasper Johns' White Numbers painting, an Agnes Martin and a backdrop wall-drawing by Sol Lewitt. This cramped display does none of the works much of a service and, looking at Andre's bricks now, it is salutory to note that all sense of outrage has gone. They look just like classical modern art of the minimal persuasion, which is exactly what they are and what they represent. Other Andre works are scattered about Tate Modern, and this exhibition feels like a historical footnote. Now, a big Lewitt show would be timely - there has just been a touring retrospective in the US - but Andre's return to the Whitechapel after 22 years, a period in which stasis rather than development has marked the artist's career, appears redundant.

But then Andre has never really developed, or changed, or altered his position as an artist. That is part of the point of his work. He arranges hunks of wood, sheets and cubes of metal or stone, in a given space. The work attunes you not only to the materials and their order, but also to the space itself and their place in it.

I'm beginning to feel that vague irritation theatre critics must feel when their remarks are lifted onto posters to promote works they've written about. The Whitechapel's press release quotes me saying: "Andre's work is about being a body in the world, and about measuring that world against ourselves." Without being too revisionist about it, one might add that one can have this kind of relationship without recourse to art. But maybe we needed art to show us the way.

Andre's current Whitechapel exhibition contains works from his whole career, including early typewriter poems (a kind of severe concrete poetry much better read in a book than looked at on walls) and photographs of early works, many now destroyed. As documentary souvenirs of minimalism's origins, from 1958-63, they hold our interest, but it feels a bit pedagogic. The poems, too, have been better presented elsewhere, and the selection of extant small early works are displayed in too museological a manner.

Aside from this, what? Grids of metal plates, shunting out at angles from the wall. Narrower metal plates skittering along the floor next to a wall. Shiny ingots of bis muth, indium and cadmium catch the eye with their different qualities of reflectivity and sheen. A copper spiral that looks super-elegant on a wooden floor, a large layout of horizontal and vertical chunks of cedar.

Smaller presentations of individual works, or groups of works, suit Andre and the spaces he works with better. A leaner show would have been problematic, but truer to the spirit of his art, and a more thorough retrospective would have demanded an even bigger space. Whether we need either right now is more the issue. I've measured myself against the world and felt myself, and it, wanting.

Carl Andre, Whitechapel Art Gallery, London E1, till August 27 (020-7522 7878).

fields.headline: The saddest story in rock
fields.standfirst: In 1988 John Fogerty was sued for plagiarising his own songs.  Adam Sweeting talks to the Creedence Clearwater Revival frontman about 12 years of bitter legal battles
fields.trailText: In 1988 John Fogerty was sued for plagiarising his own songs. Adam Sweeting talks to the Creedence Clearwater Revival frontman about 12 years of bitter legal battles
fields.body:
If writing a batch of rock's most exhilarating hit singles is a good way to gain admission to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, becoming entangled in high-profile lawsuits brings a different kind of immortality. John Fogerty has achieved both. Weirdly, even tragically, his solo career has been marred by his involvement in a string of legal disputes with his erstwhile record label, Fantasy, and clashes with his ex-bandmates from Creedence Clearwater Revival, of which he was the lynchpin until it split in 1972. It remains to be seen whether he will be remembered for his music or his lawsuits.

Fogerty, 55, is now sweeping across Europe supporting Tina Turner on her farewell tour. But he remains an ambiguous figure. During his heyday in Creedence Clearwater Revival it was he who wrote the band's hits, from Proud Mary (1969) to their last million-seller, Sweet Hitch-Hiker (1971). Since then, his solo career has produced gems such as Centerfield (1985) and Blue Moon Swamp (1997), both of which have demonstrated Fogerty's knack for concocting songs that are "about as contrived as the weather", as critic Greil Marcus put it.

But a total of six albums in 27 years (only five of them comprising new material) seems a barely adequate return from so legendary a performer. For when Fogerty should have been in the studio, he was consulting lawyers or sitting in court.

"I have had a lot of trouble with Fantasy Records. " Fogerty told me while promoting the release of Blue Moon Swamp. "In 1988 I had to go through a plagiarism trial where I was sued for sounding like myself, and people tell me this was unprecedented. I spent more than three years trying to resolve these issues, but sadly it didn't work."

In the bizarre self-plagiarism case, Fantasy and its boss Saul Zaentz claimed that Fogerty's 1985 song Old Man Down the Road was merely his old Creedence song, Run Through the Jungle, with a new title. The label wouldn't have been able to bring the suit if Fogerty hadn't sold them the rights to his old material, something any aspiring pop star would be strenuously advised not to do in these more artist friendly days. Fogerty won the case, but then had to jump through further legal hoops to win back $1.35m dollars in costs.

While countless musicians, from George Michael to Spandau Ballet, have found themselves in litigation with managers, record companies or each other, they have eventually reached some sort of conclusion, even if they're not very happy with it. But Fogerty seems doomed never to achieve the outcome he thinks he deserves. The problems date right back to Creedence Clearwater's original contract with Fantasy.

"We were the only artists that mattered on the label. We were selling almost 99.9% of the company's records. We had signed a contract thinking we were all in it equally. I thought we would share to a great degree in the company's success. But then it didn't happen. Fantasy own the songs and they're supposed to pay me as the songwriter, but I've had to fight to get royalties from 1980 and every year after that. Basically, to get paid I had to sue them, that was their stance."

After Creedence split, Fogerty found himself bound to Fantasy as a solo artist. His awareness that he was a bankable asset at the peak of his powers merely increased his sense of outrage. "I felt like I was their little prisoner in their dungeon, their little mouse in a cage that they played with," he shuddered. "To take somebody that was at their height, like Elvis or The Beatles, and then treat them so badly is really a horrible thing."

During the late 70s and early 80s, he grew so sick of it all that he abandoned music and lived with his family on a farm in Oregon. Then in 1985, he re-emerged with a new record deal with Warner Bros and the album Centerfield. It looked as if he'd turned a corner - until the plagiarism lawsuit came along.

That was not the worst of it. In 1990, his brother Tom died from respiratory failure following a long struggle with tuberculosis. The five Fogerty boys had been brought up by their single mother in California, and Tom had been Creedence's rhythm guitarist, but not even their family bond could survive John's feelings of betrayal. "Tom ended up over the years evolving mentally into some sort of weird Patti Hearst syndrome," said John. "That's what I call it when they kidnap you and you end up siding with your captors, and that's what Tom did. In some trick of mental agility, he ended up befriending Saul Zaentz against me. By the end of his life Tom was saying 'Saul is my best friend'. He even wrote me nasty letters saying things like 'Saul and I will win'. It was very unresolved and very sad."

How does he remember Tom? "I have very confused feelings for my brother because there was a time when things were happy. The best I can say in Tom's case is he was the older brother and the younger brother had a lot more talent, therefore he was jealous even to a greater degree than the other two in Creedence Clearwater Revival."

Tom's death didn't soften John's attitude towards the other band members. In 1993, when Creedence were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, Fogerty refused to allow drummer Doug Clifford and bassist Stu Cook to perform with him at the traditional end-of-ceremony jam. Cook and Clifford have responded by forming Creedence Clearwater Revisited and going on the road playing the old Fogerty hits, though he has tried to throw a spanner in the works. In 1996, he sued Cook and Clifford, seeking to prevent the use of the Creedence Clearwater name. He won a temporary injunction, but the band are now using their chosen name again, and toured Germany last month.

It saddens Stu Cook. "I'm sure that doctors have all kinds of names for this sort of behaviour," he commented. "It's the saddest story in rock and one of the longest ongoing stupid feuds."

Meanwhile, Fogerty has become a litigation junkie. At the end of last year, he even sued his former attorney Kenneth Sidle, who had helped him to win back his costs following the plagiarism case. John Fogerty should be remembered as a great songwriter. Instead, he risks becoming better known as an appellant in textbooks of precedent-setting case law.

John Fogerty appears with Tina Turner at Wembley on Saturday and Sunday. Box office: 020-8902 0902.

fields.headline: No: 1674 John Birt
fields.trailText: Age: 56 and no remission for good behaviour.
fields.body:
Age: 56 and no remission for good behaviour.

Appearance: Bow St magistrates, I imagine. He has a shoplifter's look about him.

Come again? Lord Birt has been appointed to be Tony Blair's Crimebuster - his Crime Tsar, if you prefer.

The Tsar looks awfully like that Dalek bloke who used to run the BBC. Are they by chance related? Funny you should mention that: they are one and the same.

But that John Birt looks older than Dixon of Dock Green. He knows nothing about crime. Not all the staff at the BBC would agree with that statement, including those sacked, re-skilled or exiled from Broadcasting House to the wastes of TV Centre on the advice of Birtian management consultants whose fees ate up whole swathes of programme budgets.

TV Centre is close to Wormwood Scrubs Prison, now you mention it. Many BBC highbrows believe that Birt-speak memos alone could sustain a successful prosecution for murder of the English language.

I suppose Birt's a Tony Crony? Heavens no, he's a crossbench peer. But he did attend Cherie's 40th birthday party and is an old chum of Peter M**del**n.

Blair's so smart, he must have a reason for the appointment that us ordinary licence-payers wouldn't understand. There is a theory that Birt drove viewing figures down dramatically and may be able to do the same for those rising crime figures. Just by looking at them.

Is Crimebuster Birt getting paid for all this work then? Alas, there is no scope here for jokes about Lord Birt's tax arrangements or pension. He is not even getting an Armani policeman's uniform.

Do say: "John abhors violence, but his associate Mr Dyke will give you a bunch of fives unless you hand back the rights to Test Match cricket and the Premiership highlights."

Don't say: "The way Birt dropped News at Ten like that, it was a crime."

webTitle: A half-century of pain, violence, torture, war, evil and anger

fields.headline: A half-century of pain, violence, torture, war, evil and anger
fields.standfirst: The sheer bloody-mindedness of Leon Golub thrills
fields.trailText: Leon Golub's paintings are nasty. They always have been nasty, they go on being nasty. They are bitter, raw and abrasive. Some depict unconscionable acts: beatings, riots, interrogations, debasements.
fields.body:
Leon Golub's paintings are nasty. They always have been nasty, they go on being nasty. They are bitter, raw and abrasive. Some depict unconscionable acts: beatings, riots, interrogations, debasements. Others, particularly his more recent works, have a sullen, careless humour. Now in his late 70s, dogged by old man's troubles, Golub paints the dog itself, snarling and ravaging, pausing to lick its balls. He paints rapacious eagles, moth-eaten sphinxes, skulls and slogans, Prometheus as a condemned Titan. Prometheus, with the eagle about to strike, screams: "Fuck, I didn't expect this!"

Golub is as bloody-minded and awkward and battling as ever he was. His retrospective exhibition, at the Irish Museum of Modern Art in Dublin, opened last Thursday. Walking the long corridors and intimate side-rooms of Imoma with Golub, is to walk a half-century of pain and violence, torture, war, evil and anger. We walk from the mythic battles, his giants and corruscated gods and Pompeiian cinder-men of the 1950s and early 60s, to the floundering napalmed figures which came in the wake of the American insurgence in Vietnam. Timelessness was replaced by the timely, and Golub turned to overt depictions of modern war - cowed Vietnamese farm-kids on one side of the canvas, American youth, battledressed and with all their machinery, on the other.

Where once Debuffet had informed Golub's solvent-abused, built-up and scraped away painted surfaces, now the Picasso of the Charnel House, and the nightly news, stood sway. And then came portraits of Franco, Brazilian dictator General Geisel, Nelson D Rockefeller, Kissinger, Pinochet, Ho Chi Minh and Fidel Castro. Their images came from Time and Newsweek; he rendered them carefully, but without implied comment. He painted them as the camera saw them, in all their hubris, in their uniforms and in their coffins; dictators in their shades. Franco, removed from a context in which he was originally kissing someone's cheek (Salazar's maybe), looks like he's whistling. A series of Rockefeller portraits chart the ravages of power.

I think of Saul Bellow's Augie March. Like Augie, Golub is an American, Chicago-born, and goes at things as he has taught himself. And like Augie, Golub is a jew, giving witness to what was - for ill as much as good - America's century. Golub's political radicalism, his anger at the world and America's part in it (the Vietnam war, all those other overt and covert operations, the unprincipled machinations of big business, the inequalities of the land of the free) has always set him apart. His subjects, as well as his cross-grained approach, may have stalled his career in America, but not his achievement.

As abstract expressionism came and went, as minimal and conceptual art generated compliant heroes for the new international capital of the art world, Golub went his own way. He and his wife of almost 50 years, the artist Nancy Spero, lived in Italy and then in Paris, returning to the USA at a moment when painting such as his had little place. But really, he has been centre-stage all along. In the renewed enthusiasm for figurative painting in the early 1980s, his work stood as a kind of rejoinder to the breast-beating sophistications of younger artists like David Salle and Julian Schnabel.

Golub is a painter bearing witness to his times. His work of the 1970s and 80s is only paralleled by Gerhard Richter's paintings of the Baader-Meinhoffs. One might almost regard Golub's work as a kind of social realism, but for the fact that it is too sardonic and too individual to be seen as affirmation of a collective conscience, or of anybody's dream. When he paints interrogators, or mercenaries, or the guys on the street corner, he knows, and often lets you know, what coercion and disenfranchisements lead them to this place.

We walk through a world of squalid interrogation rooms and shadows where the abducted are thrown in the boot of a car. We stand over the bodies, wandering how to dispose of them. Someone urinates on a victim who has a mashed-in face. We hang around with old black footsore folks, and with guys like Vinnie from Last Exit to Brooklyn. We hurry past white-trash racial suprematists who give us obscene, antic gestures. We go to El Salvador, we come back, and things are much the same at home.

You see things in Golub's work you've never wanted to think about, much less look at, unless it has been in movies, or in morbid fantasy. At their best, his paintings are irrefutable. He learned, from cinema and from abstraction, the use of emptiness, the blank screen, the close-up, cropping, grouping and isolation. He has a great sense of staging. Most of all, an unerring feel for characterisation - the details of the tableaux, the frozen moment. He paints geeky nervous trigger-happy dangerous types, urbane CIA politicos, the harassed station chief, the foot-slogger, the implacable psychopath who likes the dirty work. He can do haircuts, shoes, varicose veins, cigars smoked to the butt. He can do sweat and menace and fear, and the unspoken threat that hangs in the air.

Walking and talking with Golub, it is clear that he has spent a lot of time inside these paintings, getting to know his inventions. Individual figures may be derived from porno mags and news-stand rags, weird fanzines, fashion plates, Guns & Ammo, Field and Stream (the man pissing on his victim may have been derived from a shot of a man holding a fishing rod), but they become something else when Golub paints them.

Just as Philip Guston's late style derived, in part, from Krazy Kat and Robert Crumb cartoons, so something of the rangy, evil-mouthed gawkiness of some of Golub's figures might itself have fed the style of Beavis and Butt-head. It would be a nice reciprocation. And scary, too, if you think that, one day, those kids might have to go to war.

Golub's paintings hang, for the most part, unstretched on the wall. The paint - applied, scraped-off, applied again - leaves the image imbedded in the weave of the painting as much as on it. The images have a tremendous clarity and force: wristwatches, tattoos, knobbly fingers, a newly-shaved GI haircut, manacles and shiny boots aren't mere props or modern dress, but the texture of life at a certain period. I can think of few painters who can achieve this, without becoming boring. And although he hectors at times (so, too, does Oliver Stone), he can also give us a painting which announces the end of the world, with a parade of dancing girls.

If only, you want to say, if only there had been more time for Golub to paint at full throttle, inventing his scenarios, getting inside his characters, reporting back from those dread corners of the world. At best he paints like a novelist or a film director. But let's not forget he also does the props, the costumes, the lighting. And, however much he invents in these paintings, the story is already out there, the bad thing done. Now, in the late paintings, Golub paints his own vicissitudes. A man, prone between the paws of a lion, holds up a little placard? It says: "Why Me?" Well, why not. One thing Golub is really proud of, he told me, was the look in the eagle's eye, a kind of savage knowing pitiless look. It stares back at me, down the long corridor of Golub's exhibition.

fields.headline: Shop till you drop
fields.standfirst: Ultrasoundings
fields.trailText: I shouldn't actually have gone shopping at all. My blood pressure is up and this is bad, very bad, at my stage of pregnancy.
fields.body:
Week 32

I shouldn't actually have gone shopping at all. My blood pressure is up and this is bad, very bad, at my stage of pregnancy. The next thing you know, you can have swollen hands and feet, and that can be a symptom of pre-eclampsia. This means, as far as I can make out, that the baby's hormones for making your heart beat faster to get blood to the placenta start to win out over your own calming hormones and your blood rushes round so hard, you break veins in your kidneys.

Then you can get full-blown eclampsia which is terribly rare but had, you may remember, dreadful consequences for that nice Doctor Green on ER. Of course, modern medicine will catch you before you get to that stage. They put you in hospital and sedate you - a terrifying thought. I shouldn't think terrifying thoughts. That's the trouble with blood pressure - you can raise it just by thinking about it. I've had to give up ER.

I don't know how long I can keep swimming, either - not because of the exertion but because of lane rage. Ideally, I should be staying calm and tracking the cat about the house. He follows a yogic regime of meditation, stretches, naps and massage so strictly, it's a wonder he has a pulse at all. He also has fluff for brains and doesn't read pregnancy books. I've now got to the sections where the women are pictured sorting ickle vests and socks while practising their squats and straight-backed sitting. I have no ickle vests. In fact, if I don't act soon, Baby will have to be wrapped in an old towel and sleep in a drawer.

My bump is still growing exponentially: in a week's time, I won't be able to get through swivel doors. So, for the third time, I've set off to a major chain store - and stood open-mouthed in the baby department for half an hour before returning empty-handed. How has this happened? Partly, I've got to admit, it's nostalgia. I want baby goods to be the same as when I was a child, in the same way that parents are reassured by seeing their child in blazer and cap, regardless of the merit of the school.

This is why I come over all Prince of Walesish at any item - and there are many - decorated with the horrid Disney Winnie-the-Pooh rather than the proper Ernest Shepard one and why I'm drawn to entirely impractical Black Watch carrycots instead of the car seat you're legally obliged to have. But I also object to anything that says "development" or "stimulating" on it - and that cuts out a whole swathe of items. It enrages me that anyone should think I am dim enough to believe blasting an embryo with a "foetal microphone" (£40) will "stimulate its language development" or that a black and white mobile (£20), rather than say, my face, will activate my baby's "focusing impulse".

At the same time, these things make me feel, as they are designed to, an already inadequate mother. And I have an even worse problem: my oldest friend is an eco-activist. She's been training me since we were 15. Now I look at moulded plastic and see toxins. I finger a pile of teddies and hear her telling me about working conditions in developing countries, or how an American baby uses eight times the energy units of an Indian one. Disposable nappies are just 15% of British landfill to me, a Salisbury Plain of swelling, stinking parcels of sewage, many of them adorned with Winnie-the-Pooh: our monument for the next 300 years.

The object that actually sent me spinning back through the swivel door this time was a special bin that compress-wraps your used nappies into an air-freshened string of plastic sausages. Normal people might think this is handy. I, though, envisaged each sausage gradually forming its own bubble of methane, then bursting and blasting its way past bean tins, kitchen foil and obsolete stimulating mobiles to shoot through the earth and add to the greenhouse effect. This was, I decided, the worst possible thing for my blood pressure.

Not that alternative shopping is entirely relaxing. Eco-services tend to be run by people too principled to be efficient. My organic veg service just went bust, for example, and it's going to be months before the Welsh sheep on the retraining programme get round to knitting Baby's hat. And it took three weeks to get through to the terribly nice local nappy-washing service, though the 100% cotton Velcro-fastened nappies are now on their way. At least that will give me something to sort while thinking my beautiful thoughts and practising my squats.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Who'd be a gal? Hot on the heels of "careers give you cancer ... if you're a woman" comes "being female - it makes you suicidal". Apparently nearly 15% of British women are so tired that they feel like offing themselves, with many more too busy to eat healthily, exercise regularly or even see a doctor. If there were ever a reason to get out from under the mattress, it escapes us now.
fields.body:
Who'd be a gal? Hot on the heels of "careers give you cancer ... if you're a woman" comes "being female - it makes you suicidal". Apparently nearly 15% of British women are so tired that they feel like offing themselves, with many more too busy to eat healthily, exercise regularly or even see a doctor. If there were ever a reason to get out from under the mattress, it escapes us now.

Titter ye not. New York dancer Mary Gale was given £20,000 compensation when her surgical search for a more rounded bottom ended in disaster after silicone breast implants were inserted into her backside. As the "backs are the new fronts" debate rages on, courtesy of Joely, Anna et al, one can only pale at the thought of a boom in buttock surgery. Surely, in line with the laterally thinking New York surgeon, we could find a way of using up all those leftover bits that society so blithely - and damagingly - throws away? Implants the shape of culled badgers? They're safer than soya.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Lorry driver admits guilt

A lorry driver yesterday admitted to Norwich magistrates that his driving was the cause of an accident in which a record-breaking cyclist died.
fields.body:
Lorry driver admits guilt
A lorry driver yesterday admitted to Norwich magistrates that his driving was the cause of an accident in which a record-breaking cyclist died.

Darren Greenwood, 36, of Toftwood, Norfolk, pleaded guilty to driving without due care when he was distracted by his mobile phone. He was involved in a crash which claimed the life of speed cyclist Bruce Bursford, 41. He will be sentenced later.
Husband's sentence cut
A man who killed his "nagging" wife had his jail term cut from six years to four at the appeal court in London yesterday. David Hampson, 43, of March, Cambridgeshire, was jailed at Nottingham crown court last October after admitting manslaughter on grounds of diminished responsibility.

New head for Law Society
Michael Napier, 54, a personal injury lawyer, has been elected president of the Law Society. He beat the incumbent, Robert Sayer.

£30m genome boost

Small businesses are to get £30m to help them develop new treatments for cancer and other diseases by exploiting the mapping of the human genome. The Department of Trade will provide half the funding, with at least a further £15m coming from industry.


Store taken to court

The John Lewis chain is facing a challenge for alleged sex discrimination. Brenda Cootes, 57, of West Norwood, south London, is taking the firm to an employment tribunal over a policy entitling male employees only to a £300 suit allowance.

fields.headline: Ruth Werner
fields.standfirst: Communist spy who passed the west's atomic secrets to Moscow in the cause of fighting fascism
fields.trailText: Ruth Werner, who has died aged 93 in her native Berlin, was one of the Soviet Union's star agents, a member of the wartime Red Orchestra and Lucy spy rings in Switzerland before she came to Britain, where, using the codename Sonya, she was a courier for the atom spy, Klaus Fuchs.
fields.body:
Ruth Werner, who has died aged 93 in her native Berlin, was one of the Soviet Union's star agents, a member of the wartime Red Orchestra and Lucy spy rings in Switzerland before she came to Britain, where, using the codename Sonya, she was a courier for the atom spy, Klaus Fuchs.

She was born Ursula Kuczynski into a Polish Jewish family, supporters, like Fuchs, of the German communist party (the KPD). According to Fuchs's biographer, Robert Chadwell Williams, their leftwing connections led MI5 to open a KAEOT - "keep an eye on them" - file on the family as early as 1928.

Six years later, Werner's father, Robert, arrived in Britain as a refugee. Her brother, Jürgen, joined him in London in 1936, where despite - or, indeed, because of - his communist sympathies and anti-fascist credentials, he was later recruited by the OSS, the forerunner of the American CIA, to contact resistance groups in occupied Europe and draw up intelligence reports.

Werner's career as a spy began in 1930, when, with her first husband, Rudolf Hamburger, she went to live in Shanghai. Hamburger, an architect and Soviet agent, had taken a job with the British-administered Shanghai municipal council. She later described her shock at the poverty and exploitation in the city, where she soon became involved in revolutionary and communist circles. She was approached by the German communist Richard Sorge, then the Soviet Union's masterspy in the Far East (he was executed by the Japanese in 1944). She later described it as the "one event which was to prove decisive for my future life".

Sorge, who gave Werner the codename Sonya, suggested she went to Moscow for training in espionage and radio communications at the headquarters of the Red army's intelligence service, the GRU. She travelled extensively as a GRU agent, returning to China, where she helped to organise revolutionary forces fighting the Japanese along the Manchurian border.

In 1938, after settling her children in England, Werner was sent to Switzerland, the centre for Europe's espionage networks, including the Rote Kapelle (Red Orchestra) and the Lucy Ring, which was later used by Britain to pass intelligence about Germany to the Soviet Union. There she met Allan Foote, a British member of the Lucy Ring, who introduced her to a fellow veteran of the International Brigade in Spain, Len Beurton, whom she married in 1940. With that act, she became entitled to a British passport, and, after coming close to being denounced as a Soviet spy, she made her way to England, with Len following soon after.

The family rented a cottage in Summertown, north Oxford, before moving to a large house in the nearby village of Great Rollright - a convenient place from which Werner could handle Fuchs, then living and working in Birmingham - and at the atomic research centre at Harwell.

In 1942, Fuchs contacted Jürgen, who he had known from their past communist days, and Jürgen immediately put him in touch with Werner. They had a series of meetings in Banbury, after which Werner passed Fuchs's information either to her Soviet controllers in London or directly to Moscow by radio.

In 1946, Moscow suddenly broke off contact with Werner for reasons which remain unexplained. However, it seems clear that, by the following year, her and Len's cover had been blown by Foote - if only because she was visited by two special branch officers. Whatever the truth of the matter, they appeared to have no evidence about what Werner had been up to, and, as she put it later: "They left us calmly and politely, but empty-handed." MI5 did not put her under surveillance either before or after the visits - the consequence of both incompetence and complacency.

Werner was allowed to leave Britain early in 1950, on the day before Fuchs was put on trial for giving away the west's atom secrets. As she wrote in her autobiography, Sonya's Report, which was published in Germany in 1977 and in Britain in 1991: "Either it was complete stupidity on the part of MI5 never to have connected me with Klaus, or they may have let me get away with it, since every further discovery would have increased their disgrace."

Werner had been a member of the KPD, and joined the Communist party of Great Britain in 1947. She then became a member of the former communist party of East Germany, the reformed party of Democratic Socialism, which announced her death - without giving the cause. She had been married three times, and had three children.

In an afterword to the British translation of her au tobiography, she wrote: "I had not worked those 20 years with Stalin in mind. We wanted to help the people of the Soviet Union in their efforts to prevent war, and when war broke out against German fascism, to win it".

Norman Moss writes:

Ruth Werner was one of the last of that generation of people who dedicated their lives to communism in the belief that they were working for a more humane and just society. I learned about her because I wrote a book about Klaus Fuchs. While the cold war was still on, I could not question her, but I was in Berlin after the wall came down and she entertained me and my wife to aromatic tea and cinnamon cakes.

She was a small woman with fluffy white hair and a prominent nose, and a way of peering intently through her spectacles when she talked. She was angry that British newspapers had called her a spy, a term she vehemently rejected. "I was not a spy," she insisted. "I was never in the KGB. I was a member of the Red army, in the reconnaissance service." Her insistence on this may have been because she did not want to be associated with KGB agents who spied on her fellow-East Germans, or with the hated Stasi, the East German secret police.

Werner began to serve communism during the Nazi era. "I fought against fascism," she said. "Whatever else, I can hold my head up high because of that." She had believed in communism, even in Stalin, even when he executed the old Bolsheviks. "We didn't know about Stalin's crimes," she assured me. "I remember how shocked I was when we were told about them."

She liked England, and recalled English friends fondly, seeing no difficulty in reconciling this with her espionage activities directed against Britain "There was no conflict. I had friends, and they were good people. I didn't lie to them. I just didn't tell them what I was doing, that's all."

She recalled the difficulties of combining motherhood with her career. The most painful time was when she was called to Moscow for three months' training and had to leave her two small children with her in-laws - her chiefs had decided that, if the children came with her, one of them might pick up a Russian word and blurt it out, thus giving away the fact that she had been in the Soviet Union.

Like many former East Germans, Werner disliked many aspects of reunification. "It wasn't unification, it was annexation," she said. "I approved of glasnost, yes. The GDR actually tried to ban some of Gorbachev's articles - that was too much." But she had not foreseen the way events would go.

A visitor from Berlin told me last month that Wener was still a lively conversationalist. I recalled her last words about communism. She said she still believed in true socialism, and thought deformations had caused it to fail. But she admitted that she could find no faith in the future to replace the one she had lost. "For me, this is not a good time to be old," she said. Her tone was not bitter, but sad.

fields.bodyText: Ruth Werner, who has died aged 93 in her native Berlin, was one of the Soviet Union's star agents, a member of the wartime Red Orchestra and Lucy spy rings in Switzerland before she came to Britain, where, using the codename Sonya, she was a courier for the atom spy, Klaus Fuchs. She was born Ursula Kuczynski into a Polish Jewish family, supporters, like Fuchs, of the German communist party (the KPD). According to Fuchs's biographer, Robert Chadwell Williams, their leftwing connections led MI5 to open a KAEOT - "keep an eye on them" - file on the family as early as 1928. Six years later, Werner's father, Robert, arrived in Britain as a refugee. Her brother, Jürgen, joined him in London in 1936, where despite - or, indeed, because of - his communist sympathies and anti-fascist credentials, he was later recruited by the OSS, the forerunner of the American CIA, to contact resistance groups in occupied Europe and draw up intelligence reports. Werner's career as a spy began in 1930, when, with her first husband, Rudolf Hamburger, she went to live in Shanghai. Hamburger, an architect and Soviet agent, had taken a job with the British-administered Shanghai municipal council. She later described her shock at the poverty and exploitation in the city, where she soon became involved in revolutionary and communist circles. She was approached by the German communist Richard Sorge, then the Soviet Union's masterspy in the Far East (he was executed by the Japanese in 1944). She later described it as the "one event which was to prove decisive for my future life". Sorge, who gave Werner the codename Sonya, suggested she went to Moscow for training in espionage and radio communications at the headquarters of the Red army's intelligence service, the GRU. She travelled extensively as a GRU agent, returning to China, where she helped to organise revolutionary forces fighting the Japanese along the Manchurian border. In 1938, after settling her children in England, Werner was sent to Switzerland, the centre for Europe's espionage networks, including the Rote Kapelle (Red Orchestra) and the Lucy Ring, which was later used by Britain to pass intelligence about Germany to the Soviet Union. There she met Allan Foote, a British member of the Lucy Ring, who introduced her to a fellow veteran of the International Brigade in Spain, Len Beurton, whom she married in 1940. With that act, she became entitled to a British passport, and, after coming close to being denounced as a Soviet spy, she made her way to England, with Len following soon after. The family rented a cottage in Summertown, north Oxford, before moving to a large house in the nearby village of Great Rollright - a convenient place from which Werner could handle Fuchs, then living and working in Birmingham - and at the atomic research centre at Harwell. In 1942, Fuchs contacted Jürgen, who he had known from their past communist days, and Jürgen immediately put him in touch with Werner. They had a series of meetings in Banbury, after which Werner passed Fuchs's information either to her Soviet controllers in London or directly to Moscow by radio. In 1946, Moscow suddenly broke off contact with Werner for reasons which remain unexplained. However, it seems clear that, by the following year, her and Len's cover had been blown by Foote - if only because she was visited by two special branch officers. Whatever the truth of the matter, they appeared to have no evidence about what Werner had been up to, and, as she put it later: "They left us calmly and politely, but empty-handed." fields.headline: Lancashire launches child abuse inquiry
fields.trailText: Police are investigating allegations of 30 years of institutionalised sex abuse at council run care homes and residential schools in Lancashire.
fields.body:
Police are investigating allegations of 30 years of institutionalised sex abuse at council run care homes and residential schools in Lancashire.

Detectives already have the names of 11 people they want to interview over allegations of abuse at seven residential care homes across the county. It is possible that some still have access to children in their care.

Operation Nevada, the code name for the inquiry, is expected to produce many more names and could be in force for three years.

The claims of abuse centre on private and local authority children's homes, residential schools and care establishments, from the 1970s to the early 1990s.

It follows publication of the Waterhouse report into widespread sexual abuse of children in care homes in north Wales.

The report criticised oversights and inadequacies in the care system in north Wales, where hundreds of children suffered physical and sexual abuse. It made 72 recommendations, calling for changes to the way local councils, social services and the police deal with children in the area.

Detectives in Lancashire revealed that they had taken many calls in the first few hours of the operation.

Detective Inspector Steve Marston, who is leading the inquiry, said: "So far we have 11 people we want to interview, who have worked at seven homes across Lancashire. All the officers on the team have been trained to deal with investigations of this nature and we would encourage people to come forward and speak with us if they were sexually abused while in care or at school in Lancashire.

"The inquiries will centre on those alleged offenders who are still working with children or operating in the care environment. Other allegations that have been reported to police and already investigated will also be revisited if necessary."

Max Winterbottom, of Lancashire county council, said the allegations were believed in the main to be historic. "Rigorous screening procedures involving the police and the Department of Health are in place so that anyone applying for a post working with children in any capacity within the county council is thoroughly vetted," he said.

"We are confident that should the police come across any information that any child in Lancashire may be vulnerable to abuse by someone who is caring for them, they will inform us immediately. The necessary steps would then be taken with parents or other carers for the child's immediate protection."

Many other police forces already have investigations into claims of child abuse at care homes - at least 22 inquiries are being conducted in England and Wales.

Investigations into sex abuse in council care homes have already taken place in Cheshire, Merseyside and Greater Manchester.

Any victims of child abuse in Lancashire care homes can contact the Operation Nevada team on 01772 410544.

fields.headline: Syrians endorse Bashar
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: One month after the death of President Hafez al-Assad, Syrian voters turned out yesterday to confirm the succession of his 34-year-old son, Bashar.
fields.body:
One month after the death of President Hafez al-Assad, Syrian voters turned out yesterday to confirm the succession of his 34-year-old son, Bashar.

With no candidates opposing him Bashar is guaranteed to win, but to some of the 9.5m voters it was not enough to mark "yes" on the ballot papers: they pricked their fingers to seal their votes with blood.

"I love Bashar, I pledged allegiance to him in my blood," a woman farmworker said, waving her bloodstained thumb outside one of the 25 polling stations set up in Lebanon for Syrian expatriates.

In Damascus, Bashar arrived to vote at his old school, driving himself in a black and grey car. Teachers and students greeted him with cheers, hugs and kisses, and he told them he had chosen to vote at his school "because I owe you a big favour".

Elsewhere, voting was generally quiet, with only small official demonstrations outside polling stations. Previous referendums have been accompanied by singing and dancing, but this time the celebrations were muted because the 40 days' mourning for the late president is not yet over.

The foreign minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, said that the referendum was proof that those who had thought that Hafez al-Assad's death would lead to anarchy and instability had lost their bet.

In Britain there were three polling stations - in London, Manchester and Sheffield - for the Syrian community, which includes a large number of students.

fields.headline: Defiant Barak holds on
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, said a prayer for peace yesterday as jeering MPs aimed a parting swipe at him with two no-confidence votes, forcing him to delay his flight to a historic summit in the US.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, said a prayer for peace yesterday as jeering MPs aimed a parting swipe at him with two no-confidence votes, forcing him to delay his flight to a historic summit in the US.

He narrowly survived the first of the votes, underlining the lack of support for his mission to Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland, where talks with the Palestinians begin today.

His government coalition, or at least what remains of it after the defection of three of its members on Sunday, did not fall, because his opponents failed to muster an absolute majority of 61 of the 120 Knesset seats.

But his failure to win even a simple majority - the result was 54 for the no-confidence motion, 52 against and seven abstentions - is a further reminder that the Knesset is angry with his secretive approach to the negotiations.

He left for the US as soon as the result was announced, hours behind schedule and troubled by the fact that many of his colleagues in parliament suspect that he will sell out Israel's security interests at this high-stakes meeting.

Commentators say that if the summit achieves a final settlement of the 52-year conflict with the Palestinians, Mr Barak will call a general election. They are uncertain what will happen if he returns with a more modest deal.

If the talks collapse outright, he could be forced into a government of national unity with the rightwing Likud party.

In a defiant speech Mr Barak told parliament yesterday that, while his government no longer commanded a majority, as the directly elected prime minister he still had a mandate to make peace.

He said he would negotiate with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, "in the name of the parents of Israel, the children of Israel, and the grandparents of Israel".

A poll yesterday showed that 52% believed he should still go to Camp David.

It found that despite the collapse of his coalition, 53% of Israelis believe he has a mandate to make concessions to the Palestinians, against 44% per cent who do not.

But the Knesset was furious at his efforts to circumvent its authority. In his speech, Mr Barak reached out to the rightwing and religious parties which have left his coalition by reaffirming that the contested city of Jerusalem would remain the "eternal and undivided capital of Israel".

His opponents were un-convinced. "He will do everything at this summit to get a peace treaty," said Silvan Shalom, whose Likud party tabled yesterday's no-confidence motion.

"He knows he cannot come back with his tail between his legs. The only thing that can save us is if Arafat refuses to move"

 President Ezer Weizman ended an illustrious career yesterday with an early resignation and a tarnished image.

Under pressure to resign because of a money scandal, the 76-year-old president stepped down three years before the end of his second term.

Since parliament made him president in 1993 he has come under fire for crossing the lines of his largely ceremonial post, blasting rightwing governments and encouraging dovish leaders to move on the path to peace.

webTitle: Wobbling bridge could take its toll

fields.headline: Wobbling bridge could take its toll
fields.trailText: The thousands who queued in vain to experience the Millennium Bridge's notorious wobble may get another chance to test their nerve high above the Thames.
fields.body:
The thousands who queued in vain to experience the Millennium Bridge's notorious wobble may get another chance to test their nerve high above the Thames.

The team behind the £18.2m "blade of light" which links St Paul's and the new Tate Modern on London's South Bank revealed yesterday that they were considering bowing to public demand and opening the bridge to a limited number of thrill seekers before the wobble is fixed.

There is, however, one slight catch. Unlike the quarter of a million brave souls who crossed the bridge last month before it was shut by police, the public may this time have to pay for the privilege.

A token toll of £1 to pay for security costs is being considered, numbers will be strictly limited, and subversive elements who attempt to walk in step will be ruthlessly dealt with.

Engineers blamed "synchronised walking" for exacerbating the wobble in the steel structure, the first horizontal suspension bridge of its type ever built.

The phenomenon is well known to bridge builders, and can cause havoc on piers too. The most celebrated case involved Brighton's West Pier, which rocked violently when promenaders swayed in time to a brass band which played at its opening in the 1880s.

That such a wobble should put paid to the cutting-edge Millennium Bridge more than a century later caused acute embarrassment to its engineers Ove Arup. The chairman, Tony Fitzpatrick, had boasted at the opening that he was "prepared to put a large bet that more people will cross it in its first month than visit the dome in a year".

The bridge's architect, Lord Foster, was quick to lay the blame on the engineers, who are confident of rectifying the "excessive movement" with shock absorbing dampers.

David Bell, chairman of the Millennium Bridge trust, confirmed it was exploring the idea of reopening the bridge before the dampers are fitted.

"Reopening the bridge for a temporary period might be a possibility, but a number of important issues are outstanding, including security, crowd control and public liability," he said.

"It has been put to the trustees that it would be possible to charge a small toll to cover costs of controlling access to the bridge during this temporary period, or to find sponsorship to cover these costs. No decision has yet been made."

Nearly half the money to pay for the bridge came from lottery funds.

webTitle: Chief surgeon must end the bloodshed

fields.headline: Chief surgeon must end the bloodshed
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: There is a fascinating resemblance between these days and the crucial moments of the birth of the Israeli nation: November 1947 (when the Jewish people decided to accept the UN partition plan for Palestine) and May 1948 (Israel's declaration of independence by David Ben Gurion). Ehud Barak is facing a challenge of Ben Gurionian dimensions; he seems to be meeting this challenge with Ben Gurionian courage.
fields.body:
There is a fascinating resemblance between these days and the crucial moments of the birth of the Israeli nation: November 1947 (when the Jewish people decided to accept the UN partition plan for Palestine) and May 1948 (Israel's declaration of independence by David Ben Gurion). Ehud Barak is facing a challenge of Ben Gurionian dimensions; he seems to be meeting this challenge with Ben Gurionian courage.

The circumstances of Israel/Palestine 2000 are very different from those of 1947-48: the risks are different and so are the horizons. Yet the magnitude of the decisions, the vision and the courage they call for are similar.

In 1947, the UN partition plan was rejected by all the Arabs, but painfully accepted by the Jews, who recognised that the country is the homeland of two peoples, not of one - contrary to the prevailing Zionist ethos of the time. The Jews also had to forfeit their holiest places, and accept that the UN partition plan left several Jewish towns and villages under Arab sovereignty.

Ben Gurion's decision to accept this solution evoked an outcry from the hawkish Jewish opposition of the time. True, Ben Gurion enjoyed a broader parliamentary support than Ehud Barak does today - yet let us not forget that in last year's elections Mr Barak received a clearer mandate from the Israeli electorate than was ever secured by Ben Gurion.

On May 14 1948, when Ben Gurion resolved to declare Israel's independence, he was taking risks far more fateful than any Israeli-Palestinian agreement might entail these days. In 1948 Ben Gurion faced an all-out, immediate invasion by five regular Arab armies into the state he was about to declare. The opposition facing Ben Gurion on that day was so strong that his historic resolution passed by a margin of just one vote. This time the opposition was not militant or hawkish, as in November of the previous year, but rather terrified and defeatist, unaware of the unique historic opportunity, playing for time and seeking to postpone the moment of truth.

Ehud Barak and his colleagues, it seems, must now struggle against both types of opposition simultaneously: a 1947-like hawkish opposition and a 1948-like cowardly opposition. To judge by Mr Barak's conduct, he has the guts to face both these challenges. The question, however, is not just one of his personal and political courage, but also of the energy of the doves in Israel to support him while some of his more hawkish or opportunistic partners are defecting.

The doves must support Ehud Barak now, not just by crossing their fingers for him, but by taking to the streets of Israel, and promptly. It will be sad and dangerous if, as in the days of Yitzhak Rabin and Shimon Peres, the hawkist right wing control the streets, while the silent majority sit in their armchairs. We should turn out now, to show the country and the world that millions of Israelis accompany their prime minister with warmth, support and wishes for success.

Go to Camp David, Ehud Barak. Go with courage and caution and wisdom and vision and empathy for others, and with your sharp sense of reality. Go to Camp David like a surgeon walking into the operating theatre: the theatre in which the future of both Israel and Palestine will be decided.

The majority of Israelis are ready for this operation even if it hurts, knowing that after the surgery, if it is successful, all of us may recover from a hundred years of bloodshed.

Most Israelis are not terrified by the moment of truth: they have been awaiting it for years. And they should say so, loud and clear, out in the streets. Right now.

It will be sad and dangerous if, as in the days of Yitzhak Rabin and Shimon Peres, the hawkist right wing control the streets, while the silent majority sit in their armchairs. We should turn out now, to show the country and the world that millions of Israelis accompany their prime minister with warmth, support and wishes for success. Go to Camp David, Ehud Barak. Go with courage and caution and wisdom and vision and empathy for others, and with your sharp sense of reality. Go to Camp David like a surgeon walking into the operating theatre: the theatre in which the future of both Israel and Palestine will be decided. The majority of Israelis are ready for this operation even if it hurts, knowing that after the surgery, if it is successful, all of us may recover from a hundred years of bloodshed. Most Israelis are not terrified by the moment of truth: they have been awaiting it for years. And they should say so, loud and clear, out in the streets. Right now. © Amos Oz

webTitle: Woman jailed for pursuit of TV celebrity

fields.headline: Woman jailed for pursuit of TV celebrity
fields.trailText: The retired BBC weatherman Bill Giles yesterday expressed sympathy for a nurse sent to jail after a nine year harassment campaign in which she claimed to be his daughter.
fields.body:
The retired BBC weatherman Bill Giles yesterday expressed sympathy for a nurse sent to jail after a nine year harassment campaign in which she claimed to be his daughter.

Joanna Toner, 40, was jailed for two and a half years at Barnstaple crown court, Devon, after admitting breaching a restraining order of August 1998, when she was also jailed for six months, forbidding her to contact Mr Giles or his wife, Maureen.

Toner, of Tiverton, who has two children, had also pleaded guilty to arson charges and a bomb hoax. After yesterday's hearing Mr Giles, 60, said: "I feel very sorry for her. The fact she has pleaded guilty means she realised the problem she had."

Toner had sent up to a dozen letters a day to Mr Giles, his wife, people in their village and staff at the weather centre in London. "I was proposed to be Joanna's father."

Peter Greenfield, defending, said Toner intended to pursue this claim "through the correct legal channels".

fields.headline: Reverse for tube train passengers
fields.trailText: A late night tube train with 100 passengers aboard rolled backwards for 1,000 metres, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
A late night tube train with 100 passengers aboard rolled backwards for 1,000 metres, it was revealed yesterday.

Passengers on the London Underground's Northern line found themselves travelling at around 18mph in the wrong direction.

The train came to a halt when it passed an automatic stop signal and there was no damage to the train or injuries to passengers.

Passengers were then able to get off the train at Chalk Farm station in north London.

Asked if the driver fell asleep at the controls, a London Underground spokeswoman said: "We just don't know." LU has now begun an investigation and the driver, who passed a breath test after the incident and is awaiting the result of a drug test, has been "stood down from all duties" pending the results of the inquiry.

The incident happened at 12.50am last Saturday when a northbound train ran backwards downhill from just outside Belsize Park to Chalk Farm.

"We are conducting an investigation to discover exactly how and why this incident occurred. As far as we know, this is the first time something like this has happened," said an LU spokeswoman.

webTitle: Green light for new kind of ketchup

fields.headline: Green light for new kind of ketchup
fields.trailText: Heinz disclosed yesterday that it is planning to launch a green-coloured version of its ketchup in the US in October, and British teams will be keeping a close eye on sales with a view to following suit.
fields.body:
Heinz disclosed yesterday that it is planning to launch a green-coloured version of its ketchup in the US in October, and British teams will be keeping a close eye on sales with a view to following suit.

A spokesman for the company said: "We like to think of ourselves as an innovative company, so in the US trials were carried out with child focus groups and the kids said they wanted to see the red sauce in a new colour.

"Blue was tried out first, but deep green was settled on as it was considered to have more 'kitchen logic'."

The spokesman added: "The green ketchup is also expected to be a hit on St Patrick's Day [March 17]."

Red tomato ketchup was one of the first products to be made by the company and has been on sale in its present form (above) for 125 years.

It is hoped that the product will appeal to more youngsters when it turns green, by making meal time fun.

Although it will be spinach-coloured, the ketchup will in fact be made from green tomatoes and will also contain added vitamin C.

fields.headline: £293,000 for whistle blower
fields.trailText: A former accountant who was sacked after blowing the whistle on his manager's expense claims was awarded  more than £293,000 compensation yesterday in one of the first cases brought under a law which protects whistleblowers from victimisation.
fields.body:
A former accountant who was sacked after blowing the whistle on his manager's expense claims was awarded more than £293,000 compensation yesterday in one of the first cases brought under a law which protects whistleblowers from victimisation.

Antonio Fernandes took his case to an employment tribunal after he was dismissed by Reading-based Netcom Consultants when he raised concerns about expense claims of £370,000 by the managing director, Steven Woodhouse, who "fobbed him off" when he asked for receipts.

The London tribunal found the response of Netcom's US parent company, XSource, was to "get rid" of Mr Fernandes, now 59, and leave Mr Woodhouse in place. Only later, after a further investigation, was the managing director asked to resign.

Mr Fernandes, of Calcot, near Reading, said the award of £293,441, in one of the first cases to be taken under the Public Interest Disclosure Act, was "a good award, more than I expected". He has been unable to get another job and the award will replace the salary he would have earned until retirement.

The act, which has been hailed by US campaigners as the most far reaching whistleblower law in the world, provides for unlimited compensation for workers penalised for raising concerns about wrongdoing.

The charity Public Concern at Work, which backed the case, said the award was a "wake up call" to employers. "If they do not have an effective whistleblowing policy, they will pay dearly," said its director, Guy Dehn.

webTitle: Tories give warning on dome debts

fields.headline: Tories give warning on dome debts
fields.trailText: The Tories last night warned the government against using money from the sale of the Millennium Dome to pay off the troubled attraction's debts.
fields.body:
The Tories last night warned the government against using money from the sale of the Millennium Dome to pay off the troubled attraction's debts.

The warning came as ministers were shown the final presentations from the two remaining bidders vying to take over the dome at the end of the year. The dome has twice been bailed out with lottery loans and at one point this spring was only hours from bankruptcy.

The shadow environment spokesman, Archie Norman, claimed the government was "trying to bail out the big top with cash meant for inner cities", a charge which the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the millennium commission flatly denied.

The Japanese bank Nomura is believed to have bid £100m. It wants to keep many of the dome's contents, but add Yellow Submarine World, based on the Beatles song, and a Where the Wild Things Are experience, based on the book by Maurice Sendak. The Legacy group wants to turn the dome into an "information age" business park.

fields.headline: Teacher challenges blacklist
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A former primary school teacher whose name is on an official blacklist of people thought unsuitable to work with children challenged the list's legality in the high court yesterday.
fields.body:
A former primary school teacher whose name is on an official blacklist of people thought unsuitable to work with children challenged the list's legality in the high court yesterday.

Richard Drabble, his QC, told Mr Justice Newman that SW, who cannot be named for legal reasons, had become tainted by unproven allegations of sexual abuse. Despite an inquiry finding that the allegations could not be substantiated, his name was placed on the health consultancy service index of people deemed unsuitable to work with children.

Mr Drabble said that the index, operated by the health secretary, was "unlawful and unsustainable" because people suspected of abuse had no right of appeal and there were no proper procedural safeguards to protect them, contrary to the European convention on human rights.

Mr Drabble said SW was suspended in July 1992, and again in 1997. He was dismissed after Worcester county council entered his name on the index on the basis of the first allegations.

fields.headline: Alert over Broadmoor smuggling
fields.trailText: Broadmoor high security hospital in Berkshire yesterday announced an investigation into how a patient with a history of violence managed to gain possession of a mobile phone and disposable camera.
fields.body:
Broadmoor high security hospital in Berkshire yesterday announced an investigation into how a patient with a history of violence managed to gain possession of a mobile phone and disposable camera.

The inquiry will also cover allegations that he taped confidential conversations between staff to gain information that could be used against fellow patients.

A hospital spokesman said two nurses have been suspended after allegations of unprofessional behaviour.

It is understood that the breach of security came to light a month ago.

A female nurse was suspended at about the same time, after separate allegations concerning her friendship with a patient. A male nurse was suspended a week later.

Broadmoor houses about 430 patients.

An inquiry under Peter Fallon QC recommended early last year the closure of Ashworth hospital on Merseyside after finding that a young girl being brought to the unit by a member of her family was allowed to associate with the patients.

Frank Dobson, then health secretary, decided the need for such a mental health facility was too great to permit closure.

In May, the government announced plans to spend £55m on improving security at Broadmoor, Ashworth and Rampton hospital in Nottinghamshire.

Ray Rowden, former director of high security hospitals on the NHS executive, said the smuggling of a mobile phone, camera and audio equipment was a serious breach.

Mr Rowden said he understood patients involved in the latest incident were connected to events at Ashworth that sparked the Fallon inquiry.

fields.headline: Camp David's gates reopen
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Palestinian and Israeli negotiators will gather at the US presidential retreat, Camp David, today for a summit that could end 50 years of conflict in the Middle East. But they arrive more in apprehension than expectation, and time - at least under Bill Clinton's presidency - is running out.
fields.body:
Palestinian and Israeli negotiators will gather at the US presidential retreat, Camp David, today for a summit that could end 50 years of conflict in the Middle East. But they arrive more in apprehension than expectation, and time - at least under Bill Clinton's presidency - is running out.

With the Israeli right in revolt and talk of wide gaps on key issues, the usually irrepressible Israel prime minister, Ehud Barak, has put the chance of success at no more than 50-50. The Palestinians, for their part, fear their leader, Yasser Arafat, will be persuaded to make more concessions than his people will swallow.

On the American side, some suggest, President Clinton's first objective is to ensure that, if the summit fails, someone else will get the blame. But there is more at stake for Mr Clinton than that: success would redeem his presidency for the history books and give a huge boost to the Democrats' election campaign.

Israelis and Palestinians alike will seek to emphasise today how little scope they have for manoeuvre. Mr Barak can point to the fragility of his coalition, amply demonstrated by his opponents in the past few days.But his position is perhaps more secure than it looks. In the event of a deal he has promised a referendum, which would allow the more extreme elements of his coalition no more weight than is their due.

Mr Arafat also has a problem with his constituency, but although his hand appears to be a weak one, it is not hopeless. He has threatened to declare a Palestinian state unilaterally if there is no agreement and the Israelis have responded by threatening to annex parts of the occupied territories. It is debatable which side would suffer most if that happened.

One approach the US could take would be to bridge some of the gaps with dollars. It worked in 1978, when Israel was placated by the hope that the US would pay cost of replacing three airfields in Sinai if the Israelis vacated them. This time, however, they are talking billions with noughts on.

The Palestinians are said to be seeking $40bn (£26.4bn) in aid for the new state, plus tens of billions towards solving the refugee problem. Israel is looking for even more.

webTitle: Police bail MP over parking dispute

fields.headline: Police bail MP over parking dispute
fields.trailText: The veteran Labour MP Stuart Bell has been questioned by police and bailed after an alleged fracas with a neighbour over a long running dispute about parking in their shared drive.
fields.body:
The veteran Labour MP Stuart Bell has been questioned by police and bailed after an alleged fracas with a neighbour over a long running dispute about parking in their shared drive.

The MP for Middlesbrough, a barrister and author, was taken to the town's police station after a complaint from his neighbours, following an argument outside their £200,000 Victorian terraced homes.

He was released without charge pending further investigations, and was back at work at the House of Commons yesterday. Neighbours said that the incident followed a minor bump in the drive, when Mr Bell's wife Margaret appeared to reverse the couple's £18,000 BMW into a parked van belonging to the son of their neighbour, Gordon MacClure.

Mr Bell, 63, who has been MP for Middlesbrough for 17 years, made national headlines by championing parents involved in the 1987 Cleveland child abuse inquiry. His solicitor, Donald O'Rourke, said yesterday: "I would be surprised if anything comes of it. Mr Bell was not charged with any offences and he will not be making any statement."

Neighbours in The Avenue, a quiet part of the Teesside town, said that bad feeling over parking in the drive behind the terrace went back for some years.

One neighbour, who did not want to be named, said: "It seems Margaret may have reversed her car into the van and that is how the incident started. It's very embarrassing but that's as much as I know."

Mr MacClure, who is retired and in his 70s, said that he had been on holiday in the Lake District at the weekend when the alleged incident took place.

He said: "My son has told me what happened and I have been in contact with the police and I am waiting for an officer to come and see me. I have been advised to say nothing else at this stage."

webTitle: Adopted baby must go back to the US

fields.headline: Adopted baby must go back to the US
fields.trailText: A Texas adoption agency has won a unique high court order to get back a baby it handed over to an English couple straight after birth on the strength of a report from an unqualified social worker.
fields.body:
A Texas adoption agency has won a unique high court order to get back a baby it handed over to an English couple straight after birth on the strength of a report from an unqualified social worker.

The attempted adoption, which cost the couple $19,000 (£13,000), raises doubts about US adoption controls. While adoption agencies are strictly regulated in some American states, others fall below British standards.

The couple, who live in the south of England with their 15-year-old son, have been deemed unsuitable adoptive parents by their local social services department. Social workers, who discovered that the couple had the baby when she was taken for medical treatment, took her into care and placed her with foster parents.

They contacted the adoption agency and suggested that it try to get back the baby, whose adoption had not been finalised.

The order by Mr Justice Johnson, one of the family division's most senior judges, is the first to be granted to an adoption agency under the Hague convention, drawn up to return children kidnapped by estranged parents in tug-of-love battles. The agency will have its legal costs met by the British taxpayer.

The judge made the order last Thursday, but cleared it for publication only yesterday. He said yesterday that his decision would have been much more difficult had the baby spent a year or more with the couple and become settled. But she was only seven months old and living with foster parents.

In his judgment, he criticised the way the adoption process had been handled: "I do not think anybody could begin to believe this was a proper way of deciding the future of a human being." He said that the baby girl, identified only by the initial J, was born in Texas on December 18 and immediately handed over by her mother, who had relinquished all parental responsibility, to the adoption agency.

Two days later the prospective father from England went to the US, and J was handed over after he signed an adoption agreement.

The judgment states that $19,000 was paid to the agency, but the agency's solicitor, Carolynn Usher, said her client, a non-profit concern, had not taken that much, and suggested that it might be a total figure for the couple's cost and expenses, including airfare.

She said the US view was that it was in the child's interest to have a quick placement, while agencies in Britain took "a more cautious approach".

The judge said the agreement provided for the adoption to be finalised within seven months and referred to "home visits" by a social worker.

But having signed the agreement and paid the money, the adoptive father returned to Britain with the child, who was only six days old. No home visits had taken place.

Mr Justice Johnson said a surprising feature of the case was that the adoption proceeded on the basis of a report by an independent social worker with no professional qualifications.

The judge said the social services department was concerned when it discovered the baby was living with the couple "because it believed that there were compelling reasons why the couple should not be regarded as able to provide a safe and secure home for J".

The official solicitor supported the agency's application, after receiving undertakings that Texas child care agencies and courts would be involved in determining J's future.
