fields.headline: Ice cool winner
fields.standfirst: Ice cream, once the preserve of the rich, is now everybody's favourite, thanks to technology
fields.trailText: Ice cream, once the preserve of the rich, is now everybody's favourite, thanks to technology
fields.body:
Next time you buy an ice cream pause before you guzzle it. You are holding a cold link to history in your hand. What was once a luxury at the feasts of the fabulously wealthy is yours to munch any time the impulse grabs you.

What are the origins of ice cream?

It is said that Marco Polo brought the knowledge of ice-cream making back with him from China in the 13th century. There is no evidence and it is doubtful that he reached China.

However, the use of ice and snow to cool food and drink dates back more than 4,000 years. Alexander the Great is known to have ordered the digging of pits in which to store mountain ice, and the Romans put snow in their wine.

If you mix salts such as alum in water a reaction occurs which causes the temperature of the water to drop. This chemistry may have travelled from India to the Middle East where Arabs used it to cool sugared drinks they called "sharab" - the early version of sorbet. Thanks to trade or the writings of Arab scholars, the salt technique came to southern Europe. Water ices appeared in Italy by the middle of the 17th century and in Naples they added fruit to cold sweetened milk. Ice cream had arrived!

What contributed to making ice cream available for everyone?

When King Charles II ate ice cream at a banquet at Windsor Castle in 1671 it was only served to him and the people at his table. So it was across Europe. Ice cream was just for the rich people who could afford to build ice houses to store ice "farmed" from winter lakes and ponds.

It was not until the 19th century that ice cream became the food of humbler folk. Several factors contributed. Chefs, who once might have only cooked for royalty, set up restaurants. Their menus included ice cream. Second, recipe books featuring ice-cream dishes became popular. In one of these by a Mrs Marshall, published in 1888, the first mention of ice-cream cones occurs.

Better transport meant ice dropped in price - London received supplies from as far away as Norway. Poverty caused many Italians to seek their fortunes in Britain and America - often they became involved in the ice-cream trade. With the arrival of electricity, inventors created the first refrigerators. Ice cream could be stored and the stage was now set.

How much ice cream is sold in Britain?

About 370 ice-cream makers operate in Britain. There are two main types: impulse products (cones and stick ices) and premium products (luxury ice creams designed for home eating). Sales are worth a cool £1 billion a year. Most goes to a few international firms. Seven in 10 ice creams bought on impulse in the UK are made by Wall's. More than 60 million Magnums are eaten in Britain every year - one for every resident.

How did Wall's come to dominate the UK ice-cream scene?

It found clever ways of distributing its ice cream. There were "stop-me-and-buy-one" tricycles and then ice-cream vans. It lent shops refrigerators in which only Wall's ice creams could be stored. Rivals, such as Lyons Maid and Mars were cut off from large parts of the marketplace.

Has Wall's had an unfair advantage?

Yes, say its rivals. In 1989 Mars extended its famous chocolate bar into a dairy ice cream. Frustrated by its inability to get its product into many shops, it pressed British governments to loosen Walls' grip. In January the government backed a ruling that, among other measures, Wall's would have to allow shop owners to fill up to 50% of its freezer space with rivals' products. This summer will be the last season that Wall's has the big distribution advantage. Talk of an ice-cream revolution is in the air.

Further activities

 Behind every ice cream there is a story. Track down the origins of the Sundae, the Knickerbocker Glory and the Peach Melba.

 Merchandising tie-ins between ice creams and films or cartoon characters make up a significant number of the products on the market. Invent a stick ice that reflects a character in one of your class readers or set texts. Make the shape, flavours and texture fit the character's personality.

 Research the big ice cream manufacturers on line

Mars, Unilever (for Birds Eye Wall's ), Ben and Jerry's

 Haagen Dazs may sound Scandinavian but it is an invented name. Research the original launch of the product.

 The trade association for ice-cream manufacturers contains a wealth of information.

fields.headline: Pictures
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor tells all there is to know about pictures on the internet
fields.body:
Pictures can look wonderful on the web. Try visiting www.uxbridge.ac.uk and wait for the page to load. After a while, a few gloriously high-resolution photos will appear. (You might want to boil a kettle in the meantime). Now try www.rosa.co.uk The photos are not quite as sharp, but that hardly matters when the page loads so fast.

"The top advice for anyone using pictures on a website is not to make images too big," says Tim Mcevilly, one of the designers at Guardian Unlimited. "Pages should be less than 50k. If you want to use big photos, have thumbnails that people can click on."

The bigger the number of bytes a page contains (the Altavista search engine displays these), the longer it takes to load, and the more bored visitors will become as they wait to see it. If, on the other hand, they see a page of thumbnails - smaller versions of pictures on other pages - they can choose which to see in detail by clicking on them (for example see The National Protrait Gallery).

The photos you want to add to a site may already be in electronic format - if they arrive as email attachments, for example, or if (probably illegally) you dragged them off another site. Or they might come from a digital camera. Alternatively, they may have to be scanned in. But before you embed them in a web page they will almost certainly need to be altered.

Only very fortunate web designers will have access to Photoshop, which is the industry's standard package for manipulating pictures and costs around £400. However, most scanners and digital cameras have basic software that lets you resize photos, get rid of red-eye and change the contrast. Paintshop Pro is another. One of the most useful places to find out about adapting images for the web is Webmonkey.

Web images come in two basic formats: the GIF (with a file name ending in .gif) and the JPEG (.jpg) file. Because the GIF has only 256 colours, photos normally look better in JPEG format and other images in GIF. Webmonkey's article Gif vs. jpeg will help you choose.

Some people will always fall upon a colour palette and a web page with the same blind enthusiasm as infants mixing paint. Since learning from other people's mistakes is always more entertaining than following rules, visit the Websites That Suck to see some blatant abuses of free webspace.

fields.headline: Maths Year 2000
fields.trailText: "Maths is fun" is the message of Maths Year 2000 and books with maths puzzles, quests, themes and storylines are a great way to explore and investigate mathematical ideas.
fields.body:
"Maths is fun" is the message of Maths Year 2000 and books with maths puzzles, quests, themes and storylines are a great way to explore and investigate mathematical ideas for seven- to 11-year-olds as well as motivate the reluctant reader and retarded mathematician! You can also take a trip to <A HREF="http://www.mathsyear2000.org"" TARGET="_NEW">Matrix, Maths Year 2000's new, interactive museum and gallery.

Murderous Maths: The Essential Arithmetricks
Kjartan Poskitt
(Scholastic, £3.99)

Chainsaw Charlie, Half Smile and the gang will help you count your way out of the diabolical death trap and stop the horrendous green-spot epidemic in this funny collection of cartoons and stories. Kjartan Poskitt knits in explanations of the maths and mathematical terms in a series of these entertaining Murderous Maths books. But it carries a warning: "This book contains some rather rude sums!"

Number Puzzles: Solve the Sums, Seek the Crystal!
Peter Patilla
(Walker Books, £1.99)

This graphic novel will appeal to reluctant readers as well as reluctant mathematicians who like the "quest" format of solving the puzzles of mazes, runes, caves, pyramids and swamps to get to the magical crystal. Sky Master and Planet Prince provide the commentary while the Wise Monkey offers clues and directions.

Design a Pram
Anne Fine
(Mammoth Yellow Bananas, £3.99)

Applying mathematical skills to solve real practical problems has always been the sure-fire way to turn children on to maths, and this book is a lovely example of how children can rise to the task when they are set an interesting challenge. It is the story, simply but artfully told, of a harassed teacher, Mr Oakway, who is trying to write his annual reports and sets the children a spontaneous challenge to design a pram. Little does he know what the outcome will be, and that the children employ so much mathematical ingenuity that he has to judge the results. Classic Anne Fine irony!

One in a Million: a book of poems where maths is fun
compiled by Moira Andrew
(Young Puffin, £3.99)

We can all come to love the pattern, structure and symmetry of maths and many of us will come to love it through the creative and narrative insights that are provided by poems about maths. This collection includes both traditional rhymes and contemporary work by poets such as Judith Nicholls and Russell Hoban. It is also arranged by theme so you can pick out reflective, thought-provoking, witty and even funny poems about everything from height and weight, money and shopping to shape, pattern, time, days and dates. Proof that maths really is fun!

Ruby's Recipes
Akulah Agbami
(Mammoth Storybook, £3.99)

Ruby's mum, Arlene, runs a busy Caribbean restaurant. The trouble is, it's just a bit too successful for Ruby's liking because she doesn't get to see her mum as often as she would like. So Ruby decides to embark on a "Teach yourself to cook course" and starts with the "cakes and biscuits" section, with predictably disastrous results! This delightful story shows how important the mathematical skills of weighing, measuring and estimating are and how you really cannot afford to take them for granted. Ruby's mum, big brother Jerry and Grandma come to the rescue and in the process demonstrate the maths of some delicious recipes. I know, I've tried some of them!

webTitle: Unknown work of Romantic poet uncovered

fields.headline: Unknown work of Romantic poet uncovered
fields.trailText: A previously unknown poem by the 19th century poet laureate Robert Southey has been found hidden in a dusty collection of post amassed by a fanatical autograph hunter who pestered distinguished contemporaries.
fields.body:
A previously unknown poem by the 19th century poet laureate Robert Southey has been found hidden in a dusty collection of post amassed by a fanatical autograph hunter who pestered distinguished contemporaries.

The untitled ode to an Edinburgh sunrise sheds a new and unexpectedly sympathetic light on Southey's view of Scot land and the Scots, whom the poet notoriously dismissed as "miserably puny" and "the ugliest nation in Europe apart from the French".

The 37 lines on the Scottish capital, written in 1805, eight years before Southey became poet laureate, compare the city at dawn to King Arthur's Camelot, with the sun burning the morning mist off the castle and Holyrood House. The ode, which fits with Southey's description in a letter of the time of "wild red skies" slanting along Edinburgh's rooftops, was found in the Brooks collection, 12 leather-bound volumes of autographs collected by John Crosse Brooks, a Tyneside shipbuilder and amateur historian. The trove is being investigated in detail for the first time by a Newcastle University postgraduate researcher, Christopher Goulding, after years in restricted access at the city's Society of Antiquaries.

"The collection has already yielded previously unpublished letters by Percy Shelley and Lord Byron," said Mr Goulding. Unknown poems by Southey are rare finds, as he was meticulous about editing his work and recorded that material sifted out should be "consigned to the flames". He was poet laureate from 1813 to his death in 1843 and is best known for romantic ballads such as The Inchcape Rock and How Does the Water Come Down at Lodore? Although prolific, his ruthless editing and collection of all his approved poems in 10 volumes in 1838 has led to only two or three brief passages being found since his death.

The poem was wrapped in several signed letters from the poet to his publisher, which Brooks bought at a literary auction.

Patient, I climbed the hill and on its height

Paus'd for my pulse play'd quick. I cast mine eyes

Down on the city that I late had left.

Had the noon sun shone full upon the vale

Lovely had been the scene, but lovelier now,

For thro the windings of the glen, the mist

Spread white and moveless, over the town towers

Stretching its long ascent, and high above

Tinged with the early ray. The reddening ray

Beam'd on the pile that crests the ancient hill

Where Arthur with the last of Camelot

Scattered the Saxon tribes; the broken light

Shone in the morning, and its glittering pile

Seem'd like some fabric sear'd by magic power

Amid the clouds, searching whose strange ascent

Many a good errant night might roam below

Vainly adventuring. Lovelier now the scene

Than in the richness of a summer eve,

For all familiar to the eye was veil'd

And the deep obscure delighted while it mock'd

The baffled light. The Sun shone cheerfully

On the clear summit that my toil had gain'd,

And where the fir trees skirted the deep grove,

Shot a slant beam upon their branchless trunk

Their bright brown bark, and tinged its rusty moss.

The autumnal leaves to the fresh morning air

Their grateful odour gave; the broken dew

Clouded the green sward grey; and the thin stem

Of the grass-blossom bent with little globes

Whose whole collected waters had not brimm'd

Some Elfin's acorn cup. Onward I went -

It seem'd as I looked down upon the Sun

That climbing glorious up the eastern heaven

Flash'd on my dazzled sight: anon the mist

Roll'd on and veil'd its beams, and in a sea

Of cloud wrapt all things, - only visible

Thro' the white vapour was the beamless Sun.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: How can I keep up my daughter's interest in books and numbers without creating a rebel at home!
fields.body:
Teachers say children's numeracy and literacy levels drop alarmingly during the long summer break. Without wishing to impose a strict reading and counting regime, I'd like to know how I can keep up my daughter's interest in books and numbers without creating a rebel at home!

Stephen Keeler is an education consultant specialising in language and literacy.

Whoa! Hold it there. Firstly, no compelling evidence suggests all children's literacy and numeracy levels drop "alarmingly" during the summer holidays.

But some evidence suggests the literacy and/or numeracy skills of children who struggle in these areas are more likely to deteriorate when they stop practising them for a long period. Regular use of text, narrative and other linguistic devices helps to develop competence in literacy. Also, systematic exposure to numeracy tasks, sustained practice routines and the involvement of a good role model will invariably help children become numerate.

For many children the summer holiday offers an increasingly rare chance to escape pressures to perform and conform. They can forget all about SATs and the passed-on hysteria of an Ofsted inspection. For others it's all too easy to let things slide.

You will know your daughter's strengths and weaknesses. If not, ask her teacher(s), but don't demand detailed "homework" schedules - most teachers will, rightly, resist. In many ways, it is not especially helpful to lump literacy and numeracy skills together. But since both can usefully be practised with great enjoyment for all concerned, and certainly without her needing to rebel, why not try a few ideas:

Ask your daughter's teacher(s) to suggest holiday activities. Many good schools give summer reading suggestions and more are making number activities available to pupils out of school.

Check out your local bookshops. Most larger chains run various holiday workshops in story-telling and science. Watch out for author visits, maths sessions and book promotions.

What is your local education authority offering as summer schools? Besides summer "play" schools, some run one-off, one day workshops, take themed days out - say, to the Roald Dahl Gallery at the Buckinghamshire County Museum in Aylesbury (01296 331441) or the annual three-week book festival during August in Charlotte Square, Edinburgh (hotline: 0906 553 5060), which has a full children's programme.

Visit a local museum of childhood to look at children's books, counting toys and science games of earlier generations. Use your local library or newspaper, or the internet, to find lists of museums, addresses, phone numbers and details of opening hours.

A day out just visiting the children's section of a large or specialist children's bookshop can be fun, especially your child is asked to handle the money for the train tickets or to buy the drinks and sandwiches later - check the change, of course.

Involve children in household tasks such as writing your shopping list from your dictation, and comparing prices, weights and volumes of items you buy in the supermarket. Encourage your child(ren) to send postcards to friends and relatives when you go away.

Make time, occasionally and without pressure, for multiplication table tests-where your child tests you. Extend the idea of your children writing tests by being prepared to submit yourself to, for example, a Harry Potter quiz, or a mental arithmetic marathon (especially on long car journeys).

fields.headline: A shadow on sixth forms
fields.standfirst: Theresa May  pledges to keep school sixth forms, however weak and inadequate
fields.trailText: Theresa May pledges to keep school sixth forms, however weak and inadequate
fields.body:
The Learning and Skills Bill channels funding away from sixth forms. It is part of Labour's levelling agenda to get rid of school sixth forms in favour of further education and tertiary colleges.

The bill threatens the viability of sixth forms across the country by introducing sweeping powers to close sixth forms that are inadequate or have significant weaknesses in one or more areas. The government has failed to properly define inadequate, or weaknesses. A school's sixth form is said to be inadequate if it is failing "to give pupils over compulsory school age an acceptable standard of education" or the school has "significant weaknesses in one or more areas of activities for pupils over compulsory school age".

It is clear that a school may not be failing, but still could be said to be suffering from significant weaknesses, and thus fall foul of the second limb of the test. Is a sixth form with a small number of subjects on offer, or small classes, inadequate? Questions like these are of particular interest to rural sixth forms and those that are just starting out. When a sixth form is first introduced it is by common assent inadequate. Imagine a school inspector carrying out a normal inspection and asking himself how he should define the situation. On reading the legislation he would have to say that the school is inadequate, and hence sound the death knell for those just starting to build up a reputation.

Under the bill funding will now come via Learning and Skills Council grants, which will form part of the schools' budgets. However it is provided that "the grants shall be used for the purposes of, or purposes connected with, the provision by schools of education suitable to the requirements of persons above compulsory school age."

In other words all the money does not have to go on school sixth-form provision. Moreover the Learning and Skills Councils funds will come from top-slicing local education authorities.

How schools spend their budget between classes is currently a matter for them. This arrangement is yet another example of government interference in how schools are run.

The uncertainty of the bill's impact is a major concern of ours, especially with regard to the allocation of £6bn by the two statutory committees. We are also concerned about the scope of local councils' power to vary national rates when these are out of line with local circumstances, and the obvious risks of bureaucracy and over-centralisation in a scheme of this nature.

The situation is unacceptable. Our children only have one chance in education and they deserve the best. School sixth forms offer higher standards and increased choice to pupils. The percentage of children achieving five A-C grades at GCSE is higher in a school with a sixth form than in a school without. Our survey of heads in London schools which have sixth forms, showed that 99% thought that a sixth form offered intangible benefits not offered by sixth form colleges, and 60% believed that their sixth form was under threat from the government's proposals.

Furthermore over 60% agreed with our free schools policy, which involves direct funding of schools and gives heads complete control over their budgets. We want to be able to give schools the freedom to retain, expand or set up new sixth forms. We believe that each school should be able to set its own admissions policy, have greater flexibility over the curriculum and determine term times and opening hours.

Young people want choice and diversity in the provision of further education, rather than the removal by stealth of sixth forms, by this government. Our aim is to provide a system which is characterised by diversity and choice and caters for children of all abilities.

 Theresa May, MP is shadow secretary of state for Education and Employment.

fields.headline: Heart on sleeve
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones has been there, done that and is getting the T-shirt
fields.trailText: Janet Jones has been there, done that and is getting the T-shirt
fields.body:
A camel, as everyone knows, is a horse designed by a committee. I very much hope that whatever it was that happened to the horse does not happen to our college T-shirts. There is a proposal, in our college, to raise our profile and get the T-shirt, three T-shirts to be precise:

T-shirt one: How to be a student.

T-shirt two: How to be a teacher.

T-shirt three: How to be a manager.

T-shirt four: How to be a support staff, was vetoed for three reasons: the grammar does not work; the words are the wrong ones to carry across the body; a manager's T-shirt would probably fit a support staff as well as it would fit a manager.

This is how the proposal might go in our college - as it would in any other.

Our two-letter logo will be on the backs of all three T-shirts, colour-coded to match the words which will be on the fronts.

T-shirt one will be green on white. T-shirt two will be rainbow on white. T-shirt three will be grey on white.

The T-shirts will come in three sizes: small, medium and large. These will not correspond to student, teacher and manager. All sizes will be available in all T-shirts.

The committee will monitor political correctness. The T-shirts will be 100% cotton. The cotton will be 100% organic. The T-shirts will be made in a co-operative workshop in a developing country where no one is exploited. No experiments will be made on any animals in the manufacture of the T-shirts.

The washing instructions will be prescriptive and inclusive: do not rub isolated stains; machine wash warm; normal; wash dark colours separately; do not bleach; spin; do not tumble dry; reshape while damp; dry flat; dry away from direct sunlight; warm iron. Alternatively, the T-shirts can be dry cleaned.

All the words on all the T-shirts will be in English. (This will be a matter of regret to some members of the committee.)

The words themselves will cause more meetings and discussions than the manufacture, design, distribution or price of the T-shirts. The T-shirts will be profit-making.

The position described on each T-shirt will have three principles to guide it. The principles will not be numbered as numbers suggest priorities. The three principles will be bullet pointed.

The fronts of the T-shirts will read as follows:

How To Be a Student

 Be present

 Be punctual

 Study

How To Be a Teacher

 Be present

 Be punctual

 Teach

How To Be a Manager

 Be previous

 Be available

 Be absent.

No camels here, I hope.

fields.headline: Glazing
fields.trailText: Glazing
fields.body:
I'm afraid there's been a bit of a row. So I see.

And there's a bit of a hole. What was it this time?

The Shorter Oxford. You chucked a dictionary at him?

We take our Scrabble seriously. But not your windows. That's the third this year.

He's too good at ducking. I'm not complaining. Do you want reinforced glass this time?

Good idea. I suppose you clear up after a lot of domestic rows. We glaziers do many things, madam.

Oh, do tell. We cut glass, plastic or any window material and put it where and when it's needed: domestic double-glazing, big plate-glass shop fronts, glass roofs on industrial buildings, stained or leaded glass.

It's not just boring old glass? We use our knowledge of the properties of each glazing material and the position it is to be installed in to choose the appropriate material.

And there's the Plasticine, too. We call it putty, madam.

Do you specialise, or all do everything? There are specialists, especially in smaller firms. The staple work is window fixing, security, safety or high-wind glass, double-glazed windows and pre-glazed doors and roof glazing.

You obviously get around. Not half. Glaziers work both indoors and outdoors in all weathers and on construction sites where it can be pretty dirty or noisy. And often we work high up and need ladders, scaffolding and suspended cradles.

And you need muscles? Yep. We have to handle large, heavy panes of glass carefully.

Sounds dangerous. Working with glass requires a great deal of safety awareness, not just for ourselves but for other workers and members of the public.

What qualities are useful? Practical ability. The work takes methodical planning. Accurate measurement is essential. We need to be able to follow drawings, plans and written or spoken instructions. Cutting glass is a skill, which can be dangerous if care is not taken. Some specialist jobs, such as stained glass work, require a creative approach to colour and shape.

Any entry requirements? Not really, although a few GCSEs (grades A-G) are usually needed for entry as a trainee craftsperson. Maths, English and technology subjects are useful for the parts of the job that involve measurements and calculations and for theoretical training. Entrants for apprenticeships or training schemes may have to pass a selection test.

What about training? Most glaziers train on the job and gain vocational qualifications part-time at college. They are likely to work towards NVQs in installing glass structures and architectural glazing systems. There is a three-year construction apprenticeship scheme open to over-16s with a structured training programme aimed at NVQs levels 2 or 3.

 Glass and Glazing Federation, 44-48 Borough High Street, London SE1 1XB Telephone: 020-7403 7177

 Glass Training Ltd, BGMC Building Northumberland Road, Sheffield S10 2UA Telephone: 0114-266 1494

 Construction Industry Training Board (CITB), Bircham Newton, King's Lynn, Norfolk PE31 6RH Telephone: 01485 577 577

 Construction Apprenticeship Scheme Helpline Telephone: 01485 57833

 Federation of Master Builders, 14-15 Great James Street, London WC1N 3DP Telephone: 020-7242 7583

 learndirect 0800 100 900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses

fields.headline: Shipping news
fields.standfirst: Seafarers needed for tomorrow's merchant navy
fields.trailText: Seafarers needed for tomorrow's merchant navy
fields.body:
If schoolkids are still taught the line about Britain being a seafaring nation, it's probably confined to their history lessons. That is not how most of us see ourselves nowadays.

As Michael Grey, former editor of Lloyds List, asked in a recent speech to the Marine Society: "Isn't it sad that the only ship that everyone in the 21st century knows of is an early 20th-century failure called the Titanic?"

So the news that the merchant navy is launching a recruitment drive prompts a typical response: do we still have one?

The answer from the Chamber of Shipping, the British shipping trade association, is a resounding yes.

In fact the merchant navy is a vital industry. Britain depends on the sea for 95% of its trade. British shipping is the country's fifth largest service-sector earner, contributing £2.6bn net to Britain's balance of payments. The merchant fleet is about 1,600 vessels, of which about 600 are "trading" ships.

And now the government intends this to get bigger, a lot bigger. It is hoped that the merchant navy, the generic term for the civilian shipping industry, consisting of companies operating a wide variety of vessels, from small tugs, coasters and ferries through to the large ocean going tankers, containers and cruise ships, will grow as a result of the tonnage tax which comes into effect this October.

British shipping companies will be taxed on the size or tonnage of their ships, rather than on actual profits, which will enable them to compete on the same footing as international rivals.

The tax is designed to boost morale in one of the nation's most important industries and prompt the repatriation of many UK-owned ships to the UK register and increase the UK-owned fleet. This, of course, would increase employment opportunities both at sea and in related shore-based occupations.

To opt for the tonnage-based tax, companies must either commit to recruiting and training a specified number of British cadets per year, or contribute to a maritime National Training Trust.

This is not the only reason, however, why the merchant navy is soon going to need many more young men and women. The merchant navy's current workforce of 29,309 seafarers, of whom 17,356 are officers, is ageing. Seventy-three per cent of UK officers are aged between 40 and 65. Officers are retiring at a much quicker rate than they can be replaced. It is estimated that the number of officers will only recover if the cadet intake averages 1,450 per year. It is currently running between 500 and 600.

These days the vast bulk of recruitment is at officer level. There are far fewer jobs for ratings. The economic reality is that deep sea ships are staffed almost entirely by crews from the third world, who cost less in wages. There are more opportunities for British ratings on coastal ships.

At present there simply are not enough school-leavers or graduates thinking of a career in the merchant navy.

"The sea has lost its shine for young people for a number of reasons," says Andrew McNeil, of the Chamber of Shipping.

"People simply don't see ships any more in rivers such as the Mersey or Thames which were once full of them. Containerisation means that ships are loaded and unloaded at ports far away from centres of population."

For those youngsters who do opt for a life on the ocean wave, there is a three-year training course, during which their companies pay them.

The shore-based elements are taught at four institutions: the Southampton Institute, Glasgow College of Nautical Studies, South Tyneside College, and Blackpool and Fylde College. Up until now the courses have led to a number of qualifications, including an HND. Now a degree programme has been launched.

Like getting a supertanker to stop, reversing the decline in interest in maritime careers will be a gradual process.

"It'll be a long slow haul, but we are used to that," says McNeil.

fields.headline: Surprise, surprise
fields.standfirst: Who will gain most from Gordon Brown's latest funding bonanza? Why, the south, of course, say  Lee Elliot Major and  Richard Colebourn
fields.trailText: Who will gain most from Gordon Brown's latest funding bonanza? Why, the south, of course, say Lee Elliot Major and Richard Colebourn
fields.byline: Lee Elliot Major and  Richard Colebourn
fields.body:
Science in the south-east is set to be the main winner of the £1bn boon in research funds unveiled out of the blue by the Treasury and the Wellcome Trust last week. Grants for university research facilities and buildings will be allocated predominantly to institutions which already attract the lion's share of research funds. There is also more government money for the £550m X-ray facility near Oxford, jointly funded with the charity.

Wellcome's plans for a £100m park for scientific businesses near Cambridge, meanwhile, are finally set to get the green light from local planners.

Chancellor Gordon Brown's leaked announcement came as a complete surprise to the research and funding councils which will allocate the grants to universities. In the spirit of former Wellcome-government deals, the decision was made at the last minute: finalised last Monday night between Wellcome Trust director Mike Dexter and senior Treasury officials.

Brown is making a habit of shocking the academic world: universities were outraged when the Treasury suddenly announced £68m for Cambridge University to forge a transatlantic link with MIT.

But, alongside the euphoria over this extra money, officials and university representatives gave a collective sigh of relief that the grants will not be allocated through the open competition used for the £750m joint infrastructure fund over the last three years. Many multi-million pound infrastructure bids failed to receive funds at the final hurdle in the competition, wasting considerable time and resources in universities.

Instead of receiving bids from universities, funding will this time be allocated formulaicly, "determined by excellence and volume of research" in the government's words. (Academics will also be expected to raise 25% of project funding by their own means.)

This is likely to mean that money will be awarded in a pro rata fashion to institutions, proportional to how much money they have already won. During 2002-4, £300m of the funds will be allocated on the back of the results of the Research Assessment Exercise, and £375m on the back of research council funding. This will almost definitely mean that the golden triangle of research heavyweights in the south-east - Oxbridge, Imperial and University College London - will automatically secure most of the new money. As revealed in the Guardian last week, the latest research funding figures show that these four secure about a quarter of all research grants awarded to UK universities.

Wellcome, meanwhile, will allocate £225m of its money to the redevelopment of buildings and the refurbishment of labs in the biomedical sciences. Many of these projects are likely to come from highly rated but failed applications in the JIF scheme. Many senior officials will welcome the fact that Wellcome and the government agencies will not this time have to work together to deploy the new infrastructure funds. There is also more government money for the £550m X-ray facility near Oxford, jointly funded with the charity. fields.headline: Ghost buster
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot  explains why Vic Tandy of Coventry University is doing time in a cellar
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot explains why Vic Tandy of Coventry University is doing time in a cellar
fields.body:
She called herself a white witch. One of three, as it happens, who had visited a 14th-century cellar near Coventry Cathedral at different times.

Word had spread that there was a "presence" down there. Whatever it was certainly put the fear of God into witch number three. She was up the steps and through the tourist information office, which stands over the cellar, almost before staff had noticed she'd gone. Almost, but not quite.

Carole Jung, assistant manager of the tourist office at the time, noticed that the witch looked "frightened to death". And she wasn't surprised. She, too, had had first-hand experience of the apparition and felt as though she were "intruding, disturbing something" when she took tours down the cellar.

Others had been affected as well. Colour was seen to drain from the face of a visiting Canadian journalist, who said later that he was sure the face of a woman had been peering over his right shoulder.

News of these strange phenomena had spread, not only to the community of white witches but also to Coventry University. Vic Tandy was more interested than most. He is experimental officer and part-time lecturer in the school of international studies and law. He could also be described as the university's chief ghost buster.

Two years ago, he and Dr Tony Lawrence of the psychology department wrote a paper called Ghosts in the Machine for the journal of the Society for Psychical Research. They cited infrasound as the cause of apparitions seen by staff at a so-called haunted laboratory in Warwick.

Tandy has just sent in another contribution to the same magazine. It is called Something in the Cellar, and it nails the culprit which terrified a Canadian journalist and a white witch. Infrasound, again.

Infrasound, what's more, at the same level as that found in the Warwick laboratory: 18.9 Hz. As the .9 suggests, this is a very accurate reading established over a lengthy period using a sophisticated spectrum analyser from the university's department of engineering.

Infrasound is not easy to measure because it vibrates at a frequency below the level of human hearing. "Evidence from Nasa and other sources suggests that it can cause you to hyperventilate and your eyeballs to vibrate," says Tandy. Having established its presence here at a level likely to cause anxiety and apparitions, he is now trying to establish why some people are affected and not others.

Meanwhile, he is developing a device - "a sort of litmus test" - which will detect the presence of infrasound. It won't cost thousands and it won't require a 13-amp plug. "That does rather restrict your areas of research," he says with a grin. For the time being, he is using another spectrum analyser, cheaper than the one belonging to the engineering department, and battery-driven.

Still, with its stylish silver case and its laptop screen, it looks rather incongruous parked on a glass display case full of medieval bone pins, 16th-century clay pipes and other artefacts from Coventry's illustrious past. Modern science on top of ancient history.

Surely science in the 21st century will confine the ghosts to history by explaining them away. Not necessarily. "When it comes to supernatural phenomena, I'm sitting on the fence. That's where scientists should be until we've proved that there isn't anything," says Tandy, who has had some personal experience of what it's like to feel a ghostly presence.

It happened some years ago when he was designing anaesthetic machines in that "haunted" Warwick laboratory. A cleaner had already given in her notice, complaining that she had seen a grey object out of the corner of her eye and "gone all cold".

Tandy was working late one night when the grey thing came for him. "I felt the hairs rise on the back of my neck," he recalls. "It seemed to be between me and the door, so the only thing I could do was turn and face it."

It disappeared. But only to reappear in a different form the following day when Tandy, a keen fencer, was oiling his foil and changing its grip for a forthcoming tournament. "The handle was clamped in a vice on a workbench, yet the blade started vibrating like mad," he remembers.

This time it was daylight. There were other people around. Although the hairs were rising once again, he was determined to find a scientific explanation. Why did the blade vibrate in one part of room and not another? Because, as it turned out, infrasound was coming from a fairly new extractor fan.

"When we finally switched it off, it was as if a huge weight was lifted," he says. "It makes me think that one of the applications of this ongoing research could be a link between infrasound and sick-building syndrome."

Tandy has yet to establish the source of the infrasound beneath Coventry's tourist information centre. But he is coming to the conclusion that it has nothing to do with the sandstone cellar in the former Benedictine priory: "The highest readings are in the doorway and the corridor outside. That's what's resonating." It's a modern corridor, built a few years ago to provide access for tourists.

Some visitors have apparently been spooked before they have even set foot over the cellar's threshold, although they might take some convincing of that. Especially the white witch.

fields.headline: Rocking the cradle
fields.standfirst: The government's failure to see the links between pre- and post-16 study risks undermining its lifelong learning initiative, say leading academics
fields.trailText: The government's failure to see the links between pre- and post-16 study risks undermining its lifelong learning initiative, say leading academics
fields.body:
Joined up thinking was always supposed to be one of the present government's strong points. This image has become a little tarnished just lately, with the prevarication over the Euro and U-turns on fox hunting and on the spot fines for hooligans. But the one area where you wouldn't expect the government's credibility to come under attack is lifelong learning. Yet this is precisely what happened last week at a conference of leading academics at the Institute of Education.

The problem is not lifelong learning per se. No one disagrees with the emphasis the government places on the need to retrain the workforce and to increase the levels of basic skills among adults; what is at issue is the way it goes about it.

For the most part, the government views adult learning as a purely post-16 problem, a completely separate issue to primary and secondary education; it even formalises these divisions within the DfEE by having a Minister for Lifelong Learning who has no responsibilities for the pre-16 sector. Yet there is evidence to suggest that what happens in the formative years of a person's education has a profound effect on their ability and enthusiasm to return to education as an adult, and that any initiatives to stimulate and promote lifelong learning which fail to acknowledge this are almost certainly going to be undermined.

The conference, "Creating lifelong learners: a new and inclusive vision" was primarily the brainchild of Dr Ann Hodgson, senior lecturer in the lifelong learning group at the Institute of Education.

"Through various discussions with colleagues over the past year or so," she says, "I realised that my suspicions that structural problems within the primary and secondary sectors are detrimental to post-16 learners were widely shared. The conference was a forum for pooling different research and thinking on the subject with a view to producing a coherent overall view."

Dr Hodgson decided it was time not just to pay lip service to the idea of lifelong learning as a cradle to grave activity, and included on her invitation list experts in all field of education from nursery level upwards. Moreover, instead of regarding lifelong learning as a policy instrument to be imposed on the post-16s, the conference took the novel approach of looking at the issue from the perspective of the learner, and trying to uncover what might help or hinder him or her in seeing learning as a desirable activity. The results made interesting listening.

"It's important to have a safe and secure environment where learners feel able to take risks and to fail," Dr Hodgson continues. "What we found were structures that actively inhibit learning from taking place. Constant testing against national age-bound attainment standards is bad both for students and for teachers. It promotes teaching to pass tests, rather than for learning. We know from ongoing research that internally driven assessment, where students are given clear feedback, is what moves people forward, while heavy-handed age-related external assessment creates barriers to learning and a climate of underachievement among schools, teachers and pupils."

Professor Jean Rudduck of Homerton College, Cambridge, continued this theme with her research showing that children's view of learning is dominated by exams and the anxiety they create; but the most impressive evidence came from Professor Kathy Sylva of Oxford University who presented a paper on early childhood education up to the age of eight, based on a longitudinal study of 23-year-olds in the US.

This suggested that the best learning environment was a learning structure equally divided between formal activities imposed by adults and those dreamed up by the children themselves. She believes that the government's obsession with more and more formal structures in primary education, as witnessed by the literacy and numeracy hours, are detrimental both to the children's learning patterns as a whole and to the wider sphere of their socialisation with their peers.

The key area where the education system falls apart is at GCSE.

"We are the only country to examine 10 subjects at 16," says Dr Ken Spours, a senior lecturer also of the lifelong learning team at the Institute of Education.

"What we need is a flexible ladder of study and assessment for the 14 to 19 age group, where students can learn at their own pace. To be fair, Curriculum 2000 is a step in the right direction, but at the moment GCSE is the cliff face which 50% of school leavers fall off; anyone leaving without five passes at grades A to C is branded a failure and feels severely demotivated from continuing or re-entering education."

"What the conference suggested was that the government and educationalists were working off different policy models," Dr Spours continues.

"The goverment is focused on a short-term politically generated approach of remedying the failures of previous governments. It has concentrated far too much on the emergency measures of trying to make good the deficiencies in basic skills, so much so that it has missed the long-term problems."

For his part, Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, is keen to defend his government's record and plays down any perceived differences.

"What we're trying to do is create a learning system that allows people to learn what they want, when they want, how they want and where they want," he said, before going on to acknowledge that the government needed to be creative in ensuring that children get and keep the habit of learning. "We need to change the perception of learning from something that is done to you to something that is done by you."

Mr Wicks also pointed to new initiatives to smooth the year to year transitions, and the primary-secondary transfer in particular, but it is hard not to conclude that the minister is stuck between a rock and a hard place not of his own making. Most of the problems that were identified at the conference fall entirely within the remit of David Blunkett.

So, do Dr Hodgson et al seriously expect the secretary of state to start dismantling its ever more vigilant external assessment systems? It has made focal points of its primary and secondary education strategy.

"It's not a question of either/or where SATs are concerned," says Dr Spours in an unexpected display of diplomatic realpolitik.

"You can still test; you just need to step back and look at the implications of what you're doing."

fields.headline: Cash benefits
fields.standfirst: A skill is almost as good for your pocket as a degree
fields.trailText: A skill is almost as good for your pocket as a degree
fields.body:
The age-old assumption that a degree leads to a much fatter salary than a vocational qualification is about to be smashed.

New research to be published this week will show that the earnings gap between graduates and those holding advanced vocational qualifications is not so high as is thought.

Holding a degree brings 9% more in annual earnings than not having one. This compares with a 7.5% annual earnings boost of having a higher national diploma (HND).

Other vocational qualifications at level 3 and above reap similarly sizeable salary advantages.

But far smaller positive earnings were found from national vocational qualifications (NVQs) at levels 1 and 2 by researchers at the Centre for Economics in Education in London.

The results of the study, commissioned last summer by the DfEE, will be welcomed by ministers and - understandably - by the further education sector.

Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, also applauds the research's findings that basic numeracy and literacy skills bring significant earnings and employment advantages compared with not having these skills.

Wicks, who is due to speak at the study's launch on Thursday at a conference in London, says it strongly backs up the government's desire to tackle Britain's high levels of adult illiteracy and innumeracy.

The findings ought to have an impact on the decisions taken at 16 and 18, says Anna Vignoles, one of the four researchers who carried out the study.

"We'll certainly see that parents, children and their advisers who have to take those difficult decisions won't be so quick to assume that the academic qualification is immeasurably superior."

She said the study found marked gender differences. Women reap a higher return from academic qualifications than men, but this situation is reversed with vocational qualifications.

The research concludes that an A level gives a woman a 19% earnings advantage over a woman with no A levels. A man with an A level enjoys a 17% positive earnings advantage over the man without one.

A man with an HNC or HND enjoys a 15% annual earnings advantage over a man without. Having the same qualification gives a woman a 9% advantage.

Women with nursing and teaching qualifications also get higher returns from them than men.

The research set out to calculate returns for major academic and vocational qualifications, including City & Guilds, RSAs, and Btecs.

It added a new twist on previous work in this area, by taking the length of study for each qualification into account.

For instance, the data showed that men earned a 28% annual return from a degree, compared with a 15% return from an HNC. But the latter takes two years to do and the degree typically requires three years.

"Annualising" these figures gives a return per year of study and narrows the apparently large gap between the two qualifications, says Vignoles.

The study took its raw data from three sources: the National Child Development Study, the International Adult Literacy Survey and the Labour Force Survey.

fields.headline: Prospect park
fields.standfirst: Opening up higher education to older students is a complex but vital business, argues  Phil Revell
fields.trailText: Opening up higher education to older students is a complex but vital business, argues Phil Revell
fields.body:
Cassandra Bailey left school with virtually no qualifications and a feeling that education was something that other people did. "No one really expected me to go on and do GCSEs or A levels," she remembers.

A series of low-paid jobs persuaded the 23-year-old single mother that she needed to improve her prospects. She decided that she would confound her teachers and catch up on the education she had missed at school.

The first step was a two-year maths course. That led to an Open University access course and then to a degree course.

The Labour vision of a graduate economy depends on a huge expansion of higher education and a corresponding increase in the diversity of the student body. The traditional three-year degree course, with its assumption that the typical student will be 18, full-time and resident on campus, is likely to become an early casualty. Part-time courses, home study, distance learning and portable modules will become the norm.

Government plans already acknowledge a move towards this goal. On current projections a third of the students in 2001-2 will be part-timers, and future growth is envisaged to be almost entirely driven by part-time provision.

The new proposals have attracted flak from critics, who accuse the government of dumbing down and creating qualifications inflation. HEFC plans to widen access in postcode areas that are under-represented on degree courses were attacked in a Quality Assurance Agency report, which raised concerns about the dropout rate on some courses. The agency's chief executive John Randall says some institutions "need to think about whether a degree programme, with all that it involves in terms of intellectual rigour and theoretical underpinning, is appropriate."

Mass participation was the mantra of Mike Fitzgerald at Thames Valley. His encounter with the agency, which resulted in TVU becoming the first higher-education institution to be judged to be failing and to his resignation, has encouraged the critics of wider access to higher education and muted the voices of some supporters. But academics who have wide experience of recruiting outside the traditional A-level pool are more confident that universities can deliver a quality product to a larger audience.

"We haven't got anywhere near the ceiling of the number of people who could meaningfully be educated to bachelors, masters or doctorate level," argues Tim O'Shea, master of Birkbeck College in London. He dismisses accusations of dumbing down degrees as "uninformed snobbishness", sees part-time provision as a logical way to expand student numbers.

"It's easier for institutions which deal with part-timers to expand. You can do some of it as distance education, you can lease accommodation. Look at the old mechanics institutes, which evolved into institutions like ourselves, Strathclyde and Umist - there are institutions which have been doing this stuff consistently. We're not a tiny minority."

"Each year we admit 11,000 new students," says John Birch, vice-chancellor of Wolverhampton University. "But only a couple of thousand of those come with A levels."

Wolverhampton has worked hard to promote higher education in communities where there were no role models for post-16 education. Conventional employment in the Black Country was in steel. When that disappeared in the eighties, there was a desperate need for education. Successful recruitment has come from a policy of slowly building partnerships with schools, colleges, employers and community groups.

Birch is dismissive of those who label the degrees won by his students as second class. "If you look at the people reporting on these issues, or the ones being quoted, most have come through the traditional route." He thinks the government will need to develop funding which allows institutions to tailor courses to student demand.

"It would be a major incentive if we looked to funding modules or transferrable credits so that students could structure their learning to suit their own social needs and not be disadvantaged by a particular format which is predicated on 18-year-olds from middle-class families."

That some institutions have failed to meet the watchdog's criteria is partly a result of the rapid expansion in the sector. The worry is that concerns about a few courses that are failing to make the grade in a few institutions could have too much influence on overall policy.

"It means ignoring distinctions between institutions," says Tim O'Shea, "and making the decision to fund the learning of students, whether full- or part-time."

John Birch argues that the system should be as simple as his students' aspirations.

"If you look at the requirements of the kind of people who want to study with us, they're rather straightforward. They want to gain employability, give themselves social confidence, improve their lives."

fields.headline: Vision on
fields.standfirst: Donald Macleod on plans for a new type of work-based qualification - the foundation degree
fields.trailText: Donald Macleod on plans for a new type of work-based qualification - the foundation degree
fields.body:
Hussam works for a small new design company in Liverpool which is wanting to diversify into video production. He has experience of computer-aided design but no formal qualifications, so his boss decides to send him to university part-time to learn professional skills.

The nature of the job means he can't manage regular day release but can do one- or two-week periods at a local further education college and a university in the city. He will also do a lot of his training in his workplace or at other firms who have facilities and equipment, to emerge with a foundation degree. Hussam now has the choice of a specialist career in video or carrying on with his studies for an honours degree.

At the moment Hussam is a figment of David Blunkett's imagination. This week the Higher Education Funding Council for England called on universities, colleges and employers to breath life into him - and 2000 students like him - by bidding to run the new foundation degrees announced by the education secretary in February.

Central to the government's plan to expand higher and further education, foundation degrees will be two-year qualifications for fulltime students, although most students are expected to do their studying part-time while they earn and learn.

As there is a large work-based element in the planned degree, it should suit people already in work. Universities are being asked to form consortia with employers and further education colleges to offer the new degrees from 2001.

The university validates the degree - something the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals insisted on - and vouches for the quality of the courses being delivered at a college or in the workplace.

Employers must be involved in the design of courses and verify that there is demand locally or nationally for the skills involved. The funding council is promising up to £5m for prototype schemes.

But does anyone want a foundation degree? The sharp fall in applications for two-year Higher National Diplomas (HNDs) has prompted doubts about the demand for the new qualification, which is modelled on the American associate degree taken at the equivalent of further education college.

But ministers are optimistic that work-linked courses will appeal. In fact they intend most of the further growth in the numbers of students in higher education pledged by Tony Blair to be achieved through foundation degrees. Students must not only acquire academic knowledge but show they have applied it in the workplace.

Sam, for instance - another figment of the funding council's imagination - will do a lot of her foundation degree in the electronics wholesaler where she works as an administrator. Her progress in information technology depends partly on evening classes at a local college and on distance-learning materials from a university; but the rest is closely tied to her work. She might have an employer mentor in the IT industry, and her assignments are likely to relate to her work in the firm.

But degree holders will also be able to progress to an honours degree with an extra year and a term's full-time study, or the equivalent part-time. Ministers at first wanted to cap the proportion going on to honours, but this restriction was removed in the light of CVCP protests.

According to Baroness Blackstone, minister for higher education, the foundation degree has the potential to raise the skill level of the workforce, particularly in new industries. "It will forge new alliances between universities, colleges and employers. It will bring more people into higher education with a richer mix of backgrounds than ever before. It will fuse the academic and vocational paths to high-level qualifications."

Five pointers describe the government's hopes for the foundation degree

 Employer involvement

 The development of knowledge

 Application of skills in the workplace

 Credit accumulation and transfer

 Progression - within work and/or to an honours degree

fields.headline: Shock tactics
fields.standfirst: Alison Brace finds this year's controversial Carnegie Medal winner not afraid to bother the puritans
fields.trailText: Alison Brace finds this year's controversial Carnegie Medal winner not afraid to bother the puritans
fields.body:
For a 65-year-old, there is something almost adolescent about novelist Aidan Chambers; youthful enthusiasm for self-discovery is shot through with a rebellious streak. "I find getting old fascinating," says the former teacher and monk without a hint of cynicism.

His outlook is perhaps not so surprising: he quit teaching and the monastic life in the late sixties and has spent his days since seeing the world through the eyes of youngsters on the brink of adulthood.

His latest novel - Postcards From No Man's Land - has just earned him the coveted Carnegie Medal, awarded by the Library Association's Youth Libraries Group. The judges described it as "exceptional - the kind of book that gives you hope for the future of literature for children and young people".

But the award has come as a surprise to Chambers. "I just don't win things and for the last 10 years or so I have not been aware of much attention being given me here."

Mention books for teenagers and most people will think of Harry Potter - also a contender for this year's Carnegie - and Adrian Mole. But Chambers' novels are gritty, complex and deal with contentious issues. Adult novels, in other words, but written from the point of view of a young person. "It has certain literary and artistic benefits," says Chambers, who also has a loyal adult following.

"When you are in your teenage years you are consciously experiencing everything for the first time, so adolescent stories are all beginnings. There are never any endings. As far as content goes - the stuff that bothers the puritans - my rule is, anything that the young protagonist could actually experience or witness happening in real life can go into the book."

Postcards touches on euthanasia, war, adultery, art and sexual identity as viewed by a 17-year-old visiting Amsterdam for the first time, and an old lady looking back on her awakening to love during the Battle of Arnhem and its tragic aftermath.

Interestingly, Chambers, who has no children, has many more readers in mainland Europe, particularly Holland and Sweden, than he does on his home turf. Invitations from schools there to discuss his work with teenage fans keep him away from home for three months a year.

Chambers believes this is because British 16- to 19-year-olds read very little outside the curriculum. A-level English has too few set texts, he says, with pupils not being encouraged to dip into a wide variety of literature as they are on the Continent.

But his main complaint about English teaching is reserved for the current government and the previous two Tory administrations, which he blames for turning reading into a mechanical, joyless experience.

"Readers are made by readers - it is so obvious it is almost banal to say it," says Chambers. "And yet the government thinks it can do it by numbers. They are turning teachers into machines and producing factory fodder as a result. He believes the real key to improving the nation's reading habits would be to make all trainee English teachers devote three years to having a working knowledge of at least 500 books.

"You become a reader by reading the literature, not by reading the handbooks about it. Any kid here who becomes literary now does so in spite of the system and not because of it."

His own educational experience is testimony to the lasting influence of an inspirational teacher. Chambers, an only child, comes from County Durham. All the male members of his family were miners apart from his father, who was a joiner. He failed the 11-plus, but was picked out as a late developer and sent to Darlington Grammar School.

His English teacher, Jim Osborn, introduced him to books and the theatre and by 15, Chambers had secretly decided he wanted to be a writer. He credits Osborn with moving pupils on to different and more challenging texts, never letting them settle in to one style of literature. "His English lessons were magic. I can still remember lots of them."

Osborn encouraged him to become a teacher and despatched him to Borough Road College in Isleworth, Middlesex.

During his first teaching job at West Cliff High School for boys in Southend, Chambers became an Anglican and joined the Community of Glorious Ascension in Stroud.

He almost fell into writing for the teenage market by accident. "There were 6,000 volumes in that library and yet the kids were telling me there was nothing to read."

By 1966, Chambers had had his first play, Johnny Salter, published and a book called The Reluctant Reader, based on research carried out with his pupils.

By 1968 he had left teaching and the monastery behind him, met his future wife, Nancy Lockwood, and together they founded The Thimble Press and published Signal, a critical journal devoted to children's books.

But it was not until 1975 that he found his true voice as a novelist with the first of his serious teenage novels, Breaktime. By the time the second - Dance on my Grave - was published he knew there would be six in the "family". "The books are all looking at the same material - love, sexuality and so on - but each book sees it in a different way."

He believes it is crucial that youngsters "find" themselves in books. "Teenagers are better informed today, but may be none the wiser. You get to be wiser by storying the world and seeing it through other forms of consciousness than your own.

"The power of the peer group is much greater than it used to be, and there is such a commercial nature about what you wear, what you listen to, that a literature that speaks about the hidden inner person is more important than it has ever been."

He is currently researching the sixth book, whose main character will be a woman. And after that? "I'll write my old man books."

 Postcards From No Man's Land is published by Bodley Head, £10.99.

fields.headline: Young democrats
fields.standfirst: The introduction of citizenship has recruited some energetic converts
fields.trailText: The introduction of citizenship has recruited some energetic converts
fields.body:
The latest task facing teachers has a solemn ring after playground duty or the literacy hour: "Enforcing Article 12 of the United Nations' Convention on the Rights of the Child," muses Diane King in between staffroom appointments in Manchester. Excuse me while I faint. But the sonorous verbiage hides a genuinely exciting new world for students, explored today at a conference in London and in a new handbook, Citizenship, which might be sub-titled Janet and John Go Voting.

Across the country, schools and local education authorities are meeting the challenge laid down last spring by statutory order that inserted citizenship into the national curriculum. Groans from stressed teachers? Just another subject? No way.

In Manchester, since 1997, local schools and youth organisations have elected 100 representatives ranging in age from 12 to 18 to sit on the city's Young People's Council. And they take their democratic task very seriously.

As King criss-crosses Manchester in her role as a senior school-improvement officer, her steps are dogged by these little democrats, demanding action for the homeless, public transport concessions and proper nameplates on the carved wooden seats when they take over the city's council chamber.

Election time in local schools sees risqué posters on notice boards, witty leaflets in pigeon holes and turnouts of 80% and 90%. Hold King and her politician colleagues while they recover from another dizzy spell.

Councillor Bernard Stone is doing anything but having a turn, however, as he leafs through the latest decisions and requests of Manchester's elected Young People's Council. As the Labour city council's executive member for education he is now a citizenship pied piper, and it makes a refreshing change from routine agendas and minutes.

"They come up with such good ideas," he says, pointing to one year six boy, who began his career as an activist pushing for better play facilities in his ward. He is now an ace debater on the youth council. "I was watching this kid of 12 making a speech in our council chamber at their last meeting. He looked as if he'd been there all his life."

The Manchester experiment, tied rigorously to key stages from five years old upwards, has counterparts in Birmingham - whose young people's parliament voted heavily in favour of an elected mayor for the city last week - and a whole raft of initiatives that must delight Sir Bernard Crick.

It was his advisory group on citizenship (AGC), triggered by government concern that young people were opting out of the civic involvement that sustains democracy, which concluded in September 1998 that old-fashioned "civics" should make a fighting return.

Not just through schools, where Crick was worried that teachers already had too much to do; the AGC called on local councils, quangos and magistrates to join in and explain what they get up to.

In that lies the genesis of Islington's Get Smart - Take Part project, Cambridge's young citizens' jury and Hertfordshire's mobile internet cafe, the Rolling Zone, where a student internet search for "pawn" - as in "pawns of the system" - led to some unexpectedly raunchy sites and, Kathy Baker concludes diplomatically, "raised issues around literacy skills".

Baker is the compiler of today's Citizenship handbook, which the Local Government Information Unit is launching at a joint conference on the issue with the Institute for Citizenship. The key thing, she says, drawing on her previous experience as both a teacher and an NUT education officer, is the sense of excitement and fun that bubbles from the projects for mini-politicians and quangocrats.

"A lot of inventive thinking is going into bridging the gap between schools -where citizenship could just become an academic subject - and the wider community, where getting involved is the whole point,"she says.

The Institute's Julia Talbot makes the same point: "Young citizens don't just want to study; they want to be heard, want to meet their local councillors or chair of education, want to influence decisions and effect change," she says.

That's where Manchester's experiment seems to be working, according to Anne Faherty, a council officer who takes the chief executive role when Brendan McGowan, 17, plonks himself down three times a year in the Victorian throne normally occupied by Manchester City Council leader Richard Leese.

The youth councillors learn rapidly how long and compromise-dogged democratic change can be, but they have seen real changes follow from their debates, whose recommendations are put before the plenary MYPC.

"They discussed and drafted a system of peer-counselling for young people - which involved going to a contemporary instead of teachers about issues like bullying," says Faherty. "It was well thought out, persuasively argued and it got a budget and now it's happening."

Pats on the head get a suitably spiky response from Brendan, on his mobile phone between the constant engagements that beset an active citizen at sixth-form college. His priority is one that strikes an echo with the Bernard Stones of this world: "What's happened to our budget? We got £18,000 the first year, but it's down to £5,000 this year and £5,000 for next. If they're going to take us seriously, they shouldn't skimp."

Brendan's commitment, though, is impressive - now into his third year of balancing MYPC membership with the demands of GCSEs, sport and social life. The council has also tapped girl power to the extent of an almost equal gender balance, and classroom enthusiasm has seen healthy ratios of ethnic minorities and inner-city students elected.

The idea isn't just crudely to rear "tomorrow's politicians", says Stone, although that is happening; he and his colleagues can hardly resist comparing MYPC vim with the complete absence of under-25s on local councils, health authorities, benches and other arms of the voluntary state.

Oh, and the nameplates are useful too. "The students tended to sit by schools," says Faherty, "so we used their nameplate to mix them up. It's made friendships right across Manchester, and encouraged thinking in terms not of "My area" but of "Our city".

 Manchester Young People's Council has links to many other sites. Citizenship: challenges for councils is published by LGIU, 22 Upper Woburn Place, London WC1H OTB, cost is £15 (incl p&p)

 www.ednet.org.uk
