Councillor Bernard Stone is doing anything but having a turn, however, as he leafs through the latest decisions and requests of Manchester's elected Young People's Council. As the Labour city council's executive member for education he is now a citizenship pied piper, and it makes a refreshing change from routine agendas and minutes. "They come up with such good ideas," he says, pointing to one year six boy, who began his career as an activist pushing for better play facilities in his ward. He is now an ace debater on the youth council. "I was watching this kid of 12 making a speech in our council chamber at their last meeting. He looked as if he'd been there all his life." The Manchester experiment, tied rigorously to key stages from five years old upwards, has counterparts in Birmingham - whose young people's parliament voted heavily in favour of an elected mayor for the city last week - and a whole raft of initiatives that must delight Sir Bernard Crick. It was his advisory group on citizenship (AGC), triggered by government concern that young people were opting out of the civic involvement that sustains democracy, which concluded in September 1998 that old-fashioned "civics" should make a fighting return. Not just through schools, where Crick was worried that teachers already had too much to do; the AGC called on local councils, quangos and magistrates to join in and explain what they get up to. In that lies the genesis of Islington's Get Smart - Take Part project, Cambridge's young citizens' jury and Hertfordshire's mobile internet cafe, the Rolling Zone, where a student internet search for "pawn" - as in "pawns of the system" - led to some unexpectedly raunchy sites and, Kathy Baker concludes diplomatically, "raised issues around literacy skills". Baker is the compiler of today's Citizenship handbook, which the Local Government Information Unit is launching at a joint conference on the issue with the Institute for Citizenship. The key thing, she says, drawing on her previous experience as both a teacher and an NUT education officer, is the sense of excitement and fun that bubbles from the projects for mini-politicians and quangocrats. "A lot of inventive thinking is going into bridging the gap between schools -where citizenship could just become an academic subject - and the wider community, where getting involved is the whole point,"she says. The Institute's Julia Talbot makes the same point: "Young citizens don't just want to study; they want to be heard, want to meet their local councillors or chair of education, want to influence decisions and effect change," she says. That's where Manchester's experiment seems to be working, according to Anne Faherty, a council officer who takes the chief executive role when Brendan McGowan, 17, plonks himself down three times a year in the Victorian throne normally occupied by Manchester City Council leader Richard Leese. The youth councillors learn rapidly how long and compromise-dogged democratic change can be, but they have seen real changes follow from their debates, whose recommendations are put before the plenary MYPC. "They discussed and drafted a system of peer-counselling for young people - which involved going to a contemporary instead of teachers about issues like bullying," says Faherty. "It was well thought out, persuasively argued and it got a budget and now it's happening." Pats on the head get a suitably spiky response from Brendan, on his mobile phone between the constant engagements that beset an active citizen at sixth-form college. His priority is one that strikes an echo with the Bernard Stones of this world: "What's happened to our budget? We got £18,000 the first year, but it's down to £5,000 this year and £5,000 for next. If they're going to take us seriously, they shouldn't skimp." Brendan's commitment, though, is impressive - now into his third year of balancing MYPC membership with the demands of GCSEs, sport and social life. The council has also tapped girl power to the extent of an almost equal gender balance, and classroom enthusiasm has seen healthy ratios of ethnic minorities and inner-city students elected. The idea isn't just crudely to rear "tomorrow's politicians", says Stone, although that is happening; he and his colleagues can hardly resist comparing MYPC vim with the complete absence of under-25s on local councils, health authorities, benches and other arms of the voluntary state. Oh, and the nameplates are useful too. "The students tended to sit by schools," says Faherty, "so we used their nameplate to mix them up. It's made friendships right across Manchester, and encouraged thinking in terms not of "My area" but of "Our city".  Manchester Young People's Council has links to many other sites. Citizenship: challenges for councils is published by LGIU, 22 Upper Woburn Place, London WC1H OTB, cost is £15 (incl p&p)  www.ednet.org.uk

fields.headline: Off the buses
fields.standfirst: Labour is urging more children to walk to school, but at the same time giving parents a wider choice of schools, turning kids into pint-sized commuters
fields.trailText: Labour is urging more children to walk to school, but at the same time giving parents a wider choice of schools, turning kids into pint-sized commuters
fields.body:
If you happen to be passing through St Albans on a weekday morning just before nine, you may come across a woman pushing a shopping trolley with a dozen or so children in tow. Don't worry. This isn't cider lady on the rampage, but the last word in green transport policy.

Every schoolday at Wheatfield School two parents take up position at opposite ends of a crocodile of children to kick-start the walking bus. The children throw their satchels and folders into the trolley and the whole lot then march to school, stopping from time to time at designated pick-up points to allow others to join en route.

The Wheatfield scheme is cheap, non-polluting, decongests the roads and has the added benefit of keeping the children in some sort of shape. It is just the sort of thing David Blunkett must have had in mind when he recently urged everyone to get back into the habit of walking to school.

To be fair to the nation's cholesterol levels, about half of all children, particularly those of primary age, still do walk to school, but this is a significant fall from the 1970s when about 72% walked. Some of the differences can be put down to increased car ownership and parental fears for safety, but there is still a sizeable and growing number of commuter kids for whom walking to school is never going to be an option.

Schools don't come much more remote than those in the Orkneys, and of the 1,754 primary and 1,366 secondary children on register, more than 1,700 are entitled to school transport provided by the islands' education department. For primary schoolchildren this may just involve a bus journey, as many of the smaller islands have their own schools. But with just four junior secondary schools on the larger islands, and with the only two secondary schools that educate up to university level both on Orkney itself, pitching up for school can be a long haul for some children.

"A typical journey for those living on the inner islands might involve a 20-minute ride by car or bus, followed by a 20-minute ferry journey with another 20-minute bus ride at the other end," says Kevin Balfour, the administration officer for the Orkneys education department. "For those living further away, a daily commute is not a viable option so children spend their weekday nights in a hostel and only take the ferry home at weekends."

Sometimes, even a ferry isn't an option. North Ronaldsay is so isolated that Orkney has the provision to fly children to secondary school on the main island, though no children at present qualify for this five-star service. What strikes one most about the Orkney set-up is just how well the system works. Given the extremes of bad weather and the comparatively few hours of winter daylight, it is astonishing that only two days in the whole of the last academic year were lost to those travelling in by water. A day at school must seem a doddle after a force eight gale in the North Sea.

Even in Northamptonshire, by no means the wildest county in the UK, getting to school can be a problem. Silverstone Junior and Infants schools both serve a couple of out-lying villages, the furthest of which is five or six miles away - a tough daily hike for even the fittest six-year-old.

Until comparatively recently, most parents were happy to send their children to school on the bus, and the kids seemed happy with the arrangement, too. "It was much more interesting going on the bus than by car with my mum," says seven-year-old William Lawson, though his mother believes his preference might have something to do with being force-fed spelling tests in the car.

But all this changed when parents cottoned on to the fact that the bus service may not be as safe as it seemed. "If the school takes your children on trips during school hours then rigorous safety checks apply," says Sarah Lawson. "But before school hours, anything goes. The LEA put the bus service out to public tender and chose the cheapest. With the new company, United Counties Stagecoach, the buses no longer have seat belts or escorts. We were even told that the bus was a public service and that anyone could travel on it.

"There have been other problems, too. The bus hasn't always shown up, it has got lost and when we expressed concern about the speed, the driver told us that there were new time-tables and he couldn't keep up. We've complained to the council but little has happened, so most of us have now chosen not to use the service."

A few weeks ago, a double-decker bus turned up to collect the two remaining children who were using the service and, symbolically, promptly broke down. One man who isn't surprised by this turn of events is Simon Larter, the head teacher of Northamptonshire Grammar School. In September last year, 14 of his pupils were involved in a road accident when the mini-coach they were travelling in crashed into two parked cars.

"The ambulance crew said it was only because the pupils were wearing seat belts that they escaped serious injury," said Larter. The school has now initiated a campaign to make it illegal for public service vehicles that carry children not to have seatbelts, rather than for the decision to be left to the discretion of local authorities.

Distance and safety are by no means the only reasons why children sometimes end up being driven to school. In fact, the government's own policy and example on school selection has encouraged many parents to turn their kids into pint-sized commuters. Tony Blair ignored the Catholic school on his then Islington doorstep and instead sent his two eldest sons to the London Oratory, some six or seven miles away in Hammersmith, west London. Harriet Harman made a similar choice for her son, and where these two politicians have led, others have followed. Some, it must be said, out of necessity rather than inclination.

"Parental choice works just fine if you can actually get your children into the school you want," says Alex Benady, a south London father of two. "But what the system has done for everyone else is to turn schooling into a lottery. Those schools with good reputations become everyone's first choice and are hopelessly oversubscribed, and the vast majority of people are left disappointed and unsure what to do next. You can't even try to second-guess the selection procedures for most schools' annual intake because they are thoroughly opaque."

Benady applied to seven primary schools in the area for a place next year for his four-year-old son. He has been turned down by every single one. "One of the schools was a beacon school," he continues, "but the rest were all just average state schools. The only school we think we could still get into is one that has huge problems, with disastrous SATs results, a large intake of troubled children and widespread bullying, and I'm not prepared to send my son there. As a result we've had to consider an independent school but even that is an unsatisfactory 10- to 15-minute drive away. The only other option we have is to move."

Outside London, parental choice tends to be a hypothetical rather than a practical issue as the distances involved in more rural areas often preclude more than the nearest option, but some parents will go to almost any lengths to ensure their children go to the right school. The average journey time for pupils to Manchester Grammar School is more than an hour each way, with some children coming in from as far as Sheffield and Blackpool, and most will pass one or two schools on the way where they have declined places.

"Our working day reflects our pupils' travelling time," says Dr Martin Stephen, the High Master of Manchester Grammar. "We start at 9.10am and end at 3.45pm. Ease of travel is far more important than the time it takes, and most children regard the journey as a relaxant rather than a stressor. Our bus service has almost become a rite of passage and many boys prefer to take it rather than travel in to Manchester with their parents."

Dr Stephen points to the school's 87% pass rate at grades A and B at A level and the thriving community of extracurricular clubs and societies as proof that the children aren't exhausted by or unhappy with the travelling.

"You accept the travelling if you value and enjoy what you get at the end of it. In my six years in charge, I've only ever had two boys come to me with commuting problems. One was a boy whose parents had divorced and whose mother had moved to a remote part of Derbyshire, and the other was a boy who had had a local bus service cancelled."

None of which cuts too much ice with Benady, who spent two hours each day travelling across south London to school as a teenager. "I found the journey deeply depressing and corrosive," he recalls. "My home and school life became separated from one another and I ended up not knowing anyone where I lived."

Not everyone reacts in the same way, of course, but not for the first time, one senses that Labour's policies are pulling in opposite directions. Almost by definition, parental choice equates to more travel and yet at the same time Blunkett is urging us all to walk to school. Time for a third way, perhaps.

webTitle: Where school is a bowl of cherries

fields.headline: Where school is a bowl of cherries
fields.standfirst: The fruit trees in a London orchard are getting some TLC from an unlikely source
fields.trailText: The fruit trees in a London orchard are getting some TLC from an unlikely source
fields.body:
Over 50% of seven- to 11-year-olds experience stress at school, according to recent research commissioned by London Electricity. Pressure to do well in exams, homework and bullying all figure prominently.

If this presents a somewhat stark view of modern life, then the solution, as expressed by the children themselves, is reassuringly simple. Youngsters place a high value on playing, talking and generally having "fun" in their school grounds.

The charity Learning through Landscapes has long had a mission to see young people doing just this, through well designed, managed and frequently used school grounds.

Last month, London Electricity and Learning through Landscapes supported the National School Grounds Week, with London Electricity granting awards to more than 7,000 schools to help them to make the most of their own "great outdoors". For many of these schools, such as La Sainte Union, this week was the perfect opportunity to build upon existing projects.

La Sainte Union is an 11-18 state convent school in Camden fortunate enough to have an orchard within the school grounds, belonging to the neighbouring convent. Britain's orchards are in a state of rapid decline, with 150,000 acres lost over the past 40 years. The school's orchard was dangerously close to being lost, too, but thanks to the initial impetus of the National Orchards Campaign and with the help of the charity Common Ground, the girls at the school began the hard work of restoring it in January 1999.

Nancy O'Brien, the teacher in charge, remembers that of the 68 trees in the orchard, some planted 150 years ago, only three were producing fruit when the project began. "Most of the trees are apple and pear, but we also have a quince tree and a cherry tree. Last autumn, 30 of the trees produced fruit," she recalls. O'Brien has attended several courses, run by the British Trust for Conservation Volunteers, which have been fully utilised at school.

Learning through Landscapes argues that school grounds can enrich all areas of the curriculum, and this is certainly the case at La Sainte Union. Sarah Perring, 13, has been involved with the project since the beginning and was one of the pupils who worked with an environmental artist to create a "teepee" installation in the orchard made of branches.

In the "wildlife corridor", developed with the help of a volunteer parent, Sarah reports that there are "mushrooms growing, robins and loads of different insects", and O'Brien has sent various lichen samples to be analysed by Leeds University. In addition, four RSPB bird boxes have been mounted high up in the trees.

Alex Malesa, 14, is one of the pupils who has been interviewing people, to build up an oral history of the orchard, and taking photographs for the school's website.

The web pages feature the recollections of one of the convent's sisters, who remembers the orchard in 1952 when she began her training as a novice and spent her recreation time "peeling, slicing and preparing the next day's afters".

There is a real sense of uncovering the past and preserving for the future. Samantha Montes, 14, has worked on the project diary, which contrasts the changes that have taken place in the orchard since the restoration began. She records what is happening on a monthly basis.

O'Brien detects a real passion across the school for the project. "They enjoy seeing the orchard's development, and I can see their own personal development as a result."

In their English lessons, year 7s wrote poetry, looking at the orchard throughout the year. Emma Folan's poem includes the lines: "Running in and out through the blossomed trees/ So care-free/ Summer joys - problems distant miles away." For Emma at least, stress doesn't appear to be a big problem.

fields.headline: Filling the hot seat
fields.trailText: Governors need to be aware of the new arrangements for electing chair and vice-chair under new regulations.
fields.body:
Governors need to be aware of the new arrangements for electing chair and vice-chair under new regulations. The spirit of the new procedures, to make the process transparent to all members of the governing body, must be welcomed but there are some technical issues.

For the first time, from last September, elections were required to be held by secret ballot. This was a positive step forward in avoiding the embarrassment of a public statement of disloyalty in the interests of progress. Anecdotal evidence suggests that this change alone has already done much to challenge chairs who may have become past their best.

From April this year, all governors "willing to stand" as chair or vice-chair are invited to put forward their names for listing on the agenda for the appropriate meeting. This gives all governors the chance to participate, and advance notice prompts the governing body to consider the chairship in a more deliberative fashion. We will know progress is being made when governing bodies begin to consider the chairship before inviting nominations.

There is, however, a potentially dangerous loophole in the current process, which does not allow for any further names to be taken at the meeting unless no names have been forthcoming. Could an undesirable candidate slip through unopposed?

Clearly governors need to be organised to ensure that there are appropriate advance nominations - remembering that no governor employed in the school may stand.

Backstop procedures would be good practice. Seeking a proposer and seconder for each nomination in the meeting would be a sensible way to ensure the support of other governors and, where one name only is put forward, holding an election requiring a simple majority in favour is recommended. In the absence of such support for a candidate then other names would have to be allowed.

A technical minefield? Possibly. But this is a process worth getting right for such a pivotal role.

 Jane Martin is Education Officer (school governance and development) with Dudley local education authority. She writes here in a personal capacity.

fields.headline: Exam stress is hurting children
fields.standfirst: Euan Blair landed in hot water for a binge after his exams.  Tony Mooney says it is time to axe GCSEs
fields.trailText: Euan Blair landed in hot water for a binge after his exams. Tony Mooney says it is time to axe GCSEs
fields.body:
As the father of two children who have just about survived their adolescent years without too many mishaps, my heart goes out to Tony Blair after the arrest of his son Euan for being drunk and incapable. However, in the sober moments of reflection after this public embarrassment, Blair ought to reconsider one of his most famous speeches about being tough on crime and tough on the causes of crime. The second part ought to be prominent in his thinking.

There can be little doubt that one of the factors contributing to Euan's condition was the need to release the pressure that had built up over the months preceding his GCSE examinations. As a secondary school headteacher, I watched with concern during the 1980s and 90s as the demands of politicians for better measurable school results raised the stakes for teenagers at GCSE. I saw at first hand just how important these examinations became in terms of self-identity and self-worth and I now believe that they are a hindrance to the academic development of our young people.

Anyone needing to be convinced of the excessive pressures that young people face in the build-up to GCSE should read the paper just published by Professor Martyn Denscombe of De Montfort University, Leicester. Denscombe has questioned over 1,600 young people aged 15-16 about what they regard as the main threats to their health. "Time and again," writes Denscombe, "young people talked of the stresses involved as they worked in school towards their 16+ examinations." Irrespective of their social background or whether they were planning to leave school at 16 to find work, "the vast majority of the young people were caught up with the pressure".

It is clear from what young people say that one source of their pressure comes from the feeling that the GCSE examination is the first one that really matters. Despite having taken national Standard Assessment Tasks (SATs) and other school exams, the youngsters believed that their performance at GCSE was the first time their achievements and potential were to be publicised. As such, a major foundation of their future self-identity was being constructed.

One of Tony Blair's gurus, Anthony Giddens (director of the London School of Economics and an architect of the Third Way) agrees with what teenagers are saying when describing what he terms as "fateful moments". These are times "when events come together in such a way that an individual stands, as it were, at a crossroads in his existence". To most teenagers, GCSE examinations are certainly fateful moments in their lives.

But how have national public exams set at an age not even contemplated in many other countries been allowed to become so important at such a sensitive time in the lives of young people? One answer is the political climate around education that Tony Blair has been so instrumental in creating. As Professor Denscombe says, "government policies in recent years have raised the profile of GCSE results and, as we enter the new millennium, there is little indication of any relaxation of this regime."

Teenagers are aware of the political dimension associated with their GCSE performance and see their teachers as "stress amplifiers" as a result. They know that teachers are constantly nagging and pressurising them about work because they themselves are being judged by the publication of GCSE league tables. Many GCSE students now believe that this nagging is a result of teacher anxiety about their own positions rather than a desire to see their charges do well. As a result, the teachers may be contributing to teenage stress.

As one of the interviewed students says: "If teachers eased back a little, I think there would be less stress. Because at the end of the day we know what we've got to do. I mean it's like preaching all the time. But we don't need it for all the way throughout the year."

As Tony Blair contemplates how best to deal with his son's excessive stress-release mechanism, he might wish to consider the words of Tracey, another year 11 student, who talked about her attempted suicide. She said: "Just before my overdose, one thing that contributed to me taking it was school. I mean, I had teachers all running round me, going 'You've got your mocks! You've got your mocks! If you don't get good grades you won't go to college.' And I just got really stressed, really easily and that was one of the reasons, because of all the stress of exams and stuff."

It is time to stop this examination madness for 16-year-olds. Since most of them now stay on beyond the age of 16 and gain further qualifications, the GCSE examination has outlived its usefulness. Delaying the moment when young people become officially "labelled" through an examination that they consequently interpret as a measure of their personal worth can only be of benefit.

fields.headline: Sing in the rain
fields.standfirst: Pop was bedraggled but unbowed in London and Glasgow this weekend, say  Betty Clarke and  Elisabeth Mahoney
fields.trailText: Pop was bedraggled but unbowed in London and Glasgow this weekend, say Betty Clarke and Elisabeth Mahoney
fields.body:
W hile there are numerous summer festivals for indie kids, the clean world of pop has never had a grubby home. But Party in the Park, an annual pop fest held in Hyde Park, has changed all that.

This weekend more than 40 acts gathered, along with 100,000 fans, to celebrate in the pouring rain. From Artful Dodger to Billie, Kylie and the increasingly glamourous Moloko, if it had hit the charts, it was here.

The oddest sight came when Elton John, here known as EJ, stepped in to replace a member of boy band Backstreet Boys, AJ, who was home nursing his sick grandfather. Embarrassing doesn't get close to it.

Victoria Beckham, on the other hand, was worth close scrutiny on this her first solo outing. Together with the Truesteppers for Out of Your Mind, she looked fantastic, hair extensions and all. The fact that she mimed, along with over half the other artists, didn't distract from her triumph.

But it was down to old hands Bon Jovi to give the kids a good time. Running through a couple of hits and rounding off with a surprising cover of Lulu's Shout, Jon Bon Jovi strutted, teased, pulled his shirt off and shook his maracas, proving just how much fun pop can really be. BC

S ome things in festival land never change. The queues for the scary toilets never shorten; in Scotland, it rains real sheets of driving rain all weekend. At Glasgow's T in the Park people sported free yellow plastic sheets to keep the damp out. They looked a lot like packets of Quavers.

Iggy Pop looked more like one of those bacon-flavoured treats of old, a Frazzle, all lean and brown. In the wild, wild weather it was left to consummate performers like him to inject the crowd with something close to a lust for life. He pulled it off with gusto, encouraging the crowd to join him on stage for The Passenger.

On the main stage, the acts divided into those that could rise above the sodden atmosphere (All Saints, Moby, Macy Gray, Supergrass) and those that failed to (Gomez, Idlewild, Ocean Colour Scene). A better option by far was to take refuge in the tented arenas, especially the King Tut's Tent, with some very fine options to dry off to (Badly Drawn Boy, Moloko, Toploader, Coldplay).

But it was left to the headline acts to lift us from our squelchy misery. Travis may be overrated, but nothing could have been finer, in these climes, than Why Does It Always Rain on Me? The soggy crisps rejoiced.

webTitle: Pakistan hit out over Waqar ban

fields.headline: Pakistan hit out over Waqar ban
fields.standfirst: Waqar lands ban for fiddling with ball
fields.trailText: Having seen Shoaib Akhtar dubbed a chucker, Salim Malik banned for life over match-fixing and Wasim Akram adjudged "not above board", Pakistan were never going to lie down and let another of their all-time greats have his reputation trampled on.
fields.body:
Having seen Shoaib Akhtar dubbed a chucker, Salim Malik banned for life over match-fixing and Wasim Akram adjudged "not above board", Pakistan were never going to lie down and let another of their all-time greats have his reputation trampled on.

So it was no surprise yesterday when the country's cricket officials waged war on the New Zealand referee John Reid, a day after he suspended the paceman Waqar Younis for ball-tampering.

"I don't trust the man," fumed General Tauqir Zia, chairman of the Pakistan Cricket Board. "I have written to the International Cricket Council saying it should either remove Reid from the panel or not make him a match referee for Pakistan's matches ... He is biased against our cricketers."

Television footage showed Waqar picking at the seam during Saturday's one-day match against South Africa in Colombo. The veteran of 308 test wickets was suspended by Reid for one game, making him the first player ever to be banned for ball-tampering. But Zia accused Reid, a former New Zealand captain, of being ignorant of the rules of cricket and exploiting "the slightest opportunity to embarrass Pakistan players".

Zia said that after voicing his concern to the umpires, Reid was required by the game's laws to respect their judgment. "The umpires saw the ball and told Reid they found nothing wrong with it. Reid, however, went ahead and penalised Waqar on his own."

Reid declined to comment yesterday but the former Pakistan wicketkeeper Rashid Latif, a leading light in the anti-corruption crusade, praised the referee's decision. "Action must be taken against cricketers who use foul tactics," he said. "I am not against Waqar or Wasim Akram but I know much more about ball-tampering ... For Pakistan's sake, I don't want to add much more."

Pakistan have a history of confrontation with Reid, who Zia claimed was instrumental in the banning of Shoaib - later overturned by the ICC - for allegedly bowling with a suspect action.
